<p>Until you understand its file include/exclude logic, you might be missing
matches that you were expecting it to catch.  However, this is part of the
utility value of the tool, so it's worth learning, and anyway you can always
use the <code>-f</code> option to see what files it <em>does</em> include.</p>

<hr />

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#ack">ack</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#file_selection">file selection</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#tricks_and_tips">tricks and tips</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#the_ACKRC_file">the ACKRC file</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#trouble_shooting">trouble-shooting</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#option_comparision_with_grep">option comparision with grep</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#options_missing_in_ack">options missing in ack</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#options_different_in_ack">options different in ack</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#options_identical_in_both">options identical in both</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="file_selection">file selection</a></h3>

<p>Ack's most visible feature is that it is recursive by default.  This isn't
about just saving a few keystrokes to type <code>grep -r</code> -- ack by default
ignores most build/version control meta files, binary files, and any files
whose type it does not know anything about.  As a result, it often searches a
much smaller set of files.</p>

<p>In increasing order of files included, the options are:</p>

<ul>
<li>(default) -- no unknown file types</li>
<li><p><code>--text</code> -- any file that looks like "text" to perl's <code>-T</code>
operator.  However, the following one-line patch is often needed to
reconcile this statement with the actual truth:</p>

<pre><code>@@ -1713,7 +1713,7 @@



 sub is_interesting {
-    return if /^\./;
+    # sita return if /^\./;

<pre><code> my $include;
</code></pre>

</code></pre></li>
<li><p><code>-a</code> -- search all files, even binary files</p></li>
<li><code>-u</code> -- search even the directories it normally ignores, like
<code>.git</code>, <code>CVS</code>, etc.</li>
</ul>

<p>Other things that influence the selection are:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>-n</code> -- no descending into subdirs</li>
<li><code>-G regex</code> -- only paths matching regex are included</li>
<li><code>--perl</code>, <code>--noperl</code> and many other similar options -- see <code>ack
--help type</code> for details</li>
<li><code>--type-set</code> and <code>--type-add</code> -- see below</li>
<li><code>--ignore-dir=DIR</code></li>
<li><code>--follow</code> -- follow symlinks; off by default</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="tricks_and_tips">tricks and tips</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><code>-g REGEX</code> -- combination of <code>-f -G REGEX</code> to quickly see what
files match a regex in the current tree; can be faster to type than
find|grep</li>
<li><code>--passthru</code> -- colors matches but does not discard non-matching
lines; great for simple cases of log watching</li>
<li><code>--line=1,3,6-9</code> can be more convenient than telling sed or awk to
print only lines with a certain line number</li>
<li>grep ignores <code>-c</code> (count) when <code>-l</code> or <code>-L</code> are also used.
Ack gives you meaningful output in both cases</li>
<li><p>to search files with an extension that ack does not know about (say
"lfy"), try</p>

<pre><code>ack --noenv --type-set abc=.lfy --abc pattern
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="the_ACKRC_file">the ACKRC file</a></h3>

<p>You can set options permanently in an <code>~/.ackrc</code> file.  Here's mine.  I
prefer to search all "text" files (though I patch it as shown above because I
prefer not to exclude "dot-files").  Smart-case is a neat way of never having
to worry about specifying the case-ignore setting: if the regex has only lower
case characters, it behaves like "ignore case" is set.  I like to see the
files sorted, and I specify what pager I want to use and its options.</p>

<pre><code>--text
--smart-case
--sort-files
--pager=less -rF
</code></pre>

<h3><a name="trouble_shooting">trouble-shooting</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><code>-f</code> allows you to see what files are being included by its internal
logic for the set of options in effect</li>
<li><code>--noenv</code> -- turn off all environment and ackrc settings if things
don't seem to work right</li>
<li><code>-Q</code> -- turn off regex meta characters if needed</li>
<li><code>--flush</code> -- if you're piping to a command and there are timing issues</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="option_comparision_with_grep">option comparision with grep</a></h3>

<h4><a name="options_missing_in_ack">options missing in ack</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-n</code> -- prefix line number (this seems like a big omission!)</li>
<li><code>-q</code> and <code>-s</code> -- quiet/silent/no-messages options</li>
<li><code>-z</code> -- input terminated by null bytes</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="options_different_in_ack">options different in ack</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-Z</code> in grep is <code>--print0</code> here</li>
<li><code>-NUM</code> is <code>-C NUM</code> here; the -C is mandatory</li>
<li><code>-e</code> is <code>--match</code> here</li>
<li><code>-F</code> is <code>-Q</code> here; treat patterns as fixed strings</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="options_identical_in_both">options identical in both</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-i</code> -- ignore case (but I prefer smart-case; see above)</li>
<li><code>-v</code> -- invert match</li>
<li><code>-w</code> -- word match</li>
<li><code>-l</code> -- names of files with matches</li>
<li><code>-L</code> -- names of files without matches</li>
<li><code>-o</code> -- print only matching part</li>
<li><code>-mNUM</code> -- stop reading a file after NUM matches</li>
<li><code>-A/-B</code> -- after and before context (but see note on -C above)</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Using squidGuard for content filtering</h1>

<p>To make squid aware of squidguard:</p>

<pre><code>redirect_program /usr/local/bin/squidGuard -c /usr/local/squidGuard/squidGuard.conf
redirect_children 8
redirector_bypass on
</code></pre>

<p>The redirector_bypass option tells squid to ignore the redirector if it
becomes unavailable for some reason.</p>

<p><sup>Source: <a href="http://www.linux.com/article.pl?sid=07/02/06/1752220">http://www.linux.com/article.pl?sid=07/02/06/1752220</a></sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>ncat</h1>

<p>(aka: oh God please not yet another netcat clone!)</p>

<p>ncat ships with the new nmap 5.  In general, <a href="socat.html">socat</a> cleans its
clock, except for these points:</p>

<ul>
<li>can act as a proxy <em>server</em></li>
<li><p>broker mode; see <a href="http://nmap.org/ncat/guide/ncat-file-transfer.html">http://nmap.org/ncat/guide/ncat-file-transfer.html</a></p>

<pre><code>host3$ ncat -l --broker
host2$ ncat host3 &gt; outputfile
host1$ ncat --send-only host3 &lt; inputfile
</code></pre>

<p>Note that it's important for host2 (the receiving host) to connect to the
broker before host1 (the sending host) does. The broker does not buffer
received data to send to hosts that connect later. After the file is
transferred, it is necessary to forcible disconnect the Ncat on host2 with
ctrl+C. The broker never disconnects any of its clients.</p></li>
<li><p>chat mode: <code>ncat -l --chat</code> on the server and everyone else just does
<code>ncat server</code>.  (Chat mode is a special case of broker mode where the
server adds a connection ID to each output line so you sorta know who said
what)</p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Flatfield images</h1>

<p>So, the theory of "flatfields" goes like this:</p>

<ul>
<li>Before the night starts ...
<ul>
<li>take a picture of a uniform, bright scene: a "flatfield image"</li>
<li>use the pixel values of this "flatfield" to define the relative
sensitivity of each pixel </li>
</ul></li>
<li>During the night ....
<ul>
<li>take pictures of stars, galaxies, etc. </li>
</ul></li>
<li>Afterwards ...
<ul>
<li>divide the pictures of stars by the "flatfield" image to correct for
differences in sensitivity</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>Source: <a href="http://spiff.rit.edu/classes/phys445/lectures/flats/flats.html">http://spiff.rit.edu/classes/phys445/lectures/flats/flats.html</a></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>parchive2/par2 notes</h1>

<p>Note: I have no idea what the "-l" does.  Limit to what???</p>

<p>Here's some explanation of the various options; the documentation is not very
clear on some of these points and I experimented to find some of this.</p>

<pre><code>-b&lt;n&gt;  : Set the Block-Count
-s&lt;n&gt;  : Set the Block-Size (Don't use both -b and -s)
</code></pre>

<p>These options control how the input is divided for processing.  "-b" is the
number of blocks to divide the input into.  Alternatively, "-s" is the block
size to use for processing.  Clearly b * s = file-size, which is why you can't
specify both.  The default appears to be "-b2000"; I can't think of a major
reason to mess with this.</p>

<pre><code>-r&lt;n&gt;  : Level of Redundancy (%%)
-c&lt;n&gt;  : Recovery block count (Don't use both -r and -c)
</code></pre>

<p>These options control the amount of recovery data created.  The less your
trust your medium, the more you need to increase this.</p>

<p>The default seems to be "-r5" (5%), and the computed "-c" will thus be
file-size*r%/s, where s is the blocksize given/computed above.  If you
take all the defaults this reduces to 100 (5% of 2000) regardless of file
size.</p>

<p>In practice, supplying "-r" seems easier then supplying "-c".</p>

<pre><code>-u     : Uniform recovery file sizes
-l     : Limit size of recovery files (Don't use both -u and -l)
-n&lt;n&gt;  : Number of recovery files (Don't use both -n and -l)
</code></pre>

<p>These options determine how many recovery files are made and how the recovery
blocks are distributed among them.</p>

<p>Without "-u", the par2 files are created with 1, 2, 4, 8, ... blocks.  So you
can easily compute "n" (# of recovery files created) when "c" recovery blocks
are needed.  Again, if you take all the defaults, "n" turns out to be 7.</p>

<p>With "-u", instead of a GP starting with 1, it just divides them equally.
(With all other settings at default, you get 2 15s, then 5 14s, total 100).</p>

<p>The "-n" takes a little explaining.  Let's say the computed "n" is 9, and you
override it by saying "-n4".  Then, instead of par2 files going 1, 2, 4, 8...,
they go 32, 64, 128, etc., until the number of blocks needed are created.  Of
course, 32 is 2^(9-4) -- essentially scale up in powers of two to compensate
for the lesser number of files.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Funny Quotes</h1>

<ul>
<li>I'm a consultant - I convert gibberish into cash-flow.</li>
<li>When you're too old to think, you reminisce -- from a talk by van Jacobsen</li>
<li>Doug Carlin: I'll speak slowly so that those of you in the room who have PhDs can understand me. 
<ul>
<li>from the movie Deja Vu (2006)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>info browser cheatsheet</h1>

<ul>
<li><code>[</code> and <code>]</code> are the faster eqvts of <code>space</code> and
<code>backspace</code> for paging through an entire info tree; they only show the
first page of each node before moving to the next one</li>
<li><code>m</code> for menus and <code>f</code> for xrefs can use <code>TAB</code> for completion</li>
<li><code>l</code> is very important, esp when you have used xrefs to jump out of the
chain</li>
<li><code>u</code> moves "up"</li>
<li><code>d</code> directory node<br></li>
<li><code>t</code> top node<br></li>
<li><code>i</code> index node, searchable<br></li>
<li><code>,</code> search for next index match entry (not tried yet)</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="netcat_cheat_sheet">netcat cheat sheet</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#netcat_cheat_sheet">netcat cheat sheet</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Usage">Usage</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Cheat_Sheet">Cheat Sheet</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#major_features">major features</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Example_uses_the_light_side">Example uses -- the light side</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Example_uses_the_dark_side">Example uses -- the dark side</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Notes">Notes</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#NT_version">NT version</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#NT_only_features">NT-only features</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Examples">Examples</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#PROBLEMS_with_Netcat_1_1_for_NT">PROBLEMS with Netcat 1.1 for NT</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="Usage">Usage</a></h3>

<pre><code>[v1.10]
connect:    nc            [-options] hostname port[s] [ports] ... 
listen :    nc -l -p port [-options] [hostname] [port]
options:
        -e prog     program to exec after connect [dangerous!!]
        -b          allow broadcasts
        -g gateway  source-routing hop point[s], up to 8
        -G num      source-routing pointer: 4, 8, 12, ...
        -h          this cruft
        -i secs     delay interval for lines sent, ports scanned
        -l          listen mode, for inbound connects
        -n          numeric-only IP addresses, no DNS
        -o file     hex dump of traffic
        -p port     local port number
        -r          randomize local and remote ports
        -q secs     quit after EOF on stdin and delay of secs
        -s addr     local source address
        -t          answer TELNET negotiation
        -u          UDP mode
        -v          verbose [use twice to be more verbose]
        -w secs     timeout for connects and final net reads
        -z          zero-I/O mode [used for scanning]
port numbers can be individual or ranges: lo-hi [inclusive]
</code></pre>

<h3><a name="Cheat_Sheet">Cheat Sheet</a></h3>

<p>Recommended options: </p>

<ul>
<li>author recommends <code>-v -w 3</code> all the time.</li>
</ul>

<p>Closing a connection:</p>

<ul>
<li>Waits for network side to close before exiting.  When using the <code>-w</code>
timeout, it waits for that long after stdin is closed, does a "final net
read", then closes the socket and exits.</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="major_features">major features</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>Outbound or inbound connections, TCP or UDP, to or from any ports</li>
<li>Full DNS forward/reverse checking, with appropriate warnings</li>
<li>Ability to use any local source port</li>
<li>Ability to use any locally-configured network source address</li>
<li>Built-in port-scanning capabilities, with randomizer</li>
<li>Built-in loose source-routing capability</li>
<li>Can read command line arguments from standard input</li>
<li>Slow-send mode, one line every N seconds</li>
<li>Hex dump of transmitted and received data</li>
<li>Optional ability to let another program service established connections</li>
<li>Optional telnet-options responder</li>
</ul>

<p>Arguments from stdin:</p>

<ul>
<li>If no command arguments are given at all, netcat asks for them, reads a
line from standard input, and breaks it up into arguments internally.
This can be useful when driving netcat from certain types of scripts, with
the side effect of hiding your command line arguments from "ps" displays.</li>
</ul>

<p>(<code>-v</code> without <code>-n</code>) full DNS check:</p>

<ul>
<li>Do a full forward and reverse name and address lookup for the host, and
warn about the all-too-common problem of mismatched names in the DNS.</li>
</ul>

<p>UDP stuff:</p>

<ul>
<li>please read the README again for caveats etc.</li>
</ul>

<p>(<code>-l</code>) Restricting who connects to a listening nc:</p>

<ul>
<li>If you specify a target host and optional port in listen mode, netcat will
accept an inbound connection only from that host and if you specify one,
only from that foreign source port.</li>
</ul>

<p>(<code>-e</code>) exec mode:</p>

<ul>
<li>Command name only; cannot take arguments!  If you want to launch something
with an argument list, write a two-line wrapper script or just use inetd
like always.</li>
</ul>

<p>port-scanning:</p>

<ul>
<li>See first syntax in <em>Usage</em> above.  If more than one port is thus
specified, netcat connects to <strong>all</strong> of them, sending the same batch of
data from standard input [up to 8K worth] to each one that is successfully
connected to.</li>
</ul>

<p>(<code>-r</code>) random local and scanned ports:</p>

<ul>
<li>Scanning is normally done downward in the range given unless <code>-r</code> is
given.</li>
</ul>

<p>(<code>-v -v</code>) verbosity in port scanning:</p>

<ul>
<li>Specifying multiple ports also suppresses diagnostic messages about
refused connections, unless <code>-v</code> is specified twice for "more
verbosity".</li>
</ul>

<p>(<code>-z</code>) for scanning:</p>

<ul>
<li>Prevents sending any data to a TCP connection and very limited probe data
to a UDP connection, and is thus useful as a fast scanning mode just to
see what ports the target is listening on.</li>
</ul>

<p>source-routing:</p>

<ul>
<li>Please first learn how this works in general, then hit the README again!
(<code>traceroute -g</code> may be a good start)</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Example_uses_the_light_side">Example uses -- the light side</a></h3>

<p>scripts:</p>

<ul>
<li>plenty in the distribution; please read!</li>
</ul>

<p>replacement for telnet:</p>

<ul>
<li>must use this more often... esp on windows</li>
</ul>

<p>better scanning example:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>typing</p>

<pre><code>echo QUIT | nc -v -w 5 target 20-250 500-600 5990-7000
</code></pre>

<p>Sending in QUIT and using the timeout will almost guarantee that you see
some kind of greeting or error from each service, which usually indicates
what it is and what version.</p>

<p><strong>Beware of the <em>chargen</em> port, though...</strong></p></li>
</ul>

<p>more intrusive example:</p>

<ul>
<li>is in scripts/probe</li>
</ul>

<p>minimal web server:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>For shipping things to a PC that doesn't have any network applications
except a TCP stack and a web browser.</p></li>
<li><p>run this on some handy server</p>

<pre><code>(echo HTTP/1.0 200 OK; \
    echo Content-type: application/octet-stream; \
    echo; cat WomenAreComplicated_1.jpg ) |
nc -v -l -p 3333
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>point the browser at <a href="http://somehost:3333/whatever">http://somehost:3333/whatever</a></p>

<p>Since it's cumbersome to add content-length and keepalive headers to
enable the browser to detect when the transmission is complete, you need
to make the netcat side close when done.  Best way is to add a <code>-w 10</code> or
something.</p>

<p>However, remember that in that case you must either (1) start the browser
download within the 10 seconds (since the <code>-w</code> applies to both the initial
connect as well as "final net read") or (2) put the netcat in a shell loop
until it "succeeds" (exit code 0).</p></li>
</ul>

<p>avoiding "address in use" error:</p>

<ul>
<li>By binding to a specific address.  This lets you place netcat "in the way"
of a standard service (assuming the standard service is bound to "any")</li>
</ul>

<p>simple TCP redirector under inetd:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>for inbound services.  Example :</p>

<pre><code>www stream tcp nowait nobody /etc/tcpd /bin/nc -w 3 realwww 80
</code></pre>

<p>and you have a simple and effective "application relay" with access
control and logging.  Note use of the wait time as a "safety" in case
realwww isn't reachable or the calling user aborts the connection --
otherwise the relay may hang there forever.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>stress test networks:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>generate huge amounts of useless network data for various performance
testing.  For example, doing</p>

<pre><code>yes AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA | nc -v -v -l -p 2222 &gt; /dev/null
</code></pre>

<p>on one side and then hitting it with</p>

<pre><code>yes BBBBBBBBBBBBBBBBBBBBBB | nc othermachine 2222 &gt; /dev/null
</code></pre>

<p>from another host will saturate your wires with A's and B's.  The "very
verbose" switch usage will tell you how many of each were sent and
received after you interrupt either side.  Using UDP mode produces
tremendously MORE trash per unit time in the form of fragmented 8 Kbyte
mobygrams -- enough to stress-test kernels and network interfaces.</p>

<p>Firing random binary data into various network servers may help expose
bugs in their input handling.  example in data/data.c (src pkg?) includes
ability to generate random dataat well-chosen points in a data stream!</p></li>
</ul>

<p>debugging network protocols using the hex dump:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>Bind a listening netcat to a local port, and have it run a script which in
turn runs another netcat to the real service and captures the hex dump to
a log file.  This sets up a transparent relay between your local port and
wherever the real service is.</p>

<p>Be sure that the script-run netcat does <strong>not</strong> use <code>-v</code>, or the extra
info it sends to standard error may confuse the protocol.  Note also that
you cannot have the "listen/exec" netcat do the data capture, since once
the connection arrives it is no longer netcat that is running.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>test remote sysloggers:</p>

<ul>
<li>Make a UDP connection to port 514 and type in <code>&lt;0&gt;message</code>, which
should correspond to "kern.emerg" and cause syslogd to scream into every
file it has open [and possibly all over users' terminals].  Look in
sysog.h for other numbers (example, <code>&lt;38&gt;</code> could be auth.notice).</li>
</ul>

<p>protect X against outside access:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>X is stupid enough to listen for connections on "any" and never tell you
when new connections arrive, which is one reason it is so vulnerable.
Once you have all your various X windows up and running you can use netcat
to bind just to your ethernet address and listen to port 6000.  Any new
connections from outside the machine will hit netcat instead your X
server, and you get a log of who's trying.</p>

<p>Since netcat only handles one listening connection per run, make sure that
whatever way you rig it causes another one to run and listen on 6000 soon
afterward, or your real X server will be reachable once again.  A very
minimal script just to protect yourself could be
    while true ; do
        nc -v -l -s <your-addr> -p 6000 localhost 2
    done
which causes netcat to accept and then close any inbound connection to
your workstation's normal ethernet address, and another copy is
immediately run by the script.  Send standard error to a file for a log of
connection attempts.</p>

<p>If your system can't do the "specific bind" thing all is not lost; run
your X server on display ":1" or port 6001, and netcat can still function
as a probe alarm by listening on 6000.</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Example_uses_the_dark_side">Example uses -- the dark side</a></h3>

<p>hijack listeners:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>-e</code> in conjunction with binding to a specific address can enable
"server takeover" by getting in ahead of the real ones, whereupon you can
snarf data sent in and feed your own back out.  At the very least you can
log a hex dump of someone else's session.</li>
</ul>

<p>backdoor shell:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>-e</code> to start a remote backdoor shell is easier than constructing a
file for inetd, and you can access-control it against other people by
specifying a client host and port.  Example is in scripts/bsh.</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Notes">Notes</a></h3>

<p>A discussion of various caveats, subtleties, and the design of the innards:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>If you want to use a normal full-blown telnet to get to something but also
want some of netcat's features involved like settable ports or timeouts,
construct a tiny "foo" script :</p>

<pre><code>#! /bin/sh
exec nc -otheroptions targethost 23
</code></pre>

<p>and then do</p>

<pre><code>nc -l -p someport -e foo localhost &amp;
telnet localhost someport
</code></pre>

<p>and your telnet should connect transparently through the exec'ed netcat to
the target, using whatever options you supplied in the "foo" script.
Don't use <code>-t</code> inside the script, or you'll wind up sending <strong>two</strong>
option responses.</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="NT_version">NT version</a></h3>

<h4><a name="NT_only_features">NT-only features</a></h4>

<p>Ability to run in the background without a console window</p>

<pre><code>-d
</code></pre>

<p>Ability to restart as a single-threaded server to handle a new connection</p>

<pre><code>-L
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Examples">Examples</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>get a quick shell going
    nc -l -p 23 -t -e cmd.exe
Using AT to schedule Netcat would run it with user <code>NT
AUTHORITY\SYSTEM</code>.</li>
<li>Do a little exploring and see if the firewall you may be behind lets port
53 through.  Then,
    nc -L -p 53 -e cmd.exe</li>
<li>The <code>-L</code> (note the capital L) option will restart Netcat with the same
command line when the connection is terminated.  This way you can connect
over and over to the same Netcat process.</li>
<li><code>-d</code> (detach from console) will let Netcat run without an ugly console
window cluttering up the screen or showing up in the task list.</li>
<li>You can even get Netcat to listen on the NETBIOS ports that are probably
running on most NT machines.  This way you can get a connection to a
machine that may have port filtering enabled in the TCP/IP Security
Network control panel.  Unlike Unix, NT does not seem to have any security
around which ports that user programs are allowed to bind to.  This means
any user can run a program that will bind to the NETBIOS ports.</li>
<li>You will need to bind "in front of" some services that may already be
listening on those ports by binding to a specific IP address :
    nc -v -L -e cmd.exe -p 139 -s xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
Now you can connect to the machine on port 139 and Netcat will field the
connection before NETBIOS does.  You have effectively shut off file
sharing on this machine by the way.  You have done this with just user
privileges to boot.</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="PROBLEMS_with_Netcat_1_1_for_NT">PROBLEMS with Netcat 1.1 for NT</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-w</code> works for final net reads but not for connections.</li>
<li><code>-e</code> in UDP mode has problems.</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="Vimperator_6">Vimperator 6</a></h1>

<p><sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Vimperator_6">Vimperator 6</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Emergency_stuff">Emergency stuff</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Browsing_1">Browsing 1</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Browsing_2">Browsing 2</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Zooming">Zooming</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Other_stuff">Other stuff</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Concerns">Concerns</a><br>
</sup></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="Emergency_stuff">Emergency stuff</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>disable all, good for gmail text box etc; Escape to get out</p>

<pre><code>&lt;c-q&gt;
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>disable only next key</p>

<pre><code>&lt;c-v&gt;
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>get back menu/toolbars etc</p>

<pre><code>set go=mbT
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Browsing_1">Browsing 1</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>vim-like keybindings</p>

<pre><code>h, j, k, l, &lt;c-d&gt;, &lt;c-u&gt;, gg, G, 0, $...
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>caret mode start</p>

<pre><code>i
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>reload, skip cache</p>

<pre><code>r, R
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>close tab, undo</p>

<pre><code>d, u
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>focus on next/previous frame</p>

<pre><code>]f, [f
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>view web page name, info</p>

<pre><code>&lt;c-g&gt;, g&lt;c-g&gt;
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>view source, with external editor (VIM, what else?)</p>

<pre><code>gf, gF
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>focus last used input field or first one on page</p>

<pre><code>gi
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>open a prompt to switch buffers (tabs)</p></li>
<li><p>TAB-completion works great; any part of the title or url</p>

<pre><code>b&lt;number or pattern&gt;&lt;enter&gt;
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>go to the first tab, last tab, switch to last used tab</p>

<pre><code>g0, g$, &lt;c-^&gt;
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>set buffer-local mark at the current position, across-buffers mark</p>

<pre><code>m{a-z}, m{A-Z}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>jump to mark above</p>

<pre><code>'{a-z}, '{A-Z}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>search for text</p></li>
<li>\c anywhere in pattern == force ignorecase</li>
<li><p>\C == noic, \l == linksonly, \L == fulltext</p>

<pre><code>/pattern, ?pattern, n, N, etc
*, #    just like in vim
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Browsing_2">Browsing 2</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p><strong>open "next"/"previous" link</strong></p>

<pre><code>]], [[
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>open a link by typing the number or the link text, new tab</p>

<pre><code>f, F
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>other actions on links:</p>

<pre><code>;;              hover
;s/;a           save its destination/save as
;o/;t/;O/;T     as for o/t/O/T
;v              view source!  (WOW!)
;y/;Y           yank url/text
;f/;F           like f/F but in AlwaysHint mode
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>open, in new tab, based on current url</p></li>
<li>can open multiple, separated by <code>comma-space</code></li>
<li>TAB-completion is excellent -- urls and titles too</li>
<li><p>firefox keywords and search engines work great</p>

<pre><code>o, t, O, T
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>yank current location to clipboard, current text</p>

<pre><code>y, Y
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>paste (put) a URL into the current tab, new tab</p>

<pre><code>p, P
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>go up to parent URL, website root</p>

<pre><code>gu, gU
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>increment last number in URL, decrement</p>

<pre><code>&lt;c-a&gt;, &lt;c-x&gt;
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>add a quickmark</p>

<pre><code>M{a-zA-Z0-9}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>open a quickmark, in a new tab</p>

<pre><code>go{a-zA-Z0-9}, gn{a-zA-Z0-9}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>add a bookmark</p>

<pre><code>a -t title -T tag1,tag2 -k keyword [url]
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Zooming">Zooming</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>zoom in, zoom in more, zoom out, zoom out more, set % (default 100)</p>

<pre><code>zi (+), zm, zo (-), zr, [n]zz
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>same, but including non-text elements</p>

<pre><code>zI, zM, zO, zR, [n]zZ
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Other_stuff">Other stuff</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>record macros (uppercase to append), play macros</p>

<pre><code>q{0-9a-zA-Z}, [count]@{0-9a-z}
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Concerns">Concerns</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><code>b &lt;search string&gt;</code> seems to be case-sensitive...!</li>
<li>the <code>set inv&lt;option&gt;</code> doesn't seem to be documented</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="LIRC_linux_infrared_remote_control">LIRC -- linux infrared remote control</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#LIRC_linux_infrared_remote_control">LIRC -- linux infrared remote control</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_usr_local_bin_lirc_start_"><code>/usr/local/bin/lirc.start</code></a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_etc_sysconfig_lircd_"><code>/etc/sysconfig/lircd</code></a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_etc_lircrc_"><code>/etc/lircrc</code></a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_etc_lircd_conf_"><code>/etc/lircd.conf</code></a><br></p>

<hr />

<p>This is my short howto on this topic, based solely on managing to control
<code>mplayer</code> and <code>xine</code> using the remote control for a small boombox I
have.  This may not be sufficient for other hardware scenarios.</p>

<p>First, make sure the BIOS settings show IR enabled, and assigned to (in our
example) <code>COM2</code>.  This corresponds to <code>/dev/ttyS1</code> on Linux.  For
other COMs adjust accordingly.</p>

<p>Install whatever RPMs you can find regarding lirc, including dkms-lirc.  Then
create the files shown below.  <strong>Warning</strong>: the last file
<code>/etc/lircd.conf</code> is almost certainly not what <em>you</em> want -- be sure to
run <code>irrecord</code> and create your own for <em>your</em> remote, or use one of the
hundreds of pre-built ones.</p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="_usr_local_bin_lirc_start_"><code>/usr/local/bin/lirc.start</code></a></h3>

<pre><code>#!/bin/bash

# best if started from /etc/rc.local
# does not work automatically after suspend/resume; module needs to be
# unloaded and reloaded

set -x
service lircd stop
setserial /dev/ttyS0 uart none
setserial /dev/ttyS1 uart none

depmod -a
modprobe lirc_sir irq=3 io=0x02f8

service lircd start
chmod a+rw /dev/lirc/0              # I can't be bothered to fine-grain this!

# quick ref of trouble-shooting commands
# mode2 -d /dev/lirc/0              # to test if stuff is coming through
# irrecord -d /dev/lirc/0 stereo    # produces /etc/lircd.conf
# irw                               # see if your buttons are recognised properly
# mplayer -input cmdlist    or xine --keymap=lirc
</code></pre>

<p>Notes on the above:</p>

<h4>setserial</h4>

<p>The <code>setserial</code> command makes the serial port driver, which has by default
grabbed all serial ports, give it back to the lirc driver.  This is necessary.</p>

<p>Why did I put in a <code>setserial</code> for <code>/dev/ttyS0</code> also?  I don't remember!  I
will have to try without it and see what happens...  TODO</p>

<h4>chmod</h4>

<p>If you are paranoid about this, use groups and fix it.</p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="_etc_sysconfig_lircd_"><code>/etc/sysconfig/lircd</code></a></h3>

<pre><code># Customized setings for lirc daemon

# The hardware driver to use, run lircd --driver=? for a list

DRIVER=default

# Hardware driver module to load
HWMOD=lirc_sir

# The device node that communicates with the IR device.
# if you are using lirc_serial, set DEVICE to /dev/ttyS[0-9]
# where 0-9 is the serial port your IR receiver is plugged

# with devfs enabled
DEVICE=/dev/lirc/0
#DEVICE=/dev/lirc/serial

# without devfs
#DEVICE=/dev/lirc

# Serial port for the receiver (for serial driver)
# COM1 (/dev/ttyS0)
#COM_PORT=/dev/ttyS0
#DRIVER_OPTS="irq=4 io=0x3f8"

# COM2 (/dev/ttyS1)
COM_PORT=/dev/ttyS1
DRIVER_OPTS="irq=3 io=0x2f8"

# COM3 (/dev/ttyS2)
#COM_PORT=/dev/ttyS2
#DRIVER_OPTS="irq=4 io=0x3e8

# COM4 (/dev/ttyS3)
#COM_PORT=/dev/ttyS3
#DRIVER_OPTS="irq=3 io=0x2e8"
</code></pre>

<hr />

<h3><a name="_etc_lircrc_"><code>/etc/lircrc</code></a></h3>

<pre><code>begin
    button = OSD
    prog = mplayer
    config = osd
end

begin
    button = MUTE
    prog = mplayer
    config = mute
end

begin
    button = PAUSE
    prog = mplayer
    config = pause
end

begin
    button = FFSHORT
    prog = mplayer
    config = seek +10 0
end

begin
    button = BKSHORT
    prog = mplayer
    config = seek -10 0
end

begin
    button = FFLONG
    prog = mplayer
    config = seek +60 0
    repeat = 1
end

begin
    button = BKLONG
    prog = mplayer
    config = seek -60 0
    repeat = 1
end

begin
     button = VOLUP
     prog = mplayer
     config = volume 1
     repeat = 1
end

begin
    button = VOLDN
    prog = mplayer
    config = volume -1
    repeat = 1
end





# visibility toggle of UI windows
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = OSD
    prog   = xine
    repeat = 0
    config = ToggleVisibility
end

# audio muting toggle
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = MUTE
    prog   = xine
    config = Mute
end

# playback pause toggle
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = PAUSE
    prog   = xine
    config = Pause
end

# set position to -7 seconds in current stream
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = BKSHORT
    prog   = xine
    config = SeekRelative-7
end

# set position to +7 seconds in current stream
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = FFSHORT
    prog   = xine
    config = SeekRelative+7
end

# set position to -60 seconds in current stream
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = BKLONG
    prog   = xine
    repeat = 1
    config = SeekRelative-60
end

# set position to +60 seconds in current stream
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = FFLONG
    prog   = xine
    repeat = 1
    config = SeekRelative+60
end

# increment audio volume
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = VOLUP
    prog   = xine
    repeat = 1
    config = Volume+
end

# decrement audio volume
begin
    remote = stereo
    button = VOLDN
    prog   = xine
    repeat = 1
    config = Volume-
end
</code></pre>

<hr />

<h3><a name="_etc_lircd_conf_"><code>/etc/lircd.conf</code></a></h3>

<pre><code># this config file was automatically generated
# using lirc-0.8.3-CVS(default) on Sun Feb  3 00:17:00 2008
#
# contributed by
#
# brand:                       stereo
# model no. of remote control:
# devices being controlled by this remote:

begin remote

  name  stereo
  bits           15
  flags SPACE_ENC|CONST_LENGTH
  eps            30
  aeps          100

  header       2363   636
  one          1164   637
  zero          563   637
  gap          45187
  min_repeat      9
  toggle_bit_mask 0x0

      begin codes
          QUIT                     0x5422
          OSD                      0x7122
          MUTE                     0x7B26
          PAUSE                    0x6626
          FFSHORT                  0x1126
          BKSHORT                  0x6126
          FFLONG                   0x6E26
          BKLONG                   0x2E26
          VOLUP                    0x2422
          VOLDN                    0x6422
      end codes

end remote
</code></pre>

<hr />
</html>

<html>
<h1>networking - bridging</h1>

<p><sup><strong>Warning</strong>: this is from a 2002 document; check <code>man brctl</code> etc before
committing.  Also, the new "ip" command set may have a different idea of how
to do this, more current!</sup></p>

<p>create a bridge</p>

<pre><code>brctl addbr br0
</code></pre>

<p>switch off /spanning tree protocol/ because we have a simple, non-looping setup</p>

<pre><code>brctl stp br0 off
</code></pre>

<p>attach the ethernet interfaces to the bridge</p>

<pre><code>brctl addif br0 eth0
brctl addif br0 eth1
</code></pre>

<p>now these two devices -- <em>eth0</em> and <em>eth1</em> do NOT need an IP address of their
own</p>

<pre><code>ifconfig eth0 down
ifconfig eth1 down
?? why is this needed?
ifconfig eth0 0.0.0.0 up
ifconfig eth1 0.0.0.0 up
</code></pre>

<p>(optionally), give the interface one single IP</p>

<pre><code>ifconfig br0 10.2.3.4 up
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>notes on using SSH for tunnels</h1>

<h3>layer 3 VPN/tunnels using ssh</h3>

<ul>
<li><code>sshd_config</code> on the server must specify <code>PermitTunnel yes</code> or no dice</li>
<li><p>create the two tun devices beforehand, as root, and tie them to your
userid; the names have to be tunN (ssh expects them that way)</p>

<pre><code>tunctl -u sitaram -t tun0   # on both machines
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>connect; note we just give the two 0's -- the "tun" prefix is assumed.
Also note you can't use the "any" syntax (which causes the ssh
client/server to attempt to create the tun device, which requires root
privileges)</p>

<pre><code>ssh -w 0:0 sitaram@server
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>give IP addresses to each side; type</p>

<pre><code>ifconfig tun0 10.1.1.1 10.1.1.2 netmask 255.255.255.252
</code></pre>

<p>on one machine, and</p>

<pre><code>ifconfig tun0 10.1.1.2 10.1.1.1 netmask 255.255.255.252
</code></pre>

<p>on the other</p></li>
<li><p>make sure the firewall isn't blocking stuff; type this on <strong>both</strong>
machines (or use other means to ensure this)</p>

<pre><code>iptables -I INPUT -i tun+ -j ACCEPT
iptables -I OUTPUT -o tun+ -j ACCEPT
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>Now check <code>ip addr</code> and try pinging the other guy.</p></li>
</ul>

<hr />

<p>(Optional) When done, don't forget to <code>service shorewall restart</code> on both
machines, and, on the server, comment out the <code>PermitTunnel</code> directive and
restart sshd.</p>

<h3>layer 2 tunnels</h3>

<p>It is possible that setting "Tunnel ethernet" specifically in <code>ssh_config</code> may
make the above work similarly for layer 2.  Perhaps it will default to
expecting <code>tapN</code> instead of <code>tunN</code> etc., too.  I haven't felt the need to try
it yet.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>How to handle bad mime-types in emails</h1>

<h3>Problem</h3>

<p>You get an email from someone using a crap mail client which doesn't put in
the proper mime-type for files, instead using a generic
<code>application/octet-stream</code> for all files.</p>

<p>TB now goes by the extension, but the OS-default application for the extension
is something you don't like.</p>

<p>And as a result of the generic mimetype, the "always use this..." box is
greyed out in TB's attachment handler dialog, and you're tired of constantly
telling TB what application to use.</p>

<p>You are unable or unwilling to change the OS-default application, and would
like to fix it within TB only.</p>

<h3>Non-solution</h3>

<p>You may be tempted to read
http://kb.mozillazine.org/Actions<em>for</em>attachment<em>file</em>types and hope for
salvation.  Forget it.  Not in this case (on FF3B3 anyway) :-)</p>

<h3>Solution</h3>

<p>So you read <a href="http://kb.mozillazine.org/MimeTypes.rdf">http://kb.mozillazine.org/MimeTypes.rdf</a> and decide to do the
following:</p>

<ul>
<li>if feeling adventurous, delete <code>mimeTypes.rdf</code> from the profile directory</li>
<li>run TB, open an email <strong>sent correctly</strong> (with proper mime-type), choose
your application, tell TB to "always use this..." blah blah</li>
<li><p>close TB, open the <code>mimeTypes.rdf</code> file and make the following change
in it.  (There's only one line to add; the rest is to give you context!)</p>

<pre><code>--- mimeTypes.rdf   2008-03-03 13:40:00.000000000 +0530
+++ -   2008-03-03 13:45:43.498568201 +0530
@@ -1,26 +1,27 @@
 &lt;?xml version="1.0"?&gt;
 &lt;RDF:RDF xmlns:NC="http://home.netscape.com/NC-rdf#"
          xmlns:RDF="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"&gt;
   &lt;RDF:Seq RDF:about="urn:mimetypes:root"&gt;
     &lt;RDF:li RDF:resource="urn:mimetype:application/pdf"/&gt;
   &lt;/RDF:Seq&gt;
   &lt;RDF:Description RDF:about="urn:mimetypes"&gt;
     &lt;NC:MIME-types RDF:resource="urn:mimetypes:root"/&gt;
   &lt;/RDF:Description&gt;
   &lt;RDF:Description RDF:about="urn:mimetype:application/pdf"
+                   NC:fileExtensions="pdf"
                    NC:value="application/pdf"
                    NC:editable="true"
                    NC:description="PDF document"&gt;
     &lt;NC:handlerProp RDF:resource="urn:mimetype:handler:application/pdf"/&gt;
   &lt;/RDF:Description&gt;
   &lt;RDF:Description RDF:about="urn:mimetype:externalApplication:application/pdf"
                    NC:path="/usr/bin/kpdf"
                    NC:prettyName="kpdf" /&gt;
   &lt;RDF:Description RDF:about="urn:mimetype:handler:application/pdf"
                    NC:alwaysAsk="false"
                    NC:saveToDisk="false"
                    NC:useSystemDefault="false"
                    NC:handleInternal="false"&gt;
     &lt;NC:externalApplication RDF:resource="urn:mimetype:externalApplication:application/pdf"/&gt;
   &lt;/RDF:Description&gt;
 &lt;/RDF:RDF&gt;
</code></pre></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Proxy bypass</h1>

<p><a href="http://www.google.com/gwt/n">http://www.google.com/gwt/n</a> -- start with a known URL</p>

<ul>
<li>seems to proxy inline images also</li>
<li>just type a URL</li>
<li>much cleaner URLs resulting from browsing; you'll feel like actually using
them :-)</li>
<li>wont do gmail</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="http://www.google.com/xhtml">http://www.google.com/xhtml</a> -- start with a search</p>

<ul>
<li>search interface to the above; morphs into the "/gwt/n?n=" style URL on
the first link you click but the URL is much more complicated</li>
<li>does gmail, sort of, but most work proxies will catch it anyway</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>openDNS IP numbers</h1>

<pre><code>nameserver 208.67.222.222
nameserver 208.67.220.220
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>graphviz notes for the 'dot' program</h1>

<p>links</p>

<pre><code>http://www.graphviz.org/Gallery.php             # limited use but still...
http://www.graphviz.org/content/dot-language    # called 'lang' in this doc
http://www.graphviz.org/content/attrs           # 'attrs' (reference; complex/long)
http://www.graphviz.org/content/node-shapes     # 'nshp' (reference; but see notes below)
http://www.graphviz.org/content/color-names     # 'clrs'
</code></pre>

<p>Qs:
  - what is 'a -- b [type=s]'?
  - examples or better docs required for
      - 'pos' to specify a position?
      - 'group'
      - 'concentrate'
      - 'ordering'
      - 'ranksep'
      - 'ratio'
      - 'orientation' (portrait/landscape not mentioned in docs!)
  - all features marked DW either don't work or don't work predictably; expect
    to take time to learn if you need those features</p>

<p>general concepts and notes</p>

<ul>
<li>attributes defined in 'node', 'edge' or 'graph' statements are inherited
by objects defined later</li>
</ul>

<p>general attributes</p>

<pre><code>color=red
    use http://www.graphviz.org/content/color-names or #FFDD00 style
fillcolor=blue
    node and cluster only; requires 'style=filled'
    'color' is used for fill if fillcolor is not defined
fontcolor=green
label="string"
</code></pre>

<p>graph attributes</p>

<pre><code>'aspect=1.3'
    (DW) control runaway width/height for large fan-in/fan-out
bgcolor = red
    background color for entire canvas
    it is also the initial fill color (can be "transparent")
rankdir = TB            // or LR, BT, RL
splines = true          // or false or ortho

size = "4,4"            // inches
splines = false         // makes them all straight lines
</code></pre>

<p>node attributes</p>

<pre><code>image="foo.png"         // also see imagescale (DW)
    seems to have trouble with jpg and ps; only png works predictably right now
label="string" shape="record"
    then 'string' can be special; see 'record-based shapes' later
shape (see below)
style = dashed, dotted, solid, invis, bold, filled, diagonals, rounded
</code></pre>

<p>(additional notes on node attributes)</p>

<pre><code>'nshp' says: The geometry and style of all node shapes are affected by the node
attributes fixedsize, fontname, fontsize, height, label, style and width.
</code></pre>

<p>edge attributes</p>

<pre><code>arrowhead=normal        // also arrowtail
    http://www.graphviz.org/content/attrs#karrowType has more, like dot,
    odot, none, vee, inv, crow, and so on
a -&gt; b [dir=both color="red:blue"]
    edge is drawn using parallel splines, one per color in list
dir=both
    (direction of arrow) or forward, or back, or none
style = dashed, dotted, solid, invis, bold
minlen=2
    seems to be similar in effect to 'rank=same' but some shortening of
    the arrows seems to happen; TODO experiment
weight=50
    integer cost of stretching an edge; the heavier the weight, the
    shorter, straighter and more vertical the edge is
arrowType = normal/none/dot/odot/empty/diamond/...
    # lots more; see http://www.graphviz.org/content/attrs#karrowType
</code></pre>

<p>node shapes:</p>

<pre><code>polygon based:

    ('rect', 'rectagle', 'box' are synonyms.  So are 'none' and 'plaintext')

    shape = ellipse         // or box, circle, doublecircle, plaintext
        // point -- reduces to minimum
        // [shape = polygon, sides=5]
        // [shape = box, style = rounded]
        // [shape = circle, width = 0.2, fixedsize = true, label = ""]

record based:

    record-based shapes are awesome!  Example:

        digraph structs {
            node [shape=record];
            struct1 [label="&lt;f0&gt; left|&lt;f1&gt; mid\ndle|&lt;f2&gt; right"];
            struct2 [label="&lt;f0&gt; one|&lt;f1&gt; two"];
            struct3 [label="hello\nworld |{ b |{c|&lt;here&gt; d|e}| f}| g | h"];
            struct1:f1 -&gt; struct2:f0;
            struct1:f2 -&gt; struct3:here;
        }

    'nshp' says use shape=none and an HTML-like label instead of a
    record-based shape.  However, while that is certainly more flexible,
    it is *much* more cumbersome!  And user-defined shapes are not really
    any use at all!

    TODO: do explore the html-like junk when something really complex
    turns up...
</code></pre>

<p>useless stuff</p>

<ul>
<li>'digraph' is commonly used.  'graph' seems useless, especially since you
can simulate that with dir=none</li>
</ul>

<p>tricks to constrain layout</p>

<pre><code>nodesep = 1.0           // (at graph level)
    // minimum space between two adjacent nodes in the same rank, in inches
A -&gt; B [weight=50]      // makes it straighter
C -&gt; D [minlen=2]       // pretend there're empty nodes in between

C -&gt; D [constraint=false]
    // the edge is not used in ranking nodes

{ rank=same; A; D; }
    // probably better than 'constraint=false', since you don't even need
    // an actual edge between A and D for this to work (think A-&gt;B-&gt;C-&gt;D
    // combined with this statement)

TODO: play with this/these
    Rank constraints on the nodes in a subgraph. If rank="same", all nodes
    are placed on the same rank. If rank="min", all nodes are placed on
    the minimum rank. If rank="source", all nodes are placed on the
    minimum rank, and the only nodes on the minimum rank belong to some
    subgraph whose rank attribute is "source" or "min". Analogous criteria
    hold for rank="max" and rank="sink". (Note: the minimum rank is
    topmost or leftmost, and the maximum rank is bottommost or rightmost.)
</code></pre>

<p>other tips</p>

<pre><code>// make 2 lines in one shot
A -&gt; { B; C }

joining or merging certain edge routes.  this is nicer/easier than the
method in the FAQ http://www.graphviz.org/doc/FAQ.html
    digraph G {
      yourvirtualnode [shape=point,width=.01,height=.01]
      a -&gt; yourvirtualnode [arrowhead=none]
      yourvirtualnode -&gt; {b;c}
    }
</code></pre>

<p>subgraphs</p>

<pre><code>`subgraph cluster0` etc -- pretty cool too; see examples in
git-notes/images.  A subgraph whose name starts with "cluster" has a
special meaning to dot.

'lang' says: If supported, the layout engine will do the layout so that
the nodes belonging to the cluster are drawn together, with the entire
drawing of the cluster contained within a bounding rectangle. Note that,
for good and bad, cluster subgraphs are not part of the DOT language, but
solely a syntactic convention adhered to by certain of the layout engines.

compound = true
    allow edges between clusters; use with lhead/ltail
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>ip command quickref</h1>

<p>FIXME: the source formatting is screwed up by having to fit inside
wiki_creole; markdown will make it simpler with a little effort</p>

<p><sup>from <a href="http://www.policyrouting.org/iproute2.doc.html">http://www.policyrouting.org/iproute2.doc.html</a></sup></p>

<h4>ip link</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>ip link [ show [ dev ] eth0 ]</code> <br />
<code>ip link [ show up ]</code></li>
<li><code>ip link set [ dev ] eth0</code> <br />
...<code>up | down</code> <br />
...<code>addr MAC-ADDR</code></li>
<li>if <code>qdisc</code> is listed as <code>noop</code> it is a blackhole</li>
<li><code>qlen</code> is TX queue length in packets</li>
</ul>

<h4>ip addr</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>ip addr add|delete|flush|[show|list]</code></li>
<li><code>ip addr add [local] 172.19.58.2/24 dev eth0</code> <br />
...<code>peer 1.2.3.4/16</code> <br />
...<code>label eth0:1</code>
<ul>
<li>you can add multiple addresses to the same interface; just run the
same commands with another address</li>
</ul></li>
<li>then there's also <code>scope global|site|link|host</code>
<ul>
<li><code>site</code> is for IPv6 only; valid only inside this site; <code>link</code>
valid only on this device</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>ip addr del [127.0.0.1/8] dev lo</code> if no argument given the first
address listed is deleted</li>
<li><code>ip addr [show|list|lst|sh|ls|l] [dev] eth0</code></li>
</ul>

<h4>ip neigh</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>ip neigh [ show | help ] [ nud all ]</code>
<ul>
<li>statistics <code>ip -s neigh show</code> gives you a "ref" (number of users of
the entry), and the number of seconds since the entry was last
used/confirmed/updated</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>ip neigh add 172.19.58.9 lladdr 00:0e:7f:3d:e6:a4 dev eth0</code>
<ul>
<li><code>nud perm</code> seems to be implied, <code>noarp</code> seems to act weird
(won't show up in <code>ip neigh show</code> unless you add <code>nud noarp</code> or
<code>nud all</code> to the command; see help for others.</li>
<li><code>perm</code> is like <code>noarp</code> except it cannot expire automatically</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>ip neigh flush</code></li>
</ul>

<h4>ip route</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>ip route show</code>
<ul>
<li><code>ip route list match 1.2.3.4</code> shows which route would be taken for
1.2.3.4
<strong>* <code>ip route get 1.2.3.4</code> is <em>*even better</strong>!</li>
<li>can subset by "dev", "via"
<em></em></em> <em>rare</em> also by "proto", "scope", "type" (unicast, local,
blackhole, etc.)</li>
<li>meanings of "proto" and "scope" in output of <code>ip route show</code>: look
for rt<em>protos and rt</em>scopes in
<a href="http://www.policyrouting.org/iproute2.doc.html">http://www.policyrouting.org/iproute2.doc.html</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>ip route [ add | del | chg | repl | etc ] to [ unicast ] 1.2.3.4/20 dev
eth0</code>
<ul>
<li>in place of <code>unicast</code> you can also have <code>local</code>,
<code>unreachable</code>, <code>blackhole</code> etc.; see help</li>
<li><code>via g.at.ew.ay</code>
<em><em></em> <em>rare</em> <code>add nat 10.1.1.1 via 203.1.1.1</code> may be useful
sometimes but until we know more we should stick to iptables natting!
For example this is one-to-one natting so the 203.x had better be a
free IP!</li>
<li><code>tos &lt;value&gt;</code>; values are:
<strong></em> 0x80 -- flash-override
<em></strong> 0x40 -- immediate
<strong></em> 0x20 -- priority
<em></strong> 0x10 -- lowdelay
<strong></em> 0x08 -- throughput
<em></strong> 0x04 -- reliability
<em></em></em> 0x02 -- mincost</li>
<li><code>metric | pref 10</code></li>
<li><code>scope &lt;scope val&gt;</code> see /etc/iproute2/rt_scopes</li>
<li><em>rare</em> <code>proto static</code> to protect manually-added route from being purged if a route daemon starts</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="Notes_on_my_Creole_format">Notes on my Creole format</a></h1>

<p><strong>OBSOLETE -- I no longer use creole.  Markdown is much better at DWIMming by
indentation</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Notes_on_my_Creole_format">Notes on my Creole format</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#My_extensions">My extensions</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Basic_Creole_as_implemented_by_Text_WikiCreole">Basic Creole as implemented by Text::WikiCreole</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#OFFICIAL_MARKUP">OFFICIAL MARKUP</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#EXTENDED_MARKUP">EXTENDED MARKUP</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="My_extensions">My extensions</a></h3>

<ul>
<li>a rudimentary TOC is created from the first 4 levels if you use
<code>[[TOC]]</code> on a line by itself.  You can change that to some other
depth by saying <code>[[TOC 3]]</code> for instance</li>
<li>explicit triple curlies (TCs) are created based on indentation.  Each
block of lines indented 8 or more spaces is one TCS block</li>
<li>explicit first-level blocks are created as needed: the first 4-space
indented line that is not inside a bullet list gets a ":" at the start
(see Creole syntax below for what that means)</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Basic_Creole_as_implemented_by_Text_WikiCreole">Basic Creole as implemented by Text::WikiCreole</a></h3>

<p>The following is culled straight from <code>perldoc Text::WikiCreole</code></p>

<h4><a name="OFFICIAL_MARKUP">OFFICIAL MARKUP</a></h4>

<pre><code>    Here is a summary of the official Creole 1.0 markup
    elements.  See &lt;http://www.wikicreole.org&gt; for the full
    details.

    Headings:
    = heading 1   -&gt;    &lt;h1&gt;heading 1&lt;/h1&gt;
    == heading 2      -&gt;    &lt;h2&gt;heading 2&lt;/h2&gt;
    ...
    ====== heading 6  -&gt;    &lt;h6&gt;heading 6&lt;/h6&gt;
</code></pre>

<h5>Various inline markup</h5>

<pre><code>    ** bold **    -&gt;    &lt;strong&gt; bold &lt;/strong&gt;
    * italics *   -&gt;    &lt;em&gt; italics &lt;/em&gt;
    *** both ***      -&gt;    &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt; both &lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;
    [[ link ]]    -&gt;    &lt;a href="link"&gt;link&lt;/a&gt;
    [text](link) -&gt; &lt;a href="link"&gt;text&lt;/a&gt;
    &lt;http://cpan.org&gt;     -&gt;    &lt;a href="http://cpan.org"&gt;http://cpan.org&lt;/a&gt;
    line \\ break     -&gt;    line &lt;br /&gt; break
    {{img.jpg|alt}}   -&gt;    &lt;img src="img.jpg" alt="alt"&gt;

    Lists:
    * unordered list    &lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;unordered list&lt;/li&gt;
    * second item           &lt;li&gt;second item&lt;/li&gt;
    ## nested ordered  -&gt;       &lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;nested ordered&lt;/li&gt;
    *** uber-nested         &lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;uber-nested&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;
    * back to level 1       &lt;/ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;back to level 1&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;

    Tables:
    |= h1 |= h2   -&gt;    &lt;table&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;th&gt;h1&lt;/th&gt;&lt;th&gt;h2&lt;/th&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;
    |  c1 |  c2     &lt;tr&gt;&lt;td&gt;c1&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;c2&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;

    Nowiki (Preformatted):
    {{{         &lt;pre&gt;
      ** not bold **      ** not bold **
      escaped HTML:   -&gt;      escaped HTML:
      &lt;i&gt; test &lt;/i&gt;       &amp;lt;i&amp;gt; test &amp;lt;/i&amp;gt;
    }}}         &lt;pre&gt;

    {{{ inline\\also }}} -&gt; &lt;tt&gt;inline\\also&lt;/tt&gt;

    Escape Character:
    ~** not bold **    -&gt;    ** not bold **
    tilde: ~~      -&gt;    tilde: ~

    Paragraphs are separated by other blocks and blank lines.
    Inline markup can usually be combined, overlapped, etc.  List
    items and plugin text can span lines.
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="EXTENDED_MARKUP">EXTENDED MARKUP</a></h4>

<pre><code>    In addition to OFFICIAL MARKUP, Text::WikiCreole also supports
    the following markup:

    Plugins:
    &lt;&lt; plugin &gt;&gt;        -&gt;    whatever you want (see creole_plugin above)
    &lt;&lt;&lt; plugin &gt;&gt;&gt;      -&gt;    whatever you want (see creole_plugin above)
        Triple-bracket syntax has priority, in order to allow you to embed
        double-brackets in plugins, such as to embed Perl code.

    Inline:
    ## monospace ##     -&gt;    &lt;tt&gt; monospace &lt;/tt&gt;
    ^^ superscript ^^   -&gt;    &lt;sup&gt; superscript &lt;/sup&gt;
    ,, subscript ,,     -&gt;    &lt;sub&gt; subscript &lt;/sub&gt;
    __ underline __     -&gt;    &lt;u&gt; underline &lt;/u&gt;
    (TM)            -&gt;    &amp;trade;
    (R)         -&gt;    &amp;reg;
    (C)         -&gt;    &amp;copy;
    ...         -&gt;    &amp;hellip;
    --          -&gt;    &amp;ndash;

    Indented Paragraphs:
    :this           -&gt;    &lt;div style="margin-left:2em"&gt;&lt;p&gt;this
    is indented       is indented&lt;/p&gt;
    :: more indented      &lt;div style="margin-left:2em"&gt;&lt;p&gt; more
                              indented&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

    Definition Lists:
    ; Title         -&gt;    &lt;dl&gt;&lt;dt&gt;Title&lt;/dt&gt;
    : item 1 : item 2     &lt;dd&gt;item 1&lt;/dd&gt;&lt;dd&gt;item 2&lt;/dd&gt;
    ; Title 2 : item2a    &lt;dt&gt;Title 2&lt;/dt&gt;&lt;dd&gt;item 2a&lt;/dd&gt;&lt;/dl&gt;
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>MASQ with iptables</h1>

<p>Assume:</p>

<pre><code>eth0 has xx.xx.xx.xx as your WAN IP
eth1 has yy.yy.yy.yy as your LAN IP
</code></pre>

<p>Then, this is how you MASQ</p>

<pre><code># Delete and flush. Default table is "filter". Others like "nat" must be explicitly stated.
iptables --flush
iptables --table nat --flush

# Delete all chains that are not in default filter and nat table
iptables --delete-chain
iptables --table nat --delete-chain

# Set up IP FORWARDing and Masquerading
iptables --table nat -A POSTROUTING --out-interface eth0 -j MASQUERADE
iptables -A FORWARD --in-interface eth1 -j ACCEPT

# Enables packet forwarding by kernel 
echo 1 &gt; /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward
</code></pre>

<p><sup>Source: <a href="http://www.howtoforge.com/nat_iptables">http://www.howtoforge.com/nat_iptables</a> (article has misleading
title: it's actually masq, not NAT)</sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Scratched CDs?</h1>

<p><sup>from <a href="http://www.om3ga.co.uk/2006/07/27/scratched-cds-no-problem">http://www.om3ga.co.uk/2006/07/27/scratched-cds-no-problem</a></sup></p>

<p>"<em>To apply the toothpaste take the tiniest bit on the tip of your finger,
and without touching the CD with your finger its self, apply the
toothpaste to only the scratched area (and just around it). Now put it
under the tap and dribble water on it, so that the toothpaste goes sort of
mushy. Now tilt the CD over a sink very gently so that the water runs off,
but the toothpaste stays. Now, like all the other methods, rub it in with
a lint free cloth, but this time you really need to go to town, as you are
actually trying to round off the scratches.</em>"</p>

<p>[well that didn't work...]</p>

<p>"<em>Yes, hair gel, and guess what? It worked!</em></p>

<p><em>I applied it in much the same way as the toothpaste, except I didn't
dribble water on it. I rubbed it first. Even though I applied it to one
area, it ended up evenly spread around the whole disc. I then dribbled
water on to loosen it up so I could rub the excess off.</em>"</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="deep_stuff">deep stuff</a></h1>

<blockquote>
  <p><sup><strong>Caveat</strong> I am not sure how all this works when the filenames have
    spaces in them.  In an ideal world, people who put spaces in filenames
    would be shot, but this isn't an ideal world.</sup></p>
</blockquote>

<p>The <code>hashdeep</code> program is part of the badly-named <code>md5deep</code> suite.  <code>ssdeep</code>
is similar, but uses fuzzy matching to find similar files, using an algorithm
that is a "second cousin twice removed" of the magic that drives rsync.</p>

<p><code>dcfldd</code> is in a completely different domain (it's more like a "superdd"), but
I've lumped it in here because of the Kornblum connection.</p>

<hr />

<p>This document has the following sections</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#deep_stuff">deep stuff</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Comparing_two_directories">Comparing two directories</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Finding_duplicates_and_similar_files">Finding duplicates and similar files</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#hashdeep_details">hashdeep details</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#dcfldd_details">dcfldd details</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="Comparing_two_directories">Comparing two directories</a></h3>

<p>There are 2 ways of doing this.</p>

<p>If you don't have to pre-compute both sets of hashes (that is, you can
efficiently access one directory "live"), you should do the following:</p>

<pre><code>cd old
hashdeep -elr . &gt; /tmp/dir.hdout
cd new
hashdeep -k /tmp/dir.hdout -elr . -avv
# for extra speed, use "-c md5" on both commands above
# note that hashdeep has a problem with filenames containing commas
</code></pre>

<p>The output is interpreted like so:</p>

<pre><code>newfile: Moved from oldfile (easy)
newfile: No match (no eqvt in old)
oldfile: Known file not used (no eqvt in new)
</code></pre>

<p>If you have to pre-compute both of them, (like they are not "local" to the
node on which your software is running) you can do a "content match" like
this:</p>

<pre><code>cd old
md5deep -elr . |sort &gt; /tmp/old.mdout
cd new
md5deep -elr . |sort &gt; /tmp/new.mdout
cd /tmp
# see files extra in old
join -v1 old.mdout new.mdout
# see files extra in new
join -v2 old.mdout new.mdout
</code></pre>

<p>You can use the '-o' syntax of join to suppress printing the hash itself,
or various other combinations of the left and the right side.  This can
help you detect renames and moves, although you may have to do some
post-processing of lines containing two files names in order to do so.</p>

<h3><a name="Finding_duplicates_and_similar_files">Finding duplicates and similar files</a></h3>

<p>Fastest way to find <strong>exact</strong> duplicates:</p>

<pre><code>md5deep -elr -of . dir1 ... | sort | uniq -w32 --all-repeated=separate
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>-of</code> to md5deep is to prevent symlinks from showing up, otherwise you'll
<strong><em>lose data!!</em></strong> You can use <code>-D</code> instead of <code>--all-repeated=separate</code> for
automated processing.</p>

<p>To find <strong>similar</strong> files, <code>ssdeep</code> is a pretty cool program, and
works great for all but the smallest files (though I haven't really tested
it with GB-size files).  Though it takes over 8 times more CPU than MD5,
and doesn't have a good progress indicator, it's useful because it's
unique -- I'm not aware of any other program that even attempts to do this
sort of matching.</p>

<p>To find similar files within on one or more local directories:</p>

<pre><code>ssdeep -vlr -d dir1 [dir2 ...]
</code></pre>

<p>When all the directories aren't local to the same machine:</p>

<pre><code>ssdeep -vlr dir1 &gt; dir1.ssdeepout
# now copy that file from machine 1 to machine 2
ssdeep -m dir1.ssdeepout -vlr -d dir2
</code></pre>

<p>There's a subtle difference between these two methods though.  The stuff
coming from the <code>-m</code> argument is only a reference, so those names will
never appear on the left side of the "dir1/file1 matched dir2/file2..."
output.  In the first method, dir1 and dir2 can both appear on the left
side.</p>

<p><strong>WARNING</strong>: ssdeep isn't a good way to find exact duplicates -- it's not only
slow, it misses really small (and maybe really large also?) files.  <em>Use it
only for finding approximate matches.</em></p>

<h3><a name="hashdeep_details">hashdeep details</a></h3>

<p>Hashdeep's <em>audit</em> mode is what you used above, and the <code>-k</code> refers
to a file containing "k"nown hashes.  The <code>-vv</code> is required to see the
right amount of detail on what files mismatched etc.</p>

<p>Apart from audit mode, you can also do the following when you specify <code>-k
known-list</code>:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>-m</code>: positive match -- list each file in the argument list that matches
some file in the known list.  You can add <code>-w</code> to see both the filenames</li>
<li><code>-x</code>: negative match -- list files in arglist that did not match anything
in the known list</li>
</ul>

<p>If you're in a hurry (and your accuracy needs aren't forensic-level), use
<code>-c md5</code>; the default does both md5 and sha1, which takes about 4-5
times longer.</p>

<h3><a name="dcfldd_details">dcfldd details</a></h3>

<p>This is an awesome command.  For most purposes the old <code>dd</code> command is
as good, but here's what makes dcfldd a real life-saver:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>multiple outputs (ever felt handicapped by what <code>tee</code> can do?) including
executable programs!</p>

<pre><code>dcfldd of=a of=b of:='md5sum &gt;c' of:='sha1sum &gt;d'
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>better progress indicator (<code>status=on</code>)</p></li>
<li>file splitting like <code>split</code></li>
<li>partial hashing (example, <code>hashwindow=2M</code>)</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>GNU ddrescue or dd_rescue</h1>

<h3>Tips</h3>

<ul>
<li>always use a logfile; it helps you make multiple runs optimally</li>
<li>on subsequent runs, use <code>-r</code></li>
<li><p>Really bad media: be sure to make the first run <code>-r 1 -n</code> then later
perhaps <code>-r 3</code>!</p></li>
<li><p><strong>cool feature</strong>: you can use multiple copies of a backup, with the same
logfile across all sessions, to merge the good parts of each and get a
whole good copy!  Very useful for CD-based backups of really important
stuff.</p></li>
</ul>

<h3>Some flags</h3>

<ul>
<li><p>to retry error areas detected on a previous run of ddrescue, you must give</p>

<pre><code>-r 3    # or some non-zero value
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>for CD-ROMs, you must give</p>

<pre><code>-b 2048
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>to stop after copying so much data</p>

<pre><code>-s
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>do not try to split error areas into smaller ones</p>

<pre><code>-n
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3>Extra stuff</h3>

<ul>
<li><p>raw devices may be useful in some cases; see info for more, but the summary is:</p>

<pre><code>ddrescue -n /dev/hdb /dev/hdc logfile
raw /dev/raw/raw1 /dev/hdb
ddrescue -r3 -C /dev/raw/raw1 /dev/hdc logfile
raw /dev/raw/raw1 0 0
e2fsck -v -f /dev/hdc
mount -t ext2 -o ro /dev/hdc /mnt
</code></pre></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>starting a program from xinetd</h1>

<p>The <code>wait = no</code> is important.  Most of the other gotchas can be found
by checking syslog after <code>service xinetd start</code>, but this one needs
some serious RTFM :-)</p>

<p>The program being called is just a filter -- take some input, return some
output!</p>

<pre><code>service dss
{
    id = dss
    type = UNLISTED
    flags = NODELAY NORETRY
    disable = no
    socket_type = stream
    protocol = tcp
    wait = no
    instances = 1
    server = /tmp/dss
    port = 8421
    user = sitaram
}
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Encrypting swap</h1>

<p>from <a href="http://loop-aes.sourceforge.net/loop-AES.README">http://loop-aes.sourceforge.net/loop-AES.README</a></p>

<pre><code>swapoff -a

# change the fstab line to something like:
/dev/hda666 none swap sw,loop=/dev/loop6,encryption=AES128 0 0
# [I ignored the "sw," and it still worked... sita]

dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/hda666 bs=64k conv=notrunc # paranoid
mkswap /dev/hda666

swapon -a

rm -rf /var/log/ksymoops
# avoid some errors at boot time; see source URL
</code></pre>

<p>Running <code>swapon -a</code> will set up loop devices using random keys, run
mkswap on them, and enable encrypted swap on specified loop devices.</p>

<p><strong>Note</strong>: If you are using encrypted swap and you wish to upgrade your
kernel, you may need to use a matching loop.o.  Please see source URL.</p>

<h3>other examples in the source URL:</h3>

<pre><code>7.2. Example 2 - Partition backed loop with gpg encrypted key file
7.3. Example 3 - Encrypted partition that multiple users can mount
7.4. Example 4 - Encrypting /tmp partition with random keys
7.5. Example 5 - Encrypting root partition
7.6. Example 6 - Boot from CD-ROM + encrypted root partition
7.7. Example 7 - Boot from USB-stick + encrypted root partition
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>mutt</h1>

<p><a href="http://applications.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/11/30/1227239&amp;tid=37&amp;tid=85&amp;tid=70&amp;pagenum=1">http://applications.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/11/30/1227239&amp;tid=37&amp;tid=85&amp;tid=70&amp;pagenum=1</a>
contains lots of tips on mutt, but the "must have" ones are:</p>

<pre><code>local mailbox
    set spoolfile=/path/to/spool
pop3 mailbox
    set pop_user = "username"
    set pop_delete = no
    set pop_pass = "password" # best not to put it in muttrc
    set pop_host = "pop.myserver.com" # default is pop3 on port 110
(or)
    set pop_host = "pops://pop.gmail.com:995"  # note the popS
imap mailbox
    set spoolfile=imaps://imap.server.com/INBOX
    set imap_user=username
    set imap_pass=password # see above
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>all sorts of stuff</h1>

<p>These tips are too small to have their own files.  They are in approximately
reverse chron order.</p>

<ul>
<li><p>type /msg nickserv register <your-password> <your-email> in irssi to
register the nickname</p></li>
<li><p>mounting a samba share with spaces in the name.  (Please be kind to the
environment and shoot the bastard who used spaces in directory names after
you've gotten his files off his fscking share)</p>

<pre><code># cat &gt; /root/.smbcredentials
username=India\129633
password=whatever
# cat &gt;&gt; /etc/fstab
//1.2.3.4/Shyam\040-\040Laptop\040Backup    /tmp/shyam        cifs    credentials=/root/.smbcredentials,iocharset=utf8,file_mode=0777,dir_mode=0777 0 0
# mount /tmp/shyam
</code></pre>

<p>and then later, this also worked:</p>

<pre><code>mount -t cifs "//1.2.3.4/Shyam - Laptop Backup" /tmp/shyam -o ip=1.2.3.4,noperm,uid=500,user=India\\327367,password=Deepu~Guru2610
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>flushing the disk cache</p>

<pre><code>sync
echo 3 &gt; /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>changing the scheduler</p>

<pre><code>echo cfq &gt; /sys/block/sdb/queue/scheduler
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>oooh nice one for tattoo talk!  Note: remote is 1440x900, local is
smaller, so must chop (chopping top left here)</p>

<pre><code>ssh deskr \
    ffmpeg -f x11grab -r 1 \
    -s 1280x800 -i :0.0+160,100 \
    -an -f avi -y - |
ffplay -f m4v -
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>ssh-agent stuff</p>

<p>when SSH<em>AGENT</em>PID is not set, the standard file (<code>id_rsa</code>) works fine.  A
non-standard id file needs either the <code>-i</code> parameter to ssh, or a host
para in <code>~/.ssh/config</code>.</p>

<p>if "ssh-add -l" shows some key(s), then only those keys will be used;
everything else will be ignored</p>

<p>if you use passphrases for all your keys, you will use the agent anyway,
so it all works</p></li>
<li><p>converting something to 3gpp, to play on a mobile phone; this seems to be
a good set of parameters, but if you really care, test various
combinations.  The audio is tricky -- most websites will tell you mp3 or
faac, but <code>ffmpeg -formats | grep E.*aac</code> will tell you what library you
actually have; in plf systems it's libfaac, not just faac</p>

<pre><code>ffmpeg -i $1 -s 176x144 -vcodec h263 -r 25 -b 96k -ab 64 -acodec libfaac -ac 1 -ar 44100 $1.3gp
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>highlighting STDERR</p>

<ul>
<li><p>first, create a file that looks like this.  Call it "red" and put it in
the path</p>

<pre><code>#!/bin/bash

while read line
do
    echo -e '\e[91m'$line'\e[0m'
done
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>when running a program that produces mixed STDOUT and STDERR, do this</p>

<pre><code>pgm opts 2&gt; &gt;(red) [...]
</code></pre>

<p>where the ellipses represent whatever else you would have done with
pgm's STDOUT normally, if any</p></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>optimising ext4 -- mostly from
<a href="http://www.linux-mag.com/id/7272/2/">tytso</a></p>

<p>normal optimisations:</p>

<ul>
<li>mount with <code>noatime</code></li>
<li>if you can, make a fresh ext4 image rather than just convert from ext3</li>
</ul>

<p>"my machine is quite reliable, thank you!"</p>

<ul>
<li>mount with <code>commit=600</code> (my laptop running MDV seemed to acquire this by
default, and you can pick some other value for a desktop if you like)</li>
</ul>

<p>"reliability?  who cares!"</p>

<ul>
<li>disable journal (<code>noload</code>??)</li>
<li>mount with <code>barrier=0</code></li>
</ul>

<p>"security?  I've got nothing to hide...!"</p>

<ul>
<li><code>data=writeback</code>; you can make this the default using <code>tune2fs</code>, which
is actually the only way to set this for the root filesystem</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>using virtual hosts in lighttpd
(<a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/aix/library/au-spunix_greattools/index.html">source</a>)</p>

<pre><code>$HTTP["host"] == "www2.example.org" {
  server.document-root = "/var/www/lighttpd/host2
}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>recording from a builtin mic:</p>

<pre><code>rec -t aiff - | lame - out.mp3
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>ogg2mp3 puts out static?  Try the following command (the 44.1 in the "-s"
option to lame comes from checking the "Rate:" reported by ogginfo):</p>

<pre><code>oggdec &lt; file.ogg -b 16 -e 0 -R -s 1 -o - - |
    lame -r -s 44.1 --bitwidth 16 --signed --little-endian - - &gt; file.mp3
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>permissions problems on smbmount?  try <code>noperm</code></p>

<pre><code>mount *1.2.4.8/share /mp -o uid=500,noperm
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>wifi used to work fine but suddenly does not?  Check if wpa_cli status
shows everything is OK, and your real problem is a DHCPNAK followed by the
interface going down.  In that case,</p>

<ul>
<li>try deleting all the stale dhcp leases (look for files names something
like /var/lib/dh<em>/</em>lease*)</li>
<li>if that doesn't work, and if <code>lsmod | grep mac80211</code> is true, then try
removing the word "down" from all <code>ifconfig</code> lines in
<code>/sbin/dhclient-script</code>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.ces.clemson.edu/linux/f7_setup.shtml">http://www.ces.clemson.edu/linux/f7_setup.shtml</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.intellinuxwireless.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=1468#c12">http://www.intellinuxwireless.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=1468#c12</a></li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>suspend to disk (s2disk) on mdv 2009</p>

<ul>
<li>created a new file called <code>pm-fallback-hibernate</code> in
<code>/etc/acpi/actions</code>, modelled after existing <code>pm-fallback-suspend</code></li>
<li><code>s/shutdown/hibernate/</code> in <code>/etc/acpi/events/power</code></li>
<li><p>I don't remember what the default values were, but change them to these
in <code>/etc/sysconfig/powersave/events</code></p>

<pre><code>EVENT_BUTTON_POWER="suspend_to_disk"
EVENT_BUTTON_SLEEP="suspend_to_disk"
EVENT_BUTTON_LID_OPEN="ignore"
EVENT_BUTTON_LID_CLOSED="suspend_to_ram"
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>kde4's kpowersave is crap; don't rely on it, not even to run the
screensaver -- test it or do it manually before hitting the power
button or closing the lid!</p></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>quick tip for postfix in "relay" mode; add something like this to
<code>/etc/postfix/main.cf</code></p>

<pre><code>myhostname = sitaram.atc.tcs.com
mydestination = $myhostname, localhost.$mydomain
