mydomain = atc.tcs.com
relayhost = 172.25.149.2
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>manual mirror selection for MDV 2009:</p>

<pre><code>GET &lt;http://api.mandriva.com/mirrors/basic.2009.0.i586.list&gt; | egrep -i -o http.*586
# pick one of them, say klid.dk, and
urpmi.addmedia --distrib --mirrorlist &lt;http://klid.dk/ftp/mandriva/official/2009.0/i586&gt;
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>mkdosfs on the RCA emusic mp3 player requires "-S 2048"</p></li>
<li>man pages and col -b
<ul>
<li>append <code>-c</code> to the line <code>NROFF /usr/bin/nroff -Tutf8 -mandoc</code> in
<code>/etc/man.config</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li>midnight commander looks ugly on konsole
<ul>
<li><em>either</em> use mc's <code>-a</code> argument,</li>
<li><em>or</em> unset <code>LANG</code> and <code>LC_CTYPE</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li>for palm sync: add <code>modprobe visor vendor=0x54c product=0x66</code> to <code>/etc/rc.modules</code></li>
<li><p>using sshfs</p>

<ul>
<li>RPMs needed: <code>libfuse</code>, <code>fuse</code>, <code>sshfs-fuse</code></li>
<li>setup needed: <code>mknod -m 666 /dev/fuse c 10 229</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Manually controlled, absolutely low-level, internet access through various
modems; see <code>usbmodem.sh</code></p></li>
<li><p>plug-and-play: see ../code/<em>.rules and ../code/wvdial.</em>.conf</p>

<ul>
<li>if it doesn't work, try ttyUSB0 instead of ttyACM0 (below) before
digging deeper!  If that also doesn't work try running <code>modprobe
usbserial vendor=0x1b7d product=0x070a</code> (or similar) first</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>to strip out the VirtualBox stuff from IE screenshots to send to morons
like Tata Indicom:</p>

<pre><code>mkdir t; map "convert __F__ -crop 1026x769+0+29 t/__F__"
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>lots of tips on killing the annoying, loud, PC speaker beeps, from
<a href="http://fixunix.com/debian/532303-pc-speaker-cannot-disabled.html">http://fixunix.com/debian/532303-pc-speaker-cannot-disabled.html</a> and
elsewhere</p>

<ul>
<li><code>rmmod pcspkr</code> and/or blacklist it in some file in /etc/modules.d.  Also
try <code>rmmod snd-pcsp</code> and blacklisting that too</li>
<li>check if <code>cat /proc/asound/cards</code> lists it as a card (it apparently
starts doing that when it finds pcspkr blacklisted!); if so, disable it
using <code>alsamixer -c&lt;card number listed in above output&gt;</code> (M to mute)</li>
<li><code>setterm -bfreq 0</code> prevents bell sound at console, and <code>xset b off</code> does
the same in X</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p><code>mkinitrd</code> within a chroot environment requires that proc and sys also be
mounted, otherwise it doesn't do all the right things.  You'll need to do
something like this first (and make sure you umount/Ctrl-D in the reverse
order when done!)</p>

<pre><code>mkdir j; mount ... j
mount -t proc proc j/proc
mount -t sysfs sys j/sys
chroot $PWD/j
mount /boot     # if /boot was on its own partition
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>the <code>mkinitrd</code> itself needs to be checked carefully to make sure it is
picking up the right modules; use <code>-v</code>.  For example, it takes the root
fstype from <code>/etc/fstab</code> so keep that in mind if you're upgrading from
ext3 to ext4!</p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Installing and mounting using EncFS</h1>

<p><strong>Using encrypted filesystems is RISKY. Your filesystem becomes even more fragile than before. TAKE REGULAR BACKUPS!</strong></p>

<h3>How does EncFS work?</h3>

<p>EncFS works on files and directories, not an entire block device. This means
that it does not encrypt your hard drive. It modifies file names and contents.
The data is stored on the underlying filesystem and metadata is preserved.
File attributes such as ownership, modification date and permission bits are
not encrypted.</p>

<h3>What are EncFS's benefits?</h3>

<ul>
<li>easy to use; requires no special setup</li>
<li>makes it easy to perform backups while not mounted. You can use 'rsync' or
any other tool that you would use on an ext3 filesystem</li>
<li>can be used with secondary passwords.  <strong>USE WITH CARE</strong></li>
<li>option to read passwords from an external program or stdin (standard
input) for flexible custom scripting</li>
<li>FUSE based filesystems are visible only to the user who mounted them; not
even root can see them!</li>
</ul>

<h3>Installing EncFS</h3>

<p>urpmi got the following files when I installed it:</p>

<pre><code>kernel-source-stripped-2.6.17.5mdv-1-1mdv2007.0.i586.rpm
kernel-2.6.17.5mdv-1-1mdv2007.0.i586.rpm
dkms-2.0.13-3mdv2007.0.noarch.rpm
dkms-fuse-2.5.3-3mdk.i586.rpm
libencfs1-1.3.1-1mdv2007.0.i586.rpm
librlog1-1.3.7-2mdv2007.0.i586.rpm
encfs-1.3.1-1mdv2007.0.i586.rpm
</code></pre>

<p>Load the FUSE module</p>

<pre><code>/sbin/modprobe fuse
</code></pre>

<p>(this was not needed on Mandriva)</p>

<pre><code>usermod -Gfuse sitaram
</code></pre>

<h3>Using EncFS</h3>

<p>:<strong>WARNING</strong>: Use only absolute path names with EncFS!</p>

<p>Create working directories:</p>

<pre><code>mkdir -p ~/encrypted ~/plain
</code></pre>

<p>Now you can mount the new EncFS volume for the first time. This assumes a
default configuration:</p>

<pre><code>encfs /home/sitaram/encrypted /home/sitaram/plain
</code></pre>

<p>(Go with the defaults for now and remember the password well!  The
password can be changed later using encfsctl)</p>

<p>Now start using <code>~/plain</code> normally.  Check what's in <code>encrypted/</code>:</p>

<pre><code>ls -al ~/encrypted/
drwxr-xr-x 2 jdoe jdoe 4096 2007-05-15 20:26 .
drwxr-xr-x 4 jdoe jdoe 4096 2007-05-15 20:25 ..
-rw-r--r-- 1 jdoe jdoe   22 2007-05-15 20:26 2JkbGxSVzUCZoj9ggUxT9Sou
-rw-r----- 1 jdoe jdoe  224 2007-05-15 20:25 .encfs5
</code></pre>

<p><strong>WARNING</strong>: <code>.encfs5</code> is a special file. When performing backups or
restoring data, make sure to keep this file. If you lose it, you will not
be able to recover your data.</p>

<p><strong>NOTE</strong>: Meta information is not encrypted. Permissions, ownership, and
modification date are the same.</p>

<h3>TIPS</h3>

<ul>
<li>For the primary password, choose a strong password containing lowercase
and capital letters, numbers, and punctuation marks. Make it easy to
remember but hard to guess. Do not use your dog's name, date of birth, or
phone number.</li>
<li>It may be hard to detect that you use two passwords because encrypted
files are stored in the same folder. If you have a large number of files
encrypted with your primary password and only a few files encrypted with
the secondary one, it is very likely that your secondary files may go
unnoticed.</li>
<li>Using multiple passwords may be very frustrating for somebody examining
your system. They will probably give up. Keep in mind that using multiple
passwords is not easy and you may forget them. Keep in mind that the
chances of restoring your data if this happens are almost zero.</li>
</ul>

<p><sup>Source: <a href="http://www.redhatmagazine.com/2007/06/13/dual-password-encryption-with-encfs/">http://www.redhatmagazine.com/2007/06/13/dual-password-encryption-with-encfs/</a></sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>ths screen program</h1>

<p>You know, this was probably the very <strong>first</strong> open source program I ever used
in my life!  We had these horribly long compiles (MF COBOL with an Oracle
pre-compiler stage that seemed to bloat the COBOL <em>source</em> by about a
hundred times!), and our network was very flaky.  Without putting "<code>screen
-DR</code>" at the bottom of each of our "<code>.profile</code>" files we would never
have managed.</p>

<p>But this program can do so much more, like replace kibitz!</p>

<pre><code>screen -S foo   # on your friend's terminal
screen -x foo   # on your terminal
</code></pre>

<p>This requires both of you to log in as the same user, so you may want to
create a dummy one for that purpose, and then move to the real environment.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Ubuntu</h1>

<h3>Ubuntu -- user/group mappings to capabilities</h3>

<p>users and groups --> user privileges mapping to groups</p>

<pre><code>plugdev     : access external storage devices automatically
admin       : administer the system
fuse        : allow use of fuse file systems like...
dip         : connect to internet using a modem
adm         : monitor system logs
fax         : send and recieve faxes
audio       : use audio devices
cdrom       : use CD-ROM drives
floppy      : use floppy drives
dialout     : use modems
scanner     : use scanners
tape        : use tape drives
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>recoll</h1>

<h4>searching</h4>

<ul>
<li>in simple search, wildcards are <code>*</code>, <code>?</code>, and <code>[]</code>
<ul>
<li>wildcards not anchored at the start are slooooooow!</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Initial Caps will disable stem expansion</li>
<li>"words inside phrases" are not stem expanded</li>
<li>double-click on any word adds it to the search bar</li>
<li>advanced search
<ul>
<li>can be restricted to a doctype, subtree, etc.</li>
<li>"this phrase" and "terms in proximity" are very useful</li>
<li><strong>be sure to use caps</strong> to disable stemming when using "terms in
proximity", otherwise the resulting query gets too long and complex.
Not that it really matters most of the time; it's still quite fast!</li>
</ul></li>
<li><strong>term explorer</strong> is very useful when you don't even know what you're
searching for!</li>
</ul>

<h4>browse results</h4>

<ul>
<li><strong>right-click to open parent email when result found in an attachment!</strong></li>
<li>you can browse successive results in a single preview window by typing
Shift+ArrowUp/Down in the window</li>
<li>close a preview tab by Ctrl-W</li>
<li>search <strong>inside</strong> a preview tab by <code>/</code> and <code>F3</code></li>
<li>shift+preview opens a new preview window instead of a new tab in an
existing preview window</li>
</ul>

<h4>query language</h4>

<ul>
<li>fields
<ul>
<li>title <code>==</code> subject <code>==</code> caption; meaning based on context</li>
<li>from <code>==</code> author</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>OR</code> must be in caps</li>
<li>prefix <code>-</code> to negate</li>
<li><strong>OR has precedence over AND!!!</strong></li>
<li><strong>no parens supported</strong></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>rsync, lftp, aria2, curl, wget, mc -- when to use what</h1>

<p>Note: 'simultaneous' means multiple, different, URLs, 'segmented' means
multiple connections opened to the same URL (hammers the server),
'distributed' means multiple connections opened to different (mirror) URLs
hosting the same file (like metalink)</p>

<pre><code>                                rsync   mc      lftp    curl    aria2   wget

    simultaneous downloads                      y               y (*)
    segmented downloads                         y               y (*)
    distributed downloads                                       y
    metalink                                                    y

    sftp using ssh-agent        y       y       Y
    http, ftp                                   y       y       y       y
    metalink, bittorrent                                        y

    interactive/batch           b       i       i       b       b       b
    mirroring                                   y                       y
    recursion (web)                                                     y
    job control etc                             Y
    lists/sequences                             y (*)   y       y (*)
    cookies, forms, etc                                 y
</code></pre>

<p>Notes:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>rsync is very efficient for changed files</p></li>
<li><p>lftp is the overall best tool</p>

<ul>
<li>has better completion than mc</li>
<li>goes to <code>$HOME</code> of the remote user instead of <code>/</code></li>
<li>can start downloads and continue to explore, or exit while they're all
running!</li>
<li>can do lists and sequences neatly; see my .lftprc for a very cool alias
that does the job except numbers don't 0-pad</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>aria2</p>

<ul>
<li>does segmented downloads <strong>by default</strong>!</li>
<li>needs the <code>-Z</code> option to do simultaneous downloads</li>
<li>does not seem to follow redirects</li>
<li>can do lists and sequences (it doesn't have placeholders for output
names like curl does, but that's OK)</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>only <code>wget</code> does <em>recursion</em> of a website</p>

<ul>
<li><p>common usage is:</p>

<pre><code>wget -c -w 5 --random-wait -r -l 0 -k -np
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>you can use, e.g., '-l 2 -p' to limit to 2 levels but get all the
prerequisites of the pages obtained</p></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>curl is left with pretty much nothing but forms and cookies now!</p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Upside-Down-Ternet</h1>

<p><sup>from <a href="http://www.ex-parrot.com/peter/upside-down-ternet.html">http://www.ex-parrot.com/peter/upside-down-ternet.html</a></sup></p>

<p>squid redirector script</p>

<p>some other options from
<a href="http://www.enterprisenetworkingplanet.com/netsecur/article.php/3653006">http://www.enterprisenetworkingplanet.com/netsecur/article.php/3653006</a>
(which sets up squid as a transparent proxy and also, weirdly, tells you
exactly what you should look for on the kismet pages to get your wifi
cracking sessions started!)</p>

<pre><code>"/usr/bin/mogrify", "-swirl 30"
"/usr/bin/mogrify", "-charcoal 10"
"/usr/bin/mogrify", "-paint 10"
</code></pre>

<p>but they take up too much CPU time.  Here are my choices (sorted by CPU time taken for an 800x600 image):</p>

<p>TODO: make WikiCreole give us some table borders</p>

<pre><code>        seconds     mogrify option      optional argument       

        0.17        flip        
        0.18        negate      
        0.19        solarize        10      
        0.22        transpose       
        0.22        transverse      
        0.29        spread              4       
        0.32        shade               45      
        1.24        swirl               30      
        1.56        monochrome      
        1.59        implode             4       
        1.80        shear               10x10       
        2.38        edge                4       
        2.59        rotate              15      
        4.10        paint               4
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>beamer</h1>

<h2>what theme to use</h2>

<p>S = section, SS = subsection, nav = navigation, authinfo = cool stuff at the
bottom of the slide, ooo = mini-bullets for navigation (very, very, cool!)</p>

<p>The default properties are shown below, but keep in mind that I have made
changes that (1) eliminate the stupid navigational symbols, and (2) insert
authinfo regardless.</p>

<p>This makes Darmstadt the best for logo-needing shows (like for $DAYJOB), and
Hannover the best for personal stuff.</p>

<p>Warsaw is very impressive, but useful only when there are 4 or less sections
(and subsections in each section), <em>and</em> none of the slides are really packed.</p>

<pre><code>(+) space, (-) no beamer specials
        default/boxes is POP (plain old PPT)
        Pittsburgh = POP, with slide title right-justified

(+) space, (+) authinfo, (-) no S/SS, (-) no nav
        Madrid

(+) full S/SS text nav (-) less horizontal space (-) no logo
        Hannover is LHS, light blue
        Goettingen is RHS, light blue
        Marburg is RHS, dark blue

(+) S/SS text, (+) cool 1-row ooo nav, (-) no authinfo
        Frankfurt shows only S, not SS
        Darmstadt adds one line for current SS also

(+) S text, (+) multi-row ooo nav, (-) no SS text, (-) no authinfo
        Singapore

(+) authinfo, (+) S|SS text (-) no nav
        AnnArbor is yellow
        CambridgeUS is maroon

(+) S|SS nav, (+/-) some authinfo, (-) no ooo so takes space
        Warsaw
        the authinfo is not as cool as AnnArbor etc
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Ajax security notes</h1>

<p>non ajax model</p>

<ul>
<li>calls to server are coarse: a whole bunch of info gets sent in one large
"form" and a whole page comes back fully assembled</li>
</ul>

<p>ajax model</p>

<ul>
<li><p>calls to server are much more granular; queries and responses more
numerous and correspondingly smaller</p></li>
<li><p>lot of logic gets done in browser; final page assembled in browser, for
all preactical purposes</p>

<p>So Ajax ends up with a lot more functions in the API exposed, a lot more
entry points into the backend, if you will.</p>

<p>Stuff which typically gets done once per request (authentication,
authorisation, input validation/sanitisation) must still get done once per
request, except it may now have to be done by much lower level functions
in the API than by something at a higher level.</p>

<p>Both these issues are much more likely to be present if you blindly
ajaxify a traditional website, although they can also happen to a freshly
designed ajax site if you're careless enough!</p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Compare directory metadata without storing the full archive!</h1>

<pre><code>Record the state of a directory:

        dar -c - -G startstate -R /home/sitaram &gt;/dev/null

later:

        dar -c - -G newstate -A startstate -R /home/sitaram &gt;/dev/null
        dar -as -l newstate

will give you what changed between then and now!
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>gimp photo blending modes</h1>

<ul>
<li><strong>Dissolve</strong>: allow a % of BG to show through the FG.  Random parts of FG
are made partially transparent and the rest fully transparent.  FG must
have an alpha channel &lt; 255, or it doesn't work</li>
<li><strong>Addition</strong>: min(F+B, W)</li>
<li><strong>Subtraction</strong>: max(B-F, 0) -- this is <em>not</em> symmetrical</li>
<li><strong>Difference</strong>: |B-F| -- this <em>is</em> symmetrical; same as |F-B|</li>
<li><strong>Multiply</strong>: F*B/255 -- always darker than both F and B</li>
<li><strong>Divide</strong>: nominally the reverse of Multiply (i.e., B*255/F), but
actually B*256/(F+1) to avoid div-by-0</li>
<li><strong>Screen</strong>: lightens exactly like Multiply darkens; same formula, but uses
(255,255,255) as the origin instead of (0,0,0).  Always lighter than both
F and B.  Actual formula is W - (W-F)*(W-B)/255</li>
<li><strong>Overlay</strong>: combination of Multiply and Screen.  (B*S + (1-B)*M)/255,
where M and S are the results from the Multiply and Screen formulae.  The
mix is controlled by BG: if BG is dark, M dominates, else S dominates.
Overall, it tends to make an image darker where BG is already dark and
lighter where BG is already light.</li>
<li><strong>Hue</strong>: Take H from FG, and S and V from BG</li>
<li><strong>Saturation, Value</strong>: analogous to above</li>
<li><strong>Color</strong>: take H and S from FG, and 'lightness' from BG.  (Lightness is a
bit less bright than value and closer to perceived brightness.)</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="Knoppix_and_USB">Knoppix and USB</a></h1>

<p>This helps you get a portable Linux environment to take with you wherever you
go:
  * a USB stick that boots into Knoppix
  * your choice of software on the stick, apart from what came with the
    Knoppix CD/DVD
  * your settings and home directory retained across sessions
  * you can also continue to use the remaining space on the stick for more
    typical purposes (transporting files)</p>

<p>The following is from actually doing this with a Knoppix DVD (not a CD) and an
8 GB stick for my nephew, who's away at a college where the general level of
cluefulness in the computer lab does not extend to a choice of operating
systems :-(</p>

<hr />

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Knoppix_and_USB">Knoppix and USB</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#size_and_prep_USB">size and prep USB</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#copy_stuff">copy stuff</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#copy_boot_directory">copy <code>boot</code> directory</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#install_extlinux">install extlinux</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#copy_the_rest_of_the_DVD">copy the rest of the DVD</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#usage">usage</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#first_use">first use</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#important">important</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#other_hints_and_tips">other hints and tips</a><br></p>

<hr />

<p>http://www.knoppix.net/wiki/Bootable<em>USB</em>Key is a good starting point but
that's all it is.  Most of it is cruft and the rest I have not actually
followed :-)  You don't have to do most of the stuff in there, especially the
bit about doing this from within knoppix -- any recent/decent Linux can be
used to create this USB if you have the Knoppix DVD handy.  There's one
section on making the BIOS actually recognise and boot from USB that's useful
though.</p>

<h3><a name="size_and_prep_USB">size and prep USB</a></h3>

<p>The stick has to be able to hold the entire CD/DVD's contents, plus whatever
extra software you want to install.</p>

<p>The extra software and customisation you do is stored in a "persistent knoppix
image" -- basically a file called <code>knoppix.img</code>.  You have to decide in
advance how big this should be, and it <em>cannot</em> be stored on the same
partition as the DVD itself (I have no idea why).  So you need at least 2
partitions.</p>

<p>Further, I prefer that both those partitions be <code>ext3</code>, and create a third
one with FAT32 with the rest of the space for temporary file transfer
purposes -- you never know what sort of idiot will want to borrow your USB
stick for a few minutes and accidentally delete some crucial file on it, so
it's better they don't even see those partitions!</p>

<p>So here's what my stick looks like:
  * partition 1, EXT3, bootable, about 5 GB
    * this should be the size of the CD/DVD plus a bit extra
  * partition 2, EXT3, about 2 GB
    * contains <code>knoppix.img</code>, presized to about 1 GB
    * the rest is lean (non-FAT, get it?) free space just in case I need some
  * partition 3, FAT32, the rest of the disk, for general use</p>

<h3><a name="copy_stuff">copy stuff</a></h3>

<p>You need to do 2 things: copy the contents of the DVD, and run <code>extlinux</code>.
This is the sequence in which I did them; other sequences may also work</p>

<h4><a name="copy_boot_directory">copy <code>boot</code> directory</a></h4>

<p>Mount the future boot disk</p>

<pre><code>mount /dev/sdz1 /j
</code></pre>

<p>There's an interesting point in the URL above about buggy CHS handling of USB
sticks, so long story short, I copied the boot files first (note <strong>no</strong>
trailing slash after the word <code>boot</code> below)</p>

<pre><code>rsync -av /media/cdrom/boot /j
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="install_extlinux">install extlinux</a></h4>

<p>Let's keep things the way <code>extlinux</code> wants them (as opposed to how
<code>isolinux</code> wants them!):</p>

<pre><code>mv /j/boot/isolinux /j/boot/extlinux
mv /j/boot/extlinux/isolinux.cfg /j/boot/extlinux/extlinux.conf
/bin/rm /j/boot/extlinux/isolinux.bin
</code></pre>

<p><code>extlinux</code>, unlike <code>isolinux</code>, runs on a <em>mounted</em> file system, so</p>

<pre><code>extlinux --install /j/boot/extlinux
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="copy_the_rest_of_the_DVD">copy the rest of the DVD</a></h4>

<p>This is the part that takes time:</p>

<pre><code>rsync -avP /media/cdrom/ /j --exclude boot
</code></pre>

<p>sync/unmount/sync again, then reboot.  Your USB stick is ready!</p>

<h3><a name="usage">usage</a></h3>

<h4><a name="first_use">first use</a></h4>

<p>The very first time you use it, before doing anything else, create a
persistent Knoppix image (Knoppix menu, Utilities).  Choose /dev/sdz2 for it,
and give it some suitable size (I gave it 1.1 GB).  Then reboot.</p>

<p>On the next reboot, use the package manager, setup repositories (you only need
2 of them - stable/updates and stable; unselect the rest), and install
whatever you want.</p>

<h4><a name="important">important</a></h4>

<p>On each reboot after the first, you will need to make sure you watch the boot
and hit "OK" on the prompt to mount the persistent knoppix image.  Just hit
the left arrow key then hit enter at that prompt.  If you walk away from the
computer, you will find that this prompt times out and knoppix boots without
mounting the persistent image.  This is a security feature.</p>

<h3><a name="other_hints_and_tips">other hints and tips</a></h3>

<ul>
<li>It may be a good idea to upgrade the whole thing every time a new version
comes out, because upgrading packages essentially wastes the space in the
DVD image (5 GB) partition.</li>
<li><p>For the same reason, it might be even better to do this whole thing with a
Knoppix <strong>CD</strong> rather than a DVD, and manually install what you need.
You'll have to install a lot more, but correspondingly you're wasting a
lot less space on the first partition.</p>

<p>It's a trade-off, really.</p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>File sync -- include/exclude rules and order</h1>

<h4>rsync</h4>

<ul>
<li>order matters, first matching pattern acts</li>
<li>no pattern matches the candidate: default is include (use an ultra
wildcard at the end if needed, like: <code>- **</code>)</li>
</ul>

<h4>rdiff-backup</h4>

<ul>
<li>(same as rsync)</li>
</ul>

<h4>dar</h4>

<ul>
<li>order doesn't matter</li>
<li>no match: default is include if no <code>-P</code> (prune) matches the candidate</li>
</ul>

<h4>unison</h4>

<ul>
<li>order doesn't matter</li>
<li>no match: ignore/not status is inherited from the parent</li>
<li>ignorenot overrides ignore if both match</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="aptitude_and_friends">aptitude and friends</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#aptitude_and_friends">aptitude and friends</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Command_line_Package_Management_with_Aptitude">Command-line Package Management with Aptitude</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Important_note_on_using_multiple_package_managers">Important note on using multiple package managers</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#The_feature_that_gets_all_the_press_">The feature that gets all the press...</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#The_choices">The choices</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Configuring_aptitude">Configuring aptitude</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Common_operations">Common operations</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Package_Selection">Package Selection</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Working_on_a_specific_package_or_packages_">Working on a specific package (or packages)</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Using_dpkg">Using dpkg</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Cheat_sheet">Cheat sheet</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Search_patterns">Search patterns</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Search_output_formatting_in_aptitude">Search output formatting in aptitude</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Sort_rules_on_output">Sort rules on output</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="Command_line_Package_Management_with_Aptitude">Command-line Package Management with Aptitude</a></h3>

<p>This article is meant to serve as a quick reference for package management at
the command line using <code>aptitude</code> and similar tools.  Where more than one tool
does the job, we will describe only the <code>aptitude</code> way.</p>

<h3><a name="Important_note_on_using_multiple_package_managers">Important note on using multiple package managers</a></h3>

<p>Before we dig into the article, there is one caveat.  For various reasons (see
later), it is considered inadvisable to mix package managers, as far as the
actual install/remove/upgrade operations are concerned.  However, querying and
exploring the package repository using a mix of tools is perfectly fine.</p>

<p>This article describes the ways in which aptitude is superior to apt-get, as
well as the situations in which you will still need apt-get, apt-cache, etc.
(There are even situations in which you have to use "<code>dpkg</code>"!  For example,
the <code>recoll</code> package, which I tend to use heavily, has to be downloaded as a
<code>.deb</code> and installed manually via <code>dpkg -i</code>.)</p>

<p>The article assumes you know some of the basic terminology of package
management.</p>

<h3><a name="The_feature_that_gets_all_the_press_">The feature that gets all the press...</a></h3>

<p>The one feature of aptitude that gets all the attention (or used to, until
apt-get acquired the "autoremove" option) is that <code>aptitude</code> keeps track of
whether a package was manually installed by the administrator, or it was
installed to satisfy a dependency.  As a result, when a package is removed,
packages that were installed as its dependencies can also get removed, as long
as <em>no other installed package</em> is using them.</p>

<p>This is also the reason why mixing package managers can cause trouble.  To be
fair, you can tell aptitude (using the <code>markauto</code> and <code>unmarkauto</code> options)
which packages were explicitly installed and which ones were installed as
dependencies, so even if you do mix tools and find that <code>aptitude</code> seems to
want to do the wrong thing, running these commands will tell it who's the boss
:-)</p>

<h3><a name="The_choices">The choices</a></h3>

<p>These are the choices.</p>

<ul>
<li>for the command line
<ul>
<li><code>apt-get</code> (and its cousins <code>apt-cache</code>, etc)</li>
<li><code>aptitude</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li>for a text-based (ncurses) GUI
<ul>
<li><code>aptitude</code>: You might notice that aptitude is the only one with
both a CLI and a GUI, even if it is just an ncurses GUI.  However, in
this article we will only be talking about the command line interface.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>for a GUI
<ul>
<li><code>synaptic</code> (on Ubuntu)</li>
<li><code>adept</code> (on kubuntu)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>All of them are equally good at the basics, but there are some important
differences in capabilities.  The most important ones are listed here :</p>

<ul>
<li><code>apt-cache</code> has a <code>policy</code> command which tells you how many versions of
the package exist, in which repository they are found, and which one it
will choose to install if you ask it to install the package</li>
<li><code>apt-get</code> has a <code>--print-uris</code> option, which prints out all the
URIs it would download.  This is <em>invaluable for a system with a slow
internet connection</em>.  Just use some offline mechanism (like a USB stick)
to get the files from some other machine with a faster connection, put
them all in <code>/var/cache/apt/archives</code>, and run <code>aptitude install
...</code>; it'll notice the files already exist and won't attempt to download
them.  I have even upgraded from Ubuntu Feisty (7.04) to Gutsy (7.10)
using this method; about 40 megabytes were eventually downloaded directly
by the machine being upgraded, while the rest (about 600 MB) were obtained
in this manner.</li>
<li>As I said, none of the "aptitude versus apt-get" articles on the web seem
to mention aptitude's excellent query capabilities.  For example, you can
ask: give me the download size and installed size of all installed
packages that depend on any package whose name contains "perl" or
"python".\ \
What's more, you can use the same query patterns in commands - in the
above example, once you have seen the list, you can simply replace the
command ("search") with another command (say, "install") to upgrade all
those packages.  Nothing in apt-get comes close.  For example, I like to
stay uptodate on perl stuff, so I can run
    aptitude install "~i ~U ~n^perl"
to upgrade all installed (<code>~i</code>) and upgradable (<code>~U</code>) packages
whose name (<code>~n</code>) starts with (<code>^</code>) the word <code>perl</code>.
<em>Note</em>* : search patterns can match more than you intended unless you
anchor the regex with <code>^</code> and <code>$</code>, especially if the package has a
short name that could be a substring of other package names</li>
<li><code>aptitude</code> can be made to pause for confirmation using the <code>-P</code>
flag.  When it pauses, you can get <strong>detailed dependency information</strong>
that tells you clearly why each install/remove choice was made, <strong>version
information</strong>, or information about the <strong>extra space</strong> taken by each
package as a result of this action.  Just type a "?" at the prompt for
these and many more powerful things that are possible!</li>
<li><code>aptitude</code>'s output when searching for packages can be <strong>sorted</strong> as
well as <strong>formatted</strong> to your taste/needs; see below for details.</li>
</ul>

<p>[Side note: The 2 complaints I have against APT are (i) that it doesn't store
"time of install" anywhere, like RPM does, and (ii) there's nothing like <code>rpm
-V</code> to verify all the files of a package and find out which ones have changed.
The first issue can be worked around by trawling the log files, but the second
one can't.]</p>

<h3><a name="Configuring_aptitude">Configuring aptitude</a></h3>

<p>Make sure you add a line saying</p>

<pre><code>aptitude::Recommends-Important "false";
</code></pre>

<p>in <code>/root/.aptitude/config</code>.  This says "just because a package is
<em>recommended</em> doesn't mean you should go and install it" ;-) Apart from making
things a little faster and leaner, this option is also consistent with the
behaviour of <code>apt-get install</code>.</p>

<h3><a name="Common_operations">Common operations</a></h3>

<p><em>Note</em>*: Even though there is a cron job that updates the package database
every day, it's best to do an</p>

<pre><code>aptitude update
</code></pre>

<p>before any installations, upgrades, or removals.</p>

<h4><a name="Package_Selection">Package Selection</a></h4>

<p>This is, as I said before, where <code>aptitude</code> really shines, and it seems better
to describe this with examples than by any other method.  The examples will
demonstrate the power as well as serve as a tutorial or a quick reference to
this feature.  Also, remember that although most of the examples use <code>search</code>
as the command, you can just as easily substitute any other command (like
<code>install</code>, <code>remove</code>, <code>purge</code>, etc.) to perform that action on the packages
that would be selected by the selection expression.</p>

<p><em>Note</em>* : search patterns can match more than you intended unless you anchor
the regex with <code>^</code> and <code>$</code>, especially if the package has a short name that
could be a substring of other package names</p>

<ul>
<li><p>all packages known to the system</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search .   # about 25,000 results, on my machine
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>all installed pkgs</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~i
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>all packages having perl in the name somewhere</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search perl
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>all packages starting with the word perl</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~n^perl
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>all installed pkgs starting with the word perl</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search '~i ~n^perl'
</code></pre>

<p>Note the quotes above; if a search pattern has multiple terms they are
AND-ed together.  Without the quotes they would be treated as 2 separate,
unrelated, search patterns, and aptitude would process them separately and
simply combine the output, so you get many, many, more results.</p></li>
<li><p>packages removed but whose config files still remain</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~c
</code></pre>

<p>purge (remove config files of) all such packages</p>

<pre><code>aptitude purge ~c
</code></pre>

<p>Notice how the same package selection operator can be used for real
actions also.</p></li>
<li><p>packages that aptitude marks as "automatically installed as dependencies"</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~M
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages that were automatically installed but are no longer needed</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~g
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>new packages</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~N
</code></pre>

<p>You should look at these once in a while to see what sort of new packages</p>

<p>are getting into the repos, and when you've seen them, you should tell
aptitude you're done seeing them by saying</p>

<pre><code>aptitude forget-new
</code></pre>

<p>so the next time you use <code>~N</code> it won't show you these packages again.</p></li>
<li><p>packages ready to be upgraded</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~U
</code></pre>

<p>Let's say there are plenty of packages with upgrades available, but
(perhaps due to lack of time or bandwidth), I wish to upgrade only perl :</p>

<pre><code>aptitude install "~U ~i ~nperl"
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages that depend on the package called perl</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~D^perl$    # note the ^ and the $
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages that depend on any package containing the string perl</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~Dperl      # note no ^ and $ to anchor the regex
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages that are depended on by perl</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~R^perl$    # R means reverse depends
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages that recommend perl</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~Drecommends:^perl$
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages that are recommended by perl</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~Rrecommends:^perl$
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages with someword in the description</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~dsomeword
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages with <strong>both</strong> words in the description</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search '~dword1 ~dword2'   # note the quotes
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>packages with <strong>either</strong> word in the description</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search ~dword1 ~dword2     # will return many more results!
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="Working_on_a_specific_package_or_packages_">Working on a specific package (or packages)</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>get detailed information about a package</p>

<pre><code>aptitude show -v pkg
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>install a package</p>

<pre><code>aptitude install pkg          # you can add suffixes to the packagename
</code></pre>

<p>you can add the following suffixes to a packagename to perform multiple
actions (install package A, remove package B, etc) in the same command</p>

<pre><code>+       install
-       remove
_       purge
=       hold
:       cancel changes (??)
+M      marked as auto-installed
+m      ...manual...
&amp;M      mark already installed pkg as auto-installed
&amp;m      mark already installed pkg as manually installed
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="Using_dpkg">Using dpkg</a></h4>

<p>Finally, note that you do sometimes have to use <code>dpkg</code>; nothing else will do!
So here's how you want to work directly on a <code>.deb</code> package file :</p>

<ul>
<li><p>get information about the package</p>

<pre><code>dpkg -I pkg.deb
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>list files within the package</p>

<pre><code>dpkg -c pkg.deb
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>extract files from the package</p>

<pre><code>dpkg -x pkg.deb     # -X for verbose extract
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>install the package</p>

<pre><code>dpkg -i somepkg.deb
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<p>For an already installed package :</p>

<ul>
<li><p>get information about the package</p>

<pre><code>dpkg -s pkg         # also lists files marked config files!
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>list files within the package</p>

<pre><code>dpkg -L pkg
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>find out which installed pkg a file belongs to; note that no other command
does this, unless you install the optional <code>apt-file</code> package</p>

<pre><code>dpkg -S file        # dont need full path
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="Cheat_sheet">Cheat sheet</a></h3>

<p>The rest of this should be seen as a cheat sheet for using <code>aptitude</code>
effectively.  The man page and the README tend to be much larger, and not very
optimised for a quick check of some feature.</p>

<h4><a name="Search_patterns">Search patterns</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>The search patterns use regular expressions, whose meta-characters need
escaping, e.g., <code>g\+\+</code>.  This again needs to be escaped from the
shell of course, so in practice it's usually either</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search 'g\+\+'
</code></pre>

<p>or</p>

<pre><code>aptitude search g\\+\\+
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>When you specify multiple patterns, they are processed separately and the
results combined.  This is not quite the same as OR-ing them; if a package
satisfies more than one search pattern, it <em>will appear multiple times</em>
in the output.</p></li>
<li><code>!</code> negates; eg, <code>!~b</code> means pkgs that are not broken</li>
<li><code>(grouping|alternation)</code> are available</li>
<li><p>The following special patterns exist (see manual for more)</p>

<pre><code>    ~b                  packages that are broken
    ~c                  packages that have been removed but their config
                        files are still present in the system
    ~i                  installed pkgs (~c packages do not appear here)
    ~M                  automatically installed packages
    ~N                  new packages
    ~U                  any installed pkg ready to be upgraded
    ~Aarchive           which archive? eg ~Atesting; from testing archive
    ~aaction            what action is pending? eg ~ainstall (or upgrade,
                        downgrade, remove, purge, hold, keep) -- action
                        must be actually queued up
    ~D(perl|python)     DEPENDS (ON); list of pkgs that depend on any pkg
                        whose name matches perl|python
    ~DBpattern          ...like above but only broken dependencies
    ~Rpattern           REVERSE DEPENDS; depended on; list of pkgs that
                        &lt;pattern&gt; depends on
    ~dword              look for "word" in description
    ~nname              eg ~n^lib
    ~Oorigin            eg '!~Oubuntu ~i' shows me libdvdcss2 and
                        w32codecs!!!
    ~Pprovides          PROVIDES; eg ~Pmail-transport-agent
    ~ppriority          this could be "extra", "optional", "important",
                        "required" or "standard"
    ~ssection           eg "~sgnome ~i" -- what gnome stuff do I have
                        installed?
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="Search_output_formatting_in_aptitude">Search output formatting in aptitude</a></h4>

<pre><code>The search output formatting uses the `-F` flag.  Some of the
important fields are listed below; check out the README for more fields as
well as information on how to adjust the width of each column etc.

    %a - action pending,        %c - current state
    %p - pkg name,              %d - description,
    %D - download size,         %I - install size
    %v - current version,       %V - candidate version
    %t - archive it came from (like feisty, feisty-security, etc).
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Sort_rules_on_output">Sort rules on output</a></h4>

<pre><code>There are only 4 fields that can be sorted on

        installsize
        name
        priority
        version

You can sort on any combination.  For example,

        -O priority,~name

means sort by priority, and within that reverse sort by name
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Digital Blending</h1>

<p><sup>from <a href="http://www.luminous-landscape.com/tutorials/digital-blending.shtml">http://www.luminous-landscape.com/tutorials/digital-blending.shtml</a></sup></p>

<p><strong>doesnt work very well</strong> -- much better to use manual masking once you
realise what exactly this does</p>

<ul>
<li>drop the darker one as a new layer on top of the lighter one</li>
<li>right click the top layer (darker one) and add a layer mask, black</li>
<li>left click the bottom layer, Ctrl-A, Ctrl-C</li>
<li>right click on the layer mask, select both edit and show layer mask</li>
<li>Ctrl-V, then anchor it.  You should see a B/W image in the mask</li>
<li>with the B/W showing, Filter/Blur/Gaussian Blur, radius 40
<ul>
<li><strong>OR</strong> if the two pictures are EXACTly the same in
composition/focus/DOF, use colors/auto/equalise on the B/W mask</li>
</ul></li>
<li>make sure "disable layer mask" is not set, both the layers are visible
(the "eye")</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>kdiff3</h1>

<p><strong>awesome</strong>!</p>

<p>but in dir mode, there may be some gotchas... like only files visible in tree
will make it to the output :-)  Anyway krusader is better for that.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="socat_netcat_on_steroids">socat -- netcat on steroids</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#socat_netcat_on_steroids">socat -- netcat on steroids</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Quick_tips_and_options">Quick tips and options</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#specific_HOWTOs">specific HOWTOs</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#some_concepts_generics">some concepts/generics</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#more_help_from_the_intertubes">more help from the intertubes</a><br></p>

<h3><a name="Quick_tips_and_options">Quick tips and options</a></h3>

<ul>
<li>always specify <code>,reuseaddr</code> on any <code>LISTEN</code> if you want to rerun the
command immediately</li>
<li>use <code>fork</code> to keep the program listening for more connections</li>
<li>specify <code>,verify=0</code> on any SSL stuff to avoid cert hassles
<ul>
<li>when you really need security, do what
<a href="http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat-openssltunnel.html">http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat-openssltunnel.html</a> says
:-) It sets up the certificates on both sides properly.  [Not clear how
you set up multiple clients though]  It sets up the certificates on both
sides properly.  [Not clear how you set up multiple clients though]</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>other options</p>

<pre><code>retry=10,intervall=5
forever,intervall=5
ignoreeof           # like tail -f
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="specific_HOWTOs">specific HOWTOs</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>unwrap SSL to talk to port 995 as if it were 110</p>

<pre><code>socat TCP4-LISTEN:1100,reuseaddr,fork OPENSSL:127.0.0.1:995,verify=0 &amp;
nc 127.0.0.1 1100
USER ...
PASS ...
# etc
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>generic CONNECT wrapper for any protocol (in this case port 22, assuming
squid.conf allows CONNECT requests to port 22):</p>

<pre><code>socat TCP4-LISTEN:2022,reuseaddr,fork \
PROXY:squid.server:home.server:22,proxyport=3128,proxyauth=user:pass
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>example ssh config/session, assuming squid allows CONNECT on port 22</p>

<pre><code>$ tail -5 .ssh/config
host isp
    user sitaram
    hostname shell.isp.com
    port 22
    proxycommand socat - PROXY:squid.server.ip:%h:%p,proxyport=3128
$ ssh isp
sitaram@shell.isp.com's password:
</code></pre></li>
<li><p><a href="http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat-openssltunnel.html">http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat-openssltunnel.html</a> is a good
HOWTO on setting up a single-shot ssl connection between 2 socats.
Briefly, it involves creating <code>.pem</code> and <code>.crt</code> files on server and
client, and exchanging the <code>.crt</code> files with each other.  The <code>.pem</code> files
are secret and must be protected.</p>

<pre><code>FILENAME=server     # or "client"
openssl genrsa -out $FILENAME.key 1024 
openssl req -new -key $FILENAME.key -x509 -days 3653 -out $FILENAME.crt 
cat $FILENAME.key $FILENAME.crt &gt;$FILENAME.pem 
chmod 600 $FILENAME.key $FILENAME.pem 

# usage: server side
socat ssl-l:4433,reuseaddr,cert=server.pem,cafile=client.crt echo
# client side
socat stdio ssl:localhost:4433,cert=client.pem,cafile=server.crt
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="some_concepts_generics">some concepts/generics</a></h3>

<p><sup>the following is from <a href="http://www.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/04/13/1515258">http://www.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/04/13/1515258</a></sup></p>

<p><a href="http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat">Socat</a> has been described as "netcat on
steroids." It can read from and write to files, pipes, and all kinds of
sockets. I use it mostly for port forwarding (TCP relay). For example, to
forward all incoming connections on port 1234 of my host to port 1234 of
destination.host:</p>

<pre><code>socat TCP4-LISTEN:1234,fork,reuseaddr TCP4:destination.host:1234
</code></pre>

<p>I also use it as a replacement for <a href="http://stunnel.mirt.net">Stunnel</a> to
tunnel connections through SSL. This is, for example, how I sometimes make an
HTTP-only server support HTTPS in a pinch:</p>

<pre><code>socat OPENSSL-LISTEN:443,fork TCP4:localhost:80
</code></pre>

<p><sup>the following is from <a href="http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/linuxwochen2007-socat.pdf">http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/linuxwochen2007-socat.pdf</a></sup></p>

<ul>
<li><p>socat essentially takes two "address" specifications and bounces data
between them.  Common address types are:</p>

<pre><code>-                               # stdio
tcp4:host:port
tcp4-l:port                     # tcp4-l is short for tcp4-listen
exec:/bin/ls,pty                # run program in sub-process
ssl:https.server:443,verify=0   # ssl client
ssl-l:443,cert=./server.pem     # ssl server

# files, devices, named pipes, pty
fd:3                            # existing file descriptor
open:file.txt
open:/dev/tty
create:newfile
pipe:./named.pipe
pty,link=$HOME/dev/pty0

# UNIX domain stream client, server
unix-connect:/tmp/.X11-unix/X0
unix-listen:$HOME/dev/socket1,fork
# UNIX domain datagram sender, receiver
unix-sendto:/dev/log
unix-recv:/dev/log
unix-recvfrom:$HOME/dev/askmewhat,fork
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>really cool address types:</p>

<pre><code>readline,history=$HOME/.socat_history
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>too much trouble?</p>

<pre><code>system:'while read ...; \
    do ...; done' \
    ,pipes
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>examples:</p>

<pre><code># TCP server with direct script
socat tcp-l:7000,reuseaddr exec:"/bin/cat",nofork

# VPN using tun/tap, server and client side commands
socatÂ -d -d tcp-l:50500,reuseaddrÂ TUN:192.168.10.2/24,up
socatÂ tcp:50500Â TUN:192.168.10.3/24,up
# use SSL instead of TCP if needed
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>some of the examples are <em>awesome</em>:</p>

<ul>
<li>slide 15: double-client in the office, double-server at home</li>
<li>slide 31: broadcast and multicast</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="more_help_from_the_intertubes">more help from the intertubes</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat-tun.html">http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat-tun.html</a> helps you create a
simple tunnel using an actual TUN device, <strong>which socat creates</strong>, on each
side.  Very cool!</li>
<li><a href="http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat.html#EXAMPLES">http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat.html#EXAMPLES</a> is also a good
starting point.  The full man page causes, as one of my friends' says,
"cognitive overload".</li>
<li>for a really cool trick search for "end-close" in the above EXAMPLES url!</li>
<li><a href="http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/linuxwochen2007-socat.pdf">http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/linuxwochen2007-socat.pdf</a> has
<em>lots</em> of great stuff</li>
<li><a href="http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat-tun.html">http://www.dest-unreach.org/socat/doc/socat-tun.html</a> has more details on
the tun/tap stuff</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>MDV setup stuff</h1>

<ul>
<li>vim /etc/*/tmpwatch and add "-a -c" as options for the tmpwatch commands</li>
<li>add relatime to all ext3 mounts in fstab and remount</li>
<li>add data=writeback for laptops and UPS protected machines</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="notes_from_the_Advanced_Bash_Scripting_Guide">notes from the Advanced Bash Scripting Guide</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#notes_from_the_Advanced_Bash_Scripting_Guide">notes from the Advanced Bash Scripting Guide</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Debugging_coolness">Debugging coolness</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#From_the_advanced_bash_scripting_guide">From the advanced bash scripting guide</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#The_read_command">The <code>read</code> command</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Incrementing_a_number">Incrementing a number</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Shell_variable_command_output">Shell variable &lt;= command output</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#I_O_to_from_a_shell_block">I/O to/from a shell block</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Sequences">Sequences</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Combining_stderr_into_stdout">Combining stderr into stdout</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Here_string">Here string</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Tests_and_matches">Tests and matches</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Batch_use_only">Batch use only</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#History_viewing">History viewing</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="Debugging_coolness">Debugging coolness</a></h3>

<pre><code>export PS4=':$0.$LINENO:'
# now use "-x"
</code></pre>

<h3><a name="From_the_advanced_bash_scripting_guide">From the advanced bash scripting guide</a></h3>

<p><sup>source: <a href="http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/abs-guide.pdf">http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/abs-guide.pdf</a></sup></p>

<h4><a name="The_read_command">The <code>read</code> command</a></h4>

<p>if reading from a terminal:</p>

<pre><code>read -t timeout     # for terminal OR pipe
read -s             # silent (no echo) for passwords
read -p prompt      # no trailing newline after prompt; nice!
read -e             # use readline
</code></pre>

<p>others:</p>

<pre><code>read -n nchars      # return after nchars read
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Incrementing_a_number">Incrementing a number</a></h4>

<pre><code>(( n++ ))
(( n = n + 1 ))     # more general form
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Shell_variable_command_output">Shell variable &lt;= command output</a></h4>

<p>Really old way:</p>

<pre><code>ls|wc -l|while read ans; do ...; done
</code></pre>

<p>A better way:</p>

<pre><code>read ans &lt; &lt;(ls|wc -l)
</code></pre>

<p>A way to get multi-line output into a single variable</p>

<pre><code>read ans &lt;&lt;&lt;$(ls -al)
</code></pre>

<p>Best way:</p>

<pre><code>ans=`ls|wc -l`
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="I_O_to_from_a_shell_block">I/O to/from a shell block</a></h4>

<p>good for a lot of cases where I was doing a <code>while..do...done</code></p>

<pre><code>{ block } &lt; file
{ block } &gt; file
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Sequences">Sequences</a></h4>

<p><code>{a..e</code>}, just like the <code>seq</code> command except you're not restricted to
integers.  However, you cannot replicate <code>seq</code>'s <code>-w</code> option.</p>

<h4><a name="Combining_stderr_into_stdout">Combining stderr into stdout</a></h4>

<p>My old way:</p>

<pre><code>&gt;filename 2&gt;&amp;1!
</code></pre>

<p>A better way; but can't be used to pipe to a pager, for example :-(</p>

<pre><code>&amp;&gt; filename
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Here_string">Here string</a></h4>

<p>the "here-string" has all sorts of nifty uses</p>

<pre><code>&lt;&lt;&lt; $var
</code></pre>

<hr />

<h3><a name="Tests_and_matches">Tests and matches</a></h3>

<pre><code>[[ ... ]]
</code></pre>

<p>use this instead of [ ... ] in most places.
&amp;&amp;, ||, &lt;, and > work within ~[[ ... ]], but not within [ ... ]</p>

<pre><code>[[ ... == ... ]]
</code></pre>

<p>when you don't use quotes around the parameters, this does a glob-pattern match</p>

<pre><code>[[ ... =~ ... ]]
</code></pre>

<p>this does a regex match, almost like perl</p>

<p>Also, you can safely use <code>$VAR</code> instead of <code>"$VAR"</code> -- even if it's value
contains spaces.</p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="Batch_use_only">Batch use only</a></h3>

<p>Use of the <strong>null command (<code>:</code>)</strong></p>

<pre><code># placeholder in conditional assignments
: ${username=`whoami`}

# evaluate string of variables and abort if not set
: ${HOSTNAME?} ${USER?} ${MAIL?}
</code></pre>

<p>Indirect variable reference -- use the "<code>!</code>" character</p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="History_viewing">History viewing</a></h3>

<pre><code>set HISTTIMEFORMAT="%F %T "
</code></pre>

<p>Works ok if you put it in /etc/profile.d/history.sh.  This is <strong>not</strong> a
security feature -- it's only a sanity feature :-)</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>nostalgy hack</h1>

<h3>How to make nostalgy clear the search box on a single escape</h3>

<p>find a line saying</p>

<pre><code>Search("");
</code></pre>

<p>it may be in a code block that looks like</p>

<pre><code>if (ev.keyCode == KeyEvent.DOM_VK_ESCAPE &amp;&amp; nostalgy_search_focused) {
  // -- sita -- Search(""); 
  setTimeout(SetFocusThreadPane,0);
  NostalgyStopEvent(ev);
  return;
}
</code></pre>

<p>just comment out the offending line as above</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>posix shell -- quick notes</h1>

<p>from https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DashAsBinSh</p>

<p>All in <code>code</code> for quick typing</p>

<pre><code>[[ ]] does not work; use [ ] instead

use a separate [ ] for each test if you have a composite; use &amp;&amp; and || to
connect them.  Use ordinary parens for grouping.

-z and -n need "" around the operand.  In general, use "" anyway, unless
you're sure or don't care about spaces or metas in the argument.

== does not work; use =

=~ does not work; use grep (including a pipe and a redirection!)

(( arith )) does not work; use $(( arith )) instead (see URL above for
examples)

${foo#bar} is ok, as is ##, %, and %%.  All other forms are not OK
(pattern matching, substringing)

$RANDOM may not work

ulimit may not work

let, declare, typeset, do not work

read can only do a plain read (no fancy options) and must specify a
variable (this means there is no real way to do "read -s")

echo only supports "-n"; use printf for anything fancier
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>tcpdump</h1>

<h3>Examples</h3>

<pre><code>tcpdump not port 22
tcpdump -n -i eth1 -w file.cap -s 0 not port 22
tcpdump -r file.cap
tcpdump -n dst port 80  # direction and port
tcpdump -n portrange 20-23
tcpdump src host xyz.com
tcpdump src next 172.25.148.0/23
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>aria2</h1>

<h3>quick start</h3>

<h4>pros</h4>

<ul>
<li>metalink!</li>
<li>poor man's metalink with a list of mirror URLs</li>
<li>can also do lists and sequences like curl</li>
</ul>

<h4>cons</h4>

<ul>
<li>does segmented downloads (hammers server) <strong>by default</strong> -- use <code>-s1</code>
to prevent this</li>
<li>the precise rules for -j and -s are not clear.  In particular, there seems
to be an off-by-one error somewhere or something.</li>
</ul>

<h3>details</h3>

<h4>normal downloads</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-Z</code> <strong>REQUIRED</strong> when multiple URLs refer to <strong>different</strong> files</li>
<li><code>-c</code> to resume something partly downloaded by another program</li>
<li><code>-j N</code> number of parallel downloads overall, default 5, max 45</li>
<li><code>-s N</code> connections per file, default 5, max 16</li>
<li><code>-P</code> does the curl magic of lists and sequences
<ul>
<li>example <code>http://{sv1,sv2,sv3}.example.com/[01-20:4].jpg</code></li>
<li><strong>don't forget the <code>-Z</code></strong> if these are different files!</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4>metalink</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-M metalinkfile</code></li>
<li><code>-C N</code> number of servers to connect simultaneously, default 5</li>
</ul>

<h4>torrent</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-T torrentfile</code> </li>
<li><code>-S</code> show files in torrent</li>
<li><code>--select-file=1,3,5-8</code> download only selected files from torrent</li>
<li><code>--listen-port=8681,8685-8688</code></li>
<li><code>--max-upload-limit=20K</code>, or use M for MB</li>
<li>seeding ends when either of these is satisfied
<ul>
<li><code>--seed-time=MINUTES</code></li>
<li><code>--seed-ratio=0.5</code> default 1.0</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>dar and rdiff-backup with spaces in directory names</h1>

<p>dar and rdiff-backup with spaces in directory names</p>

<ul>
<li><p>for rdiff-backup, the include/exclude file should look like:</p>

<pre><code>./donot
./DO NOT
** ./dodo
** ./DO\ DO

** **
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>and the command should look like:</p>

<pre><code>rdiff-backup --include-globbing-filelist inc-exc-list . /backup/location
</code></pre>

<p>(notice that the source directory, "." in this case, is the start of all
the entries in the inc/exc list)</p></li>
<li><p>for dar it's like this:</p>

<pre><code>-g ./donot
-g "./DO NOT"
--prune ./dodo
--prune "./DO\ DO"
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>and the command looks like:</p>

<pre><code>dar -v -c junk -B aa
</code></pre></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>krusader</h1>

<p>All in all, the synchronization is nowhere near unison (it doesn't keep
history), but is otherwise <em>pretty damn good</em>, and quite interactive.  So
it's basically a GUI eqvt of mc, (but no %f and %t, alas!)</p>

<h4>sanity customizations for a new install</h4>

<ul>
<li>look-and-feel -> operation -> rename selects extension (off)</li>
<li>look-and-feel -> operation -> fullscreen terminal (on)</li>
<li>look-and-feel -> panel toolbar (off)</li>
<li>look-and-feel -> selection mode -> konqueror mode</li>
<li>general -> move to trash (not "delete")</li>
<li>advanced -> confirmation -> unselect for del/copy/move files</li>
<li>assign alt-left-arrow to Go->Back</li>
</ul>

<h4>plus points and nice features</h4>

<ul>
<li>sync -- see section below</li>
<li>view->custom <strong>restricts view</strong> to space-sep list of globs, view->allfiles
resets</li>
<li>du -s <strong>plain</strong>: edit->calculate occupied space</li>
<li>du -s <strong>fancy</strong>: tools->disk usage -- filelight on steroids!
<ul>
<li>lots of nifty features, explore by right-click, esp. excluding stuff!</li>
<li>caveat: "step into" is really just "enter" and shift-Down doesn't work!</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4>hard to remember but useful controls</h4>

<ul>
<li>folder <strong>open in new tab</strong>: alt-ctrl-Enter</li>
<li>new <strong>net</strong> connection: ctrl-N</li>
<li>new <strong>tab</strong>: alt-ctrl-N, switch tabs: shift-Right/Left</li>
<li>goto <strong>location bar</strong>: ctrl-L</li>
<li><strong>popular URLs</strong>: ctrl-Z</li>
<li>toggle <strong>popup panel</strong>: alt-Down</li>
<li><strong>jump</strong> between command line and window: ctrl-Up/Down</li>
<li>edit file <strong>as root</strong>: Ctrl-E</li>
</ul>

<h4>note</h4>

<ul>
<li>ctrl-Right and ctrl-Left can be very confusing and therefore dangerous:
<ul>
<li><strong>but they cannot be disabled!!</strong></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4>synchronization</h4>

<ul>
<li>"compare by content" is slow but useful when sizes and dates are not
enough to decide</li>
<li>local dirs: paranoid setting: use "ignore date" and "compare by content"
if you can afford the time</li>
<li>remote dirs: "compare by content" has no rsync-like smarts -- TOO SLOW.
So either
<ul>
<li>the dates should be reliable, OR</li>
<li>"ignore date" and risk missing file changes that left file size
unchanged</li>
</ul></li>
<li>only the stuff that is visible in list gets synced, so you can compare
then weed the list to your hearts content before hitting the sync button</li>
<li>has its own profile settings, over and above the main krusader</li>
<li>file filter is great: example <code>*.good1 *.good2 | junk*</code> -- the stuff
after the vertical bar is a negation</li>
<li>the sync list can be quick-searched by typing in the filename fast...</li>
<li>other notes
<ul>
<li>read the label "duplicates" as "doubles" (i.e., opposite of "singles")</li>
<li>"not equals" button is N/A unless you check "ignore date"</li>
<li>"deletable" button is N/A unless you check "asymmetric" <em>*</em> CAREFUL!
left panel is the target, not the source (think <code>krusader --left
olddir --right newdir</code>)</li>
<li>"swap sides" button is useful to make sure the right side is a local
file, so that you can do a merge using kdiff3 and have the results
saved (remember that kdiff3 will only save to the last file in the list
if no explicit "-o" option is given)</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p><strong>caveats</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>(doc says you can sync only a part of the listed tree after comparison
is done, but doesnt work)</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>untested, esp the last one (but doc says kru doesn't support ftp via http
proxy anyway)</p>

<pre><code>&lt;ftp://public.ftpserver.org/directory/&gt;
fish://username@hostname/
sftp://username:password@sftp.foo.org/
&lt;ftp://username@my.server.org:21/directory/&gt;
smb://username:password@server/share
&lt;ftp://username@proxyusername:password@proxipassword@hostname/directory&gt;
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4>crap features</h4>

<ul>
<li>the following features are crap when used outside of the sync dialog (ie,
in the main krusader)
<ul>
<li>compare by content -- no match for MC's F9-c-c-t</li>
<li>compare directories -- only does by name/date, not content</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>mount command</h1>

<h2>common usages</h2>

<ul>
<li><p>mounting samba as a guest</p>

<pre><code>mount -o uid=501 *172.19.58.2/scratch-pad /scratch-pad
mount.cifs *1.2.3.4/smb-share /home/sitaramc/spad -o rw,nosetuids,noperm
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>encrypted file system using cryptoloop (pre-encfs method) (<strong>OBSOLETE --
use EncFS now</strong>)</p>

<pre><code>modprobe aes
modprobe cryptoloop
losetup -e AES256 /dev/loop5 /dev/hda5
file -s /dev/loop5
fsck /dev/loop5
mount /dev/loop5 /enc
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h2>mount options for security</h2>

<p>These would be useful in eliminating local privilege escalation for ISP type
systems; set these on /home, /tmp, and /var, don't let them write access
anywhere else, and you're done</p>

<ul>
<li>noexec: do not allow executables</li>
<li>nosuid: do not allow suid executable</li>
<li>nodev: do not allow devices</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Indoor photography</h1>

<p>Objective: to see people or subjects in the foreground and still see the
warmth of the room or any features or lights in the background.</p>

<p>Settings for Indoor Photography</p>

<ul>
<li>Manual mode</li>
<li>Widest aperture</li>
<li>Shutter 1/60 for wide angle, 1/120 for zoom
<ul>
<li>but avoid zoom if low light</li>
</ul></li>
<li>External slave flashes are a good idea</li>
<li>Take a few shots and see what they look like.</li>
<li>If they are not bright enough try bumping up your ISO until happy</li>
</ul>

<p>This style of photography will have great lighting on people in the foreground
and still have the impact of the room lighting and features in the shot. Just
a plain old photo with the flash will normally burn out people in the
foreground and black out the background. Give it a go! </p>

<p><sup>source: <a href="http://digital-photography-school.com/blog/how-to-achieve-great-indoor-photography-results">http://digital-photography-school.com/blog/how-to-achieve-great-indoor-photography-results</a></sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>IPv6 info</h1>

<p><sup>mostly from <a href="http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/docs/HOWTO/other-formats/html_single/Linux+IPv6-HOWTO.html">http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/docs/HOWTO/other-formats/html_single/Linux+IPv6-HOWTO.html</a></sup></p>

<ul>
<li><code>::1</code> is like 127.0.0.1</li>
<li><code>::</code> is like 0.0.0.0</li>
<li><code>::ffff:a.b.c.d/96</code> (example ::ffff:1.2.3.4) is an <strong>IPv4-mapped IPv6
address</strong> (for "sockets created by an IPv6-enabled daemon, but only
binding to an IPv4 address")</li>
<li><p><code>::a.b.c.d/96</code> is an <strong>IPv4-compatible IPv6 address</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>not clear what is the difference</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Link local: never pass through a router</p>

<ul>
<li><code>fe[89ab]x:</code> where x is normally <code>0</code> but can be any hex char</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Site local: now deprecated, but like 10.0.0.0/8</p>

<ul>
<li><code>fe[cdef]x:</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Unique Local</p>

<ul>
<li><code>fdxx:</code> or <code>fcxx:</code></li>
<li>next 40 bits are generated using a pseudo-random algorithm</li>
<li>allows two formerly independent networks to join; unlikely that all 40
bits will match!</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Global </p>

<ul>
<li><code>2xxx:</code> or <code>3xxx:</code></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>mounting a hard disk from within a knoppix boot</h1>

<p><sup>from <a href="http://aplawrence.com/Linux/mount_bind.html">http://aplawrence.com/Linux/mount_bind.html</a></sup></p>

<p>You can use mount to bind directories when using a Knoppix cdrom to recover
from mucked up linux bootloaders or resetting root passwords and whatnot.</p>

<p>Assuming that /dev/hda1 is your OS on your harddrive's main partition...</p>

<ul>
<li>Boot up with knoppix.</li>
<li><code>mount /mnt/hda1</code>
<ul>
<li>(should set that up automatically, could be in /media though)</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>cd /mnt/hda1</code></li>
<li><code>mount -t proc proc ./proc</code></li>
<li><code>mount -t sysfs sys ./sys</code></li>
<li><code>mount -o bind /KNOPPIX/dev ./dev</code>
<ul>
<li>(or is that /mnt/KNOPPIX/dev? I forget, been a while)</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>chroot ./ su -</code></li>
</ul>

<p>Or something similar to that. Should end up having full access to the hardware
from inside the chroot environment for setting up grub etc...</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>lftp notes</h1>

<p><strong>AWESOME TOOL -- ftp+++, if you ask me!</strong></p>

<h3>quick start</h3>

<h4>pros</h4>

<ul>
<li>interactive, including tab-completion; built-in help for all commands</li>
<li>downloads can be grouped, bg-ed/fg-ed, run in parallel, queued and
NOHUPped, scheduled, or conditionally run
<ul>
<li>job control: at, jobs, kill, wait, </li>
</ul></li>
<li>mirror and reverse mirror</li>
<li>lots of protocols, including fish (thought <code>mc</code> is better for that)</li>
<li>bookmarks! (hey it's interactive!)</li>
<li><strong>lots</strong> of standard Unix commands on remote that normal FTP clients don't
have
<ul>
<li>cat, more, zcat, zmore, chmod, find, mv</li>
</ul></li>
<li>standard <code>/etc/lftp.conf</code> has some nice stuff like <code>edit</code></li>
</ul>

<h4>cons</h4>

<ul>
<li>only good for straight URLs; browser emulation type stuff is better left
to curl</li>
<li>simple fish type stuff is better with MC</li>
</ul>

<h4>tricks</h4>

<ul>
<li><p>lftp can't do curl-like sequences and lists, but you can trick it using
it's own eval and source commands and my map command; see my .lftprc for a
lovely alias!  Briefly:</p>

<pre><code># starts one job with all URLs in it
source -e echo queue get junk{1,2,3}; jobs
# starts many jobs with one URL each
source -e map \"echo queue get\" junk{1,2,3}; jobs
</code></pre>

<p>The order of the keywords <code>source</code>, <code>echo</code>, and <code>queue</code> is
important.  And remember bash doesn't 0-pad numbers, so you can't easily
do {01..15} -- it ends up the same as {1..15}</p></li>
<li><p>want to start a download at 3am but don't want to use cron?  Put these in
a file and run it with <code>lftp -f</code>.  Yes, you need that second command
in that list :-)</p>

<pre><code>queue stop
queue queue stop
# sequence of lcd/cd/"queue get" commands
at 03:00 -- queue start &amp;
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>don't forget to do something like this</p>

<pre><code>set parallel 4          # affects non-interactive jobs, like scripts
set queue-parallel 4    # probably more useful
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3>details</h3>

<h4>typical usage</h4>

<pre><code>lftp site
lftp -u user[,pass] site
lftp -d # for debug mode
lftp -e "run these commands; stay connected"
lftp -c "run these commands; exit
lftp -p 12345 sftp://sitaram@1.2.3.4
</code></pre>

<h4>multiple files and mirrors</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>get</code> can specify multiple files, <code>mget</code> for globs</li>
<li><code>-c</code> is for resume/continue</li>
<li><code>-d</code> in mget/mput uses full source name on dest instead of just
putting the file in current directory</li>
<li><p><code>pget [-n N]</code> command to get a file in parallel (default 5)</p>

<ul>
<li>pget also has <code>-c</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>built-in mirror or mirror -R (reverse mirror) commands</p>

<ul>
<li>not as efficient as rsync of course :-)</li>
<li>but can use parallel mode to xfr several files in parallel!</li>
<li>needs <code>set list-options -a</code> to get dot-files</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>mirror supports lots of options: try help.  Some stuff not in help but may
work:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>--only-missing</code>, <code>--only-existing</code></li>
<li><code>--no-symlinks</code></li>
<li><code>--older-than</code> (like <code>--newer-than</code>)
<em>*</em> (timespec for this is a filename or like for the "at" command)</li>
<li><code>--parallel N</code> (N parallel file xfrs)
<em>*</em> the short form <code>-P</code> doesn't seem to work</li>
<li><code>--loop</code> (keep doing it until no changes found)</li>
<li><code>-a</code> (archive mode; see man page)</li>
<li><code>-I</code> and <code>-X</code> (include/exclude glob patterns)</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>It also supports stuff relating to timestamps, modes, suid/sgid bits, etc.</p></li>
</ul>

<h4>job control</h4>

<p>As close to integrating shell concepts into an ftp client as possible!!</p>

<ul>
<li><code>&amp;</code> for backgrounding</li>
<li><code>(...; ...)</code> &amp; for group backgrounding</li>
<li><code>^Z</code> and <code>fg</code> like in shell for moving jobs to/from bg</li>
<li><code>at</code> command!</li>
<li><code>jobs</code> command</li>
<li>can nohup itself if needed</li>
<li>pipe to any external command</li>
<li><code>&amp;&amp;</code> and <code>||</code> for conditional execution</li>
<li><code>kill</code> too!</li>
<li><code>queue</code> command to queue commands for same server; will remember
correct directory for different queued commands so don't queue up 'cd' or
'lcd' commands</li>
<li><code>repeat</code> looks cool when you need it</li>
</ul>

<h5>Examples</h5>

<pre><code>lftp&gt; cat file | gzip &gt; file.gz
lftp&gt; get file &amp;
lftp&gt; (cd /path &amp;&amp; get file) &amp;
</code></pre>

<h4>Other features and notes</h4>

<ul>
<li>"hftp" is what they call ftp over http proxy</li>
<li>slots: rather like tabs in firefox? (use alt-0 through alt-9)</li>
<li>"debug 3" if you want to see greeting messages</li>
<li>lftp expects a DIRECTORY URL; use lftpget for file URLS</li>
<li><p>there's no "lftpmget"; use something like this for command line mget:</p>

<pre><code>`lftp -c 'open -e "mget patt*" ftp.site/dir/subdir'`
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>"set list-options -a" to mirror dot-files also</p></li>
<li>"ls -R" is fine, but in the rare case you dont have it, use "find"</li>
<li>put a bunch of commands in a script and use "lftp -f script"</li>
<li>rate limiting for each connection or all together</li>
<li>a HUGE number of variables -- see man page
<ul>
<li><code>set limit-rate downrate:uprate</code> in Bps and <code>limit-total-rate</code>
(all connections)</li>
<li>also <code>limit-max</code> and <code>limit-total-max</code> limit accumulation of
unused limit (like squid delay pools recharging when quiet)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Quick photo sharpening tip</h1>

<ul>
<li>When you are ready to sharpen your photo (sharpening should be your very
last step), flatten all layers.</li>
<li>Duplicate the remaining layer.</li>
<li>Sharpen the top layer to get the best result possible.</li>
<li>Now grab the eraser and simply brush away any problem areas that have been
over-sharpened. The bottom, unsharpened layer will show through in those
spots. If your photo editor supports it, you can even erase those areas
with partial opacity to customize the amount of sharpening.</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="procps_psmisc_and_systat">procps, psmisc, and systat</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#procps_psmisc_and_systat">procps, psmisc, and systat</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#cheap_tricks">cheap tricks</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#ps">ps</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#free">free</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#fuser">fuser</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#the_w_command">the "w" command</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#pwdx">pwdx</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#pgrep_and_pkill">pgrep and pkill</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#pstree">pstree</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#the_real_masala_the_stat_commands">the real masala -- the "stat" commands</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#terminology">terminology</a><br>
