&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#system_wide">system-wide</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#pid_wise">pid-wise</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="cheap_tricks">cheap tricks</a></h3>

<h4><a name="ps">ps</a></h4>

<p>We favour BSD style; less typing overall, more consistent, etc.</p>

<p>What processes to select:</p>

<pre><code>ps U ff                 # by user
ps t 4                  # by tty, /dev/pts/4
ps t tty4               # by tty, /dev/tty4
ps pid1 pid2            # by pid
ps -C command           # by command name
    # for partial command name, use "pgrep comm | xargs ps"
ps ax                   # abso-bloody-lutely all
</code></pre>

<p>What info to print for selected processes</p>

<pre><code># 3 mutually exclusive formats:
ps l                    # long format (much better than "j"ob control format)
ps u                    # user format
ps v                    # VM format

ps e                    # show ENV after command
ps f                    # ascii art forest
ps w                    # wide output; use twice for unlimited width
</code></pre>

<p>what do the codes mean?</p>

<pre><code>D   Deep sleep (uninterruptible; usually IO)
R   Running or Runnable
S   Sleep
T   sTopped or Traced
Z   Zombie

L   Locked some pages into memory
N   Nice
&lt;   not nice

+   is in the foreground process group
l   is multi-threaded
s   session leader
</code></pre>

<p>custom format spec</p>

<pre><code>o lstart                # gives you a long start time
</code></pre>

<p>ps fo pid,ppid,tty,start,etime,time,ni,%cpu,%mem,rss:8,vsz:8,rtprio,user,group,f,stat,psr=CPU#,wchan,args</p>

<h4><a name="free">free</a></h4>

<pre><code>free -s 5   # can poll
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="fuser">fuser</a></h4>

<pre><code>fuser -m /mount/point   # any file on the mounted device
fuser -k some.file      # kill
fuser -n tcp 22
fuser 22/tcp
# other options: -u for username, -v for verbose
</code></pre>

<p><code>fuser -h</code> is brief but complete enough.  The only thing missing is that
<code>fuser 22/tcp</code> is short for <code>fuser -n tcp 22</code>.</p>

<h4><a name="the_w_command">the "w" command</a></h4>

<pre><code>...has a `-f` option to show where the user came from, unless it is
already shown by default, in which case it toggles (what a pain for
scripting!)
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="pwdx">pwdx</a></h4>

<pre><code>This is an **awesome** command that tells you the pwd for a PID or list of
PIDs.  Yes you can get the same using `lsof -p PID` and grepping for
'cwd' but this is so much easier :-)
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="pgrep_and_pkill">pgrep and pkill</a></h4>

<p>normally, matches the command name or part of it and prints just the pid</p>

<ul>
<li>"-f" says the whole command line is used to find a match</li>
<li>"-x" exact matches only (no partial matches)</li>
<li>"-l" will print the command name (or command line if "-f")</li>
<li>"-u user" to limit to that user</li>
<li>"-v" to negate the matching</li>
<li>"-n" or "-o" to select newest or oldest among matched proceses</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="pstree">pstree</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><code>pstree --haulp</code> is the most comprehensive one</li>
<li><code>pstree --haulpG|less -r</code> retains the ANSI line drawing stuff</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="the_real_masala_the_stat_commands">the real masala -- the "stat" commands</a></h3>

<h4><a name="terminology">terminology</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><strong>iowait</strong> usually means you're IO-bound, though on a desktop it could
mean you're not multitasking at all</li>
<li><strong>steal</strong> happens on VMs only; (need to look at it more later)</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="system_wide">system-wide</a></h4>

<h5>iostat</h5>

<ul>
<li>best general purpose tool in this category</li>
<li><code>-m -p -x</code> is best option combo</li>
<li><code>-x</code> gives you a lot more detail on disk activity
<ul>
<li>rrqm/s (wrqm/s) are read (write) requests merges per second</li>
<li>r/s and w/s are the number of requests that actually went to the disk</li>
<li>(not sure what "number of requests actually received" is; most likely
sum of these two)</li>
<li>avgrq-sz is in sectors</li>
<li>await and svctm are averages, in milliseconds, and await is svctm +
time in queue</li>
<li>if await - svctm > a few milliseconds, and utilisation is nowhere near
100%, it could be because of bursty, simultaneous, requests and a
longish interval.  A long, quiet, period within the measurement
interval reduces the utilisation % but doesn't affect the await
figures.  This basically means your application is too bursty and might
benefit from some internal optimisation (like readahead)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h5>mpstat</h5>

<ul>
<li>better than <code>iostat -c</code> only if
<ul>
<li>you need per-cpu reports (<code>mpstat -P ALL</code>)</li>
<li>or you need %irq, %soft(irq), and intr/s</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h5>vmstat</h5>

<ul>
<li><code>-d</code> is bad; use iostat for IO stats instead</li>
<li>default mode shows you
<ul>
<li># procs waiting to run, and # blocked</li>
<li>the usual memory stuff</li>
<li>swapin, swap out /s</li>
<li>blocks in, out /s</li>
<li>interrupts, context switches /s</li>
<li>the usual CPU stuff</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>-a</code> gets you something called "active/inactive" memory (???)
<ul>
<li>from <a href="http://www.linuxplanet.com/linuxplanet/tutorials/6593/1/">http://www.linuxplanet.com/linuxplanet/tutorials/6593/1/</a> it seems
that active pages are in-use, and inactive pages can be dirty or clean;
a clean inactive page is ready for re-use if needed</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="pid_wise">pid-wise</a></h4>

<h5>pidstat</h5>

<ul>
<li>never knew of this one in the old days :-)</li>
<li>gets you all the info you need for a specific PID (<code>-p PID</code> or <code>-C
part.of.cmdname</code>) as opposed to the whole system; could be very useful</li>
<li>the output format sucks if you combine options</li>
<li><code>-u</code> user/system/total</li>
<li><code>-d</code> IO reads/writes in KB/s</li>
<li><code>-r</code> minor/major page faults, total/resident sizes</li>
<li><code>-w</code> voluntary and involuntary context switches</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Firefox - Tips &amp; Tricks</h1>

<p><sup>from <a href="http://www.supernova00.biz/userchrome.html">http://www.supernova00.biz/userchrome.html</a></sup></p>

<ul>
<li><p>userChrome tips: edit <code>userChrome.css</code> inside
<code>.mozilla/firefox/j373sz6c.default/chrome/</code></p>

<pre><code>/* Add a keyword when adding a bookmark */
#keywordRow { display: -moz-grid-line !important; }

/* Remove Stop button when there's nothing to Stop */
#stop-button[disabled="true"] { display: none; }

/* Remove Back button when there's nothing to go Back to */
#back-button[disabled="true"] { display: none; }

/* Remove Forward button when there's nothing to go Forward to */
#forward-button[disabled="true"] { display: none; }

/* Make the active tab not bold */
tab[selected="true"] { font-weight: normal !important; }

/* Make inactive tabs hardly visible */
#content tab:not([selected="true"]) { -moz-opacity: 0.5 !important; }
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<p><sup>[from a post on the TW list...]</sup></p>

<ul>
<li>reduce working memory when browser is minimized
<ul>
<li>add new boolean <code>config.trim_on_minimize</code> value <code>true</code></li>
<li>apart from reducing memory usage on minimise, it also seems that after
you restore the browser window, it appears to use significantly less
memory than before (though more than when minimized), plus <strong>run a bit
quicker after a minimize/restore</strong>, especially if it has been running
all day with an actively edited TW document.</li>
<li>maybe because of some <em>global</em> garbage collection process that runs when
minimised?</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>#FindToolbar &gt; * {display: -moz-box; }</code>
<ul>
<li>makes <code>/</code> or <code>'</code> eqvt to <code>Ctrl-F</code> in terms of what comes up on screen</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Choosing between the gzip, bzip2, and lzma compression programs</h1>

<p>LZMA is the new kid on the block: less space and faster decompression (than
BZIP2) at the cost of much, <strong>much</strong> slower compressions.</p>

<p>(Default compression levels are GZIP: 6, BZIP2: 9, and LZMA: 7)</p>

<h3>Summary</h3>

<ul>
<li><p>Use none when</p>

<ul>
<li>almost all files in the dataset are already compressed (DUH!)</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Use GZIP when</p>

<ul>
<li>time is more important than space, or</li>
<li>system memory is very limited, or</li>
<li>a lot of files in the dataset are already compressed but nowhere near
all of them</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Use LZMA when</p>

<ul>
<li>space is more important than time, or</li>
<li>space is important AND the file will be decompressed many times</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Benchmark BZIP2, LZMA-1 and perhaps LZMA-2 when</p>

<ul>
<li>both space AND (compression) time are important, and</li>
<li>you're going to be compressing this same dataset frequently (like a
daily backup script for your email folders)</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>Otherwise just use BZIP2</p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Comparision between EEE, OLPC, and Classmate</h1>

<p><sup>from
http://reviews.zdnet.co.uk/hardware/notebooks/0,1000000333,39359143,00.htm
warning: one photo per page, too many mouse clicks needed, and <em>JS needed</em></sup></p>

<p>Let's face it, just from the size aspect, the EEE wins hands down.  Even over
the EEE!</p>

<ul>
<li>EEE is the smallest of the lot</li>
<li>OLPC has the best screen (as if this was news!)</li>
<li>OLPC doesn't have a fan (hopefully the EEE will follow suit soon)</li>
<li>EEE is the only one with a VGA connector (yeay!!!)</li>
<li>Classmate looks like the pregnant mother of the other two!
<ul>
<li>and the EEE is soooo slim -- always loved the slim ones :-)</li>
<li>see comment at the start!</li>
</ul></li>
<li>EEE has the <strong>largest</strong> keyboard, even though it is the smallest of the 3.
<ul>
<li>God is actually talking to me here and telling me which to buy :-)</li>
<li>or at least which to drool over!</li>
<li>UPDATE: bought it for my son; he loves it</li>
</ul></li>
<li>my wife would love the OLPC keyboard</li>
<li>OLPC screen is really the largest by far!</li>
<li>Classmate is very hard to get into (motherboard)</li>
<li>EEE comes with 512 MB RAM (as opposed to 256 on the other 2)</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Advanced (policy) Routing</h1>

<h3>Using rules</h3>

<pre><code>$ ip rule list
0:  from all lookup 255 
32766:  from all lookup main 
32767:  from all lookup default
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>main</code> is the table that "ip route ls" shows by default.</p>

<p>The idea is to generate rules to point to different tables to override
system-wide routing rules.</p>

<pre><code>echo 200 John &gt;&gt; /etc/iproute2/rt_tables
ip rule add from 10.11.12.13 table John
ip rule ls
ip route add default via 61.11.49.11 dev eth0 table John
ip route flush cache
</code></pre>

<p>Notes:</p>

<ul>
<li>you could have simply used 200 all over instead of "John", but using a
name helps to document the fact that 10.11.12.13 is John's IP and this is
how we will route him.</li>
<li>the <code>ip route flush cache</code> is not derivable from <code>ip route help</code>
so remember the command; it is needed for this sort of stuff to work</li>
</ul>

<h3>Additional syntax</h3>

<pre><code>ip route add 1.2.3.4/16 dev ppp1 src ip.of.dev.ppp1
</code></pre>

<p>this <code>src</code> part is new to me; it makes sure the right <em>outgoing</em> IP address is
chosen -- more complex example can be found in the "Linux Advanced Routing and
Traffic Control HOWTO"</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Unix sort</h1>

<p>Unix sort not working as you expect?</p>

<ul>
<li>get into the habit of using <code>-k 2,2</code> instead of <code>-k 2</code>, because
the latter actually means <code>-k 2,&lt;endofline&gt;</code></li>
<li>this is especially true when #2 is a numeric key, as in <code>-k 2,2n</code></li>
<li>by default, the field sep is the empty string between a non-blank and a
blank, so it's like all keys are "right justified".  To ignore leading
blanks, use <code>-b</code>.  You can apply <code>-b</code> to a single key spec or the
whole command.</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>lsof tricks</h1>

<p><sup>from <a href="http://0xfe.blogspot.com/2006/03/troubleshooting-unix-systems-with-lsof.html">http://0xfe.blogspot.com/2006/03/troubleshooting-unix-systems-with-lsof.html</a></sup></p>

<p>horribly formatted article, and right now DNS cant find the site, but mainly:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>lsof +L1</code> -- deleted but open files!</li>
<li><code>lsof -i [TCP|UDP] [@host|ipaddr]:22</code> -- who's using ssh?</li>
<li><code>lsof /dev/hda1</code> -- when umount fails with "device is busy"</li>
<li><code>lsof +D /tmp</code> -- recurse directories</li>
</ul>

<p>default param is a file system name like <code>/home</code>; when used, it will list
all processes using ANY file in that FS</p>

<ul>
<li><code>lsof +f</code> -- name treat name like a file system even if it looks like
a simple file</li>
<li><p><code>lsof -f</code> -- name treat name like a simple file even if it is a file
system (for example when you really want to know who opened "/")</p></li>
<li><p><code>lsof +d dirname</code> -- looks at dir and first level files</p></li>
<li><code>lsof +D dirname</code> -- recurses, and is SLOW</li>
<li><code>lsof -p pid1,pid2...</code> -- files for proc(s) in list</li>
<li><code>lsof -t</code> -- terse list of PIDs for killing etc.</li>
<li><code>lsof -w uid,uname,...</code> -- files for user(s) listed</li>
<li><code>lsof -c mpg</code> -- all procs whose names start with mpg; regexes allowed
if delimited by slashes</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Getting started with GRUB</h1>

<p>Boot From a USB drive using GRUB</p>

<pre><code>mkdir /mnt/usb
mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/usb
</code></pre>

<p>(The example below uses the e2fs stage file, which corresponds to the ext2
filesystem.  If sda1 has fat, get that instead...)</p>

<pre><code>mkdir /mnt/usb/grub
cp /boot/grub/stage* /boot/grub/e2fs_stage1_5 /mnt/usb/grub/
umount /mnt/usb
</code></pre>

<p>The final step is to install a master boot record on the drive, using the
GRUB shell.</p>

<pre><code>grub
grub&gt; device (hd0) /dev/sda
grub&gt; root (hd0,0)
grub&gt; setup (hd0)
grub&gt; quit
</code></pre>

<blockquote>
  <p>(Change <code>sda</code> to suit...)</p>
</blockquote>

<ul>
<li>device tells GRUB what disk device to use when processing commands.</li>
<li>root sets the default partition that GRUB will use to boot from. This is
the partition where the stage files were copied to. GRUB starts counting
at 0, not 1.</li>
<li>setup creates the MBR on the USB drive.</li>
</ul>

<p>At this point GRUB is installed, and you should be able to boot the USB disk
drive. When you do so, you should get dumped directly into the GRUB shell when
the machine is booted. For information on what you can do with the command
shell, review the <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/manual/html_node/Command_002dline-and-menu-entry-commands.html">GRUB command-line
documentation</a>
or try typing 'help'</p>

<p><sup>Source: <a href="http://www.linux.com/article.pl?sid=07/06/04/141244">http://www.linux.com/article.pl?sid=07/06/04/141244</a></sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>dig notes</h1>

<p>Best .digrc seems to be</p>

<pre><code>+short
+noshort
+answer
+additional
+authority
</code></pre>

<p>Surprisingly, a noshort following a short gives you just what you want
compared to any other combo!</p>

<h3>"Dug" a little deeper</h3>

<p>...pardon the pun!  <code>+short</code> seems to act like <code>+nocomm +nostat +nocmd
+noadditional +noquestion</code>, and maybe a few more such 'no's besides.  After
that the <code>+noshort</code> goes in and enables only the ttl etc...</p>

<p>That is, a</p>

<pre><code>dig +nocomm +nostat +nocmd +noadditional +noquestion domain.to.search
</code></pre>

<p>seems to give the same output as having that <code>.digrc</code> you see above.</p>

<h3>Common Usages</h3>

<p>You can use these abbreviations if you like</p>

<pre><code>+tra[ce]
+ns[ssearch]
+id[entify]
+co[mments]
+st[ats]
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>curl</h1>

<h3>quick start</h3>

<h4>pros</h4>

<ul>
<li>great docs, esp <code>curl -M</code></li>
<li>lots of features for http/s type stuff
<ul>
<li>lists and sequences, byte ranges</li>
<li>browser emulation like cookies, following redirects, sending forms, etc.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4>cons</h4>

<ul>
<li>strictly batch; needs a file URL not a dir URL</li>
<li>for scp/ssh/sftp type stuff, lftp/rsync/scp are much better; this one is
much more cumbersome -- doesn't use ssh-agent or .ssh/config</li>
<li>no recursion, parallel downloads, metalink support, or job control</li>
</ul>

<h3>details</h3>

<h4>curl URLs</h4>

<ul>
<li>conform to RFC 3986</li>
<li>use <code>-o file</code> or <code>-O</code> to specify where output should go (default
is stdout)
<ul>
<li>you can have one of these options for each URL given</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>(COOL!) can use lists and sequences, sequences can have a step counter,
but you must use <code>-O</code> or <code>-o</code></p>

<pre><code>curl -o "dir_#1/file_#2_#3.txt" http://any.org/archive[1-19]/vol[01-04]/part{a,b,c}.html
curl -O http://www.letters.com/file[a-z:2].txt
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>give multiple URLs on the same command to get multiple files efficiently
(reuses connection)</p></li>
<li><code>-L</code> follows redirected URLs</li>
</ul>

<h4>auth, proxies, proxy auths, and SSL</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-x proxyserver:3128</code> or set <code>ALL_PROXY</code></li>
<li>you can also set <code>http_proxy</code>, <code>https_proxy</code>, <code>ftp_proxy</code></li>
<li><code>-U proxyuser[:proxypass]</code></li>
<li><code>-u user[:pass]</code> for server
<ul>
<li>or use <code>-n</code> and <code>~/.netrc</code> containing a line like machine host.dom login
me password whatever</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>-k</code> lets you use insecure SSL certs (like ultimatix!)</li>
<li>(COOL!) (BUT DOESNT SEEM TO WORK!!) <code>-p</code> allows proxy tunnels</li>
</ul>

<h4>received headers, verbosity, trouble shooting, etc</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-C -</code> to resume/continue a transfer</li>
<li><code>-D file</code> to dump headers; can be "-" for stdin</li>
<li><p><code>-I</code> for HEAD, and <code>-i</code> for HEAD+GET</p></li>
<li><p><code>-V</code> to see what features are compiled in</p></li>
<li><code>-v</code> shows headers being sent and received, somewhat like <code>GET -USe</code></li>
<li><code>--trace -</code> is even more verbose</li>
</ul>

<h4>sent headers, cookies, etc</h4>

<ul>
<li>has cookie and jar support
<ul>
<li><code>-b "a=b; c=d"</code> or <code>-b file</code> where the "file" has plain HTTP
headers (perhaps dumped from <code>-D</code>); this file is only read, and you
can use it to seed curl with cookies from some other operation
elsewhere</li>
<li><code>-c cookiejar</code>; this file gets written to at the end, and can be
used with <code>-b cookiejar</code> on subsequent runs</li>
<li><code>-j</code> junk session cookies when reading cookies</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>-e REFERER-URL</code> </li>
<li><code>-A</code> to set user-agent header</li>
<li><code>-H "header: value"</code> adds, replaces, or removes (if you leave out the
stuff after the colon) headers</li>
<li><code>-r</code> sets a Range header
<ul>
<li>simple examples: 0-499, -500 (last 500 bytes), 999-</li>
<li>"0-0,-1" (first and last byte), "100-199,500-599", etc return multipart
responses if the web server supports it</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4>uploading files and data</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-d</code> POSTs data as application/x-www-form-urlencoded
<ul>
<li>must be URL-encoded</li>
<li>can be used multiple times (in which case curl will cat them with <code>&amp;</code>)</li>
<li><code>-d @file</code> for sending data from file; can be "-" for stdin</li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>-G</code> use GET instead of POST</li>
<li><p>also see <code>--data-urlencode</code> and <code>--data-binary</code></p></li>
<li><p><code>-F</code> POSTs data as multipart/form-data</p>

<ul>
<li>can upload binary files</li>
<li>can also specify content-type; see docs</li>
<li><p>some examples</p>

<pre><code>curl -F formfield=@file [...]
curl -F formfield=&lt;file [...]
# both "file"s can be "-" for stdin
</code></pre></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4>less important</h4>

<ul>
<li><code>-q</code> as the first parameter disables curlrc</li>
<li><code>-#</code> to get a progress bar instead of the normal display</li>
<li><code>--limit-rate 50k</code> limits average speed of the entire download,
meaning it can go higher to make up for slow periods if needed</li>
<li><code>-y N</code> and <code>-Y M</code>: abort if speed over the last N seconds is less
then M bytes/sec</li>
<li>abort if headers indicate file is larger than <code>--max-filesize</code></li>
<li><code>-m N</code> limits the whole job to N seconds</li>
<li><code>--retry</code>, <code>--retry-delay</code>, and <code>--retry-max-time</code></li>
<li><code>-z file/ts</code> to get only if remote is newer than file/timestamp; many
formats can be used for the timestamp</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>ImageMagick trick -- find photos with lots of "white" space</h1>

<pre><code>convert in.jpg -colors 2 -contrast-stretch 0 out.xpm
identify -verbose out.xpm | grep -A2 Histogram:
</code></pre>

<p>The ratio of the 2 values you see there should tell you how many pixels
were more light than dark.</p>

<p>This is not the same as picking out black-and-white shots; for that look
for "Colorspace: gray".</p>

<p>It is for picking out photos which have much more "light area" (even
off-white or cream) compared to dark area</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>wget</h1>

<p>unformatted...</p>

<pre><code>-r
    recursive

-nc
    MOST IMPORTANT ONE! (continue where you left off)

-np
    ALMOST as important!  "No Parent" sticks to given URL and child
    directories.

-w  seconds
    wait time between shots - be nice!

-P directory
    default is "."

-Q quota
    eg: -Q 2m limits total to 2MB.  Stops only at file boundaries - not in the
    middle of a file, so you may get more in practice...

-o|a logfile
    to overwrite/append
    default: screen

--spider
    check links

-i file
    read URLs from this file

-l depth
    dft 5

-A|R list
    comma-sep list of filename suffixes to accept/reject; of course HTML
    *must* be loaded...

-D domainlist
    comma-sep list of domains which are "worth" DNS-looking up (in wget's
    attempt to find alias hosts).  Domains not in this list will be rejected
    outright as possible candidates for being an alias of the host you started
    with.

    Along with -H, does something more complex - see info file node on domain
    acceptance.

--follow-ftp
    not the default when doing http - ftp files will be ignored unles you set
    this.

-k
    make relative links from non-relative ones after downloading (only for
    those which got here!)

-N
    honour timestamps and not get unchanged files
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>flickr by email</h1>

<p>Get a new "codeword" from <a href="http://www.flickr.com/account/uploadbyemail/">http://www.flickr.com/account/uploadbyemail/</a> (need
JS), then send email as follows:</p>

<pre><code>To: codeword@photos.flickr.com
Subject: short description of photo tags: onewordtag "one phrase tag"

body of email becomes description of photo
</code></pre>

<h2>Privacy in flickr</h2>

<p>My defaults (on sitaramc_f) are</p>

<ul>
<li>anyone can see</li>
<li>any flickr user can comment</li>
<li>and flickr user can add notes and tags</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>In short, DO NOT UPLOAD ANY PICTURES OF FAMILY OR FRIENDS!</strong></p>

<p>You can <strong>set non-default privacy</strong> by addressing the email to</p>

<pre><code>codeword+X@photos.flickr.com
</code></pre>

<p>where X can be</p>

<pre><code>friends
family
ff  # both
private # only you
public
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="all_about_bare_repos_what_why_and_how_to_fix_a_non_bare_push">all about "bare" repos -- what, why, and how to fix a non-bare push</a></h1>

<p><sup>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#all_about_bare_repos_what_why_and_how_to_fix_a_non_bare_push">all about "bare" repos -- what, why, and how to fix a non-bare push</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#what_is_a_bare_repo_">what is a bare repo?</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#yeah_yeah_but_why_do_I_need_a_bare_repo_">yeah yeah, but <strong>why</strong> do I need a bare repo?</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#how_do_I_fix_such_a_non_bare_push_">how do I fix such a non-bare push?</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#how_do_I_prevent_the_problem_from_happening_again_">how do I prevent the problem from happening again?</a><br></p>

<p></sup></p>

<hr />

<p><center>
<strong><em>Update for git 1.7.0 and above</em></strong>
</center></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>As of git 1.7.0, the default value for <code>receive.denyCurrentBranch</code> has
  changed from "warn" to "refuse".  As a result, on 1.7.0 and above, by
  default, you will not get into this sort of trouble.  However, this
  document is still useful as a detailed explanation of what precisely this
  problem is.  Just pretend, as you read along, that you're on a pre-1.7.0
  system or that someone set <code>receive.denyCurrentBranch</code> to "warn", "ignore"
  or 'false'.</p>
</blockquote>

<h3><a name="what_is_a_bare_repo_">what is a bare repo?</a></h3>

<p>A bare repository is a concept that is sort of unique to a Distributed VCS
like git (and, I presume, other such DVCSs like Hg/Bzr/etc also).</p>

<p>A normal git repository is a directory that contains</p>

<ul>
<li>project directories and files (the "working tree" mentioned above)</li>
<li>a single directory called <code>.git</code> containing all of git's
administrative and control files; we'll call it the <strong>magic</strong> directory
because git can't do any magic without it :-)</li>
</ul>

<p>When you do a <code>git status</code> inside such a directory, git looks inside the
"magic" directory, compares your current working tree with the "current
branch" as recorded in the magic directory, and tells you what files have
changed, etc etc.</p>

<p>A "bare" repo, as the git
<a href="http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/gitglossary.html">glossary</a>
says, is a repository that does not contain a "working tree" at all.  It
doesn't contain the special <code>.git</code> sub-directory either; instead, it
contains all the contents of the <code>.git</code> subdirectory right in the main
directory itself.</p>

<h3><a name="yeah_yeah_but_why_do_I_need_a_bare_repo_">yeah yeah, but <strong>why</strong> do I need a bare repo?</a></h3>

<p>ok; demo time...</p>

<p>Let's try creating a small repo, adding a file, committing, and checking
<code>git status</code>:</p>

<pre><code>mkdir a; cd a; git init
echo hi &gt; a;git add a; git commit -m a
git status
</code></pre>

<p>This should respond</p>

<pre><code># On branch master
# nothing to commit (working directory clean)
</code></pre>

<p>So far so good.  Now someone clones our repository, adds a new file, commits,
and pushes his changes back to our repository:</p>

<pre><code>cd ..;git clone a b
cd b; echo there &gt;&gt; b; git add b; git commit -m b
git push
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>git push</code> above sends your new commits to the "origin" repository.  More
specifically, it updates the "magic" directory on repo "a" with this new
commit.</p>

<p>Now you go back to the main repo and check <code>git status</code></p>

<pre><code>cd ../a
git status
</code></pre>

<p>which responds</p>

<pre><code># On branch master
# Changes to be committed:
#   (use "git reset HEAD &lt;file&gt;..." to unstage)
#
#       deleted:    b
</code></pre>

<p>Whoa!  What happened here?  We <strong>added</strong> a file called <code>b</code> in the cloned
repository and pushed to the "origin".  But your origin now claims you
<strong>deleted</strong> that file...?</p>

<p>To understand this, you need to realise that <strong>the "magic" directory is always
assumed to be correct</strong>; it is the "standard" against which your working tree
is compared to determine what changes you made in your working tree.</p>

<p>So when you asked for a status, git first looked inside the magic directory.
The magic directory said you should have two files, "a" and "b", but your work
tree has only file "a".  So <code>git status</code> concludes that you have deleted
the file "b"!</p>

<p>In other words, when someone changes the "magic" directory <strong>behind your
back</strong>, your locally checked out copy (your working tree) appears to have the
<strong>opposite</strong> changes made by you.</p>

<p>All this confusion can (and <em>should</em>) be avoided by using a "bare"
repository to clone and pull from, and push to.  It doesn't have a checked out
tree, so it just does what the "server" notionally does in a centralised VCS
-- records commits, branches, etc when you push to it, and gives you the
latest versions when you clone or pull from it.</p>

<h3><a name="how_do_I_fix_such_a_non_bare_push_">how do I fix such a non-bare push?</a></h3>

<p>If you did push into a non-bare repo, the first thing to do is make sure that
no one is working on that checked out work tree, and no local changes have
been made since the last checkout.</p>

<p>Once you've made sure of that, you should log onto that machine, cd to that
repo, and do this:</p>

<pre><code>git reset --hard HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>If you had local changes on that work tree, or you are not sure if you had
any, then you have a bit of a challenge.  There are ways to deal with it quite
nicely in git, but I haven't tried them yet.  Ideas:</p>

<ol>
<li><p>see if any of the HEADs in reflog match your current work tree exactly, in
which case you really do NOT have any local changes, and you can safely do
that reset.  Use <code>git reflog show your-branch-name</code> to find the topmost
commit after the most recent push or set of pushes (in case there were
more than one) and compare your work tree against that.</p>

<p>Let's say your reflog output looks like this:</p>

<pre><code>$ git reflog show master
fcbb5a7 master@{0}: push
e41b4ce master@{1}: push
6ef3360 master@{2}: commit: blah blah more blah
a48b324 master@{3}: commit: blah blah blah
48e4b98 master@{4}: commit (initial): first commit
</code></pre>

<p>As you can see, there were two "behind your back" pushes, and it is very
likely that master@{2} is the "base" for your current work tree.  So you
compare against that:</p>

<pre><code>$ git diff --stat --exit-code master@{2}
</code></pre>

<p>If there are no differences, you're probably OK to do that <code>git reset
--hard</code>.  If you're really paranoid, you'll check to make sure that
master@{2} is an ancestor of HEAD:</p>

<pre><code>git rev-list HEAD..master@{2}   # should be empty
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>anyway, if the diff above showed differences, you have a merge of some
sort coming up.  Here's what you do:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>make a temporary branch off that same commit</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -b temp master@{2}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>now you have two alternatives:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>The safe way: commit those changes.  If the work is not complete,
complete it -- you have all the time in the world now that you have
created a temp branch, and any number of pushes can now happen on
'master' without affecting you, since it isn't the checked out branch.</p></li>
<li><p>The quicker way: stash those changes using <code>git stash</code>.  I am 99% sure
stashing will work as well here, but would appreciate hearing from any
git.experts reading this (email me at sitaramc@gmail.com)</p></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>now checkout master and either merge temp or <code>git stash pop</code> depending
on which option you chose above; it's just a normal branch now!</p></li>
</ul></li>
</ol>

<h3><a name="how_do_I_prevent_the_problem_from_happening_again_">how do I prevent the problem from happening again?</a></h3>

<p>The best option is upgrade to git 1.7.0 or later!</p>

<p>If you cannot upgrade, and if you or others will continue to push into this
repo, you have to make it a bare repo.</p>

<p>To make it a "real" bare repo, just delete all the files except <code>.git</code>, then
<code>mv .git/* .; rmdir .git</code>.  Finally, edit the file called <code>config</code> and change
<code>bare = false</code> to <code>bare = true</code>.</p>

<p>If you're not comfortable playing with git at that level, there is another
alternative.  You may have guessed by now that you can make a non-bare repo
look like a bare repo for push purposes by creating and checking out a branch
that your users will not push to.  The entire repo does not have to be bare,
really...</p>

<p>So just run <code>git checkout -b DUMMY_BRANCH_DONT_USE</code> (or some such name) and
keep this branch checked out forever in this repo.  This is a cheap way to
make a non-bare repo into a bare repo for all practical purposes.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>Easy way to remember what git reset's soft/hard/mixed do</h1>

<p><sup>loosely based on <a href="http://gitster.livejournal.com/25150.html">http://gitster.livejournal.com/25150.html</a></sup></p>

<p>Assume you start from a "everything is committed and golden" state.  Let's
pretend you came to this starting point via a <code>git checkout</code>: and then you
edit a bunch of stuff, compile/test, and then <code>git add</code> and <code>git
commit</code>:</p>

<pre><code>$ git checkout mywork
...edit edit edit...
$ git add ...
$ git commit
</code></pre>

<p>If at this point you do a <code>git reset</code>, here's how the type of reset
("soft", "hard", or the default, which is "mixed") affects things:</p>

<pre><code>$ git checkout mywork
            # --hard resets to this point
...edit edit edit...
            # --mixed (default) resets to this point
$ git add ...
            # --soft resets to this point
$ git commit
</code></pre>

<p>Also note, as gitster says, that <code>git commit --amend</code> makes the <code>git
reset --soft</code> mostly redundant.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="terminology">terminology</a></h1>

<p><sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#terminology">terminology</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#general_VCS_terminology">general VCS terminology</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#git_specific_terminology">git-specific terminology</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#working_tree_repository_bare_repository">working tree, repository, bare repository</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#commits_SHAs">commits, SHAs</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#parent_commits_commit_tree">parent commits, commit tree</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#head_branch_tag">head, branch, tag</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#reachability">reachability</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#master_HEAD">master, HEAD</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#index">index</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#terminology_related_to_being_distributed_">terminology related to being "distributed"</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#clone_versus_checkout">clone versus checkout</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#accessing_remote_repositories">accessing remote repositories</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#naming_remote_repositories">naming remote repositories</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#what_is_a_bare_repository_">what is a "bare" repository?</a><br>
</sup></p>

<h3><a name="general_VCS_terminology">general VCS terminology</a></h3>

<p>A <strong>project</strong> is the minimum set of source code (and related files) that need
to be kept together to <strong>build</strong> the software.  Example: Linux</p>

<ul>
<li>each project will have one <strong>repository</strong></li>
<li>one <strong>team</strong> can work on multiple projects, so there could be multiple
repositories on each desktop</li>
</ul>

<p>A <strong>working tree</strong> or <strong>worktree</strong> is the <em>current</em> set of files that are
being worked on, tested, etc.</p>

<p>A <strong>branch</strong> in a project is an active line of development</p>

<ul>
<li><strong>master</strong> is the conventional name for the main development tree of a
project</li>
<li>other conventional branches are <strong>next</strong> (for code that is ready to come
into <em>main</em>), and various maintenance branches like <strong>v1.3</strong> or
<strong>v2.6.4</strong> to designate released versions</li>
<li>these are only conventions, not rules, but they seem to work well in
general</li>
<li>more detail about branches is in the next section</li>
</ul>

<p>A <strong>feature</strong> is a part of a project that is large and complex enough that
it's day-to-day commits would be too noisy to include in the main project.
Example: the disk subsystem, the networking subsystem, etc., in Linux</p>

<ul>
<li>a <strong>feature branch</strong> is a branch for a feature, and is usually long-lived.
This means it regularly acquires changes made in the main line, and -- at
stable points in its development cycle -- merges its changes back into the
main line</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="git_specific_terminology">git-specific terminology</a></h3>

<h4><a name="working_tree_repository_bare_repository">working tree, repository, bare repository</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>a <strong>working tree</strong> in git is the same as anywhere else.  When you edit,
compile, test, etc., it is your working tree files that are used</p></li>
<li><p>a normal <strong>repository</strong> in git consists of the working tree, plus <strong>one</strong>
extra directory at the root of the project tree (meaning at the top
directory of your project), called <code>.git</code>.  Inside this <code>.git</code> are a bunch
of files and directories which you need not worry about (and should not
mess with unless you know what you're doing)</p></li>
<li><p>a <strong>bare repository</strong> in git is a very special animal: it is a repository
<em>without</em> a working tree (so you cannot edit, compile, test etc., in it).
Central (or server) repos, meant only for people to push to and clone/pull
from, are usually bare.  Read more about it <a href="../concepts/bare.html">here</a>
if you like</p></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="commits_SHAs">commits, SHAs</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>a <strong>commit</strong> records the content of the project files at a point in time</p></li>
<li><p>every commit in git is represented by a globally unique 160-bit value (40
hex digits) which is a cryptographically secure hash of the commit data.
This is often called the <strong>SHA</strong> or SHA-1, after the algorithm used.</p>

<p><sup>"Globally unique" means no other commit in any other repository in any
other project anywhere in the world will have the same SHA.  You can
become very, very, famous in the cryptography world if you find two
different commits with the same SHA :-)</sup></p></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="parent_commits_commit_tree">parent commits, commit tree</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>every commit builds on top of one or more previous commits, called
<strong>parents</strong>.  Normal commits have only one parent, while "merge" commits
have two.  The very first commit in the tree has no parents; this is called
a "root commit".</p>

<p><sup>A repo can have more than one "root commit", but this is rare</sup></p></li>
<li><p>every commit records the SHAs of its parent(s).  It's as if every commit
has an arrow pointing to its parents, like a back pointer in a linked list</p>

<ul>
<li>thus, merge commits have two arrows pointing out</li>
<li>and a "fork" (where you created a new branch) has two or more arrows
pointing <strong>in</strong>, because it's the parent for more than one commit</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>as a result, the entire repo can look like a <strong>tree</strong>.  Strictly speaking,
this is a DAG -- or "directed acyclic graph".</p></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="head_branch_tag">head, branch, tag</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>a <strong>branch</strong> represents an active line of development; you use different
branches to track different lines of development.  Without branches,
working on multiple features or versions simultaneously would be a
nightmare!</p></li>
<li><p>in practice, a branch is a symbolic name that points to the most recent
commit on that line of development.  This "tip" commit is called the
<strong>head</strong> of that branch.</p>

<p>When you checkout a branch and make a new commit on it, the "branch" now
points to the <em>new</em> head node.  In other words, a branch is a pointer that
<em>moves as you make commits</em>.</p>

<p>A repository can track many branches, but the working tree is associated
with only one branch at a time</p></li>
<li><p>a <strong>tag</strong> is also a symbolic name given to a commit.  Tags don't "move" as
you make new commits -- they stay where they are.</p>

<p>Tags are used to mark specific milestones in a project, like "v1.3", or
"v2.9", etc.</p></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="reachability">reachability</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>you can start from a commit X and follow the parent SHAs ("arrows") until
you come to a root commit.  The commits you found in this process are all
said to be <strong>reachable</strong> from X</p></li>
<li><p>if you have commit X in some other repo, git guarantees that that repo
also has all these "reachable" commits.</p>

<p><sup>[If you know about grafts or shallow clones, you're too advanced to be
reading this document ;-)]</sup></p></li>
<li><p>when you merge a branch into the currently checked out branch, git uses
reachability to determine what commits to actually bring in.  All the
commits reachable from the branch being merged, which are not already
reachable from the current branch, are pulled in and applied</p></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="master_HEAD">master, HEAD</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><em>master</em>: default branch in a project (main development tree), by
convention</li>
<li><em>HEAD</em>: tip of the branch associated with the working tree; this is where
commits go.  Normally.  There is also something called a 'detached HEAD'
that you should be aware of.  See the article on the <a href="detached-head.html">detached
HEAD</a> for more.</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="index">index</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>a staging area for the next commit; when you commit, the current
index is turned into a real commit object</p></li>
<li><p>the <strong>index</strong> is also called <strong>stage</strong> or <strong>cache</strong></p></li>
<li><p><strong>staging</strong> a file (<code>git add file</code>) marks its <em>current</em> contents
  for inclusion in the next commit</p></li>
<li><p><strong>unstaging</strong> a file (<code>git reset file</code>, or in the case of a new
  file, <code>git rm --cached file</code>) undoes all staging since the last
  commit</p></li>
<li><p>the <strong>unstaged changes</strong> are the difference between index and
working tree (<code>git diff</code>)</p></li>
<li><p>the <strong>uncommitted but staged changes</strong> are the difference between
HEAD and index (<code>git diff --cached</code>)</p></li>
<li><p>see <a href="uses-of-index.html">uses of index</a> for the cool things you
can do with it</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="terminology_related_to_being_distributed_">terminology related to being "distributed"</a></h3>

<h4><a name="clone_versus_checkout">clone versus checkout</a></h4>

<p>In a <em>distributed</em> VCS, every developer's workstation has a full copy of the
entire repository.  It is therefore called a <strong>clone</strong> -- you <strong>clone</strong> the
remote repository, you don't merely <em>checkout</em> the latest version from it.</p>

<p>So where does <em>checkout</em> come in?  In git, you <strong>checkout</strong> a <em>branch</em> from
your local repo, so this happens <em>after</em> the clone.  Remember this is a full
repo, so you already have all the branches that the parent repo had when you
cloned.</p>

<p>By default, after the clone is done, git will <strong>checkout</strong> the same branch
that was currently checked out in the repository you're cloning from.
However, you can checkout some other branch at any time (and if you're using
git, you will checkout and manage multiple branches on your local repo all the
time, otherwise you're not really <em>using</em> git!)</p>

<h4><a name="accessing_remote_repositories">accessing remote repositories</a></h4>

<p>Every remote repository (often called just a <strong>remote</strong>) has a URL associated
with it, depending on how your local repo is able to reach it.  The simplest
URL is for a repo that is on the same machine, which can then use the <em>file</em>
protocol: <code>file:///home/sitaram/path/to/repo.git</code>.</p>

<p>Anonymous access (read-only) repositories can be grabbed using the <em>git</em>
protocol; for example, Linus Torvalds' version of the current Linux kernel is
at <code>git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux-2.6.git</code>.
Read-only repos can also use the HTTP protocol, although this is not as
efficient for continuous use.</p>

<p>A remote repository to which you have write access will almost certainly use
<em>ssh</em> as the underlying authentication protocol, so the remote URL might look
like <code>ssh://sitaram@172.1.7.2/full/path/to/repo.git</code>.</p>

<h4><a name="naming_remote_repositories">naming remote repositories</a></h4>

<p>You can refer to, (or fetch from, and push to) many remote repos in <em>your</em>
clone, because they all have different URLs.  After a while it gets
inconvenient to use the full URLs in your <code>git fetch</code> and <code>git push</code> commands,
so git allows you to give an easy to remember "nickname" for each "remote".  I
could, for instance, do this:</p>

<pre><code>git remote add sejal ssh://sitaram@sejal.herlab.ourcompany.com/path/to/repo.git
</code></pre>

<p>After this I could refer to the longer URL by the shortname "sejal" and it
would be the same thing.</p>

<h5>origin</h5>

<p>So now you know what a nickname is, you can understand what "origin" means.
"origin" is just the default name given to the remote repository when you do a
<code>git clone</code>.  So for example, if I do</p>

<pre><code>git clone ssh://sitaram@sejal.herlab.ourcompany.com/path/to/repo.git
</code></pre>

<p>then, after the clone completes, git automatically creates a remote with the
nickname <code>origin</code>, which points to
<code>ssh://sitaram@sejal.herlab.ourcompany.com/path/to/repo.git</code>.  It's just a
convenience thing.  You can delete that nickname, you can rename it to
something else, etc., if you like.</p>

<h4><a name="what_is_a_bare_repository_">what is a "bare" repository?</a></h4>

<p>This has been moved into it's <a href="bare.html">own page</a> now.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>what the heck is a <em>reflog</em> and why is it so important?</h1>

<h3>what is it</h3>

<ul>
<li><p>a reflog is a very special "branch" that records each position of HEAD
in the last 30 days (by default). So removed branches won't be purged by
prune until after waiting for 30 days, when the last reference to them
will finally be released.</p></li>
<li><p>reflog history is not shared -- it is exclusive to your repository.  This
is the only thing you lose if you clone a project as a means of performing
a backup.</p></li>
</ul>

<h3>how do I visualise it</h3>

<ul>
<li><p>the basic reflog commands are like this (the relative date is my
preference; see <code>git help log</code> for other choices)</p>

<pre><code># activity on HEAD, including timestamp
git reflog show --date=relative
# same, on some_branch
git reflog show --date=relative some_branch
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>a good way to visualise the reflog is <code>git show-branch -g</code> (or <code>-gN</code>,
where N is some integer).  This shows reflog info for the branch specified
(defaulting to the current branch), including topological relationships
and relative time.  This is useful if you had a lot of rebases or amended
commits and you think you might need one of them back :-)</p>

<p>It takes a little getting used to, so here're some hints:</p>

<ul>
<li>the top of each vertical line represents a prior position of HEAD (or
whatever branch you specified), with the latest one being the extreme
left column</li>
<li>for each commit, the non-blank commit vertically below is its parent
commit (merge commits are represented by a "-" sign)</li>
<li>so when you see a dip in the "line of peaks", you know there was a
reset to something earlier followed by a new set of commits</li>
<li>very likely, the top commit to the right of any such "dip" is probably
unreachable</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h3>why would I need it</h3>

<ul>
<li><p>I particularly like setting</p>

<pre><code>git config --global core.logAllRefUpdates true
git config --global receive.denyDeletes true
</code></pre>

<p>on bare repositories so that even if an over-zealous team member
force-pushes a bad revision, the reflog on the server will let me find the
previous (good) revisions easily</p></li>
<li><p>you can recover commits made on a detached head: see
<a href="../concepts/detached-head.html#Auld_Lang_Syne">this</a></p></li>
<li><p>you can fix a non-bare push: see
<a href="../concepts/bare.html#how_do_I_fix_such_a_non_bare_push_">this</a></p></li>
</ul>

<h3>cool tricks</h3>

<p><a href="../tools/git-reflogk">Here</a>'s a neat tool that shows you reflog output but
using gitk -- the graphical viewer.  Don't knock it until you've tried it :-)</p>

<hr />

<p><sup>based on a comment in <a href="http://blogs.gnome.org/newren/2007/11/24/local-caching-a-major-distinguishing-difference-between-vcses/">http://blogs.gnome.org/newren/2007/11/24/local-caching-a-major-distinguishing-difference-between-vcses/</a> </sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="Why_the_index_staging_area_is_so_useful">Why the index/staging area is so useful</a></h1>

<p><sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Why_the_index_staging_area_is_so_useful">Why the index/staging area is so useful</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#what_is_the_index">what is the index</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#staging_helps_you_split_up_one_large_change_into_multiple_commits">staging helps you split up one large change into multiple commits</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#staging_helps_in_reviewing_changes">staging helps in reviewing changes</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#staging_helps_when_a_merge_has_conflicts">staging helps when a merge has conflicts</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#staging_helps_you_keep_extra_local_files_hanging_around">staging helps you keep extra local files hanging around</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#staging_helps_you_sneak_in_small_changes_">staging helps you sneak in small changes ;-)</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#a_word_of_warning_">a word of warning...</a><br></p>

<p>[Also see <a href="../tips/1-vc-habits.html">good version control habits</a> for more on
a related topic.]</p>

<p></sup></p>

<hr />

<blockquote>
  <p>Newcomers to git often ask why there is such a thing as the index, and
    what use is it.  They'd rather just do <code>git add -A; git commit</code> each time
    to avoid thinking about the index at all, because it seems like one extra
    (and needless) complication.</p>

<p>So... what use is this, apart from confusing you with multiple names like
    index, staging area, and cache?</p>
</blockquote>

<h3><a name="what_is_the_index">what is the index</a></h3>

<p>The index (or any of its other names) is essentially a "holding area" for
changes that will be committed when you next do <code>git commit</code>.  That is, unlike
other VCSs, a "commit" operation does not simply take the current working tree
and check it as-is into the repository.  The index allows you to control what
parts of the working tree go into the repository on the next "commit"
operation.</p>

<p>That should be sufficient background to appreciate (in abstract terms) the
following discussion.</p>

<h3><a name="staging_helps_you_split_up_one_large_change_into_multiple_commits">staging helps you split up one large change into multiple commits</a></h3>

<p>Let's say you worked on a large-ish change, involving a lot of files and quite
a few different subtasks.  You didn't actually commit any of these -- you were
"in the zone", as they say, and you didn't want to think about splitting up
the commits the right way just then.  (And you're smart enough not to make the
whole thing on honking big commit!)</p>

<p>Now the change is all tested and working, you need to commit all this
properly, in several clean commits each focused on one aspect of the code
changes.</p>

<p>With the index, just stage each set of changes and commit until no more
changes are pending.  Really works well with <code>git gui</code> if you're into that
too, or you can use <code>git add -p</code> or, with newer gits, <code>git add -e</code>.</p>

<h3><a name="staging_helps_in_reviewing_changes">staging helps in reviewing changes</a></h3>

<p>Staging helps you "check off" individual changes as you review a complex
commit, and to concentrate on the stuff that has not yet passed your review.
Let me explain.</p>

<p>Before you commit, you'll probably review the whole change by using <code>git
diff</code>.  If you stage each change as you review it, you'll find that you can
concentrate better on the changes that are not yet staged.</p>

<p><code>git gui</code> is great here.  It's two left panes show unstaged and staged changes
respectively, and you can move files between those two panes
(stage/unstage) just by clicking on the icon to the left of the filename.</p>

<p>Even better, you can even stage <em>partial changes</em> to a file.  In the right
pane of <code>git gui</code>, right click on a change that you approve of and choose
"stage hunk".  <em>Just that change</em> (not the entire file) is now staged; in
fact, if there are other, unstaged, changes in that same file, you'll find
that the file now appears on <em>both</em> top and bottom left panes!</p>

<p><sup>[Do remember, however, that if the change is really complex maybe you should
split it into multiple commits!]</sup></p>

<h3><a name="staging_helps_when_a_merge_has_conflicts">staging helps when a merge has conflicts</a></h3>

<p>When a merge happens, changes that merge cleanly are updated both in the
staging area as well as in your work tree.  Only changes that did not merge
cleanly (i.e., caused a conflict) will show up when you do a <code>git diff</code>,
or in the top left pane of <code>git gui</code>.</p>

<p>Again, this lets you concentrate on the stuff that needs your attention -- the
merge conflicts.</p>

<h3><a name="staging_helps_you_keep_extra_local_files_hanging_around">staging helps you keep extra local files hanging around</a></h3>

<p>Usually, files that should not be committed go into <code>.gitignore</code> or the
local variant, <code>.git/info/exclude</code>.</p>

<p>However, sometimes you want a local change to a file that cannot be excluded
(which is not good practice but can happen sometimes).  For example, perhaps
you upgraded your build environment and it now requires an extra flag or
option for compatibility, but if you commit the change to the Makefile, the
other developers will have a problem.</p>

<p>Of course you have to discuss with your team and work out a more permanent
solution, but right now, you <em>need</em> that change in your working tree to do
<em>any</em> work at all!</p>

<p>Another situation could be that you want a new local file that is temporary,
and you don't want to bother with the ignore mechanism.  This may be some test
data, a log file or trace file, or a temporary shell script to automate some
test... whatever.</p>

<p>In git, all you have to do is never to stage that file or that change.  That's
it.</p>

<h3><a name="staging_helps_you_sneak_in_small_changes_">staging helps you sneak in small changes ;-)</a></h3>

<p>Let's say you're in the middle of a somewhat large-ish change and you are told
about a very important bug that needs to be fixed asap.</p>

<p>The usual recommendation is to do this on a separate branch, but let's say
this fix is really just a line or two, and can be tested just as easily
without affecting your current work.</p>

<p>With git, you can quickly make and commit <em>only that change</em>, without
committing all the other stuff you're still working on.</p>

<p>Again, if you use <code>git gui</code>, whatever's on the bottom left pane gets
committed, so just make sure only that change gets there and commit, then
push!</p>

<h4><a name="a_word_of_warning_">a word of warning...</a></h4>

<p>While the first 3 use cases are perfectly legitimate and useful uses of the
index, this last example could be dangerous if you get carried away.  You
might end up committing something that is not tested <em>exactly</em>, because you
tested with the contents of the work tree, which is not the same as the index
that is being committed.</p>

<p>Of course, using a powerful DVCS does not absolve you from the responsibility
of thinking :-)  So if you want to be 100% sure, there is a simple way to test
only the staged code:</p>

<pre><code># stash away the changes to git-tracked files that you have not staged yet
git stash save --keep-index
# now do your tests on the exact stuff being committed
make; make test     # etc...
# when satisfied, commmit
git commit

# now bring the stashed changes back to continue normal work
git stash pop
</code></pre>

<p>If you need to understand how/why this works, <a href="mailto:sitaramc@gmail.com">ask
me</a>, otherwise just use it and be happy :-)</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="gardening_tips_grafting_branches">gardening tips -- grafting branches</a></h1>

<p><sup>[If you think the jokes are bad, you don't know me very well.  Clearly that
is <em>your</em> fault, not mine :-)]</sup></p>

<p><sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#gardening_tips_grafting_branches">gardening tips -- grafting branches</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#connecting_two_unrelated_lines">connecting two unrelated lines</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#breaking_a_line_into_two_">breaking a line into two...</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_and_joining_them_parallely_branch_merge_">...and joining them parallely (branch + merge)</a><br>
</sup></p>

<hr />

<p>Even people who consider themselves really good gardeners shy away from
grafting.  Wikipedia says "For successful grafting to take place, the vascular
cambium tissues of the stock and scion plants must be placed in contact with
each other. Both tissues must be kept alive until the graft has taken, usually
a period of a few weeks."  That sounds... difficult.</p>

<p>Fortunately, Grum on IRC explained to me that all that is bunkum in git.  Git
has no issues with tissues, and if Linus had to wait a few weeks for a graft
to "take", we'd still be at kernel level 2.2 or something.</p>

<p>So, here's the long and short of grafting in git.  Enjoy!  (And thank Grum
with a ++ next time you see him on #git!).</p>

<p>Note: The following description will use the word "line" to mean "a long chain
of commits with no branch or merge within it".  In <code>gitk --all</code>, it is
literally a straight line.</p>

<h3><a name="connecting_two_unrelated_lines">connecting two unrelated lines</a></h3>

<p>Let's say you have the following history, with two unrelated lines of
development (quite easily achieved by just fetching from some other repo that
has no common commits with yours!).</p>

<p><sup>(By the way, how can you tell they are unrelated?  Easy -- just look at the
break in the graph connector after "a1"!)</sup></p>

<pre><code>$ git log --graph '--pretty=tformat:%H %d %s %n'  --all
* 891f2a69544779e7f61a6ae2c213a3c2dc2957b1  (refs/heads/a-m) a3
|
* 6a5b7c3ba50f91630f71aeaa36e2926ea6ad42f4  a2
|
* bb1cd6894bf5a073a80fb67575adb504539fca86  a1

* b2ccb766b20061124010877b5c22e69015e0d076  (refs/heads/master) b3
|
* adec8003a1c14984a8c39fc796c1ccbac27048e0  b2
|
* c5e268659a39921d87d6d50d6d3c6eccd12f4916  b1
</code></pre>

<p>Suppose the two lines are actually of the same project, and you now want to
join them. You have decided that "b1" is the true root of the repository
(probably because that is the one that a couple of thousand people have
already cloned, and you can't change that chain ;-) and want to make the "a"
line a fork from the "b" line at the point "b1".</p>

<p>Just make a graft that says that "b1" is the parent of "a1"!  Of course you
have to use the full SHA1s, and this isn't one of the more user-friendly parts
of git, but:</p>

<pre><code>$ echo bb1cd6894bf5a073a80fb67575adb504539fca86 \
c5e268659a39921d87d6d50d6d3c6eccd12f4916 &gt; .git/info/grafts
</code></pre>

<p>So now the repo looks like this:</p>

<pre><code>$ git log --graph '--pretty=tformat:%H %d %s %n' --all
* 891f2a69544779e7f61a6ae2c213a3c2dc2957b1  (refs/heads/a-m) a3
|
* 6a5b7c3ba50f91630f71aeaa36e2926ea6ad42f4  a2
|
* bb1cd6894bf5a073a80fb67575adb504539fca86  a1
|
| * b2ccb766b20061124010877b5c22e69015e0d076  (refs/heads/master) b3
| |
| * adec8003a1c14984a8c39fc796c1ccbac27048e0  b2
|/
|
* c5e268659a39921d87d6d50d6d3c6eccd12f4916  b1
</code></pre>

<p>So far so good.  You've somehow made "a1" a child of "b1", but there's
something not quite right -- the adoption has merely been recorded on a wee
bit of notepaper, called <code>.git/info/grafts</code>.  That thing could get lost,
damaged, or whatever.  In fact, it won't even make it past a clone, leave
alone pushes and pulls.  You need to get a more formal adoption certificate,
on thick, strong, bond paper.  With the logo of the local something-or-other.
Maybe even laminated!</p>

<p>Here's how to apply for one from the district magistrate's office:</p>

<pre><code>git filter-branch --tag-name-filter cat -- --all
</code></pre>

<p>And now the repo looks like this:</p>

<pre><code>$ git log --graph '--pretty=tformat:%H %d %s %n' master a-m
* b2ccb766b20061124010877b5c22e69015e0d076  (refs/heads/master) b3
|
* adec8003a1c14984a8c39fc796c1ccbac27048e0  b2
|
| * f34c278dd638a8ade860aafb47bd7a5c8d79865b  (refs/heads/a-m) a3
| |
| * 92a7be0c15b242c8204ba86a4b5191d1492b1dd4  a2
| |
| * 941e144b19e7b0fadbd3bedc295d4e1f2441ed79  a1
|/
|
* c5e268659a39921d87d6d50d6d3c6eccd12f4916  b1
</code></pre>

<p>Observant people will note that the SHA1 hashes for all the "a" commits have
changed, which of course they will.  The SHA1 hash for a commit is derived
from all parent commits, the current tree for that commit, the commit message,
author/committor info, and the date/time.  Since the <code>filter-branch</code> command
has made the relationship <em>permanent</em>, the SHAs for the "a"s change.</p>

<p>Even <em>more</em> observant people will notice that in the previous diagram, the
"a"s are in a straight line and the "b"s are on a "branch", while in the next
diagram they have switched places.  Topologically that's irrelevant, so don't
worry about it.</p>

<p><sup>
The <em>most</em> observant people will notice that instead of <code>--all</code> I have now
passed <code>master a-m</code> (the actual branch names).  This is what you will see if
you do this with <code>--all</code>:</p>

<pre><code>$ g log --graph '--pretty=tformat:%H %d %s %n'  --all
* f34c278dd638a8ade860aafb47bd7a5c8d79865b  (refs/heads/a-m) a3
|
* 92a7be0c15b242c8204ba86a4b5191d1492b1dd4  a2
|
* 941e144b19e7b0fadbd3bedc295d4e1f2441ed79  a1
|
| * b2ccb766b20061124010877b5c22e69015e0d076  (refs/heads/master) b3
| |
| * adec8003a1c14984a8c39fc796c1ccbac27048e0  b2
|/
|
| * 891f2a69544779e7f61a6ae2c213a3c2dc2957b1  (refs/original/refs/heads/a-m) a3
| |
| * 6a5b7c3ba50f91630f71aeaa36e2926ea6ad42f4  a2
| |
| * bb1cd6894bf5a073a80fb67575adb504539fca86  a1
|/
|
* c5e268659a39921d87d6d50d6d3c6eccd12f4916  b1
</code></pre>

<p>That's an artifact of the <code>filter-branch</code> command and git's well-known
principle of making it very hard to lose data.  If you did not like the
filter-branch for some reason, you would just:</p>

<pre><code>git checkout a-m
git reset --hard original/refs/heads/a-m
</code></pre>

<p>But if everything worked out, and the new tree looks good, you would type,
<strong>very carefully</strong>:</p>

<pre><code>rm -rf .git/refs/original/
</code></pre>

<p>That's it!
</sup></p>

<h3><a name="breaking_a_line_into_two_">breaking a line into two...</a></h3>

<p>What other tricks can you get up to?</p>

<p>How about taking this:</p>

<pre><code>$ g log --graph '--pretty=tformat:%H %d %s %n'  --all
* cb479e433d0fa639c5738f9b26c0cd5ca0d1e1e7  (refs/heads/master) a9
|
* 0f127260fff51ad71d092788d5630b6bf0c4764f  a8
|
* fb9c6ac521e99216d0202d54d03800e2ebd1d3a4  a7
|
* 8e48f4975469c9c9c5de644eb8eff1e165241b09  a6
|
* 6071135a250f9870aa8211eb871b4ac5d8e7e585  (refs/heads/branch) a5
|
* 179fb20ebbe3d9381b8944cc53c1ef0b893f431d  a4
|
* 891f2a69544779e7f61a6ae2c213a3c2dc2957b1  a3
|
* 6a5b7c3ba50f91630f71aeaa36e2926ea6ad42f4  a2
|
* bb1cd6894bf5a073a80fb67575adb504539fca86  a1
</code></pre>

<p>and turning it into this:</p>

<pre><code>$ g log --graph '--pretty=tformat:%H %d %s %n'  --all
* cb479e433d0fa639c5738f9b26c0cd5ca0d1e1e7  (refs/heads/master) a9 at Sat Apr 11 17:20:21 IST 2009
|
* 0f127260fff51ad71d092788d5630b6bf0c4764f  a8 at Sat Apr 11 17:20:19 IST 2009
|
* fb9c6ac521e99216d0202d54d03800e2ebd1d3a4  a7 at Sat Apr 11 17:20:17 IST 2009
|
* 8e48f4975469c9c9c5de644eb8eff1e165241b09  a6 at Sat Apr 11 17:20:15 IST 2009

* 6071135a250f9870aa8211eb871b4ac5d8e7e585  (refs/heads/branch) a5 at Sat Apr 11 17:20:13 IST 2009
|
* 179fb20ebbe3d9381b8944cc53c1ef0b893f431d  a4 at Sat Apr 11 17:20:11 IST 2009
|
* 891f2a69544779e7f61a6ae2c213a3c2dc2957b1  a3 at Sat Apr 11 16:21:44 IST 2009
|
* 6a5b7c3ba50f91630f71aeaa36e2926ea6ad42f4  a2 at Sat Apr 11 16:21:42 IST 2009
|
* bb1cd6894bf5a073a80fb67575adb504539fca86  a1 at Sat Apr 11 16:21:40 IST 2009
</code></pre>

<p>How?  Just:</p>

<pre><code>$ echo 8e48f4975469c9c9c5de644eb8eff1e165241b09 &gt; .git/info/grafts
</code></pre>

<p>We've made "a6" what is called a "root" commit -- it has no parent.  Of
course, if you do this without giving "a5" ("a6"'s original parent) a proper
name, "a5" will become unreachable.  Which is why we gave it a name.</p>

<h3><a name="_and_joining_them_parallely_branch_merge_">...and joining them parallely (branch + merge)</a></h3>

<p>Or how about not just breaking them and leaving them separate, but taking the
pieces and putting them <em>parallel</em> to each other, with the tops and bottoms
joined:</p>

<pre><code>$ echo 6071135a250f9870aa8211eb871b4ac5d8e7e585 \
bb1cd6894bf5a073a80fb67575adb504539fca86 &gt; .git/info/grafts

$ echo cb479e433d0fa639c5738f9b26c0cd5ca0d1e1e7 \
0f127260fff51ad71d092788d5630b6bf0c4764f \
179fb20ebbe3d9381b8944cc53c1ef0b893f431d &gt;&gt; .git/info/grafts

$ g log --graph '--pretty=tformat:%H %d %s %n'  --all
*   cb479e433d0fa639c5738f9b26c0cd5ca0d1e1e7  (refs/heads/master) a9
|\
| |
| * 179fb20ebbe3d9381b8944cc53c1ef0b893f431d  a4
| |
| * 891f2a69544779e7f61a6ae2c213a3c2dc2957b1  a3
| |
| * 6a5b7c3ba50f91630f71aeaa36e2926ea6ad42f4  a2
| |
* | 0f127260fff51ad71d092788d5630b6bf0c4764f  a8
| |
* | fb9c6ac521e99216d0202d54d03800e2ebd1d3a4  a7
| |
* | 8e48f4975469c9c9c5de644eb8eff1e165241b09  a6
| |
* | 6071135a250f9870aa8211eb871b4ac5d8e7e585  a5
|/
|
* bb1cd6894bf5a073a80fb67575adb504539fca86  a1
</code></pre>

<hr />

<p>They say gardening is the closest to playing God that God-fearing folks dare
to do :-)  Feel the power yet?</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="all_about_branches_and_product_maintenance">all about branches and product maintenance</a></h1>

<p><sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#all_about_branches_and_product_maintenance">all about branches and product maintenance</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#local_and_remote_branches">local and remote branches</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#topic_branches">topic branches</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#product_maintenance">product maintenance</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#throwaway_integration_branches">throwaway integration branches</a><br>
</sup></p>

<hr />

<p><sup></p>

<p><strong>CVS/SVN folks -- please read this first</strong></p>

<p>SVN and CVS treat a branch as another subdirectory of your project.
Conversely, you can also pretend a subdirectory is a branch.  In other words,
branches (and tags) share the same namespace as the subdirectories of your
project.</p>

<p>This is not the right way to think of branches.  <strong>A branch is merely an
alternate reality for your project</strong>.  That's the simplest way to put it.
Each commit is a "snapshot" of the state of your code at a certain point in
time, and each branch (consisting of a series of commits) represents a
different timeline than the other branches do.</p>

<p>Thus, branches and subdirectories have <em>nothing</em> to do with each other.</p>

<p></sup></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="local_and_remote_branches">local and remote branches</a></h3>

<p>The git repository is really just a DAG (directed acyclic graph) of commits.
Each commits points to its parent or parents (merge commits have more than one
parent).  A branch in git is merely a pointer to some commit in the DAG.</p>

<p>When you checkout a branch, git simply makes your working tree look like the
files that existed when that commit was made, and makes a note that this is
your "current" branch.  When you make a commit on top of this, git updates
this current branch to point to the new "head" commit.  This is conceptually
the same as adding a new item to a linked list and moving the "head" pointer
to the new item, if you remember your data structures course from many years
ago.</p>

<p>A developer's repository will typically have several branches residing in it,
although of course only one is "checked out" at any given time into the
working tree.</p>

<p>Apart from local branches (like <code>master</code>, <code>next</code>, and maybe <code>v1.2</code>,
<code>some-new-feature</code>), etc., you will also have a set of branches called
<strong>origin/branchname</strong> (example: <code>origin/master</code>).  These are <em>your copy</em> of
the corresponding branch from the "origin" server.  You should <a href="../concepts/detached-head.html">never commit
to them directly</a>.</p>

<p>And the most important thing is, you can have any other branches you wish!  Go
wild -- no one will stop you, and it's quite difficult to lose data so have
fun!</p>

<h3><a name="topic_branches">topic branches</a></h3>

<p>As you read about workflows in modern VCSs, you'll often hear about topic
branches. According to the <a href="http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/gitglossary.html#def_topic_branch">git
glossary</a>,
a topic branch is:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><em>A regular git branch that is used by a developer to identify a conceptual
    line of development. Since branches are very easy and inexpensive, it is
    often desirable to have several small branches that each contain very well
    defined concepts or small incremental yet related changes.</em></p>
</blockquote>

<p>A topic branch could represent any self-contained, pretty much
independent-of-others, line of development.  A specific bug, a new feature, a
refactor, a set of enhancements to a core feature, etc., can all be managed as
topics in their own right.</p>

<h3><a name="product_maintenance">product maintenance</a></h3>

<p>Let's say your version tree looks like this:</p>

<pre><code>V3---o---o---o---o---o---V4---o---o--- (master)
 \                        \
  \---o---o--- (V3maint)   \
   \                        \---o---o--- (V4maint)
    \-o--- (topicA)          \
                              \-o--- (topicB)
</code></pre>

<p>In this picture, V3 and V4 are tags representing specific versions.  V3maint
is a maintenance branch that collects ongoing fixes for V3.  These ongoing
fixes could come from commits within V3maint itself, or by integrating topic
branches such as topicA.  At various points in it's lifecycle, when things are
stable, the top commit on V3maint will be tagged V3.1, V3.2, etc., as needed.</p>

<p>(...all this applies equivalently to V4 also, of course...)</p>

<p>The "master" branch is where on-going development for the future V5 is
happening.  This "new" development may well have its own set of topic
branches, probably by feature name, but right now we'll concentrate on the
maintenance aspect of fixing bugs or making enhancements to the released
versions.</p>

<p>The simplest way to manage the flow of patches and fixes is this:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>when a change is small enough to not need a topic branch, <strong><em>commit it on
the oldest branch that needs the change</em></strong>.  In this example, that could
be the V3maint or V4maint branch, depending on whether the issue affects
V3 or not.</p>

<p>Note that you <strong>cannot commit on V3</strong>.  V3 is a tag -- a tag represents a
"fixed point" in the commit hierarchy -- it's value can't change.  You can
only commit on a "branch".  In C terms, a tag is a <code>const</code> :-)</p>

<p>Also, note that although V3maint is primarily an integration branch for
the topic branches pertaining to V3, in this case it is acting as a
"catchall" topic branch for commits that are too small to have their own
topics.</p></li>
<li><p>for larger changes, create a topic branch by making a <strong><em>fork at the
oldest branch that needs this change</em></strong>.  For a bug that is applicable to
V4 but not to V3, you'd fork a topic branch at V4.  On the other hand, if
the bug applies to V3 also, you'd fork at V3.</p>

<p><em>Note</em> that you're <em>not</em> forking at V3maint or V4maint; you're forking at
V3 or V4.  See discussion in the previous bullet about V3maint's role.</p>

<p>However, it may sometimes happen that the bug does not apply to V3 but
<em>only</em> to V3maint (perhaps it's a bug that was caused by some previous fix
within the V3maint branch).  In that case, you must commit/fork it at the
current tip of V3maint.</p></li>
<li><p>Periodically <strong><em>merge the older branches into newer ones</em></strong> so the new
branches get the benefit of accumulated fixes and enhancements on the
older branches.  This means, for instance, that we merge V3maint, as well
as topic branches that forked from V3 (like topicA), into V4maint, and
then V4maint, (plus topics like topicB) into "master", which is the future
V5, etc.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>The exception to these rules is if you have bugs on older versions that do not
apply to newer versions.  Merging fixes that are relevant <em>only</em> to V3, into
the V4 branch, is meaningless, and may even get you conflicts.  The way to
deal with those is as follows:</p>

<ul>
<li>create a new branch called, say, V3only, forked from V3</li>
<li>fixes that apply <em>only</em> to V3 go on V3only</li>
<li>fixes that apply <em>from</em> V3, to all future versions, go on V3maint</li>
<li>periodically, V3maint is merged into both V4maint as well as to V3only</li>
</ul>

<p>Note that V3only will never get merged into V4maint or V3maint, preserving the
condition that commits made in V3only are not picked up by the newer versions.</p>

<h3><a name="throwaway_integration_branches">throwaway integration branches</a></h3>

<p>In all the above discussion, we kept saying "merge X into Y".  Which is all
very well if things go fine, but how do you back out if something went wrong?</p>

<p>The answer is something called a "throwaway integration branch".</p>

<p>We'll use an analogy to understand this.  Let's say you're writing a function
to insert a bunch of items into a linked list.  And let's say it's a complex
function, and at the start, you're not sure if it's going to succeed, and you
want the "head" pointer to be updated only if the whole thing succeeds.</p>

<p>How would you deal with this?  You'd make a temporary copy of the "head"
pointer, use that in your function, and if the function returns a success
value, you'd update the real "head" pointer.  Conversely, if the function
returned an error, you would leave your real "head" pointer as it is and just
discard the temporary value.</p>

<p>Git makes creating a new branch just as easy.  So instead of doing this:</p>

<pre><code>git checkout V4maint
git merge V3maint   # what if merge fails?
make test           # what if merge succeeds but tests fail?
</code></pre>

<p>where if either of the last 2 steps fail, you have to figure out how to get
back to the old V4, you do this instead:</p>

<pre><code>git branch -f test V4maint      # forcibly set test branch to V4
git checkout test               # and check it out
git merge V3maint
make test
# all good?
git branch -f V4maint test      # forcibly set V4maint to test
</code></pre>

<p>And of course if things didn't work out you would not do that last step,
preserving your V4maint at its previous revision.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="detached_HEAD_explained">detached HEAD explained</a></h1>

<p><sup>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#detached_HEAD_explained">detached HEAD explained</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#the_analogy">the analogy</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#reality_check">reality check</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#re_attaching_the_HEAD">re-attaching the HEAD</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Auld_Lang_Syne">Auld Lang Syne</a><br>
