&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#reality_check_conclusion">reality check -- conclusion</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#footnotes">footnotes</a><br></p>

<h2></sup></h2>

<p>Git has something called a 'detached HEAD' that bears some explanation.  You
are told 'do not commit on a detached HEAD', and it is not always clear what
or why this is.</p>

<hr />

<p><font color="red">This document is here for historical reasons, and because it
provides a nice analogy.  However, <a href="../gcs/index.html">Git for Computer Scientists (my
version)</a> should be a much nicer read for most people.
Despite the name, it has very few mentions of linked lists, and no pseudo-code
at <em>all</em>!  Instead, it has a lot of nice pictures, and it also touches upon
many other issues, not just on detached HEADs.  </font></p>

<h4><a name="the_analogy">the analogy</a></h4>

<p>Forget git for a bit and think about linked lists from your data structures
course.  Specifically, consider a <em>singly linked</em> list, where each node is
created as a "child" of some existing node, and contains a link to that
"parent" node.  <font color="gray">The words "child" and "parent" are chosen
to be similar to git's nomenclature for the relationship between a commit and
its predecessor commit(s).</font></p>

<p>As with any list, you have a pointer to the node at the top of the list (we'll
call this pointer <code>list_top</code>).  This would be the most recently created node,
and so there's a chain of "parent" links that can take you all the way to the
first node created.</p>

<p>And you know how to add a new node to this linked list.  In pseudo-code:</p>

<pre><code>// insert a new node at 'list_top'
temp = malloc(...);         // ask for some memory for the struct
temp.body = ...;            // fill in the node info
temp.parent = list_top;     // fill in the backlink
list_top = temp;            // move list head to new node
</code></pre>

<p>Let's also assume that all list operations are done with some temporary
variable (that is, they never directly use <code>list_top</code> etc.).</p>

<p>Now suppose you <em>move</em> to the grandparent of the current <code>list_top</code>, to do
something (like examine that node, print it out, whatever):</p>

<pre><code>temp = list_top;
temp = temp.parent;         // parent of list_top
temp = temp.parent;         // grandparent
</code></pre>

<p>So far, no harm done; your <code>list_top</code> variable still points to the top of the
list, and you can always do <code>temp = list_top</code> to go back to where you were for
any further operations.</p>

<p>Now suppose you add a new node to the list on top of the <em>current node</em>:</p>

<pre><code>// insert a new node at 'temp'
temp2 = malloc(...);        // ask for some memory for the struct
temp2.body = ...;           // fill in the node info
temp2.parent = temp;        // fill in the backlink
temp = temp2;               // move list head to new node
</code></pre>

<p>This is the same code as before, except temp has taken the place of <code>list_top</code>
this time.</p>

<p>But 'temp' is a temporary variable, and unless you somehow save its value
into some 'global' (or 'static') variable, you risk losing that commit you
just made, oops, I mean the new node you added to the linked list :-)</p>

<h4><a name="reality_check">reality check</a></h4>

<p>A previous version of this article took the analogy too far into git
territory, and I did not realise how many facts about git I had passed
over/simplified until an extended review on irc by <em>doener</em> and <em>jsquared</em>.</p>

<p>So we'll <em>git real</em>, if you'll pardon the weak pun, and get on with
understanding a 'detached HEAD'.</p>

<p>In git, commits always go on top of HEAD.  In terms of our linked list
analogy, they 'insert a new commit at HEAD'.</p>

<p><strong>HEAD</strong> is, normally, a symbolic reference to [the tip of] a branch.  For
instance, if you do <code>cat .git/HEAD</code> on a brand new repository, you'll get back
<code>ref: refs/heads/master</code>.  When you add a commit, git actually updates
'master', because that's where HEAD points.  You can see this by doing <code>cat
.git/refs/heads/master</code> before and after making a commit.  HEAD does not
change (it's only a symbolic reference) but 'master' does.</p>

<p>When you do a <code>git checkout branchname</code>, HEAD will now become a symbolic
reference to 'branchname'.  This means <code>cat .git/HEAD</code> will return <code>ref:
refs/heads/branchname</code> now.  New commits will now go on 'branchname' instead
of master, and correspondingly, the contents of <code>.git/refs/heads/branchname</code>
will change.</p>

<p>However, when you checkout anything that is not a proper, local, branch name,
then HEAD is no longer a symbolic reference to anything.  Instead, it actually
contains the SHA-1 hash (the commit id) of the commit you are switching to.</p>

<p>This is called a <strong>detached HEAD</strong>.  Example commands that will cause your
HEAD to become detached (ouch!) are<sup><a href="#fn">[1]</a></sup>:</p>

<pre><code>git checkout master^        # parent of master
git checkout HEAD~2         # grandparent of current HEAD
git checkout origin/master  # a non-local branch
git checkout tagname        # since you cant commit to a tag!
</code></pre>

<p>These will all make <code>.git/HEAD</code> contain the actual (40-hex-digit) hash of the
corresponding commit instead of some string like <code>ref: refs/heads/branch</code>.</p>

<h5><a name="re_attaching_the_HEAD">re-attaching the HEAD</a></h5>

<p>If you made the classic error of checking out a remote branch (like <code>git
checkout origin/master</code>) and making a few commits on it before realising
something was wrong, you can recover quite easily:</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -b newbranch
# or, in 2 steps: git branch newbranch; git checkout newbranch
</code></pre>

<p>To go back to the linked list analogy way up there, you just created a new
'global' variable to save off the value of 'temp' before some other operation
overwrote it.</p>

<h5><a name="Auld_Lang_Syne">Auld Lang Syne</a></h5>

<p>What if you didn't realise this, and -- after making those commits -- blithely
switched to another branch:</p>

<pre><code>git checkout someoldbranch
</code></pre>

<p>HEAD is now a symbolic reference to 'someoldbranch', and its previous value
(the SHA-1 representing the top commit you made on the detached HEAD) has now
been overwritten.</p>

<p>So is it gone for good now, never to be seen again?  Fortunately, no!  The
commit object itself is still safe out there somewhere, but you don't know
where!  You have to find it...</p>

<p>Think back to these 2 lines in the analogy above, where the 'current node' was
updated:</p>

<pre><code>list_top = temp;            // in the first example
temp = temp2;               // in the second example
</code></pre>

<p>What if you had some sort of wrapper around that line, such that, every time
this happened, the new value being assigned is also saved away somewhere,
including information on what command called it and when.  And let's say this
information is kept for 30 days.  So, even if you lost all your pointers, you
could check this saved list and the caller/time information to jog your memory
of which one it was, and actually use that pointer value to recover the node
you 'lost'.</p>

<p>That's the 'reflog' in git:</p>

<pre><code>git reflog show HEAD@{now} -10

dcd215b... HEAD@{5 minutes ago}: commit (amend): 0-terminology: the malloc analogy added, plus
5ce8bfe... HEAD@{11 minutes ago}: commit: 0-terminology: the malloc analogy added, plus
3d93420... HEAD@{11 minutes ago}: rebase -i (pick): updating HEAD
7fdae94... HEAD@{11 minutes ago}: checkout: moving from master to 7fdae94815d6c676742c9984132b7b9e71a57f98
3d93420... HEAD@{13 minutes ago}: rebase -i (squash): updating HEAD
c55900c... HEAD@{13 minutes ago}: rebase -i (pick): updating HEAD
7fdae94... HEAD@{13 minutes ago}: checkout: moving from master to 7fdae94815d6c676742c9984132b7b9e71a57f98
e9955c8... HEAD@{14 minutes ago}: commit: s
97ab644... HEAD@{20 minutes ago}: commit: autogen
c55900c... HEAD@{23 minutes ago}: commit (amend): 0-terminology: the malloc analogy added, plus
</code></pre>

<p>Now you look at this, decide which one you want, and grab it:</p>

<pre><code>git branch thank_God_its_safe 7fdae94
# like 'thank_God_its_safe = 0x7fdae94815d6c676742c9984132b7b9e71a57f98'
git checkout thank_God_its_safe
</code></pre>

<h5><a name="reality_check_conclusion">reality check -- conclusion</a></h5>

<p>There are a few other points that don't fit the simple 'linked list' analogy,
or present some additional information that may be useful:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>a commit 'tree' is really more of a graph.  A 'directed acyclic graph', to
be precise; see <a href="../gcs/index.html">here</a> for more on this.</p></li>
<li><p>a branch can point to any node in the graph, not just the top one.  For
example, when you fork a branch called 'new' from 'master', and make 2
commits on 'new', then 'new' is pointing to the top node in that portion
of the graph, but 'master' is still pointing two commits down from the top
node.  This is because the 'master' branch represents the same set of
commits it did before; we have done nothing to change that.</p></li>
<li><p>while most commits have only one parent, a 'merge' commit has more than
one parent.  Most merges have 2 parents, but an octopus merge can have any
number of parents.</p></li>
<li><p>apart from the reflog for HEAD, git also stores a reflog for each local
branch (recording commits, rebases, merges, and so on) and each remote
branch (recording pulls/fetches mainly).  The HEAD reflog is effectively a
superset of the reflogs of all the local branches, with some extra detail
(like individual steps within a rebase, for instance).</p></li>
</ul>

<hr />

<h5><a name="footnotes">footnotes</a></h5>

<p><a name="fn"><sup>[1] Curiously, <code>git checkout master^0</code> also gets you a detached HEAD.  The
command actually says "switch to the commit that master currently points to".
Now you'd think, since 'master' and 'HEAD' are currently pointing at the same
commit, it shouldn't be a detached HEAD, but the point is not that they happen
to be pointing to the same commit.  The point is that HEAD is no longer a
symbolic ref (containing something like <code>ref: refs/heads/master</code>) and instead
contains an explicit SHA-1 in it.</sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>(from gitster.livejournal.com) the importance of archeology</h1>

<p>...some quotes from <a href="http://gitster.livejournal.com/9562.html">http://gitster.livejournal.com/9562.html</a> (part of
<a href="http://gitster.livejournal.com/2007/09/02/">http://gitster.livejournal.com/2007/09/02/</a>)</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Another important aspect of SCM is archaeology, and this is especially
    important after a project [...] accumulates a long history.  [...] in
    order to go forward, you need to be able to look back every once in a
    while.</p>

<p>This is not "learning from past mistakes".  That's bull.  I am not talking
    about failed experiments that did not pan out even from the beginning.
    The archaeology that is important is to gain better understanding of why
    things are the way they are in the current state.</p>
</blockquote>

<hr />

<p>Junio did not address this directly, but this is even more useful for <em>new</em>
developers.</p>

<p>It helps space out their learning of the system, instead of being overwhelmed
by having precisely one monolothic view of the project to look at in order to
learn it.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>blame detection</h1>

<p>Git tracks content, not files.  As a result, the <code>git blame</code> and the
<code>git gui blame</code> commands can detect code moved or copied from elsewhere in
the project.  It's a very powerful feature, accessed by specifying the
<code>-C</code> flag one or more times, but there are some nuances.</p>

<h4>move detection versus copy detection</h4>

<p>When the <code>-C</code> flag is given only once, it looks for code blocks that were
<strong>moved</strong>.  That is, it searches for new code among other files that were also
modified in the same commit.  This runs very fast.</p>

<p>When you give the flag <strong>twice</strong>, it looks for new code among <strong>all</strong> the
files in the parent commit, and so it detects code that was <strong>copied</strong>.</p>

<p><code>git gui blame</code> behaves like <code>-C -C</code> by default, but can behave like <code>-C</code> if
<code>gui.fastcopyblame</code> is true.</p>

<h4>threshold, and how to specify it</h4>

<p>There is a concept of a "threshold", which is the minimum number of
alphanumeric characters required to count something as a code move/copy -- be
sure to read under <code>-C</code> in <code>man git-blame</code>.</p>

<p>This threshold defaults to 40 characters for copy detection, and 20 for move
detection.  You can override it by appending a number to the <code>-C</code> option.</p>

<p><code>git gui blame</code> defaults to 40 for this -- it actually sets <code>-C40</code> and calls
(I assume) the command line blame tool.  If you want to override it, use the
GUI (Edit->Options), or directly set the <code>gui.copyblamethreshold</code> config
variable.</p>

<h4>documentation lacunae</h4>

<p>The documentation does not seem to be very clear about the effect of <em>three</em>
<code>-C</code> options on <code>git blame</code>.  (In the GUI this is done by choosing full copy
detection from the right click menu).</p>

<p>The best hint is in <code>builtin-blame.c</code>, which says, within a function called
<code>blame_copy_callback</code>:</p>

<pre><code>/*
 * -C enables copy from removed files;
 * -C -C enables copy from existing files, but only
 *       when blaming a new file;
 * -C -C -C enables copy from existing files for
 *          everybody
 */
</code></pre>

<p>Sidenote: correlating the single and double cases in the code with the
documentation, I imagine "removed files" actually means "code from some other
modified file in the same commit", and similarly "existing files" means "code
from any files in the parent commit".</p>

<h4>my observations</h4>

<ul>
<li>a very high threshold makes it behave like no <code>-C</code> flags were supplied</li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>what does "git pull --rebase" do?</h1>

<p>[To understand this article you need to understand what a reflog is, and what
a rebase does, especially the full form of the rebase command]</p>

<p>[My initial article was a little simplistic; more exact details added thanks
to doener!]</p>

<hr />

<p>Sometimes we have an upstream that rebased/rewound a branch we're depending
on.  This can be a big problem -- causing messy conflicts for us if we're
downstream.</p>

<p>Without going into why they would do that, and how many beers (I prefer
rum+coke, thank you!) should be offered in compensation to downstream users,
let's just try and describe how git helps you deal with it.</p>

<p>The magic is <code>git pull --rebase</code>.</p>

<p>A normal <code>git pull</code> is, loosely speaking, something like this (we'll use a
remote called <code>origin</code> and a branch called <code>foo</code> in all these examples):</p>

<pre><code># assume current checked out branch is "foo"
git fetch origin
git merge origin/foo
</code></pre>

<p>At first glance, you might think that a <code>git pull --rebase</code> does just this:</p>

<pre><code>git fetch origin
git rebase origin/foo
</code></pre>

<p>But that will not help if the upstream rebase involved any "squashing"
(meaning that the <code>patch-id</code>s of the commits changed, not just their order).</p>

<p>Which means <code>git pull --rebase</code> has to do a little bit more than that.  Here's
an explanation of what it does and how.</p>

<p>Let's say your starting point is this:</p>

<pre><code>a---b---c---d---e  (origin/foo) (also your local "foo")
</code></pre>

<p>Time passes, and you have made some commits on top of your own "foo":</p>

<pre><code>a---b---c---d---e---p---q---r (foo)
</code></pre>

<p>Meanwhile, in a fit of anti-social rage, the upstream maintainer has not only
rebased his "foo", he even used a squash or two.  His commit chain now looks
like this:</p>

<pre><code>a---b+c---d+e---f  (origin/foo)
</code></pre>

<p>A <code>git pull</code> at this point would result in chaos.  Even a <code>git fetch; git
rebase origin/foo</code> would not cut it, because commits "b" and "c" on one side,
and commit "b+c" on the other, would conflict.  (And similarly with d, e, and
d+e).</p>

<p>What <code>git pull --rebase</code> does, in this case, is:</p>

<pre><code>git fetch origin
git rebase --onto origin/foo e foo
</code></pre>

<p>This gives you:</p>

<pre><code>a---b+c---d+e---f---p---q---r (foo)
</code></pre>

<p>You may still get conflicts, but they will be genuine conflicts (between p/q/r
and a/b+c/d+e/f), and not conflicts caused by b/c conflicting with b+c, etc.</p>

<hr />

<p>So how does this actually work?</p>

<p>The command tries to find out which commits are <em>really</em> your local ones, and
which had come from upstream in an earlier fetch.</p>

<p>To do this, it looks at the reflog of the remote tracking branch
(<code>origin/foo</code>, in this case).  This reflog represents the tips of successive
<code>git fetch</code> operations on <code>origin</code>, in "most recent first" order.</p>

<p>For each reflog entry, (<code>origin/foo@{1}</code>, then <code>...{2}</code>, and so on) it checks
if that commit is an ancestor of the current branch head <code>foo</code>.  As soon as it
finds one, it picks it as the starting point for the rebase (<code>e</code> in the
example above).</p>

<p>That might sound a little complicated, but it works out fine.  Just try it
next time your upstream rebases something on you.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="How_to_use_git_over_an_HTTP_proxy_with_socat">How to use git over an HTTP proxy, with socat</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#How_to_use_git_over_an_HTTP_proxy_with_socat">How to use git over an HTTP proxy, with socat</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#a_word_about_socat">a word about socat</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#proxying_the_git_protocol">proxying the <strong>git</strong> protocol</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#proxying_the_ssh_protocol">proxying the <strong>ssh</strong> protocol</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#ssh_proxy_using_corkscrew_instead_of_socat">ssh proxy using corkscrew instead of socat</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#extra_coolness_for_github">extra coolness for github</a><br></p>

<p>Corporate firewalls and proxy typically block both of these (and often a lot
more); here's how to get around them.  </p>

<p>If you're tracking a public repo, you will need to use the "git" protocol,
because the "http" protocol is not very efficient, and/or requires some
special handling on the server side.  If you're pushing code to a public repo,
you <strong>definitely</strong> need to use the "ssh" protocol.</p>

<h3><a name="a_word_about_socat">a word about socat</a></h3>

<p>I will be using "socat", an absolute corker of a program that does so many
things it's incredible!  Other people use corkscrew, ssh-https-tunnel, etc.,
which are all specialised for just one purpose.  I prefer socat, and once you
spend the 2-3 years :-) needed to read the man page, you will see why!</p>

<p>The basic idea is that you will somehow invoke socat, which will negotiate
with the HTTP(S) proxy server using the CONNECT method to get you a clean pipe
to the server on the far side.</p>

<p>However, do note that socat does have one disadvantage: the passwords to your
proxy server are visible in to local users running <code>ps -ef</code> or something.
I don't care since I don't have anyone else logging into my desktop, and the
ability to use a program I already have anyway (socat) is more important.</p>

<h3><a name="proxying_the_git_protocol">proxying the <strong>git</strong> protocol</a></h3>

<p>When I want to download a public repo, I just type</p>

<pre><code>proxied_git clone ...repo...
proxied_git pull
</code></pre>

<p>and so on, instead of</p>

<pre><code>git clone ...repo...
git pull
</code></pre>

<p>Here's the how and why of it.</p>

<p>To proxy the git protocol, you need to export an environment variable
called <code>GIT_PROXY_COMMAND</code>, which contains the command that is to be
invoked.  I have a shell function in my <code>.bashrc</code> that looks like
this:</p>

<pre><code>proxied_git () 
( 
    export GIT_PROXY_COMMAND=/tmp/gitproxy;

    cat  &gt; $GIT_PROXY_COMMAND &lt;&lt;EOF
#!/bin/bash
/usr/bin/socat - PROXY:172.25.149.2:\$1:\$2,proxyport=3128
EOF
    chmod +x $GIT_PROXY_COMMAND;

    git "$@"
)
</code></pre>

<p>Possible variations are:</p>

<ul>
<li>you could give <code>/tmp/gitproxy</code> a more permanent name and remove the
middle pararaph completely.  I don't do this because that's too small a
file to bother with; it just seems cleaner this way)</li>
<li>you could permanently set the environment variable if <strong>all</strong> your git
repos are remote (very unlikely)</li>
</ul>

<p>One thing you <em>cannot</em> do is to roll the entire socat command into the
environment variable.  Git passes the host and port as two arguments to the
proxy command, but socat expects them in the syntax you see above, so you
<em>will</em> need to wrap it in a script as I have done.  I guess you could argue
that this is a point in favour of corkscrew etc. ;-)</p>

<h3><a name="proxying_the_ssh_protocol">proxying the <strong>ssh</strong> protocol</a></h3>

<p>The git protocol is handled directly by git (duh!), but if you use the ssh
protocol, it invokes ssh explicitly (again, duh!).</p>

<p>Ssh already has this sort of stuff built-in, so you simply add a few lines to
your <code>~/.ssh/config</code></p>

<pre><code>host gh
    user git
    hostname github.com
    port 22
    proxycommand socat - PROXY:your.proxy.ip:%h:%p,proxyport=3128,proxyauth=user:pwd
</code></pre>

<p>Now you can just say (for example):</p>

<pre><code>git clone gh:sitaramc/git-notes.git
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="ssh_proxy_using_corkscrew_instead_of_socat">ssh proxy using corkscrew instead of socat</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>download and install corkscrew (<a href="http://www.agroman.net/corkscrew/">http://www.agroman.net/corkscrew/</a>)</li>
<li>create a file (eg., ~/.ssh/myauth) and put your http proxy
username and password as "username:password" in it and save
it.</li>
<li><p>safeguard the file</p>

<pre><code>chmod 600 ~/.ssh/myauth
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>open ~/.ssh/config and add the following entry, adding an explicit path to
corkscrew if needed.</p>

<pre><code>host gh
    user git
    hostname github.com
    port 22
    proxycommand corkscrew your.proxy.ip 3128 %h %p ~/.ssh/myauth
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="extra_coolness_for_github">extra coolness for github</a></h4>

<p>Noting that many corporate firewalls block access to the CONNECT method on
ports other than 443, the good folks at github have an ssh server listening on
443 if you use the host "ssh.github.com", so you can replace the hostname and
the port in the above ssh config stanza as appropriate, and you're all set</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>create on push</h1>

<p>If you want to create a repo on a push, here's how you do it:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>put the following code somewhere on the server and make it executable.
Let's say you called it <code>/usr/local/bin/ac-grp</code> (which stands for
auto-creating-git-receive-pack ;-)</p>

<pre><code>#!/bin/bash

if [ ! -d $1 ]
then
    git init --bare $1
fi &gt;&amp;2
exec git-receive-pack "$@"
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>on the client side, instead of:</p>

<pre><code>git push user@host:reponame master
</code></pre>

<p>try</p>

<pre><code>git push --receive-pack=/usr/local/bin/ac-grp user@host:reponame master
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>if you want to make this permanent, (and this is untested, so if you use
it and it works please let me know):</p>

<pre><code>cd /usr/local/bin   # or wherever your git binaries are
mv git-receive-pack git-receive-pack.original
vim /usr/local/bin/ac-grp
    # and change the last line to refer to git-receive-pack.original
    # instead of git-receive-pack
mv ac-grp git-receive-pack
</code></pre></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>(not git-specific) version control habits of good developers</h1>

<p>This article is based on <a href="http://blog.bstpierre.org/version-control-habits">http://blog.bstpierre.org/version-control-habits</a> -- a
blog post that is well worth checking out, especially if you want more
details.  However, this article represents my priorities on this matter, and
most of the words are mine.</p>

<ul>
<li><p><strong>USE IT</strong>!  If you don't use version control you should get out of the
software development profession!</p></li>
<li><p><strong>check-in often</strong>: check-in when some logical unit of work is done
(compiles OK after major changes, or some feature is complete, or some
test was passed, etc.).  "going home for the day" is NOT a logical unit of
work; ideally you should not treat the version control system as a "backup
mechanism".  If you do this sort of time-based check-in, "<em>the danger is
that if you have to revert because you've made some disastrous changes,
you won't have a sane state to revert to</em>."</p></li>
<li><p><strong>check-in bite sized chunks</strong>: large check-ins are hard to review, and
harder to revert</p>

<ul>
<li>if you check-in 20 "logical units of work" in one shot, and the 3rd and
the 14th are bad, you'll have to revert the entire check-in, remove
changes 3 and 14, and then check-in again.  If you checked them all in
separately, you can revert just the changes that were not acceptable,
while retaining all the other stuff</li>
<li>if the "feature" is too large, create a branch and check-in locally</li>
<li>however, check-ins should be <strong>atomic</strong> -- for instance, a related
change in 2 ".c" files and a ".h" file should not become 3 check-ins if
those changes all depend on each other.</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p><strong>make sure you include everything that is needed to rebuild the
project</strong>: (this is more for single-developer projects) since we don't
want to check-in binary files like executables and libraries, we normally
set up the VCS to ignore some files based on extension or whatever.  This
list has to be made carefully, and reviewed once in a while, otherwise
something that is important to the build may get left out!</p>

<ul>
<li>in git, you can temporarily rename the .gitignore file and then do a
"git status" (or run "git gui") to see the files that git is ignoring</li>
<li>or you can clone the entire project into a new directory and see if it
compiles</li>
<li><p>or you can run:</p>

<p>git ls-files --exclude-standard -o -i</p></li>
</ul></li>
<li><p><strong>take backups</strong>!  Don't use the version control system as a backup
medium</p></li>
<li><p><strong>keep "data" outside the "source" tree</strong>: putting data in the same
directory as the source tree is a very bad practice, and in fact I expect
seasoned programmers who are reading this to go "huh?  somebody actually
does stupid things like that?" :-)  Small amounts of textual data used to
trigger specific tests are OK, and may even benefit from version control
in the sense that a test suite is an integral part of any software with
longevity.  But anything larger than that, and more so if they are binary
blobs, should NOT be in the repository.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>don't break the build</strong>!</p></li>
<li><p><strong>update ("git pull") regularly</strong>: otherwise, you risk a large effort in
resolving conflicts when you eventually do pull</p></li>
<li><p><strong>write good check-in comments</strong>: this helps people understand the
evolution of the project much better over a long period of time.  Don't
forget the second purpose of a VCS is annotation: who changed it, what did
they change, and <strong>why</strong>?</p></li>
<li><p><strong>use branches or holding areas</strong>: branching and merging is cheap and
easy, and helps you keep things separate in your own mind too.  Having a
hierarchy of branches is very useful.  For instance:</p>

<ul>
<li>"master" is what is pulled from/pushed to the repository, "work" is
where you do the day-to-day development, "ut" is where you unit test,
pulling specific commits from "work" for a build and a test, "st-it" is
for integration test/system test, and so on.</li>
<li>in git, it's easy to use the "gitk" gui to pick individual changes from
another branch into the current one</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>other cool stuff</h1>

<ul>
<li><p><a href="http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/howto/rebase-from-internal-branch.txt">http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/howto/rebase-from-internal-branch.txt</a>
-- excellent article on rebase. This article is also available in the git
installs, at least on MDV.  We already knew git was smart about not
re-applying patches already applied, based on the SHA1 being in the chain.
But the <strong>really cool</strong> thing about rebase is that it can ignore patches
even when they had a different SHA1 (in the same way that git cherry does,
by examining the changeset) which helps when your changes may have made it
into the master via email.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>cherry picking</strong> -- another good reason to make small commits!</p></li>
<li><p>cherry picking while doing a rebase; <code>man git-rebase</code> for details.  In
particular, you can rebase off of your own ancestor, to refactor a large
set of recent changes, like this:</p>

<pre><code>git rebase -i HEAD~10
</code></pre>

<p>You won't know how cool this is until you try it!</p></li>
<li><p>Advantages of doing a rebase: doing a <code>git bisect</code> on a merged chain
sometimes makes it difficult to find the specific commit that caused an
error.  See
<a href="http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/user-manual.html#bisect-merges">http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/user-manual.html#bisect-merges</a></p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1>recovering a dropped stash:</h1>

<h4>the GUI way</h4>

<p>You dropped a stash that was created recently, and now you want to recover it.
As long as you did not do a garbage collection in between, this should work:</p>

<pre><code>gitk $(git fsck | grep commit | cut -f3 -d' ') --since='1 week ago'
</code></pre>

<p>The part within the parenthesis finds all unreachable commit objects and
returns their hashes.  If you never did a garbage collect there might be too
many false positives so the <code>--since</code> clause (which you can adjust to whatever
you want of course; mine is just an example) limits the display to commits
created recently.</p>

<p>A "stash" has a very recognisable, triangular, shape in the commit DAG, and
with gitk you can visually find stashes really fast.  For me, this is the kind
of task that <em>calls out</em> for a GUI -- infrequently required, no conceivable
need to automate, and containing data that stands out visually.</p>

<h4>the command line way</h4>

<p>Writing something longer than that for a problem that occurs once in a blue
moon is not my style (very low ROI!), but doener gave me this:</p>

<pre><code>git fsck --unreachable | grep commit | cut -d\  -f3 |
xargs git log --no-walk --merges --grep='^\(WIP on \|On \)\((no branch)\|[^ ]\+\):'
</code></pre>

<p>I knew about <code>--merges</code> but not <code>--no-walk</code>, and I anticipate using it a lot
more in future :-)</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>backing up work in progress</h1>

<p>This is how you can backup everything on your local repo that is not already
on one of your remotes, including all untracked files not covered by the
ignore mechanism.  I use a script based on this to save my work to a remote
server at regular intervals, in case of a disaster (hardware failure, etc) on
the regular desktop.</p>

<pre><code># sort of like stash; untracked files also saved
git commit --allow-empty -m wip-index-state
git add -A &amp;&amp; git commit --allow-empty -m wip-worktree-state

# make a temp branch (FIXME: should we do this first?)
git branch wip-backup ||
    die 'could not create wip-backup branch; aborting';

# unstash
git reset --mixed HEAD^
git reset --soft HEAD^

# create the bundle and remove the temp branch
git bundle create /tmp/sos.bdl --all --not --remotes
git branch -D wip-backup

# copy that file wherever you want, however you want...
rsync /tmp/sos.bdl bkphost:   # or scp, or whatever
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>corruption in a git repository</h1>

<p>For now, this is just loosely formatted text, maybe like a series of case
studies.</p>

<p>IMPORTANT NOTE: <code>git fsck --full</code> is needed to reliably find repo corruption</p>

<h3>case 1: Kolkata Korruption -- 2 missing tree objects</h3>

<p>what finally worked:</p>

<pre><code># on some good repo
TYPE=$(git cat-file -t $BADOBJSHA)
git cat-file $TYPE $BADOBJSHA &gt; file

# copy file to bad repo
git hash-object -t $TYPE -w --stdin &lt; file
</code></pre>

<p>However, this may not always work; it is not certain that hash-object will
<em>replace</em> a corrupted object (as opposed to creating a <em>missing</em> object).  So
try that, <em>as well as</em> this (generic object):</p>

<pre><code># on some good repo
echo $object | git pack-objects --revs pack
# will create two files named pack-*.{idx,pack}
</code></pre>

<p>confirm:</p>

<pre><code>git verify-pack -v pack-*.idx | grep $object
# should also contain all sub objects
</code></pre>

<p>copy:</p>

<pre><code>pack* to $bad_repo/[.git?]/objects/pack
</code></pre>

<p>repack:</p>

<pre><code>repack -a -d
</code></pre>

<p>(you could also do "unpack-objects" I guess)</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="git_command_line_usage_cheatsheet_quickref">git command-line usage cheatsheet/quickref</a></h1>

<p>This document describes stuff that's not necessarily done every day.  The bare
minium stuff like <code>git add/commit/push/checkout/branch</code> etc is not
covered.</p>

<hr />

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#git_command_line_usage_cheatsheet_quickref">git command-line usage cheatsheet/quickref</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#setting_up">setting up</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#bash_aliases_for_git">bash aliases for git</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#most_useful_stuff_in_HOME_gitconfig_">most useful stuff in <code>$HOME/.gitconfig</code></a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#stuff_you_tend_to_forget">stuff you tend to forget</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#add_and_commit">add and commit</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#push">push</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#diff">diff</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#conflicts_on_pull_merge">conflicts on pull/merge</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#log_pickaxe_and_blame">log pickaxe and blame</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#misc">misc</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_oopsies_recovering_from_mistakes_"><strong>oopsies! (recovering from mistakes)</strong></a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#useful_commands">useful commands</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#grep">grep</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#log_and_show">log and show</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#reflog">reflog</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#show_branch">show-branch</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#cherry_not_cherry_pick_">cherry (not cherry-pick)</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#cat_file_repo_object_and_ls_tree_tree_object_">cat-file (repo object) and ls-tree (tree object)</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#ls_files">ls-files</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#the_bleeding_edge">the bleeding edge</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#git_bundle_lifesaver_for_disconnected_machines_">git bundle -- lifesaver for disconnected machines!</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#making_an_independent_branch_in_an_existing_repo">making an independent branch in an existing repo</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#garbage_collection">garbage collection</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#remotes">remotes</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#combining_and_splitting_commits">combining and splitting commits</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#more_exploration">more exploration</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#simulating_git_stash">simulating git stash</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#startup_tips_for_CVSers">startup tips for CVSers</a><br></p>

<h3><a name="setting_up">setting up</a></h3>

<p>I <strong>strongly</strong> recommend these settings to make life easier.</p>

<h4><a name="bash_aliases_for_git">bash aliases for git</a></h4>

<pre><code>alias g='git --no-pager'
alias gp='git -p'
alias mg='git help'
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="most_useful_stuff_in_HOME_gitconfig_">most useful stuff in <code>$HOME/.gitconfig</code></a></h4>

<p>My <code>.gitconfig</code> is <a href="../tools/my.gitconfig.txt">here</a>.  Parts of this
document assume some of these aliases.</p>

<h3><a name="stuff_you_tend_to_forget">stuff you tend to forget</a></h3>

<h4><a name="add_and_commit">add and commit</a></h4>

<pre><code># stage updates/deletes for files git already knows about
git add -u  [paths...]
# ditto for ALL files, including new ones
git add -A

# stage updates/deletes for files git already knows about AND COMMIT
git commit -a
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="push">push</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>don't forget to <code>git push --tags</code> when needed</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="diff">diff</a></h4>

<pre><code># diff between work area and stage
git diff
# diff between work area and repo (CVS model)
# note that "git diff" + "git diff --cached" == "git diff HEAD"
git diff HEAD
# other coolness
git diff "@{yesterday}"
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="conflicts_on_pull_merge">conflicts on pull/merge</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>try <code>gitk --merge conflicted_path</code></li>
<li><code>git diff MERGE_HEAD...HEAD</code> (note the <em>three</em> dots) shows you
differences between the common ancestor and your HEAD.</li>
<li>similarly <code>git diff HEAD...MERGE_HEAD</code> shows you differences between
the common ancestor and the branch you're trying to merge</li>
<li><code>git checkout --conflict=diff3 conflicted_path</code> is a novel way of
getting all 3 versions into the file so you can hack at it in vim</li>
<li><p>you can tell git blame to only show important changes, like so (pity it
does not work with the GUI blame)</p>

<pre><code>git blame -C $(git merge-base HEAD MERGE_HEAD).. conflicted_path
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="log_pickaxe_and_blame">log pickaxe and blame</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>finding out when a particular change happened or who made it</p>

<pre><code>git log -S"some code line" file.c   # why is this called pickaxe search?
git blame -b file.c
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="misc">misc</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><code>ORIG_HEAD</code>: pull or merge (or anything that moves HEAD drastically)
leave a copy of the old head with this name.  Reset can use it if needed.
(see <code>man git-reset</code>).  <code>reset</code> itself copies the old <code>HEAD</code>
to <code>ORIG_HEAD</code>, though that seems less useful</li>
<li><code>FETCH_HEAD</code>: records the branch you fetched from a remote repository
with your last 'git-fetch' invocation</li>
<li><code>MERGE_HEAD</code> records the commit(s) you are merging into your branch
when you run 'git-merge'</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="_oopsies_recovering_from_mistakes_"><strong>oopsies! (recovering from mistakes)</strong></a></h4>

<p>The following are useful to undo <strong>before a commit</strong>.  Note that these usages
of "checkout" (with <strong>specific</strong> files/paths) do not result in switching
branches but in updating the files/paths given.</p>

<ul>
<li><p>bad working copy, want to make working &lt;= staged</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -- filename
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>bad working copy, want to make working &lt;= HEAD</p>

<pre><code>git checkout HEAD -- filename
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>bad staged version, want to make staged &lt;= HEAD (working copy is not
touched)</p>

<pre><code>git reset HEAD -- filename
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<p>When things get worse, and it's not just a few files that were screwed up, use
this</p>

<ul>
<li><p>throw away all local changes and make working, staged &lt;= HEAD</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -f
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<p>The following are useful to undo <strong>after a commit</strong>, as long as you haven't
published or pushed the commit elsewhere:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>screwed up commit?  hope no one else pulled your last commit, quickly fix
the source, and then</p>

<pre><code>git commit -a --amend
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>bad commit? apply a reversed patch as an additional commit on top</p>

<pre><code>git revert HEAD^    # one revision ago
git revert "@{1 hour ago}"
git revert "@{5}"   # 5th last saved state, from reflog
    # this may not be the 5th last revision if there were resets in
    # between.
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>commit is so bad you want to roll back time?</p>

<pre><code>git reset --hard HEAD~5 # 5th last revision
    # a reset rolls back the log, but is still recorded in the reflog,
    # which gets expired after some 30 to 90 days.
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="useful_commands">useful commands</a></h3>

<h4><a name="grep">grep</a></h4>

<p><code>git grep</code> is very, <em>*very</em>, powerful.  It has pretty much all the normal grep
options, plus:</p>

<ul>
<li>doesn't search files that are not revisioned (untracked, excluded/ignored,
etc)</li>
<li>with <code>--cached</code>, looks only in the cache</li>
<li>with one or more ref names, searched only within those revisions</li>
<li>can take a pattern, like <code>*.c</code>, to restrict the files searched</li>
<li><p>can do <code>--and</code>, <code>--or</code>, <code>--not</code>, etc with patterns.  This is a pretty big
wow.  As <a href="http://gitster.livejournal.com/27674.html">http://gitster.livejournal.com/27674.html</a> says:</p>

<pre><code>git grep -e ';;' --and --not -e 'for *(.*;;' -- '*.c'
</code></pre>

<p>which searches for ';;' in all C files, unless they occur in a typical
<code>for (;;) {</code> type of construct.</p></li>
<li><p>finally, there's a somewhat gratuitously thrown in <code>--all-match</code> option,
which says "match any of these strings, but print matches only from files
that have <em>all</em> of them".  I wonder whose scratch that was... ;-)</p></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="log_and_show">log and show</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p><code>git lga</code> is pretty cool; lga is an alias in my config for</p>

<pre><code>log --graph --pretty=oneline --abbrev-commit --decorate --all
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>Check the logs to see what's happened recently</p>

<pre><code>git log [--stat] -[p] [-n &lt;number of commits to show&gt;]
git log "@{yesterday}.."
    # note the suffix "..", since the default is prefix "..", which is
    # probably not what you want
git log somefile.c
</code></pre></li>
<li><p><code>git show</code> is almost an alias for <code>git log -p -n 1</code>.  In general,
<code>git show</code> does the right thing: shows a commit as a commit, a tree as
a plain "ls", etc.  But if you're printing a large blob you better use a
pager or redirect!</p>

<pre><code>git show [ HEAD^ | HEAD^^ | HEAD@{3} | origin | origin/master | etc ]
git show 7a8b9c     # or some hex number; shows you the object
git show HEAD~3:file.c  # get file.c from 3 versions back
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="reflog">reflog</a></h4>

<p>...see this more detailed <a href="../concepts/reflog.html">note</a></p>

<h4><a name="show_branch">show-branch</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><code>git show-branch -a</code> is useful to get a bird's eye view of all your
branches and their topological relationships.</li>
<li><code>git show-branch -gN</code> (N is some number) shows you reflog info for the
current branch, including topological relationships and relative time.
This is useful if you had a lot of rebases or amended commits and you
think you might need one of them back :-)  See
<a href="../concepts/reflog.html">reflog</a> for more on this</li>
<li><p>if you need serious troubleshooting with branches, use the following.  It
may be useful in some contexts where <code>git lg</code> is too complex to figure
out what tip contains what commit, and you are unable to use gitk</p>

<pre><code>git show-branch $(git show-ref -h |cut -c41-)
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="cherry_not_cherry_pick_">cherry (not cherry-pick)</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>summary: <code>+</code> shows you commits you have that the 'upstream' doesn't</p>

<pre><code>git cherry -v upstream [head]
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>detail: for every commit in 'head' that doesn't exist in 'upstream'</p>

<ul>
<li>prefix <code>-</code> if there is at least an <em>equivalent</em> commit</li>
<li>prefix <code>+</code> if there's not even that</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>TIP: if you're trying to cut some branches (like <code>git branch --merged</code>)</p>

<ul>
<li>put the candidate to be cut <strong>on the right side</strong>, and</li>
<li>make sure there are no <code>+</code>s in the output</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="cat_file_repo_object_and_ls_tree_tree_object_">cat-file (repo object) and ls-tree (tree object)</a></h4>

<p>Note: I'm not sure what, if any, is the difference between <code>show</code> and
<code>cat-file -p</code> for "blob" objects.  For commits there is a subtle
difference.  (Try it)</p>

<pre><code># any object
git cat-file [ -t | -s | -p ] 789abc
    # find the type or size of an object, or pretty print it
    # If it's a blob, I'd use use "git show" until we find out what
    # "pretty" means for arbitrary blobs :-)
git cat-file blob 789abc        # cat the object

# any tree
git ls-tree         # files and directories, top level only
git ls-tree -l      # also show the size of the object
git ls-tree -d      # only directories
git ls-tree -r      # recurse, only files
git ls-tree -r -d   # recurse, only directories
git ls-tree -r -t   # recurse, both directories and files
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="ls_files">ls-files</a></h4>

<p>To get listings of various types of files, use <code>git ls-files</code>.  The common
but less intuitive ones are shown here, the rest can be had from the man page:</p>

<pre><code># deleted files and modified files (deleted files are also counted as
# modified, so may come up twice...
git ls-files -d -m
# what's in the index; includes files that were "git add"ed
git ls-files -s
# conflicted files
git ls-files -u
# "other files"; includes EVERYthing not in d/m/s, I think
# seems to be equal to untracked + ignored
git ls-files -o
# untracked files only
git ls-files --exclude-standard -o
# ignored files only
git ls-files --exclude-standard -o -i
</code></pre>

<h3><a name="the_bleeding_edge">the bleeding edge</a></h3>

<h4><a name="git_bundle_lifesaver_for_disconnected_machines_">git bundle -- lifesaver for disconnected machines!</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>really awesome, but be careful, not all refspecs will work on the
receiving side.  Assuming we're talking about a normal "origin" pull for
an existing clone, this is what you do</p>

<pre><code># sending side
git bundle create ~/junk HEAD^^^..
    # or say "254c8de..", assuming the receiving side has that hash)
# receiving side
git ls-remote ~/junk    # note the refs on the right side
git fetch ~/junk HEAD   # one of the refs that showed up
# now merge it wherever you want
git merge FETCH_HEAD
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>to clone a repo using this method:</p>

<pre><code># sending side: cd to repo and checkout the master or whatever, then:
git bundle create ~/junk HEAD
# receiving side: mkdir/cd some empty directory, then:
git init; git pull ~/junk
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="making_an_independent_branch_in_an_existing_repo">making an independent branch in an existing repo</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>based on
<a href="http://madduck.net/blog/2007.07.11:creating-a-git-branch-without-ancestry/">http://madduck.net/blog/2007.07.11:creating-a-git-branch-without-ancestry/</a></p>

<pre><code># ensure all changes are committed
git status
# ensure even ignored files aren't present, or you don't care
git ls-files --exclude-standard -o -i

# WARNING -- IF THE ABOVE COMMANDS SHOW ANY USEFUL FILES,
#               STOP HERE!

# create an empty tree -- choose one of these options
# if you're sure you have no dot-files
rm -rf *
# if your tree may have dot files...
git rm -r .; git clean -fdx

# remove the index
rm .git/index

# point HEAD to the new branchname, whatever it is
git symbolic-ref HEAD refs/heads/indbr

# create some files, add, commit
touch empty
git add .
git commit -m "first commit of independent branch"
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="garbage_collection">garbage collection</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>Warning: <code>git gc --prune</code> is dangerous if others may be pushing to the
repo at the same time!</li>
<li><p>Warning: <code>git gc</code> may <strong>increase</strong> the space used, since it even
unpacks objects that were in packs if they became unreachable.  This is
the same thing as <code>git repack -Adf</code> (note the uppercase "A")</p></li>
<li><p>To bring the repo size down the bare minimum, you need <em>both</em> the
following commands (neither command by itself does the whole job).  Also
Note the lowercase "a" on the "repack", which says you want to blindly
discard unreachable objects instead of keeping them as loose objects.</p>

<pre><code>git repack -adf     # kills in-pack garbage
git prune           # kills loose garbage
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>(from the do-you-really-want-to-do-this? department)</p>

<pre><code>git reflog expire --expire=10days --all
# use expire-unreachable to limit it a bit
# use branchname(s) instead of --all
# units can be seconds, minutes, etc
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="remotes">remotes</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>how do you find out how many remotes you have and what they are called?</p>

<pre><code>vim .git/config                         # or...
git remote | map git remote [-n] show   # even better!
    # use -n to prevent lookup if needed
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="combining_and_splitting_commits">combining and splitting commits</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>to split the top commit into multiple commits
<ul>
<li>start <code>git gui</code></li>
<li>choose "amend last commit" from the commit menu</li>
<li>unstage all files</li>
<li>pick files or hunks in files to stage and commit</li>
<li>continue until all changes are committed</li>
</ul></li>
<li>same as above, but the commit to split is not the top one
<ul>
<li>start an interactive rebase that includes that commit</li>
<li>mark that commit as "edit" and start the rebase</li>
<li>when the rebase pauses, use <code>git gui</code> as described above</li>
<li>continue the rebase</li>
</ul></li>
<li>to combine a set of commits and split the result in some other way
<ul>
<li>start an interactive rebase</li>
<li>move lines as appropriate so your commits are together</li>
<li>choose "squash" on the second and subsequent ones and start the rebase</li>
<li>(dirty trick warning) when the editor for the combined commit message
pops up, delete ALL the lines and save</li>
<li>use git gui as above</li>
<li>then continue the rebase</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="more_exploration">more exploration</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>to see a list of ALL the objects in the entire system, including
filenames (but this isn't tremendously useful though):</p>

<pre><code>git rev-list --objects --all
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="simulating_git_stash">simulating git stash</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>some say it's better to simulate git stash than actually use it!  The
following makes use of the fact that the repo HEAD is usually one step
behind the index, which is one step behind the working tree.</p>

<pre><code># initial values: R (repo), I (index), C (changed), and U (untracked)
# notation: repo contents/index contents/work tree contents
# R/RI/RICU; start
git commit --allow-empty -m wip-index-state
# now RI/RI/RICU; pushed index onto repo
git add -A &amp;&amp; git commit --allow-empty -m wip-worktree-state
# now RICU/RICU/RICU; pushed C/U files onto repo
    #   ... switch branch, work work work, commit ...
    #   now you want to get back to the saved state
# go back to whatever branch it was
git checkout whatever
# now RICU/RICU/RICU
git reset --mixed HEAD^ # repo=index=R+I
# now RI/RI/RICU; moved HEAD and index back one step
git reset --soft HEAD^
# now R/RI/RICU; moved HEAD back one more step
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="startup_tips_for_CVSers">startup tips for CVSers</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><strong>gotcha</strong>: <code>git add somefile</code> adds the <strong>current</strong> content of
<code>somefile</code> to the staging area.  Changes made after this do not affect
<code>git commit</code> unless you again do a <code>git add</code> or use the <code>-a</code>
option to <code>git commit</code>.
<ul>
<li><strong>you will eventually prefer this :-)</strong></li>
</ul></li>
<li><strong>gotcha</strong>: <code>commit</code> means to your local repo, not to the "server"!</li>
<li><p>these commands/options effectively bypass the "index" or "staging
area", <strong>but the INDEX is really a wonderful concept, and you really
should not bypass it like this</strong>.  See <a href="../concepts/uses-of-index.html">why the index is
useful</a> or
<a href="http://blogs.gnome.org/newren/2007/12/08/limbo-why-users-are-more-error-prone-with-git-than-other-vcses/">http://blogs.gnome.org/newren/2007/12/08/limbo-why-users-are-more-error-prone-with-git-than-other-vcses/</a></p>

<pre><code>git diff HEAD       # to see changes you made
git add             # to tell git about new files...
git commit -a       # ...and let git figure out changed and deleted files before committing
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>CVS equivalence</p>

<pre><code>CVS                 GIT
---                 ---
checkout            clone
update              pull
checkin             commit + push
add                 add
remove              rm
???                 mv
</code></pre></li>
<li><p><a href="http://github.com/guides/completely-remove-a-file-from-all-revisions">http://github.com/guides/completely-remove-a-file-from-all-revisions</a></p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="souping_up_your_bash_prompt">souping up your bash prompt</a></h1>

<p><sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#souping_up_your_bash_prompt">souping up your bash prompt</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Summary_for_the_impatient_expert">Summary for the impatient/expert</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Details">Details</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Download_bash_script">Download bash script</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Screenshot">Screenshot</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#extracode">Supplementary code</a><br>
</sup></p>

<hr />

<p>This document describes how to get command completion as well as a souped up
bash prompt.</p>

<p>Git comes with a bash script in the 'contrib/completion' directory which takes
care of command completion as well as displaying the current branch name in your
<code>PS1</code> (primary bash prompt).  We use that as a basis, and -- without digging
inside of it (meaning you can upgrade that without worry) -- we add more
functionality.</p>

<h4><a name="Summary_for_the_impatient_expert">Summary for the impatient/expert</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>normally, shows whatever <code>__git_ps1</code> sends back.  That is, completion,
branch name, and branch state text come from <code>__git_ps1</code>, in
'contrib/completion/git-completion.bash' in the git source tree</li>
<li><p>but when you</p>

<ul>
<li>switch branches, or</li>
<li>change current working directory, or</li>
<li><em>hit enter twice in quick succession at the bash prompt</em> (!!)</li>
</ul>

<p><p>it shows a color-coded count of files in various states: unmerged (bold
red), untracked (blue), modified (red), and staged (green).  In addition,
the branch name reported by <code>__git_ps1</code> is also colored (for example,
bright red when the head is detached).</p></li>
</ul>
You might be wondering about that "hit enter twice in quick succession" piece
:-) The idea is that it should be as convenient and accessible as the current
implementation, but it shouldn't really happen on <em>every</em> prompt because it's
expensive to compute and could delay the prompt.</p>

<p>The implementation is either a neat and elegant hack or kludge city, depending
on whom you ask :)</p>

<h4><a name="Details">Details</a></h4>

<p>For a while, I've wanted a quick summary of <code>git status</code> -- how many files are
staged (<code>git add</code>ed), modified, untracked, unmerged, etc.  I've also wanted a
quick indication of whether the current HEAD is a detached head, etc.  And I
wanted it to be as compact as possible.</p>

<p>But...  I didn't want 'git status' to run on every prompt -- that would be too
expensive for some of the msysgit users I support.  I wanted this extra piece
to kick in only when</p>

<ul>
<li>I change directories, or</li>
<li>I switch branches, or the branch state changes, or</li>
<li>when I want it to, but I'm too lazy to type a command to tell it (also
called psychic mode!)</li>
</ul>

<p>That last part was tough, but I'm pleased that my solution not only works, it
even works on msysgit so my Windows users are happy too!</p>

<h4><a name="Download_bash_script">Download bash script</a></h4>

<p>The part that computes the status and summarises it with colored numbers is a
hacked up version of git://github.com/lvv/git-prompt.git), and you can
download it <a href="../tools/git-completion-plus.bash.txt">here</a>.  And here's a
<a href="../tools/git-completion-plus.bash.html">syntax colored</a> version to quickly
view on a browser.  You're expected to source it into your <code>.bashrc</code>; it'll
take care of sourcing the git-supplied one, which it looks for in <code>$HOME</code>.</p>

<p>After that, you need to include the snippet of bash code given in <a href="#extracode">this
section</a>.  I used to have all this in one file, but the code to
detect the quick-double-enter has uses outside git also, so I separated that
logic from the 'git status colorisation' stuff.</p>

<h4><a name="Screenshot">Screenshot</a></h4>

<p>[Update 2009-03-19: the screenshot is not quite current but will suffice to
give you the general idea]</p>

<p>Someone asked for a screenshot so <a href="../images/git-completion-plus.png">here is
one</a>; it should give you enough of an idea.
You can see the extra information (namely, the output of <code>__git_ps1</code> being
colored, and a few numbers after that in different colors at certain places:</p>

<ul>
<li>when I hit enter twice quickly (the timestamps on the left side will tell
you when I did that)</li>
<li>when the output of <code>__git_ps1</code> changes (this is the bit inside
parentheses)</li>
</ul>

<p>The color choices retain the colors that git status shows (with <code>git config
--global color.ui true</code>) for staged and modified files -- this is green and
red, respectively.  <code>git status</code> uses red for untracked files also, but we use
blue.  Unmerged files are magenta.</p>

<p>I didn't show changing to another directory and coming back -- that would also
trigger the extra info.  I also didn't show all 4 colors (staged, modified,
untracked, unmerged) at the same time but I'm sure you get the idea.</p>

<h4><a name="extracode">Supplementary code</a></h4>

<p>The following code contains the hack to do something different if you hit
enter twice in quick succession.  It need to be run via bash's
<code>PROMPT_COMMAND</code> mechanism -- do not call it directly from <code>PS1</code> using the
<code>$(bash_command)</code> syntax.  That syntax runs things in a sub-shell, which won't
let you maintain state.</p>

<p>You'll notice there's git-specific stuff in there.  The idea is that if you
need some <em>other</em> information (like, perhaps, percentage disk free, or maybe
system load, if you don't have conky or gkrellm), then that also can use the
same mechanism; you'd just add bits of code in here, piggy-backing on the
logic already present to make things run only sometimes instead of on every
prompt.</p>

<p>Of course you can change the <code>PS1=[...]</code> lines however you like.</p>

<pre><code>export PROMPT_COMMAND=__ps1_plus
__ps1_plus()
{
    # elegant hack or extreme kludgery?  You decide...

    # I wanted a way to see a long prompt very conveniently, but
    # not on *every* prompt -- hitting enter twice in quick succession at the
    # bash prompt was about as much as I was willing to do :-)

    # The hack works by remembering the $SECONDS value at the end of each
    # unsuccesful invocation.  When the next invocation still has the same
    # $SECONDS, you know the user hit enter twice, so you do the 'git status'
    # stuff.

    # In addition, of course, if the PWD or the output of __git_ps1 itself
    # changed, that also triggers the extra stuff.

    local gitps1
    declare -F __git_ps1 &gt;/dev/null &amp;&amp; gitps1=$(__git_ps1)
    if [[ $__ps1_state != $PWD/$gitps1 || $__ps1_plus_last -eq $SECONDS ]]
    then
        __ps1_state=$PWD/$gitps1

        # if enhanced PS1 builder exists call it to set __git_ps1_text;
        # otherwise default is the git-distributed one
        __git_ps1_text=$gitps1
        declare -F __git_ps1_plus &gt;/dev/null &amp;&amp; __git_ps1_plus

        echo -n -e '\e]0;'${HOSTNAME%%.*}:
        [[ $PWD == $HOME ]] &amp;&amp; echo -n '~' || echo -n $(basename $PWD)
        echo -n -e '\a'
        PS1='\[\e[4m\e[32m\]\t \h:\W$__git_ps1_text\[\e[m\] \$ '; [[ $EUID == 0 ]] &amp;&amp;
        PS1='\[\e[4m\e[31m\]\t \h:\W$__git_ps1_text\[\e[m\] \$ '
    else
        PS1='\[\e[4m\e[32m\]\t\[\e[m\] \$ '; [[ $EUID == 0 ]] &amp;&amp;
        PS1='\[\e[4m\e[32m\]\t\[\e[m\] \$ '
    fi
    __ps1_plus_last=$SECONDS
}
</code></pre>

<hr />

<p><sup>and <a href="../tools/git-completion.bash.txt">this</a> is a copy of the v1.6.1 version of
git-completion.bash from the git source tree; you probably have it already</sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>git for computer scientists -- my version</h1>

<p>[Inside joke: Hey I rewrote gitosis so why not this?]</p>

<hr />

<p>In this document:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="#_basics">basics</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#_the_4_git_object_types">the 4 git object types</a></li>
<li><a href="#_what_is_a_SHA">what is a SHA</a></li>
<li><a href="#_what_is_a_repo">what is a repo</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a href="#_why_are_the_arrows_backward_in_your_pictures_"><strong>(why are the arrows backward in your pictures?)</strong></a></li>
<li><a href="#_branches_and_tags">branches and tags</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#_branch">branch</a></li>
<li><a href="#_more_than_one_branch">more than one branch</a></li>
<li><a href="#_more_than_one_parent_commit">more than one parent commit</a></li>
<li><a href="#_current_branch_checked_out_branch">current branch/checked out branch</a></li>
<li><a href="#_committing">committing</a></li>
<li><a href="#_naming_non_leaf_nodes">naming non-leaf nodes</a></li>
<li><a href="#_tags">tags</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a href="#_the_difference_between_branches_and_tags">the difference between branches and tags</a></li>
<li><a href="#_digressions">digressions</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#_what_is_a_git_URL_">what is a git URL?</a></li>
<li><a href="#_what_is_a_remote_">what is a "remote"?</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a href="#_local_and_remote_repos">local and remote repos</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#_remote_branches">remote branches</a></li>
<li><a href="#_multiple_remotes">multiple remotes</a></li>
<li><a href="#_fetching_and_merging_from_another_repo">fetching and merging from another repo</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a href="#_the_object_store">the object store</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#_what_is_a_repo_again_">what is a repo (again)</a></li>
<li><a href="#_objects_and_branches_tags">objects and branches/tags</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a href="#_advanced_operations">advanced operations</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#_merging">merging</a></li>
<li><a href="#_cherry_pick">cherry-pick</a></li>
<li><a href="#_rebasing">rebasing</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a href="#_the_confusion_about_checkout_versus_reset">the confusion about checkout versus reset</a></li>
<li><a href="#_detached_HEAD_and_all_that">detached HEAD and all that</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#_other_ways_to_detach_your_HEAD">other ways to detach your HEAD</a></li>
<li><a href="#_re_attaching_the_HEAD">re-attaching the HEAD</a></li>
<li><a href="#_the_reflog">the reflog</a></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<hr />

<p><a name="_basics"></a></p>

<h3>basics</h3>

<p><a name="_the_4_git_object_types"></a></p>

<h4>the 4 git object types</h4>

<p>Git keeps all its data inside a special directory called <code>.git</code> at the top
level of your repository.  Somewhere in there is what we will simply call the
<em>object store</em> (if you're not comfortable with that phrase, pretend it's some
sort of database).</p>

<p>Git knows about 4 types of objects:</p>

<ul>
<li><p><strong>blob</strong> -- each file that you add to the repo is turned into a blob
object.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>tree</strong> -- each directory is turned into a tree object.</p>

<p>Obviously, a tree object can contain other tree objects and blob objects,
just like a directory can contain other directories and files.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>commit</strong> -- a commit is a snapshot of your working tree at a point in
time, although it contains a lot of other information also.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>tag</strong> -- we will see this type a bit later.</p></li>
</ul>

<p><a name="_what_is_a_SHA"></a></p>

<h4>what is a SHA</h4>

<p>A commit is uniquely identified by a 160-bit hex value (the 'SHA').  This is
computed from the tree, plus the following pieces of information:</p>

<ul>
<li>the SHA of the parent commit(s) -- every commit except the very first one
in the repo has at least one parent commit that the change is based upon.</li>
<li>the commit message -- what you type in the editor when you commit</li>
<li>the author name/email/timestamp</li>
<li>the committer name/email/timestamp</li>
</ul>

<p>(Actually, all 4 git objects types are identified by SHAs, but of course
they're computed differently for each object type.  However, the SHAs of the
other object types are not relevant to this discussion).</p>

<p>In the end, as I said, it's just a large, apparently random looking, number,
which is actually a cryptographically-strong checksum.  It's usually written
out as 40 hex digits.</p>

<p>Humans are not expected to remember this number.  For the purposes of this
discussion, think of it as something similar to a memory address returned by
malloc().</p>

<p>It is also GLOBALLY unique!  No commit in any repo anywhere in the world will
have the same SHA.  (It's not a mathematical impossibility, but just so
extremely improbable that we take it as fact.  If you didn't understand that,
just take it on faith).</p>

<p>An example SHA: <code>a30236028b7ddd65f01321af42f904479eaff549</code></p>

<p><a name="_what_is_a_repo"></a></p>

<h4>what is a repo</h4>

<p>A repository ('repo') is a graph of commits.  In our figures, we represent
SHAs with numbers for convenience.  We also represent time going
upward (bottom to top).</p>

<pre><code>.gv file=plain plain
1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 4
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_why_are_the_arrows_backward_in_your_pictures_"></a></p>

<h3><strong>(why are the arrows backward in your pictures?)</strong></h3>

<p>So why are the arrows pointing backward?</p>

<p>Well... every commit knows what its parent commit is (as described in the
"what is a SHA" section above).  But it can't know what it's child commits are
-- they haven't been made yet!</p>

<p>Therefore a repo is like a single linked list.  It cannot be a double linked
list -- this is because any change to the contents would change the SHA!</p>

<p><a name="_branches_and_tags"></a></p>

<h3>branches and tags</h3>

<p><a name="_branch"></a></p>

<h4>branch</h4>

<p>Traditionally, the top of a linked list has a name.  That name is a BRANCH
name.  We show branch names in green circles.</p>

<pre><code>.gv master
1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 4
[g] master
4 -- master
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_more_than_one_branch"></a></p>

<h4>more than one branch</h4>

<p>(a.k.a "more than one child commit")</p>

<p>Remember we said a repo is a GRAPH?  Specifically, more than one child node
may be pointing at the same parent node.  In this case, each 'leaf node' is a
branch, and will have a name.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7
3 .. 4
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[g] master
[g] devel
[g] feature_X
4 -- feature_X
6 -- devel
7 -- master
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_more_than_one_parent_commit"></a></p>

<h4>more than one parent commit</h4>

<p>Well we can't keep creating more branches without eventually merging them
back.  So let's say "feature X" is now tested enough to be merged into the
main branch, so you <code>git merge feature_X</code>.  Here's what you get:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8
3 .. 4
4 .. 8
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[g] master
[g] devel
[g] feature_X
4 -- feature_X
6 -- devel
8 -- master
.eq 4 6 7
</code></pre>

<p>Notice that commit 8 now has 2 parents, showing that it is a "merge commit".</p>

<p>At this point, it's quite common to delete the feature branch, especially if
you anticipate no more "large" changes.  So you can run <code>git branch -d
feature_X</code>, which gives you this:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8
3 .. 4
4 .. 8
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[g] master
[g] devel
6 -- devel
8 -- master
.eq 4 6 7
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_current_branch_checked_out_branch"></a></p>

<h4>current branch/checked out branch</h4>

<p>There is a notion of a 'currently checked out' branch.  This is denoted by a
special ref called HEAD.  HEAD is a <strong>symbolic</strong> ref, which points to the
'current branch'.</p>

<pre><code>.gv file=HEAD HEAD
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7
3 .. 4
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[g] devel
[g] feature_X
4 -- feature_X
6 -- devel
7 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_committing"></a></p>

<h4>committing</h4>

<p>When you make a new commit, the current branch moves.  Technically, whatever
branch HEAD is pointing to will move.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8
3 .. 4
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[g] devel
[g] feature_X
4 -- feature_X
6 -- devel
8 -- master .. HEAD
.eq 4 6 7
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_naming_non_leaf_nodes"></a></p>

<h4>naming non-leaf nodes</h4>

<p>It's not just 'leaf' nodes, but inner nodes can also have names.  Recall the
result of merging <code>feature_X</code> earlier (see the "more than one parent commit"
section):</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8
3 .. 4
4 .. 8
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[g] master
[g] devel
[g] feature_X
4 -- feature_X
6 -- devel
8 -- master
.eq 4 6 7
</code></pre>

<p>At this point, you could leave <code>feature_X</code> as it is forever.  Or you could
delete the branch (as we showed in that section), in which case that label
would simply disappear.  (The commit it points to is safely reachable from
<code>master</code> because of the merge.)</p>

<p>You can also continue to develop on the <code>feature_X</code> branch, further refining
it with a view to once again merging it at some later point in time.  <font
color="gray">Although not relevant to the topic of this document, I should
mention that the usual practice is to first merge master back into <code>feature_X</code>
to make sure it has all the other stuff that master may have acquired till
now (this is shown by commit 9 below) before continuing further
development:</font></p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8
3 .. 4
4 .. 8
2 .. 5
.he 4 .. 9 .. 10
.he 5 .. 6
[g] master
[g] devel
[g] feature_X
10 -- feature_X
6 -- devel
8 -- master
.eq 4 6 7
8 .. 9
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_tags"></a></p>

<h4>tags</h4>

<p>More commonly, inner nodes are TAGS.  We show tag names in yellow circles.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8
3 .. 4
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[g] devel
[g] feature_X
4 -- feature_X
6 -- devel
8 -- master .. HEAD
.eq 4 6 7
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
.eq 3 "v1.0"
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_the_difference_between_branches_and_tags"></a></p>

<h3>the difference between branches and tags</h3>

<p>The main difference between a branch and a tag is branches move, tags don't.
When you make a commit with the "master" branch currently checked out, master
will move to point to the new commit.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8 .. 9
3 .. 4
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[g] devel
[g] feature_X
4 -- feature_X
6 -- devel
9 -- master .. HEAD
.eq 4 6 7
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
.eq 3 "v1.0"
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_digressions"></a></p>

<h3>digressions</h3>

<p><a name="_what_is_a_git_URL_"></a></p>

<h4>what is a git URL?</h4>

<p>Git repos are accessed by providing a URL.  There are typically 4 kinds of Git
URLs:</p>

<ul>
<li>ssh: like <code>ssh://git@server:reponame</code></li>
<li>http: like <code>http://server:reponame</code></li>
<li>git: like <code>git://server:reponame</code> -- note that this is an unauthenticated
protocol suitable only for allowing downloads of open source or similar
software</li>
<li>local file: like <code>file:///full/path/to/reponame</code></li>
</ul>

<p><a name="_what_is_a_remote_"></a></p>

<h4>what is a "remote"?</h4>

<p>A remote is a short name (like an alias) used to refer to a specific git
repository.  Instead of always saying <code>git fetch git://sitaramc/gitolite</code>, you
can add that as a remote and use that short name instead of the long URL.</p>

<p>For convenience, a 'remote' called 'origin' is automatically created
when you clone a repo, pointing to the repo you cloned from.</p>

<p><a name="_local_and_remote_repos"></a></p>

<h3>local and remote repos</h3>

<p><a name="_remote_branches"></a></p>

<h4>remote branches</h4>

<p>Git is a distributed version control system.  So when you clone someone's
repo, you get all the branches in that one.  Remote branches are prefixed by
the name of the remote, and we show them in orange.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8 .. 9
3 .. 4
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "origin/devel"
[o] "origin/feature_X"
4 -- "origin/feature_X"
6 -- "origin/devel"
9 -- "origin/master"
9 -- master .. HEAD
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
.eq 3 "v1.0"
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_multiple_remotes"></a></p>

<h4>multiple remotes</h4>

<p>You can have several remotes.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he 1 .. 2 .. 3 .. 7 .. 8 .. 9
3 .. 4
2 .. 5
.he 5 .. 6
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "origin/devel"
[o] "origin/feature_X"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/devel"
4 -- "origin/feature_X"
6 -- "origin/devel"
9 -- "origin/master"
6 -- "sitas-repo/devel"
9 -- "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- master .. HEAD
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
.eq 3 "v1.0"
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_fetching_and_merging_from_another_repo"></a></p>

<h4>fetching and merging from another repo</h4>

<p>Now let's say Sita's repo had a couple of new commits on its master, and you
run <code>git fetch sitas-repo</code>.  (We have pruned the graph a litle for clarity,
showing only the relevant commits; the rest of the commits and branches are
assumed to be present as in the previous picture).</p>

<pre><code>.gv
". . ." .. 9 .. 10 .. 11
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
11 -- "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>Now you want to merge Sita's master branch into yours.  Since your master does
not have any commits that Sita's master doesn't have (i.e., Sita's master is
like a superset of yours), running <code>git merge sitas-repo/master</code> will get you
this:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he "[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 10 .. 11
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
11 -- "sitas-repo/master"
11 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_the_object_store"></a></p>

<h3>the object store</h3>

<p>Git stores all your data in an "object store".  There are 4 types of objects
in this store: files (called "blobs"), trees (which are directories+files),
commits, and tags.  All objects are referenced by a 160-bit SHA.</p>

<p>(Details, if you like: a blob is the lowest in the hierarchy.  One or more
blobs and trees make a tree.  A commit is a tree, plus the SHA of its parent
commit(s), the commit message, author/committer names and emails, and
timestamps.  Under normal usage, you don't need to deal with all this).</p>

<p><a name="_what_is_a_repo_again_"></a></p>

<h4>what is a repo (again)</h4>

<p>Earlier, we saw that a repo was a graph of commits.  At the file system level,
