however, it is basically a directory called <code>.git</code> which looks somewhat like
this</p>

<pre><code>$ ls -al .git
total 40
drwxrwxr-x 7 sitaram sitaram 4096 Sep 14 18:54 ./
drwx------ 3 sitaram sitaram 4096 Sep 14 18:54 ../
drwxrwxr-x 2 sitaram sitaram 4096 Sep 14 18:54 branches/
-rw-rw-r-- 1 sitaram sitaram   92 Sep 14 18:54 config
-rw-rw-r-- 1 sitaram sitaram   73 Sep 14 18:54 description
-rw-rw-r-- 1 sitaram sitaram   23 Sep 14 18:54 HEAD
drwxrwxr-x 2 sitaram sitaram 4096 Sep 14 18:54 hooks/
drwxrwxr-x 2 sitaram sitaram 4096 Sep 14 18:54 info/
drwxrwxr-x 4 sitaram sitaram 4096 Sep 14 18:54 objects/
drwxrwxr-x 4 sitaram sitaram 4096 Sep 14 18:54 refs/
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_objects_and_branches_tags"></a></p>

<h4>objects and branches/tags</h4>

<p><font color="gray"></p>

<p>Hg folks should read this section carefully.  Among various crazy notions Hg
has is one that encodes the branch name within the commit object in some way.
Unfortunately, Hg's vaunted "ease of use" (a.k.a "we support Windows better
than git", which in an ideal world would be a negative, but in this world
sadly it is not) has caused enormous takeup, and dozens of otherwise excellent
developers have been brain-washed into thinking that is the only/right way.</p>

<p>I hope this section gives at least a few of them a "light-bulb" moment.</p>

<p></font></p>

<p>The really, <strong>really</strong> important thing to understand is that the object store
doesn't care where the commit came from or what "branch" it was part of when
it entered the object store.  Once it's there, it's there!</p>

<p>Think back to these three diagrams.  The first is before you did a fetch.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
"[ . . . ]" .. 9
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
9 -- "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>The next two figures are after <code>git fetch sitas-repo</code> and <code>git merge
sitas-repo/master</code>, respectively.  The fetch command added two new commits (10
and 11) to your object store, along with any other objects those commits
reference.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he "[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 10 .. 11
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
11 -- "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- master .. HEAD

.gv
.he "[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 10 .. 11
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
11 -- "sitas-repo/master"
11 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>However, note that commits 10 and 11 did not change in any way simply because
they are now in <strong>your local "master" branch</strong>.  They continue to have the
same SHA values and the object store does not change as a result of this
command at all.</p>

<p>All you did was move a pointer from one node to another.  Which is why the
linked list analogy works so well in understanding git as a DAG.</p>

<p><a name="_advanced_operations"></a></p>

<h3>advanced operations</h3>

<p>We'll now show some advanced operations with the aid of this same tree.</p>

<p><a name="_merging"></a></p>

<h4>merging</h4>

<p>First, let's do merging.  The merge you saw earlier was what is called a
"fast-forward" merge, because your local master did not have any commits that
the remote branch you were merging did not have.</p>

<p>In practice, this is rare, especially on an active project with many
developers.  So let's see what that looks like.  The starting point was this:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
"[ . . . ]" .. 9
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
9 -- "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>Now, you made some changes on your local master.  Meanwhile, sitas-repo has
had some changes which you got by doing a fetch:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he "[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 12 .. 13
9 .. 10
.he 10 .. 11
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
11 -- "sitas-repo/master"
13 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>When you merge, the end result will usually look like this:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
"[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 10 .. 11 .. 14
9 .. 12 .. 13 .. 14
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
11 -- "sitas-repo/master"
14 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_cherry_pick"></a></p>

<h4>cherry-pick</h4>

<p>A cherry-pick is not very commonly done -- in well designed workflows it
should actually be rare.  However, it's a good way to illustrate an important
concept in git.</p>

<p>We said before that a commit represents a certain set of files and
directories, but since most commits have only one parent, you can think of a
commit as representing a set of changes too.  (In fact, most older VCSs do
this).</p>

<p>Let's say one of your collaborators (this mythical "Sita" again!) made a whole
bunch of changes to his cpoy of the repo.  You don't like most of these
changes, except one specific change which you would like to bring in to your
repo.</p>

<p>The starting point is this:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
"[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 12
.he 12 .. 13 .. 14
.he 9 .. 10 .. 11
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
14 -- "sitas-repo/master"
11 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>In this, sitas-repo has 3 commits on his master (12, 13, and 14) and you are
only interested in the change that commit 13 made.</p>

<p>Don't worry about the meaning of the <code>~1</code> for now (although you ought to be
able to guess!), but here's the command you might run:</p>

<pre><code>git cherry-pick sitas-repo/master~1
</code></pre>

<p>This results in the following commit graph.</p>

<pre><code>.gv
"[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 12
.he 12 .. 13 .. 14
.he 9 .. 10 .. 11 .. "13a"
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
[o] "sitas-repo/master"
9 -- "origin/master"
14 -- "sitas-repo/master"
"13a" -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>Note that I've called the new commit "13a".  This is to reflect the fact that,
while the <em>change</em> made is the same as in the original commit 13, the <em>SHA</em>
will not be the same anymore (new parent commit, new "tree", new committer
name/email, commit time, etc).</p>

<p><a name="_rebasing"></a></p>

<h4>rebasing</h4>

<p>Instead of merging, let's say you wanted to rebase your commits on top of
Sita's commits.</p>

<p>First of all, what is rebasing?  It's basically transplanting a series of
changes from one point in the graph to another point.</p>

<p>So if you guessed that a rebase was (in principle) a series of cherry-picks,
you'd be pretty close, at least from a concept point.</p>

<p>So let's use a similar example as in the merge example before, but instead of
sitas-repo, the new commits are in "origin" (which is the "main" server for
this project).  You haad your own commits, and you did a <code>git fetch origin</code>
which brought in the latest commits from "origin", so it looks like:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he "[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 10 .. 11
9 .. 12
.he 12 .. 13
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
13 -- "origin/master"
11 -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>Now, instead of merging "origin/master" into your local master, you want to
rebase your commits on top of "origin/master".  That is, you want to pretend
your local changes were made <em>after</em> commit 13 on the origin.  So you run <code>git
rebase origin/master</code>, and this is the result:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
"[ . . . ]" .. 9 .. 10 .. 11
9 .. 12 .. 13 .. "10a" .. "11a"
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[o] "origin/master"
13 -- "origin/master"
"11a" -- master .. HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>Note that again, we're ignoring command syntax and nuances here.  This is
about concepts.  Also again, note that the SHAs of the 2 commits have changed,
since they now have new parents, trees, etc., so we represent that by
suffixing an "a".</p>

<p>Note the <em>dangling commits</em> 10 and 11.  No branch is now pointing to them, so
they're basically wasted disk space.  (They can be examined and reclaimed
using the 'reflog', or if left alone they will eventually get garbage
collected).</p>

<p>Unlike cherry-pick, a rebase is quite often done in real life.  Rebase also
has some other forms.  This form is one, but the most common is when a
developer wants to re-arrange his own local commits in a more logical sequence
before publishing/pushing them.  (I often do the eqvt of changing this:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
22 .. 23 .. "22delta" .. 24
</code></pre>

<p>where "22delta" is a minor fixup to "22", into</p>

<pre><code>.gv
"22a" .. "23a" .. "24a"
</code></pre>

<p>using "git rebase -i".</p>

<p>Notice that since commit 22 changes its SHA, all its child commits -- now
rebased -- will also have new SHAs.  This is why you should (almost) never
rebase branches that have already been published.</p>

<p><a name="_the_confusion_about_checkout_versus_reset"></a></p>

<h3>the confusion about checkout versus reset</h3>

<p><strong>Please note</strong> <font color="gray">that this section completely ignores the
myriad options available to both these commands, especially the ones that
pertain to the index and the working tree.  All we're trying to do is show
what the commands do to the branch and <code>HEAD</code>, nothing else.  As such, this is
not a complete discussion of those two commands, but only about one aspect of
them.</p>

<p>In fact, the major reason these two sometimes get confused is that people
eventually learn that <code>git checkout -f</code> and <code>git reset --hard</code> do the same
thing, and then extrapolate that to other options.  Just remember that both
those are specific cases of two quite different commands that just happen to
"meet" there, in some sense.</font></p>

<p>The basic difference is very simple:</p>

<ul>
<li>checkout changes what your current branch is (i.e., it changes where HEAD
is pointing to)</li>
<li>reset changes which commit the current branch is pointing to</li>
</ul>

<p>Here're some pictures that show you what's happening.  (Note that commits
below 6 and 7 are omitted for brevity).</p>

<p>The first picture is the common starting point.  The next two show the effect
of a checkout and a reset, respectively.  Notice which line is moving in each
picture, compared to the starting point.</p>

<pre><code>.gv starting point
"starting point for both
checkout and reset operations"
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[g] devel
6 -- devel
7 -- master
master -- HEAD

.gv
" "

.gv
"git checkout devel"
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[g] devel
6 -- devel
7 -- master
.ie master .. HEAD
.le devel -- HEAD

.gv
" "

.gv
"git reset devel"
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
[g] devel
6 -- devel
.ie 7 .. master
.le 6 -- master
master -- HEAD
</code></pre>

<p>As you can see, your current branch, when you start, is "master" (indicated by
where HEAD is pointing).</p>

<p>A "checkout" changes what is your current branch -- it is now "devel", and so
any new commits you make now will go on devel, not master.</p>

<p>On the other hand, a reset changes what commit your current branch points to.
Your branch is still master, but now it is pointing to what could potentially
be a <em>completely</em> different history.</p>

<p>(Notice that, like in the rebase example, there is now a dangling commit --
one that cannot be reached by any branch.  It is still accessible using the
'reflog' and will eventually get garbage collected)</p>

<p><a name="_detached_HEAD_and_all_that"></a></p>

<h3>detached HEAD and all that</h3>

<p>All this time you have seen HEAD pointing to a branch name, and the branch
itself pointing to a commit.  Then, when you make a commit, the branch moves
to the new commit (although HEAD still continue to point to the branch name).
If you want to recap, here's a look at just the part of the tree that concerns
us, in a simple before/after display:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
"BEFORE COMMIT"
.he "[ . . . ] " .. 3 .. 7
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
7 -- master .. HEAD
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
[o] "origin/master"
3 -- "origin/master"

.gv
"AFTER COMMIT"
.he "[ . . . ] " .. 3 .. 7 .. 8
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
8 -- master .. HEAD
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
[o] "origin/master"
3 -- "origin/master"
</code></pre>

<p>Now see what happens when you <code>git checkout v1.0</code>:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he "[ . . . ] " .. 3 .. 7
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
7 -- master
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
3 -- HEAD
[o] "origin/master"
3 -- "origin/master"
</code></pre>

<p>Notice the subtle difference?  HEAD is no longer a <strong>symbolic</strong> ref (i.e.,
pointing to a real branch).  Instead, it is pointing directly to a commit.</p>

<p>In real terms, this is literally what happens.  When you had "master" checked
out, the contents of HEAD (it's just a file in .git) are simply</p>

<pre><code>ref: refs/heads/master
</code></pre>

<p>If you <code>git checkout devel</code> (which is a local branch), it becomes</p>

<pre><code>ref: refs/heads/devel
</code></pre>

<p>However, remember what we said earlier?  Only branches can move, tags cannot.
So when you <code>git checkout v1.0</code>, HEAD now contains</p>

<pre><code>90fed7792746a9a33e24059fb171f6bbb6ffebe6
</code></pre>

<p>or some such hash.  If it did what it did for local branches, it would imply
the tag would move, right?  Which it shouldn't -- wouldn't be much of a tag if
it moved!</p>

<p>So from this point on, if you make a commit, only HEAD changes, nothing else,
since it is no longer "attached" to any local branch name"</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he "[ . . . ] " .. 3 .. 7
3 .. 8
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
7 .. master
8 .. HEAD
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
[o] "origin/master"
3 -- "origin/master"
</code></pre>

<p>The reason this is considered dangerous is that, if you now do <code>git checkout
master</code>, you get this:</p>

<pre><code>.gv
.he "[ . . . ] " .. 3 .. 7
3 .. 8
[] [y] HEAD
[g] master
7 .. master .. HEAD
[y] "v1.0"
3 -- "v1.0"
[o] "origin/master"
3 -- "origin/master"
</code></pre>

<p>Notice what happened to your new commit 8?  It's dangling.  Unreachable.
(Except by the reflog, of course, but beginners can get shaken up!)</p>

<p><a name="_other_ways_to_detach_your_HEAD"></a></p>

<h4>other ways to detach your HEAD</h4>

<p>The most common way to get into a detached HEAD state is to check out a remote
branch (like <code>git checkout origin/branch</code>), without realising that you need to
make a local copy before you make commits on it.</p>

<p><font color="gray">(Side note: the correct syntax to create and checkout a
local branch starting from a remote branch used to be <code>git checkout -t -b
branch origin/branch</code>, but modern gits will do the right thing if you simply
say <code>git checkout branch</code>; yaay for progress!)</font></p>

<p>The reason <code>git checkout origin/branch</code> creates a detached HEAD is that, while
remote branches can move, they can only do so as a result of a <code>git fetch</code> or
equivalent.  After all, they are meant to track what the <em>remote</em> has, so it
wouldn't make sense for them to acquire <em>local</em> commits!</p>

<p>Here are various ways to detach HEAD:</p>

<pre><code>git checkout origin/master  # (described above)
git checkout master^        # parent of master
git checkout HEAD~2         # grandparent of current HEAD
git checkout tagname        # since you cant commit to a tag!
git checkout &lt;SHA&gt;          # hex digits forming a full or partial SHA
git checkout master^0       # (see note below)
</code></pre>

<p>These will all make the file called <code>HEAD</code> contain the actual (40-hex-digit)
SHA of the corresponding commit instead of some string like <code>ref:
refs/heads/branch</code>.</p>

<p>That last one (<code>git checkout master^0</code>) is interesting.  The <code>master^0</code>
notation means "the actual commit that master points to", so it's just like
saying <code>git checkout &lt;SHA&gt;</code>.</p>

<p><a name="_re_attaching_the_HEAD"></a></p>

<h4>re-attaching the HEAD</h4>

<p>Modern git will warn you about losing commits on a detached HEAD if you're at
the command line, and tell you how to recover (immediately).</p>

<p>Recovery is quite easy.  If you realised you're on a detached HEAD <em>before</em>
you switched to some other branch:</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -b newbranch
</code></pre>

<p>If you switched, possibly made some commits, and <em>then</em> realised you lost some
commits on a detached HEAD, you need to check the reflog to find the lost HEAD
and switch to that using some command like:</p>

<pre><code>git branch newbranch HEAD@{1}
</code></pre>

<p><a name="_the_reflog"></a></p>

<h4>the reflog</h4>

<p>The reflog can show you all the values that HEAD has taken in the past.
Here's a simulated example.  I cloned a repo that had a master and a 'foo'
branch.  I then checked out <code>origin/foo</code>, ignored all the warnings, and made
two commits on what I thought was the "foo" branch.  Then I switched back to
master and made two normal commits on master before I realised that I had
'lost' two commits.</p>

<p>At this point, running <code>git reflog show</code> gives me the following (the most
recent HEAD value is first):</p>

<pre><code>86a8ee0 HEAD@{0}: commit: my second commit on master
e42c4d0 HEAD@{1}: commit: my first commit on master
58c1539 HEAD@{2}: checkout: moving from e2558a9d1527e5a76b39ffede1dc5ca9c650de01 to master
e2558a9 HEAD@{3}: commit: second commit on foo
1c9dfa0 HEAD@{4}: commit: first commit on foo
802f184 HEAD@{5}: checkout: moving from master to origin/foo
58c1539 HEAD@{6}: clone: from /tmp/tmp.lv5IqjK0ZI/b
</code></pre>

<p>That <code>moving from &lt;SHA&gt;...</code> is usually a sign that some commits may have been
lost.  In this case you can run <code>git branch newbranch HEAD@{3}</code> or <code>git branch
newbranch e2558a9</code> to save those commits.  (Notice that the SHA value of
<code>HEAD@{3}</code> is the same one mentioned in the <code>moving from &lt;SHA&gt;...</code> message on
the line above it).</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="common_problems_and_gotchas">common problems and gotchas</a></h1>

<hr />

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#common_problems_and_gotchas">common problems and gotchas</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_windows_keeping_files_open_in_an_editor">(windows) keeping files open in an editor</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_Not_currently_on_any_branch_">"Not currently on any branch"?</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#simple_gotchas_at_the_command_line">simple gotchas at the command line</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="_windows_keeping_files_open_in_an_editor">(windows) keeping files open in an editor</a></h3>

<p>Windows does not allow you to overwrite or delete a file that is open in an
editor.  As a result, operations such as <code>git pull</code>, <code>merge</code>,
<code>rebase</code>, etc., may experience weird problems if they attempt to update
one of the files you have kept open.</p>

<p>If you get funky errors while doing any git operations, close all editors and
try again!</p>

<h3><a name="_Not_currently_on_any_branch_">"Not currently on any branch"?</a></h3>

<p>In the graphical tool <code>gitk</code>, any "branch" that has a leading part in
yellow is a <strong>remote</strong> branch.  Do not checkout such a branch until you get a
little more familiar with git.  It is <strong>not a local branch</strong>, so checking it
out makes no sense.  For normal users, the GUI should prevent this, but it
doesn't, so I'm mentioning it.  (Think of it like a link to an XLS on a
website -- you can click the link and open it and edit it, but you can't save
it back to where it came from!)</p>

<ul>
<li><p>you will recognise you are in such a branch by one of these symptoms</p>

<ul>
<li><code>gitk</code> does not show any branch name in <strong>bold</strong> when you quit and
restart it</li>
<li><code>git gui</code> says <code>current branch: HEAD</code> at the top left</li>
<li><code>git status</code> says <code>Not currently on any branch</code></li>
<li>you are able to commit your changes but when you push them to the
remote server nothing seems to happen</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>to fix this:</p>

<ul>
<li>first give that branch a name to better deal with it for later
troubleshooting: <code>git checkout -b some_new_name</code></li>
<li>then you figure out how to merge those changes into one of the main
branches</li>
<li>then you push</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>Update: I have since written about this in <a href="../concepts/detached-head.html">more depth
here</a>.</p>

<h3><a name="simple_gotchas_at_the_command_line">simple gotchas at the command line</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p><code>git log rev</code> and <code>git diff rev</code> go in different directions.  Log shows
backward from the rev given, while diff goes forward from rev to the
working directory.</p></li>
<li><p>many commands inherit options from lower level programs and their man
pages will appear incomplete.  Read carefully to see what other commands'
options are applicable to this one.  For example, <code>git-log</code> inherits from
<code>git-rev-list</code> and <code>git-diff-tree</code>.</p></li>
<li><p>using <code>cp -a</code> copy instead of <code>git clone</code> will screw the timestamps.  A
subsequent <code>git add .</code> will make it look like every file has changed, in
terms of just the time stamp.  <em>Fix this by using <code>git status</code>, which
updates the index for such cases as a side effect.</em></p></li>
<li><p>confused by <code>HEAD^</code>, <code>HEAD~1</code>, etc.?  <code>man git-rev-parse</code> has a good
diagram.  And remember the reflog is quite different and has a different
syntax (<code>HEAD@{2</code>}).</p></li>
<li><p>cloning a repo: the following two commands are different; see
<a href="http://kerneltrap.org/mailarchive/git/2007/10/1/326757">http://kerneltrap.org/mailarchive/git/2007/10/1/326757</a> (summary: the
second one uses the git protocol, and makes no assumptions about the
original and the clone being on the same file system or even machine)</p>

<pre><code>git clone foo bar           # versus
# FIXME: fix this after permanent conversion to MD is over; should be
# a triple-slash after the "file:"
git clone file:/*foo bar
</code></pre></li>
<li><p><code>git ls-tree</code> does not seem to work well when not at the root of
<code>$GIT_WORK_TREE</code></p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="_user_overview_on_using_git_especially_with_the_GUI_tools">(user) overview on using git, especially with the GUI tools</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_user_overview_on_using_git_especially_with_the_GUI_tools">(user) overview on using git, especially with the GUI tools</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#launching_and_using_git_the_command_line">launching and using git -- the command line</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#launching_and_using_git_the_GUI_interfaces">launching and using git -- the GUI interfaces</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_git_gui_"><code>git gui</code></a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_gitk_"><code>gitk</code></a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#where_you_really_need_the_command_line">where you <em>really</em> need the command line</a><br></p>

<hr />

<blockquote>
  <p><sup>These are generic instructions that may also eventually go on a public
    website somewhere.  Anything that is CAPITALISED in the notes below must
    be replaced as appropriate to (y)our internal environment.  Contact me for
    details.  -- Sitaram Chamarty</sup></p>
</blockquote>

<h3><a name="launching_and_using_git_the_command_line">launching and using git -- the command line</a></h3>

<p>Git has a command line interface and two different GUI interfaces.</p>

<p>The command line interface allows you to do pretty much anything, and is
really the most convenient once you get used to it.  You can get to the
command line in one of the following ways:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>click the "git" or "git bash" icon on your desktop/taskbar or wherever the
install put it.  This will start with the "git bash shell" set to whatever
your "HOME" directory is.  From there you can navigate (using the <code>cd</code>
command) to wherever your repository is.</p>

<ul>
<li>the "git bash shell" is almost a complete unix shell.  So directories
like <code>E:\some\path</code> are accessed as <code>/e/some/path</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>if your repository is in <code>E:\Myname\projects\projectname</code>, open
<code>E:\Myname\projects</code> in the file manager, right click on
<code>projectname</code>, and choose "git bash here".  This will open the "git
bash" command line positioned at that directory.  </p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="launching_and_using_git_the_GUI_interfaces">launching and using git -- the GUI interfaces</a></h3>

<p>The two GUI tools are very powerful; if you don't like the command line, you
can quite easily stick to them and get by for most purposes.  Briefly, the GUI
tools are:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>git gui</code> to stage and unstage files, commit, and push</li>
<li><code>gitk</code> to get a bird's eye view your current branch, or <code>gitk
--all</code> to view all branches, local and remote</li>
</ul>

<p><sup>(<em>staging</em> a file means getting a file ready to commit -- only files that
are staged will be committed; this allows you to keep some changes "pending",
without committing them)</sup></p>

<p>Git's GUI interfaces let you do almost anything that you <strong>normally</strong> need to
do -- all the simple straightforward things as well as some sophisticated
things.  Here's how to launch them:</p>

<ul>
<li>you can launch these GUIs from the "git bash" command line (type
<code>gitk</code> or <code>git gui</code>)</li>
<li>you can right click on a directory containing a repository and choose "git
GUI here"; this launches <code>git gui</code></li>
<li>if you already have one GUI open, you can launch the other one from the
menus ("Repository -> Visualise History", or "File -> Start Git GUI")</li>
</ul>

<p>You might be wondering why there are two GUIs...</p>

<h4><a name="_git_gui_"><code>git gui</code></a></h4>

<p><code>git gui</code> shows you the current state of your work area with respect to
the currently checked-out branch.  In the top left pane, it shows you what
files are changed with respect to the last commit.  In the bottom left pane it
shows you what files have been marked "ready for commit" -- only these changes
will go into the next commit if you commit now.</p>

<p>(As I said above, git allows you to keep some changes "pending", without
committing them.  The "ready to commit" part is called the "index", "staging
area", or "cache" in the documentation, so the bottom left pane is showing you
what is in the "index".  Check out <a href="../concepts/uses-of-index.html">why the index is
useful</a> for more).</p>

<p>In either case, the changes made to the currently selected file are shown on
the right pane.</p>

<p>There are a lot of things you can do in this GUI, but here are the basic
things:</p>

<ul>
<li>you can click on the icon to the left of each file name to move it back
and forth between the two areas ("staged, ready for commit" &lt;-> "unstaged,
not to be committed right now")</li>
<li>you can also type in a suitable commit message and click the "commit"
button.  This commits the change to your local repository</li>
<li>you can also "push" the changes to some central repository so that others
can pull them</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="_gitk_"><code>gitk</code></a></h4>

<p><code>gitk</code> (or <code>gitk --all</code>, which is what I use more often) shows you a
visual tree of all the commits that have happened on this repository.  It is a
very powerful tool, allowing you to do all sorts of things like</p>

<ul>
<li>create a new branch</li>
<li>checkout (switch to) a different branch</li>
<li>delete a branch</li>
<li>create a tag</li>
<li>pick commits from some other branch to apply to the current branch</li>
<li>show differences between any two commits</li>
<li>traverse the tree of commits</li>
<li>search for commits based on all sorts of criteria</li>
</ul>

<p>A word of warning: resist the urge to "checkout" a branch if its name starts
with "remotes".  This is <strong>not a local branch</strong> so checking it out makes no
sense.  Ideally, the GUI should prevent this, but it doesn't, so I'm
mentioning it explicitly.  (Think of it like a link to an XLS on a website --
you can click the link and open it and edit it, but you can't save it back to
where it came from!)</p>

<h4><a name="where_you_really_need_the_command_line">where you <em>really</em> need the command line</a></h4>

<p>One common task that is needlessly complex in both the GUIs is <code>git pull</code>.
In a properly setup repository that has been cloned from the project master or
something like that, getting the latest changes is just a matter of typing
<code>git pull</code>.  In <code>git gui</code>, described above, this takes 4 steps,
although there is a reason for that complexity :-)</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="the_missing_gitk_documentation">the missing gitk documentation</a></h1>

<p><sup></p>

<p><code>gitk</code> is a very powerful GUI tool.  It's one of those rare beasts where the
pretty stuff is not just a crutch for the command-line-ignorant -- it actually
does really useful things that just cannot be done in a CLI.</p>

<p>Sadly, it is woefully undocumented.  Scratch that, it's almost <em>completely</em>
undocumented.</p>

<p>This is my attempt to do something about that.  Strictly speaking, you can
explore the UI and find all these features yourself, and indeed, if you find
any that are not listed here, please <a href="mailto:sitaramc@gmail.com">email me</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#the_missing_gitk_documentation">the missing gitk documentation</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#colors_and_bold">colors and bold</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#repository_operations">repository operations</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#the_main_menu">the main menu</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#browsing_the_commit_list_top_pane_">browsing the commit list (top pane)</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#browsing_the_diff">browsing the diff</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#running_a_diff_between_two_arbitrary_commits">running a diff between two arbitrary commits</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#searching_for_commits">searching for commits</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#navigating_the_commit_tree">navigating the commit tree</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#some_other_tricks">some other tricks</a><br></p>

<p></sup></p>

<h3><a name="colors_and_bold">colors and bold</a></h3>

<ul>
<li>local branch names are in a green background.</li>
<li>remote branch names are in a mixed orange/green background.  (<a href="../concepts/detached-head.html"><strong>DO NOT
checkout remote branches</strong></a>!)</li>
<li>the currently checked out branch name is in bold.</li>
<li>tags are on a yellow background.</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="repository_operations">repository operations</a></h3>

<p>All these are from the commit list (the top pane):</p>

<ul>
<li><p>right clicking on a commit message</p>

<ul>
<li>create a tag</li>
<li>create a new branch</li>
<li>reset the current branch to this commit (soft/mixed/hard)</li>
<li>cherry-pick this current onto the current branch</li>
</ul></li>
<li><p>right clicking on a branch name</p>

<ul>
<li>checkout the branch (please heed the warning above and <a href="../concepts/detached-head.html"><strong>DO NOT
checkout remote branches</strong></a>!)</li>
<li>remove the branch</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="the_main_menu">the main menu</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>reload: if you're doing stuff on the command line in another screen, and
want those changes reflected in gitk, hit <code>F5</code>.</p>

<p><code>F5</code> updates the refs and shows you their new values <em>while still showing
you the old ones</em>.  It is most useful after operations like rebase,
because you can compare the previous branch head with the new one.</p>

<p>(<code>Ctrl-F5</code>, on the other hand, is a total refresh, throwing away
everything that was previously shown.)</p></li>
<li><p>list/choose references: to quickly go to a particular reference, hit <code>F2</code>.
If there are too many, you can specify a glob pattern in the box at the
bottom to subset the list.  Clicking on a reference takes the main window
to that reference.  The list window will stay open so you can click on
other refs.</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="browsing_the_commit_list_top_pane_">browsing the commit list (top pane)</a></h3>

<p>Many of these functions also have character key bindings.  For example "n"
acts the same as a "down arrow".  I'm not listing those; if you need them,
look in the source code for a series of <code>bindkey</code> statements and match them up
with the others.  It's not hard, and you don't need to know Tcl.  (I don't).</p>

<ul>
<li>up/down arrow keys, pageup/down: obvious</li>
<li>left/right arrow keys: previous/next commit in browse history (think web
browser's back/forward)</li>
<li>shift-up/down: find previous/next match (see <a href="#sfc">searching for commits</a>
below)</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="browsing_the_diff">browsing the diff</a></h3>

<p>At any time, the bottom left pane shows a "diff", usually of the current
commit shown in the top pane.  The bottom right pane (by default) shows a list
of files in this "diff".</p>

<p><a name="bcpc"></p>

<ul>
<li>spacebar: move forward 1 page in the diff view</li>
<li>backspace/delete: ditto, but backward</li>
<li>"f": move to next file in the diff.  Both the bottom left and right panes
will show a change when you do this.</li>
<li>"b": ditto, but previous file</li>
<li>click a file in the bottom right pane: scrolls the left pane to show that
file's changes</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="running_a_diff_between_two_arbitrary_commits">running a diff between two arbitrary commits</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>left click on the "new" commit</li>
<li>navigate using the scrollbar (no keyboard shortcut, AFAICT) to some other
commit</li>
<li><em>right-click</em> and choose "Diff this -> selected"</li>
</ul>

<p>Now you can browse that diff using the keyboard or mouse.  Note that any
movement that selects a different commit (like pressing an arrow key) will
change the view to show that commit, so while examining this "diff", stick to
<a href="#bcpc">these keys</a>.</p>

<p><a name="sfc"></p>

<h3><a name="searching_for_commits">searching for commits</a></h3>

<p>Here're some ways to search for commits.  The commits that result will become
highlighted in bold, so you can see them in the context of their surrounding
changes.  You can navigate between matches using the shift-up/down-arrow keys.</p>

<p>There is a widget to the left of the search box that controls what type of
search you do.  By default it is set to "containing:", which searches the
commit message.</p>

<ul>
<li><p>searching on commit message: just hit <code>"/"</code> and type in any text.  This
will match all commits where the commit message contained the text you
typed.</p></li>
<li><p>searching by filename: navigate to some commit that affected the file.
Right click the filename in the bottom right pane and choose "Highlight
this only".  If you want to add more files to the search in an "OR" type
match, right click some other file (doesn't have to be the same commit),
and choose "Highlight this too".</p>

<p>Notice that when you do this, the search type widget changes from
"containing:" to "touching paths:".</p></li>
<li><p>searching by changed text: set the search type widget to "adding/removing
string:", then type in a search text.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>Now that you've understood that widget, take a look at the others on the right
also; they're fairly self-explanatory.  Note that the last widget (All fields,
Headlines, Comments, Author, Committer) is only valid when the type of search
widget shows "containing:".</p>

<h3><a name="navigating_the_commit_tree">navigating the commit tree</a></h3>

<p>There are several ways to navigate the tree quickly.</p>

<ul>
<li><p>the diff pane always shows all the parents and children of the current
commit.  Click on any of the hashes to go there.  Some of the text from
the commit message of those hashes is also shown, to give you an idea of
what that is.</p></li>
<li><p>the diff pane also shows all the branches to which this commit belongs.
Click any of them to go to the head of that branch.</p></li>
<li><p>when the commit graph gets really complex, the line connecting two commits
is broken.  Click on any line segment (not on a dot or a dangling
arrowhead) and the diff pane changes to show details for that line segment
-- all parents and children are shown.</p></li>
<li><p>as above, but if you click on the <em>arrowhead</em>, you will be taken to the
portion of the tree where the other end of the arrowhead would go to.
Your "current" commit is still the same; this is just a way of
"connecting" two pieces of the graph that are otherwise too far away.</p></li>
<li><p>"Follows:" and "Precedes:" show the nearest tag before and after the
commit for each branch that the commit is a part of.  For example, if you
find the commit for a bugfix or a feature you want, this will tell you the
minimum version you should upgrade to.</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="some_other_tricks">some other tricks</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>expand the diff view by using the spin control that says "Lines of
context"; the default value is 3.</p></li>
<li><p>find the "origin" of any line visible in the "diff" pane by right clicking
and choosing "Show origin of this line".  This does not make sense for
lines prefixed by a plus sign of course.</p></li>
<li><p>go to a specific commit by SHA: click on a commit, hit TAB twice to get
the focus onto the SHA1 field, then type in the first few characters of
the SHA you want.</p>

<p>If you click in the field with a mouse, it deselects the text within the
field, and (for some reason), shift-select is disabled so you have to hold
down the delete key to delete the entire field before you start typing in
the new hash.  Irritating, but it's only the mouse use, not keyboard use,
so it's ok, I guess.</p></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="DOs_and_DONTs">DOs and DONTs</a></h1>

<p><sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#DOs_and_DONTs">DOs and DONTs</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#DOs">DOs</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#setting_up_your_gitconfig">setting up your gitconfig</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#your_global_gitconfig">your global gitconfig</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_admin_every_bare_repository">(admin) every bare repository</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#write_useful_readable_commit_messages">write useful, readable, commit messages</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#DONTs">DONTs</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#actions_whose_results_can_be_confusing">actions whose results can be confusing</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#do_not_checkout_remote_branches">do not checkout "remote" branches</a><br>
</sup></p>

<hr />

<h2><a name="DOs">DOs</a></h2>

<h3><a name="setting_up_your_gitconfig">setting up your gitconfig</a></h3>

<h4><a name="your_global_gitconfig">your global gitconfig</a></h4>

<p>This is <code>$HOME/.gitconfig</code>.  Whenever you add the <code>--global</code> option to the
<code>git config</code> command, it acts on the global gitconfig file.</p>

<p>Setup your identity</p>

<pre><code>git config --global user.email your.name@your.com
git config --global user.name "your name"
</code></pre>

<p>Setup the push default: choose one of these.  New users should take the first
one, but the traditional default has always been the second one, so I'm used
to that</p>

<pre><code>git config --global push.default nothing
git config --global push.default matching
</code></pre>

<p>Setup to edit files from within "git gui"; replace "gvim -f" with whatever you
prefer</p>

<pre><code>git config --global guitool.Edit.cmd 'gvim -f $FILENAME'
git config --global guitool.Edit.noconsole yes
git config --global guitool.Edit.needsfile yes
</code></pre>

<p>If you intend to use the command line more than the GUI, please do check out
<a href="../tools/my.gitconfig.txt">my gitconfig</a> for many useful examples that will
save you lots of time and trouble.</p>

<h4><a name="_admin_every_bare_repository">(admin) every bare repository</a></h4>

<p><sup><a href="../concepts/bare.html">What is a bare repo?</a></sup></p>

<p>Make sure all updates are logged and remote deletion of branches is disabled.
If this is a "git server" (all repos are bare), you should seriously consider
just adding the <code>--global</code> option to the two commands below, so you don't have
to remember to do this on each repo.</p>

<pre><code>git config core.logAllRefUpdates true
git config receive.denyDeletes true
</code></pre>

<h3><a name="write_useful_readable_commit_messages">write useful, readable, commit messages</a></h3>

<p>A good description of this is at <a href="http://www.tpope.net/node/106">http://www.tpope.net/node/106</a>.  But
briefly, try and stick to the following guidelines:</p>

<ul>
<li>the first line of the commit message (often called a "subject") should be
a <em>summary</em> of the entire commit</li>
<li>it should not be more than about 70 characters long</li>
<li>it should include any reference info (like bug number, issue number, etc)
if applicable</li>
<li>the rest of the message ("body") can be pretty much anything, but leave a
blank line between the "subject" and the "body"</li>
</ul>

<p>Git uses the "subject" part in many places and it is very useful to have a
short, meaningful subject line for each commit.</p>

<h2><a name="DONTs">DONTs</a></h2>

<h3><a name="actions_whose_results_can_be_confusing">actions whose results can be confusing</a></h3>

<h4><a name="do_not_checkout_remote_branches">do not checkout "remote" branches</a></h4>

<p>When running <code>gitk</code> (the graphical history viewer) do NOT be tempted to right
click and checkout any branch whose name starts with "remotes/".</p>

<p>Helpfully, these branches are colored partly orange and partly green.
(Branches that are safe to checkout are colored fully green.)</p>

<p>The problem with checking out a "remotes" branch is that any commits you make
on top of them can get lost when you checkout some other branch.  See the
article on a <a href="../concepts/detached-head.html">detached head</a>.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>simple git session</h1>

<p>This is a transcript of a simple git session, using local files as the
"transport" medium.  We use a "bare" repo, in a directory called "b", as the
"server", and working clones in directories called "c" and "c2".</p>

<p>That is, we simply use the local file system as the transport protocol.
People familiar with URLs on a browser might recognise this as eqvt to
<code>file:///full/path/to/something</code>, and indeed that is exactly what git treats
it as.</p>

<p>Using ssh or http merely changes</p>

<ul>
<li>the URL used</li>
<li>the authentication required and permissions granted by the server</li>
</ul>

<p>What <strong>does NOT change</strong> is the behaviour of most git commands!</p>

<p>This means you can play with git to your heart's content in some temporary
directory.  There's no danger of messing up a real repo, or of getting
side-tracked by connectivity or permissions or even speed issues, which might
happen if you tried this with a real server.</p>

<hr />

<p>Notes: Blank lines placed before each command for clarity.</p>

<hr />

<pre><code>$ mkdir simple-demo

$ cd simple-demo

$ git init --bare b
Initialized empty Git repository in /home/sitaram/t/simple-demo/b/
</code></pre>

<p>This is your "server" repo.</p>

<pre><code>$ git clone b c
Cloning into c...
done.
warning: You appear to have cloned an empty repository.
</code></pre>

<p>That is actually the same as <code>git clone file://$PWD/b c</code>, where that
<code>file://...</code> stuff is a URL, as discussed above.</p>

<pre><code>$ cd c

$ touch file;git add file;git commit -m 'added file'
[master (root-commit) fe2f9d5] added file
 0 files changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 file
</code></pre>

<p>Now it's time to push the changes to the "server".</p>

<pre><code>$ git push
No refs in common and none specified; doing nothing.
Perhaps you should specify a branch such as 'master'.
fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly
error: failed to push some refs to '/home/sitaram/t/simple-demo/b'
</code></pre>

<p>This is a common mistake, not realising that the first push needs an explicit
branch name because your clone and the server have "no refs in common"
(meaning no branches or tags), which is true, since the server is an empty
repo, containing <em>nothing</em> at all right now.  When the two repos have no refs
in common, "git push" doesn't know what to do, so you have to be specific:</p>

<pre><code>$ git push origin master
Counting objects: 3, done.
Writing objects: 100% (3/3), 209 bytes, done.
Total 3 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
Unpacking objects: 100% (3/3), done.
To /home/sitaram/t/simple-demo/b
 * [new branch]      master -&gt; master
</code></pre>

<p>Now we go out of this clone and make a new one:</p>

<pre><code>$ cd ..

$ git clone b c2
Cloning into c2...
done.

$ cd c2

$ git log
commit fe2f9d5a80968856916b03395dd9b9f6d08d73a6
Author: Sitaram Chamarty &lt;sitaram@atc.tcs.com&gt;
Date:   Sat Oct 16 15:17:46 2010 +0530

    added file
</code></pre>

<p>And hey -- there's the commit you made in directory "c" and pushed up to the
server!</p>

<p>So now you make some changes here and push them to the "server":</p>

<pre><code>$ touch file2;git add file2; git commit -m 'added file2'
[master 48eed78] added file2
 0 files changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 file2

$ git push
Counting objects: 3, done.
Delta compression using up to 2 threads.
Compressing objects: 100% (2/2), done.
Writing objects: 100% (2/2), 237 bytes, done.
Total 2 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
Unpacking objects: 100% (2/2), done.
To /home/sitaram/t/simple-demo/b
   fe2f9d5..48eed78  master -&gt; master
</code></pre>

<p>And back in "c" you see how things look, and do other gittish things:</p>

<pre><code>$ cd ../c

$ git fetch
remote: Counting objects: 3, done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (2/2), done.
remote: Total 2 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
Unpacking objects: 100% (2/2), done.
From /home/sitaram/t/simple-demo/b
   fe2f9d5..48eed78  master     -&gt; origin/master

$ git status
# On branch master
# Your branch is behind 'origin/master' by 1 commit, and can be fast-forwarded.
#
nothing to commit (working directory clean)

$ git pull
Updating fe2f9d5..48eed78
Fast-forward
 0 files changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 file2

$ git status
# On branch master
nothing to commit (working directory clean)

$ git log
commit 48eed784d1f57f1fbae6bd75d171608d6730b30b
Author: Sitaram Chamarty &lt;sitaram@atc.tcs.com&gt;
Date:   Sat Oct 16 15:18:52 2010 +0530

    added file2

commit fe2f9d5a80968856916b03395dd9b9f6d08d73a6
Author: Sitaram Chamarty &lt;sitaram@atc.tcs.com&gt;
Date:   Sat Oct 16 15:17:46 2010 +0530

    added file
</code></pre>

<hr />

<p>There... was that so hard?</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>a very basic intro to version control and git</h1>

<h1>why</h1>

<p>../images/projects-sans-vcs.png</p>

<h1>what is a VCS</h1>

<h1>why use a VCS</h1>

<ul>
<li>reversibility or rollback@@, aka C-Y-A!
<ul>
<li>linear (on the time axis)@@, simple to implement</li>
</ul></li>
<li>concurrency
<ul>
<li>non-linear@@, all the complexity is here</li>
</ul></li>
<li>annotation</li>
</ul>

<h1>creating a repository</h1>

<ul>
<li>how hard is it?</li>
</ul>

<h1>an empty directory</h1>

<p>intro-images/empty.png</p>

<h1>add some files</h1>

<p>intro-images/sampleproj.png</p>

<h1>'git init' -- done!</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-done.png</p>

<h1>how about on windows?</h1>

<p>intro-images/empty-windows.png</p>

<h1>making a repository</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-win1.png</p>

<h1>making a repository</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-win2.png</p>

<h1>making a repository</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-win3.png</p>

<h1>done!</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-win4.png</p>

<h1>just checking...</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-done-win1.png</p>

<h1>yup -- works fine!</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-done-win2.png</p>

<h1>CLI on windows?</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-winb1.png</p>

<h1>a bash shell</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-winb2.png</p>

<h1>'git init' -- done!</h1>

<p>intro-images/init-done-winb.png</p>

<h1>what is a 'work tree'</h1>

<p>intro-images/worktree.png</p>

<h1>what is a 'repo'</h1>

<ul>
<li>A repository is just
<ul>
<li>a work tree, @@plus</li>
<li>a special '.git' directory at the top level of the work tree.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>NEVER FIDDLE WITH THIS DIRECTORY UNLESS YOU KNOW WHAT YOU ARE DOING!</li>
<li>YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!</li>
</ul>

<h1>repository</h1>

<p>intro-images/repo.png</p>

<h1>(what's inside '.git'?)</h1>

<p>intro-images/inside-dotgit.png</p>

<h1>you said 'non-linear'</h1>

<p>l:intro-images/worktree-symbol.png</p>

<ul>
<li>sure...</li>
<li>a repository keeps snapshots of the work tree...</li>
<li>...at different points in time</li>
</ul>

<h1>snap</h1>

<p>intro-images/repo-1.png</p>

<h1>snapshots</h1>

<p>intro-images/repo-2.png</p>

<h1>snapshots of the work tree</h1>

<p>intro-images/repo-3.png</p>

<h1>at different</h1>

<p>intro-images/repo-4.png</p>

<h1>at different points</h1>

<p>intro-images/repo-5.png</p>

<h1>at different points in time</h1>

<p>intro-images/repo-6.png</p>

<h1>what is a commit</h1>

<p>remember those snapshots?  Yup -- they're all commits!</p>

<p>Here, to refresh your memory:</p>

<p>h50%:intro-images/repo-6.png</p>

<h1>what is a repo again?</h1>

<ul>
<li>a work tree + .git?  @@sure, but also...</li>
<li>a bunch of commits laid out as a 'graph'
<ul>
<li>a "directed acyclic graph", if you're interested</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>DAG</h1>

<p>intro-images/dag.png</p>

<h1>what is a branch</h1>

<ul>
<li>since a graph is sort of the same as a tree (for our purposes)
<ul>
<li>it has branches</li>
<li>and those branches have names</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>branches</h1>

<p>intro-images/dag-br.png</p>

<h1>what is a tag</h1>

<ul>
<li>when you checkout a branch and then commit, the branch is now pointing at
the new 'snapshot'.  @@This means...</li>
<li>...the branch 'tip' keeps moving with every commit</li>
<li>But sometimes you want to mark a point in your development
<ul>
<li>with some sort of a permanent label</li>
<li>that stays right there, even if you add commits on top</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>tags</h1>

<p>intro-images/dag-br-tag.png</p>

<h1>general VCS concepts</h1>

<ul>
<li>"project": minimum set of source code (and related files) needed
to <strong>build</strong> the software</li>
<li>in a CVCS (Centralised VCS)
<ul>
<li>each project will have exactly one "repository"</li>
<li>on some central server</li>
<li>and each developer will checkout the project
<ul>
<li>from the server to his workstation</li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>a DVCS is different</h1>

<ul>
<li>each project will have one "central" repository
<ul>
<li>(maybe; see next slide)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>but each repository can have many "clones"</li>
<li>so each developer has a clone on his workstation
<ul>
<li>a complete copy of the repository</li>
<li>plus his own work/changes</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>central repo in a DVCS?</h1>

<ul>
<li>the developers can push and pull from each other directly
<ul>
<li>because they're also repositories just like the "central" one</li>
</ul></li>
<li>so do we still need a "central" repo?
<ul>
<li>not really@@; that's only an administrative decision now</li>
<li>not a technical requirement</li>
<li>but it makes managing projects easier</li>
<li>so yes, we still have central repos for most projects</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>what is a 'remote'</h1>

<ul>
<li>when you clone, the repo you cloned from is a 'remote' for you</li>
<li>every remote has a name (a user-friendly name you choose)</li>
<li>(special case for clone: the 'remote' has a special name: 'origin')
<ul>
<li>much nicer than using the full URL, like</li>
<li><code>ssh://sitaram@git.server/repos/myproj.git</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li>bad picture coming up...</li>
</ul>

<h1>remotes</h1>

<p>(ok that's not a bad picture; it's HORRIBLE picture!)</p>

<p>intro-images/remote.png</p>

<h1>git concepts</h1>

<ul>
<li>repo
<ul>
<li>self-contained; remove ".git" at the top and it's all gone</li>
</ul></li>
<li>branch
<ul>
<li>an active line of development</li>
<li>a repo can track any number of branches</li>
</ul></li>
<li>master
<ul>
<li>name of default branch in a new git project</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>concept detail: branches</h1>

<ul>
<li>easy and inexpensive</li>
<li>can have separate branches for separate features</li>
<li>many being worked on "simultaneously"!</li>
<li>you can switch rapidly between branches</li>
<li>boosts individual productivity as well as team productivity</li>
<li>almost all existing VCSs suck at this</li>
</ul>

<h1>individual productivity?</h1>

<ul>
<li>concurrency</li>
<li>makes context switching trivial</li>
</ul>

<h1>git concepts (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>working tree
<ul>
<li>is associated with only one branch at any time</li>
</ul></li>
<li>head
<ul>
<li>the tip of a branch</li>
</ul></li>
<li>HEAD
<ul>
<li>the tip of the branch associated with your working tree; this is where
commits go</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>git concepts (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>index: holding area for changes approved for commit
<ul>
<li>git tracks content, not files</li>
<li>lets you select some files to commit while postponing others</li>
<li>lets you keep uncommited changes hanging around</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>some more git concepts</h1>

<ul>
<li>commit ancestry</li>
<li>commit ancestry as a DAG
<ul>
<li>the essence of git is to build and traverse this DAG</li>
<li>http://sitaramc.github.com/gcs/index.html</li>
</ul></li>
<li>universal public identifier (a SHA-1 hash)
<ul>
<li>every file, directory, and commit has a unique hash</li>
<li>check the integrity of an entire repo by comparing just one 160-bit
value (40 hex digits)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>workflow</h1>

<ul>
<li>far better than anything I can try:
<ul>
<li>http://nathanj.github.com/gitguide</li>
</ul></li>
<li>so I'll just describe things at a high level</li>
</ul>

<h1>one-time setup</h1>

<ul>
<li>per developer
<ul>
<li>set up your name and email address</li>
</ul></li>
<li>per developer per project
<ul>
<li>'git init' (the first guy)</li>
<li>'git clone ...' (the others)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>err... clone?  from where?</h1>

<ul>
<li>git servers and protocols (note: git does NO access control!)
<ul>
<li>ssh (RW, access control by ssh)</li>
<li>file protocol (RW, access control by OS)</li>
<li>git protocol (RO, access control by OS/firewall etc)
<ul>
<li>needs git daemon to be started first</li>
</ul></li>
<li>old style http (RO, access control by Apache)
<ul>
<li>RW possible but painful; requires WebDAV</li>
</ul></li>
<li>new style http (RW, access control by apache)
<ul>
<li>requires git 1.6.6 or better on both server and client</li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>many users/repos?</h1>

<ul>
<li>just install 'gitolite' and be done!</li>
<li>gitolite can provide fine-grained access control</li>
<li>works over sshd or apache
<ul>
<li>sshd (or httpd) authenticates the user</li>
<li>passes the username to gitolite</li>
<li>gitolite uses the authenticated username, looks at the config file, and
makes the authorisation decision</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>normal workflow activities</h1>

<ul>
<li>checkout a branch</li>
<li>edit files</li>
<li>review your changes ('git diff', or 'git gui')</li>
<li>review other people's changes or your older commits ('gitk' -- a very
powerful GUI tool)</li>
<li>stage and commit them</li>
</ul>

<h1>normal workflow activities</h1>

<ul>
<li>push your commits to the server</li>
<li>push failed?  maybe your teammates committed something recently?
<ul>
<li>pull from the server first</li>
<li>their changes get merged into your local repo</li>
<li>then you push...</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>clean and dirty work tree</h1>

<ul>
<li>clean: all changes committed to local repo</li>
<li>dirty: some files changed, and changes not yet committed</li>
<li>PULL IS BEST DONE ON A CLEAN TREE!</li>
</ul>

<h1>clean tree - CLI</h1>

<p>intro-images/clean-cli.png</p>

<h1>clean tree - GUI</h1>

<p>intro-images/clean-gui.png</p>

<h1>dirty tree - CLI</h1>

<p>intro-images/dirty-cli.png</p>

<h1>dirty tree - GUI</h1>

<p>intro-images/dirty-gui.png</p>

<h1>staging from the GUI</h1>

<p>intro-images/staging-gui.png</p>

<h1>staged files - CLI</h1>

<p>intro-images/staged-cli.png</p>

<h1>committing from the GUI</h1>

<p>intro-images/commit-gui.png</p>

<h1>clean again!</h1>

<p>intro-images/clean-again.png</p>

<h1>conflicts</h1>

<ul>
<li>what is a conflict</li>
<li>how do you resolve it?</li>
</ul>

<h1>advanced workflow activities</h1>

<ul>
<li>cherry-pick -- pick up specific changes from another branch or repo and
make those changes happen in your repo</li>
<li>rebase -- move commits around@@; sort of like
<ul>
<li>cut off a branch where it connects to the trunk of a tree...</li>
<li>...and graft it somewhere else</li>
</ul></li>
<li>bisect</li>
</ul>

<h1>...and we're done!</h1>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="who_pushed_this_particular_commit_">who pushed this particular commit?</a></h1>

<p><sup>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#who_pushed_this_particular_commit_">who pushed this particular commit?</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#WARNING_THIS_DOCUMENT_IS_OBSOLETE">WARNING: THIS DOCUMENT IS OBSOLETE</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#one_time_setup">one-time setup</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#investigation">investigation</a><br></p>

<p></sup></p>

<hr />

<h2><a name="WARNING_THIS_DOCUMENT_IS_OBSOLETE">WARNING: THIS DOCUMENT IS OBSOLETE</a></h2>

<p>Just install gitolite -- it'll produce a much better log than anything you'll
get from this document.  See the "better logging" section of
<a href="http://github.com/sitaramc/gitolite/blob/master/doc/3-faq-tips-etc.mkd">http://github.com/sitaramc/gitolite/blob/master/doc/3-faq-tips-etc.mkd</a></p>

<p><strong>I'm keeping this document around only to show you how difficult this is
without gitolite ;-)</strong></p>

<p>Gitolite is at <a href="http://github.com/sitaramc/gitolite">http://github.com/sitaramc/gitolite</a></p>

<p>... and now, on to the document</p>

<hr />

<p>Someone on IRC postulated that git does not track who pushed a series of
commits into a server, and could allow one dev to blame some other dev by
pushing stuff with the victim's name/email as the author/committer.</p>

<p>The first answer to this of course is that you can force everything to happen
with gpg-signed tags -- the project pulls only gpg-signed tags, and if you
signed a tag (which in turn stamps the entire commit DAG upto that point) then
you'd better know what you're doing!</p>

<p>However, we don't always sign like this; it makes it cumbersome and it
requires all the devs to conform to this discipline, and is too big a price to
pay for something that may never happen.  We need something that'll just sit
in the background, saving enough info for us to track "after the fact", should
it ever become necessary.</p>

<h3><a name="one_time_setup">one-time setup</a></h3>

<p>So, the short answer, for a gitosis-administered central repo, is this:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>(as root) in <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code>, add the following lines (or change
INFO to VERBOSE if that's already present)</p>

<pre><code># Logging
SyslogFacility AUTH
LogLevel VERBOSE
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>(as the "git" user) in each repository of interest (or globally, by adding
<code>--global</code>; highly recommended for servers), do the following.  The second command is useful even in
general, but in this case the relevance is that deleting a branch wipes
out its reflog too, so you want to prevent that:</p>

<pre><code>git config core.logAllRefUpdates true
git config receive.denyDeletes true
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<p>That's it.  Of course, if your system logs get deleted after about 4 weeks or
so, you may want to keep <code>auth.log</code> out of it or do something to preserve
those logs for a longer period of time.</p>

<h3><a name="investigation">investigation</a></h3>

<p>So let's say you look at the reflog and find you want to know who pushed a
particular commit[1]</p>

<pre><code>git@git:~/repositories/testing.git$ git reflog
582b3ad... HEAD@{0}: push
f0a5fc1...
</code></pre>

<p>You're interested in <code>582b3ad</code>, so you do the following (note that the output
line below is wrapped for the purposes of this page):</p>

<pre><code>git@git:~/repositories/testing.git$ grep -r ' 582b3' logs
logs/HEAD:f0a5fc1171c967a7af975fc454a25a599066565b
    582b3ad0219d922a9aed6f5cbb3f4f9a5741df6b git master user
    &lt;git@my.domain.com&gt; 1238837842 +0530      push
</code></pre>

<p>There's a timestamp in there, that <code>1238837842</code> thing, which you have to
decode:</p>

<pre><code>$ perl -le 'print scalar(localtime $ARGV[0])' 1238837842
Sat Apr  4 15:07:22 2009
</code></pre>

<p>Come Watson, the game is afoot...</p>

<pre><code>root@git:/var/log# grep Apr..4.15:07 auth.log
Apr  4 15:07:19 git sshd[23765]: Connection from 172.25.149.2 port 56889
Apr  4 15:07:20 git sshd[23765]: Failed none for git from 172.25.149.2 port 56889 ssh2
Apr  4 15:07:20 git sshd[23765]: Found matching RSA key: fc:c1:48:1e:06:31:97:a4:8b:fc:37:b2:76:14:c7:53
Apr  4 15:07:21 git sshd[23765]: Found matching RSA key: fc:c1:48:1e:06:31:97:a4:8b:fc:37:b2:76:14:c7:53
Apr  4 15:07:21 git sshd[23765]: Accepted publickey for git from 172.25.149.2 port 56889 ssh2
Apr  4 15:07:21 git sshd[23768]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user git by (uid=0)
Apr  4 15:07:22 git sshd[23768]: Connection closed by 172.25.149.2
Apr  4 15:07:22 git sshd[23768]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session closed for user git
Apr  4 15:07:22 git sshd[23768]: Closing connection to 172.25.149.2
</code></pre>

<p>Now go to a clone of the gitosis-admin directory, and do this (I've removed
the <code>&gt;</code> signs that normally form <code>$PS2</code> so you can copy-paste this):</p>

<pre><code>$ cd keydir
$ for i in *.pub
do
    cat $i | while read r
    do
        echo "$r" &gt; /tmp/junk.pubkey
        ssh-keygen -l -f /tmp/junk.pubkey |grep fc.c1.48 &amp;&amp;
            echo ===== $i matched =====
    done
done
2048 fc:c1:48:1e:06:31:97:a4:8b:fc:37:b2:76:14:c7:53 /tmp/junk.pubkey (RSA)
===== sitaram.pub matched =====
</code></pre>

<p>And we've nailed him :-)</p>

<p><sup>
PS: a note on that shell snippet: you need to do it this way because a gitosis
pubkey file can contain more than one pubkey (for the same user of course) in
it.  Typically this is because of using different machines or whatever.  If
you pass such a file to <code>ssh-keygen -l</code> it'll only compute the fingerprint of
the first pubkey in the file.  I found this out quite luckily -- I'd
completely forgotten about the multiple keys per file thing...!
</sup></p>

<hr />

<p><sup>
[1] The reflog stores only the "tip" of a series of commits, so if the
suspicious commit is in the middle of a series which was pushed all at once,
you have some extra work.</p>

<p>The basic idea is, you take the second SHA in each reflog line, check
if it is a descendent of the commit you want, note the timestamp if so, and
then choose the earliest among them to go check in <code>auth.log</code>.</p>

<p>I'll write a script to do this if someone asks... right now I can't be
bothered :-)
</sup></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>ignoring an upstream commit permanently</h1>

<p>(untested)</p>

<p>...as usual, doener on irc, circa 2009-07-15 10:00</p>

<hr />

<h5>problem</h5>

<pre><code>A---B---C---D---E (master)
 \
  X---X---V---X (upstream)
</code></pre>

<p>You try to merge upstream to master and get a shitload of conflicts.</p>

<p>"gitk --merge" tells you that commit V is "guilty" and is just a variation of,
let's say, B (doesn't matter), that differs enough to cause those conflicts.</p>

<p>You decide that you don't want V's version of the changes, now or in future.
That is, though you will keep merging from upstream, you don't want to see "V"
ever again.</p>

<h5>assumption</h5>

<p>You never have to push this upstream; it's your private copy (think "customer
specific branch")</p>

<h5>caveats</h5>

<p>Eventually, something upstream will patch something from V, and since you
don't have that particular set of code, you'll get a patch that cannot be
applied.  At that point you can repeat this method to discard <em>that</em> commit,
or fix the conflicts somehow and move on.</p>

<h5>the hard solution</h5>

<p>Fix all the conflicts and commit.  For people still living in other version
control systems :-)</p>

<h5>the easy solution</h5>

<p>Create a branch from upstream where you revert V and merge that to master</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -b tmp upstream
git revert V        # produces commit "R"
git checkout master
git merge tmp       # please also use -m to document this properly!
git branch -d tmp

A---B---C---D---E---M (master)
 \                 /
  \               R
   \             /
    X---X---V---X (upstream)
</code></pre>

<p>Next update from upstream will lead to:</p>

<pre><code>git merge upstream

A---B---C---D---E---M---M2 (master)
 \                 /   /
  \               R   /
   \             /   /
    X---X---V---X---X (upstream)
</code></pre>

<p>(and so on; you've essentially eliminated "V" forever in your branch).</p>

<p>Note: doener calls this ugly, but I like this much better than the next one.
First, this only uses porcelain, no plumbing.  Second, the extra commit "R"
makes it clear that something happened, even if the merge commit at "M" was
not properly commented.</p>

<h5>the hackish, low-level solution</h5>

<p>Don't use this if, like me, you're not comfortable with plumbing.  This
section is just for the record, and because the idea is very cool.
Personally, I never use plumbing -- too many commands, too hard for me to
understand, even more difficult (for me) to explain.</p>

<p>Create a branch from upstream, and revert V</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -b tmp upstream
git revert V
</code></pre>

<p>Merge master to that:</p>

<pre><code>git merge master
</code></pre>

<p>Hopefully, the revert as well as the merge went pretty much conflict-free now.
So you have the merge result that you want in tmp.</p>

<p>Now, create the real merge:</p>

<pre><code>git checkout master
git merge upstream
</code></pre>

<p>This will cause conflicts again, but instead of fixing them, you just re-use
the merge result that you already have:</p>

<pre><code>git read-tree -u --reset tmp    # This reads the tree of the previous merge and
                                # puts it into the index and  working tree

git commit
</code></pre>

<p>This leads to</p>

<pre><code>A---B---C---D---E---M (master)
 \                 /
  X---X---V---X---- (upstream)
</code></pre>

<p>And the next update then gives:</p>

<pre><code>A---B---C---D---E---M---M (master)
 \                 /   /
  X---X---V---X-------X (upstream)
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="dev_integ_workflow">dev/integ workflow</a></h1>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#dev_integ_workflow">dev/integ workflow</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#workflow">workflow</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#branches">branches</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#assumptions_startup_">assumptions / startup:</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#developer_workflow">developer workflow</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#integrator">integrator</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#gitolite_advanced_features_supporing_this_flow">gitolite advanced features supporing this flow</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h2><a name="workflow">workflow</a></h2>

<p>This is one possible workflow for dev/integ using gitolite.  It assumes that
there is one "integrator" and N developers "dev1", ... "devN".</p>

<h3><a name="branches">branches</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p><code>integ</code> -- a branch that is <code>R</code> (readonly) for devs, <code>RW+</code> for integrator.
This branch will always be kept in a compilable, basically runnable, state
by the integrator.  The history of this branch will be kept reasonably
clean.</p>

<p>Each developer will start a new piece of work or task using <code>integ</code> as a
starting point, and making sure that when he submits his work it builds
upon this stable point.</p></li>
<li><p><code>dev/dev1/</code>, <code>dev/dev2/</code>, ... <code>dev/devN/</code></p>

<p>branches under the <code>dev/devX/</code> hierarchy belong to the developer called
<code>devX</code>.  He submits his work to the integrator by pushing to one such
branch and emailing the integrator the branch name (say
<code>dev/sitaram/issue3423</code> or <code>dev/someone-else/bugfix-2321</code></p></li>
<li><p>master -- a branch that is even more sacred than <code>integ</code>.  Its usage and
role are optional in the below described flow, but it can be used to
filter <code>integ</code> even more, maybe based on some EQA (External Quality
Assurance) perhaps.  If so, it's name can be changed to reflect that</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="assumptions_startup_">assumptions / startup:</a></h3>

<ul>
<li>a repo is created</li>
<li>the code is kept in a branch called <code>integ</code>, even if it is bare minimum
code in the beginning</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="developer_workflow">developer workflow</a></h3>

<p>We use a sample developer called dev5 in the examples below.</p>

<p>dev5 gets some work/spec/issue to work on.  He is given, or chooses, a short
name for the work he is doing.  Examples:</p>

<pre><code>xyz-module-error-23
bugfix-2321
issue-3394
add-vorbis-support
</code></pre>

<p>In the rest of this example we will use <code>issue-3394</code></p>

<ul>
<li><p>dev clones the repo, if not already cloned</p>

<pre><code>git clone [...]
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>fetch and checkout the current <code>integ</code> branch, making the new <code>issue-3394</code>
branch from it</p>

<pre><code>git fetch origin
git checkout -b issue-3394 origin/integ

---o---o---I
(o, o = previous commits, irrelevant to us)
I = origin/integ = issue-3394
(current branch is issue-3394)
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>(<strong>LOOP POINT</strong>) work on this branch</p>

<pre><code>git checkout issue-3394
# (edit/compile/test)
git add, git commit
# repeat as needed
# the last step should be a "test", ideally

---o---o---I---a---b---c---d
I = origin/integ
a,b,c = intermediate commits
d = issue-3394
(current branch is issue-3394)
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<p>now he's ready to send.  In the meantime, <code>integ</code> may have moved ahead, and he
has to make it work against that:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>fetch integ again and rebase</p>

<pre><code>git fetch origin

---o---o---I---J---K
K = origin/integ now

git checkout issue-3394         # if not already done
git rebase origin/integ
</code></pre>

<p>what does this rebase do?  It takes this:</p>

<pre><code>---o---o---I---J---K
             \
              \
               a---b---c---d
</code></pre>

<p>and moves the "a, b, c, d" on top of K:</p>

<pre><code>---o---o---I---J---K---a'---b'---c'---d'
(a',b',c',d' are rebased versions of a,b,c,d)
(K = origin/integ, d' = issue-3394)
</code></pre>

<p>There is a reason for doing it this way.  Dev5 is the one who knows the
new code best, and he should be integrating it with the latest version of
<code>integ</code> at any time he submits.  And since <code>issue-3394</code> is a private
branch, he can rebase it as often as he likes.</p>

<p>[SIDE NOTE] why do we use rebase instead of merge here?</p>

<p><strong>this is not a hard and fast rule -- you can use merge if you like.  Feel
free to experiment and see what works best for your team, because a lot
also depends on their level of comfort with the process</strong></p>

<p>However, in my opinion, work that has not been pushed out <em>and</em> accepted
upstream should ideally be rebased against new upstream.  The main
difference is that, if the <em>acceptance</em> of the work goes through a few
iterations (let's say it is rejected and partially redone 2-3 times),
using rebases is easier to do, and also will result in a cleaner looking
<em>final</em> commit list.</p></li>
<li><p>retest one more time, to make sure the new <code>J</code> and <code>K</code> commits have not
caused a problem for <code>issue-3394</code></p>

<p>if the test fails, he has to fix his commits (a', b', c', d') or add some
new commits (maybe e, f) and make it work.</p></li>
<li><p>when test OK, push <code>issue-3394</code> under your own hierarchy (each time he
comes back to "LOOP POINT" because something was rejected by code review
or integ testing, the <code>v1</code> will increase -- <code>v2</code>, <code>v3</code>, etc)</p>

<pre><code>git push origin issue-3394:dev/dev5/issue-3394/v1
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>send email to integrator asking him to pull and test
<code>dev/dev5/issue-3394/v1</code></p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="integrator">integrator</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>receive mail from dev5 saying <code>issue-3394</code> is done and ready</p></li>
<li><p>clone repo if not already done</p></li>
<li><p>fetch, make a test branch for testing <code>issue-3394</code></p>

<pre><code>git fetch origin
git checkout -b test_issue-3394 origin/dev/dev5/issue-3394
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>test, or do whatever he wants to do initially (maybe code review).  If he
doesn't like it, send it back for more work.  <strong>dev5 then restarts his
process from the point marked "LOOP POINT" in his workflow above</strong></p></li>
<li><p>if it is OK so far, <strong>test merge</strong> it with the current <em>integ</em> branch.
Ideally, this should be a <strong>fast forward</strong>, because dev5 <em>already</em> did
this.</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -b test_integ_issue-3394 integ
git merge origin/dev/dev5/issue-3394
# this should be a fast forward, ideally
# make some final tests
</code></pre>

<p>If something went wrong, no problem; just delete the test branch and email
dev5 saying what the problems are.  For dev5, work again starts at "LOOP
POINT"</p>

<pre><code>git branch -D test_integ_issue-3394
</code></pre>

<p>However, if the tests were all ok, move integ forward and delete test
merge branch</p>

<pre><code>git checkout integ
git merge origin/dev/dev5/issue-3394
git branch -D test_integ_issue-3394
</code></pre>

<p>This issue (3394) is now closed, unless there is a regression later.  It
has been integrated successfully, and dev5 can be assigned some other
task.</p></li>
</ul>

<h2><a name="gitolite_advanced_features_supporing_this_flow">gitolite advanced features supporing this flow</a></h2>

<p>Here's a typical gitolite conf file:</p>

<pre><code>@myteam = dev1 dev2 ... devN

repo myrepo
    RW+                 = integrator
    RW+ dev/USER/       = @myteam
</code></pre>

<p>That's it?  How does, say <code>dev5</code> (assuming he is a member of <code>@myteam</code>), get
access to write to <code>dev/dev5/something</code>?</p>

<p>That is a unique feature of gitolite :-)  When a rule has the string <code>/USER/</code>
in the "refex" (see gitolite documentation for details), it replaces it with
the name of the user invoking the push.  This is effectively the same as
manually adding one line like this</p>

<pre><code>    RW+ dev/sitaram/    = sitaram
</code></pre>

<p>for each member of <code>@myteam</code>.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="fixing_up_common_and_customer_branches">fixing-up common and customer branches</a></h1>

<p><sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#fixing_up_common_and_customer_branches">fixing-up common and customer branches</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#The_basic_rules">The basic rules</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Terminology">Terminology</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#The_nitty_gritty">The nitty gritty</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Before_you_start">Before you start</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Separating_common_and_special_">Separating 'common' and 'special'</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#utcb">Updating and testing the 'common' branch</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Merging_common_into_special_">Merging 'common' into 'special'</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Fixing_up_special_">Fixing up 'special'</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#Final_sanity_check">Final sanity check</a><br>
</sup></p>

<hr />

<p>The following document explains how to maintain a 'common' branch,
with one or more 'customer specific' branches that hang off of the
common branch.  The inspiration was a question about maintaining
'work' and 'home' configurations which differ slightly from a
'common' configuration, which leads to the same sort of problem.</p>

<p>In an ideal  world, you'd keep 'common' development in the 'common' branch,
and 'customer specific' development in the corresponding customer branches.
In the real world, often the separation was not done properly in advance,
(maybe it was not known, or maybe for initial testing reasons it had to be
done in one branch, or whatever), and so you now have a mix of 'common' and
'special' changes all together.</p>
