<p><strong>This article describes one way to 'fix up' such a mixed development into the
proper form</strong>.</p>

<h3><a name="The_basic_rules">The basic rules</a></h3>

<p>The basic rules are best described by Junio in
<a href="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/110489">http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/110489</a></p>

<ul>
<li>You make edits to common files only on the common branch.</li>
<li>You merge from common to deployment, never the other way.</li>
</ul>

<p>This document shows how one might do that.  [Junio also helped
with comments on a previous draft of this text.  However, any
errors or other problems that remain are mine.]</p>

<h3><a name="Terminology">Terminology</a></h3>

<p>We use the following terminology:</p>

<p>'common' is the branch representing the base product.  All
regular customers get this version.</p>

<p>'special' is a branch for a specific customer.  This customer
needs changes unique to his environment, which should not be
merged back into the common branch.  However, this branch must
regularly get the benefit of changes in the mainline 'common'
branch.  (This is the genesis of the two rules above).</p>

<p>If you have more than one special customer the same logic
will apply for each of them separately, although if you have
too many such customers you may also want to look at <a href="http://gitster.livejournal.com/26540.html">Never
merging back</a>
for an additional tip on this.</p>

<h3><a name="The_nitty_gritty">The nitty gritty</a></h3>

<h4><a name="Before_you_start">Before you start</a></h4>

<p>The history looks like this in the beginning:</p>

<pre><code>-----o          &lt;- special branch (current)
    /
---o            &lt;- common branch
</code></pre>

<p>The 'special' branch has been tested for the feature you are
working on, and this represents a stable point in the development
to try and re-organise the code, separate out 'common' code from
'special' code, etc.</p>

<p>Before you start, make a temporary branch TEMP from
'special'; leave special where it was.</p>

<pre><code>git checkout -b TEMP special
</code></pre>

<p>You now make some changes for the special customer, which
also involve some 'common' changes that need to be ported
back to the common branch.  The topology now looks like
this, where A, B, C, are changes that logically belong on
'common', and 1, 2, 3, are changes that are specific to this
customer.</p>

<p>Notice that the 2 sets of changes are intermixed because
that is how the development happened, and that there is even
one commit where common and special changes are mixed
(perhaps you realised this only later).</p>

<pre><code>-----o--A--B1--2--3--C          &lt;- "TEMP" branch (current)
    /
---o                            &lt;- common
</code></pre>

<p>Meanwhile, just to make things interesting, the common
branch has also had some other, unrelated changes which you
eventually want on the special branch as well.</p>

<pre><code>-----o--A--B1--2--3--C          &lt;- "TEMP" branch (current)
    /                                            
---o--X--Y                      &lt;- common
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Separating_common_and_special_">Separating 'common' and 'special'</a></h4>

<p>The first thing to do is to tease the tangled commits apart
using rebase.</p>

<p>Using <code>git rebase -i special</code>, get the topology into this
shape.  Note that we have split the "B1" commit into B and 1
separately.  <code>git help rebase</code> has a very simple and clear
section on splitting commits, so I will not detail that
here.</p>

<pre><code>-----o--A--B--C--1--2--3        &lt;- "TEMP" branch (current)
    /                                              
---o--X--Y                      &lt;- common
</code></pre>

<p>At this point, the tree that results should be identical to the one you
started this exercise with, so ideally there should be no need to test.  You
can, if you wish, check that the trees are indeed the same</p>

<pre><code>git diff TEMP@{1} TEMP
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>@{1}</code> notation specifies the shape of the TEMP branch before the rebase
started.</p>

<h4><a name="utcb">Updating and testing the 'common' branch</a></h4>

<p>Now switch to the 'common' branch and cherry pick the
changes that belong on 'common'.  The simplest way to cherry
pick is gitk.</p>

<pre><code>git checkout common
gitk
# and cherry pick first A, then B, then C, in order
</code></pre>

<p>At this point, your TEMP branch has still not changed from when you started
this re-organisation.  However, you have now introduced 3 new commits onto
the 'common' branch, so that set of changes needs to be tested to make sure
things are fine.</p>

<pre><code>-----o--A--B--C--1--2--3        &lt;- "TEMP" branch
    /                                              
---o--X--Y--A'--B'--C'          &lt;- common (current)
</code></pre>

<p>Be sure you test the new functionality before proceeding.  This test will
likely be different from your tests on the TEMP branch, because only part of
the new code in TEMP goes to 'common'.  If the test failed or required fixups,
do them in the context of the 'common' case only, right here on the 'common'
branch.  <strong>Note that this affects the rebase coming up later!</strong></p>

<h4><a name="Merging_common_into_special_">Merging 'common' into 'special'</a></h4>

<p>Once that test is done, merge from 'common' to 'special'</p>

<pre><code>git checkout special
git merge common
</code></pre>

<p>which results in the following topology:</p>

<pre><code>       A--B--C--1--2--3     &lt;- TEMP
      /
 ----o-----------------o    &lt;- special (current)
    /                 /
---o--X--Y--A'--B'--C'
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Fixing_up_special_">Fixing up 'special'</a></h4>

<p>Now all we need is to get commits 1, 2, and 3 onto 'special'.  Although this
is easiest done by using 'rebase', that will only work if your <a href="#utcb">updating and
testing on 'common'</a> did not cause any changes or fixups (that is, the
changes A, B, and C are still identical to the changes A', B', and C'.</p>

<p>In the general case, therefore, cherry-pick is better, as long as you make
sure you don't miss any commits:</p>

<pre><code>gitk
# and cherry pick first 1, then 2, then 3, in order
</code></pre>

<p>This gives you the following topology (in which we have ignored the TEMP
branch)</p>

<pre><code>                         1'--2'--3'     &lt;- special (current)
                        /
 ----o-----------------o
    /                 /
---o--X--Y--A'--B'--C'
</code></pre>

<h4><a name="Final_sanity_check">Final sanity check</a></h4>

<p>At this point you should <em>definitely</em> re-test all the changes you made, to
make sure nothing got missed out.  If there were no 'X' and 'Y' commits on
the 'commits' branch, you could try</p>

<pre><code>git diff TEMP special
</code></pre>

<p>to check that the tree is still the same as before.  But again, in the
general case, you probably will have commits 'X' and 'Y' included so it is
necessary to re-test.</p>

<p>Once all this is done, you don't need TEMP anymore, and can delete it:</p>

<pre><code>git branch -d TEMP
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>rules for .gitignore and the like</h1>

<p>Those of you who have read the manual for gitignore will have noticed that,
while the rules for precedence of the various files (pattern sources) are very
clear, the rules for the actual exclusion patterns are somewhat less so.
They're certainly accurate, but newcomers have to read very carefully if they
want to do anything moderately complex with their exclude rules.</p>

<p>One day (2009-02-18, ~16:00 IST, to be precise), 'doener' (BjÃ¶rn Steinbrink)
came up with some much simpler rules that said the same thing, and -- building
on the insight that his rules gave me -- I came up with these:</p>

<hr />

<p>Note that rule 1 merely <em>modifies</em> rules 2 and 3, it does not supercede or
preclude them.</p>

<ol>
<li>If your pattern ends with a slash, it matches only directories (and their
contents)</li>
<li>If there is no slash otherwise, it matches that name, at any depth in the
tree</li>
<li>If there is a slash anywhere else, it matches that name, relative to the
.gitignore (or <code>$GIT_WORK_TREE</code> if the pattern is from one of the other
pattern sources like <code>.git/info/exclude</code> etc)</li>
</ol>

<p>The wildcards (<code>*</code> and <code>?</code>) do not match slashes, but otherwise the patterns
are normal shell globs as defined by fnmatch(3) with the <code>FNM_PATHNAME</code> flag
set.</p>

<hr />

<p><font size=-1>Just for completeness, the pattern source priorities are, highest to lowest:</p>

<ul>
<li>command line</li>
<li>the deepest .gitignore that applies to this path</li>
<li>shallower .gitignore files until you get to <code>$GIT_WORK_TREE</code>
<ul>
<li>patterns in .gitignore files are relative to the location of the
gitignore file, not to the <code>$GIT_WORK_TREE</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li><code>$GIT_DIR/info/exclude</code></li>
<li>core.excludesfile</li>
</ul>

<p></font></p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>backing up a repo by just: git push backup</h1>

<p>This is, like many things in this directory, by doener, on irc circa
2009-03-25 19:24 Wed IST</p>

<pre><code>mkdir -p ~/backups/projectX.git
cd ~/backups/projectX.git
git init --bare
# see notes below for these two
git config core.logAllRefUpdates true
git config receive.denyDeletes true

cd /path/to/projectX
git remote add -t dont_fetch_from_the_backup --mirror backup ~/backups/projectX.git
</code></pre>

<p>Here is some documentation (paraphrased from the irc chat log).</p>

<p>It creates a bare repo to store the backup, adds a remote to the "work" repo
and then pushes.  The <code>--mirror</code> bit makes the remote act as a mirror (i.e.
"git push" will default to <code>--mirrror</code> for this remote) The <code>-t
dont_fetch_from_the_backup</code> is there because, normally, with <code>--mirror</code> you
get a bidirectional mirror setup, i.e. fetch is set to <code>refs/*:refs/*</code>, and
you don't want an accidental fetch to kill your work.  Of course simply
unsetting <code>remote.backup.fetch</code> would also do, but the error message for the
invalid ref reminds you you shouldn't be doing that.</p>

<p>My additions:  I hope that by adding the two config variables above, I can
allow non-fast forward pushes, letting the reflog act as a safety net as
usual.  The reflog does not protect from a deleted branch, hence we disallow
that (that is rare enough that I can do it manually if I need to).</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>customer branches</h1>

<!-- http://colabti.org/irclogger/irclogger_log/git?date=2009-08-15#l585 -->

<p>Here's a question that someone asked (both question and response have been
heavily edited):</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Hello. I have a Ruby on Rails application. This is currently managed using
  GIT. I have another business that wants a customised copy of this site. Is
  it possible to use GIT to do this?</p>

<p>Currently I have one site in directory "custA". I want to make a copy in
  "custB" which is a branch. They are the same base system with customer
  specific modifications.  How does this work?</p>

<p>For example, on custA, I make commits 1, 2, 3.  In custB, only commits 1
  and 3 are relevant.  Is it possible to pull only specific commits across?
  Would I be better served using a central repository and then using
  different branches, one for each site?</p>

<p>What is the "best" way to do this using Git?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>There are several issues actually being raised here, so we'll look at them one
at a time.</p>

<hr />

<h4>SVN-itis</h4>

<p>The first thing to note is that the question reflects what I have started
calling <code>SVN-itis</code> -- where "branch" and "(sub)directory" are conflated :-)</p>

<p>Some <a href="../concepts/0-terminology.html">basic
terminology</a> is
probably useful, if you're really new to git, or perhaps some info on
<a href="../concepts/branches.html">branches in git</a>, but
neither of these quite manage a cure for SVN-itis.  So let's lay it out:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>In git, there is <strong>no connection</strong> between a branch and a subdirectory.
Subdirectories are whatever your project needs them to be, and branch names
are whatever you want them to be.  You can have a branch whose name happens to
be the same as that of one of your project directories, if you really need to.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So "custA" is <strong>not</strong> a directory.  Neither is "custB"; nor indeed any other
branch.  And if you have a directory called "include" or "src" or
"Documentation", that does <strong>not</strong> become a branch in your repo!</p>

<p>When you checkout a branch called "custA", your "working tree" is populated
with the customer "A" specific version of your code.  It's very likely that
the actual directory structure for this version is pretty much the same as,
say, for customer "B", and both of them are similar to the directory structure
of the main branch.</p>

<h4>cherry-pick versus merge</h4>

<p>[also see <code>git help workflows</code>]</p>

<p>"<em>Is it possible to pull only specific commits across?</em>"</p>

<p>Well certainly yes; this is called <strong>cherry-picking</strong>, and git can do that
from the command line, or from the GUI.  But it is <strong>not</strong> the right thing to
do in this circumstance, or indeed many other similar ones.</p>

<p>In terms of "history", a cherry-pick is the same as "take a diff of <em>that</em>
commit versus it's parent, and apply that same change <em>here</em> in <em>this</em> branch,
and commit".  Git does not remember that you pulled this change in any way
whatsoever, and does not associate these two commits (the one you picked, and
the new one made here as a result) in any long term way to ease maintenance.
[Experts: <em>patch-id</em> is not relevant here for this discussion so leave it
alone ok? :-)]</p>

<p>Secondly, if the feature you implemented was spread across more than one
commit (as any non-trivial feature <em>should</em>!), you have to remember to
cherry-pick <em>all</em> of them.  In the <em>right order</em>!  Miss one, or pick them in
the wrong order, and things go bad.</p>

<p>When you <strong>merge</strong> a branch, on the other hand, git remembers that you merged
it.  And since you only deal with the tip of the branch, not individual
commits, it's git's job to make sure that they all come in, and in the right
order.  In particular, (as <code>git help workflows</code> says), </p>

<pre><code>...a merge can carry over the changes from 1, 10, or 1000 commits with
equal ease, which in turn means the workflow scales much better...
</code></pre>

<p>So the long term way to do this is by merging.  Just remember that when you
merge a branch, <em>all</em> the changes in that branch are brought in (merging is
<em>not</em> a selective operation) so it is best to <em>create a different branch for
each logically separate set of changes</em>.</p>

<h4>customer specific branches</h4>

<p>The idea is you use one common branch, and two (or as many as you need)
customer specific branches.  All common changes go into the master, and each
customer branch gets changes that pertain only to that customer.  Periodically
(when master is considered to be at a stable point), you'll merge changes from
master into the customer branch (<code>git checkout custA; git merge master</code>).
This brings in newer "common" code into the customer branch. You will
<strong>never</strong> merge the other way -- that would pollute master with
customer-specific code.</p>

<p>When you make a delivery to customer A, you checkout the "custA" branch and
send that.  And of course similarly for other customers.</p>

<p>Now let's say you acquire a new customer, "C", and a bit later find a feature
that customers A and C want, but B doesn't.  You create (aka "fork") a branch
off of master (<code>git checkout -b AC_feature master</code>), code/test it, making
commits as you go, and then merge it into A and C (<code>git checkout A; git merge
AC_feature</code> and similarly for customer C).  You do <strong>not</strong> code it in A and
then rely on merging A into C, because that would get all of A into C.</p>

<p>If, sometime later, you find a minor bug in that feature, you make the change
in the same branch (<code>git checkout AC_feature; edit/test/commit</code>), and then you
merge it into <code>custA</code> and <code>custC</code> as above.</p>

<h4>Summary</h4>

<p>The main thing we're avoiding in all this is cherry-picking specific commits
because you only wanted a part of that code in this branch -- cherry-picking
is certainly doable, but it is not scalable and in the long term it's a pain.</p>

<p>Of course, you do have to be disciplined about which branch you make each
commit in, in order to keep things properly separated.</p>

<p>But <a href="special-branch-fixups.html">here</a> is one way to fix up things if you did
not manage to do that for some reason.</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>fixup whitespace errors</h1>

<p>When you have whitespace errors in a repo and want to fix them all together,
here's what you do.  Written by doener circa 2009-07-12 19:23</p>

<p>So let's say the following code is in <code>~/git-scripts/ws-fix.sh</code></p>

<pre><code>#!/bin/bash

# from doener (who else!)
# to be called as an index-filter

if git rev-parse --quiet --verify $GIT_COMMIT^ &gt;/dev/null
then
        against=$(map $(git rev-parse $GIT_COMMIT^))
        git reset -q $against -- .
else
        # Initial commit: diff against an empty tree object
        against=4b825dc642cb6eb9a060e54bf8d69288fbee4904
        git rm --cached -rfq --ignore-unmatch '*'
fi

git diff --full-index $against $GIT_COMMIT | git apply --cached --whitespace=fix
</code></pre>

<p>Notes:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>the <code>map</code> translates the original sha1 to the sha1 of the rewritten
commit.  The diff needs to go against the rewritten one, so that the patch
applies without conflicts/fuzz.</p></li>
<li><p>run this like: <code>git filter-branch --index-filter '. ~/git-scripts/ws-fix.sh'</code></p></li>
<li><p>a pictorial representation of what this script does each time it is
called (also from doener a few minutes later when I still couldn't get
it!):</p>

<pre><code>Original:

A---B---C---D---E

Rewritten so far: (1 == rewritten A, and so on)

1---2---3

To create 4 we do:

map D^ == map C == 3

so: git diff 3 D | git apply ....
</code></pre></li>
</ul>

<p>Other possibilities:</p>

<p>If the whitespace problem causing conflicts is something like indentation
shift, etc., and is not amenable to <code>git apply --whitespace=fix</code>, the
following may work.  We assume the "remote" version is the one with the
unnecessary indentation changes:</p>

<pre><code>git show :1:filename &gt; filename
git diff -b :1:filename :3:filename | git apply
# (might need munging; the diff header has :1: and :3: in it...)
git merge-one-file :1:filename :2:filename $(git hash-object -w filename) filename
</code></pre>
</html>

<html>
<h1>for people who think Hg is just as good</h1>

<p>Hg is almost as good as git.  Linus pretty much says so in his famous
googletalk.</p>

<p>Almost :-)</p>

<p>Here're some links about Hg; detailed commentary from me may come later, but I
doubt I will have the time or the inclination.  It's not like this is SVN and
I have to strenuously keep you away from it -- go ahead and use Hg if you like
it and it fits your work style :-)</p>

<p>Also, I have no intention of becoming an Hg expert to answer questions or
criticisms about this page.  If you think something is wrong, tell me and I'd
be happy to update it.</p>

<h3>Local branches</h3>

<p>Hg does not permit a quick experimental branch just to test some wild idea
quickly.  Check out the "Branch Management" section in
<a href="http://www.rockstarprogrammer.org/post/2008/apr/06/differences-between-mercurial-and-git/">http://www.rockstarprogrammer.org/post/2008/apr/06/differences-between-mercurial-and-git/</a>.</p>

<p>Read the last 3 paras of that section, at least.</p>

<!--

Also, because the branch name is in the changeset, the branch lives forever.
The only short-term branches are clone branches. That just doesn't encourage
quick experiments.

In git, a branch is just a head (see above). Making changes to a branch
actually moves the pointer to the new changeset. This head must be explicitly
shared across repositories.

In practice, this drops the cost down to approximately zero. You won't
accidentally push code you don't mean to. You won't have to be reminded of a
failed experiment for the rest of your life, and you won't have to fear
naming them in such a way that they don't collide with something someone else
has done somewhere else. 

-->

<h3>Projects</h3>

<p>Mozilla: quote from
<a href="http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/preed/2007/04/version_control_system_shootou_1.html">http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/preed/2007/04/version_control_system_shootou_1.html</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><em>"As good, performant Win32 (and Mac and Linux) is a hard-requirement, Git
    lost in early Kombat rounds. This is unfortunate because (as we would soon
    find out), lots of issues with the other systems did "just work" in Git."</em></p>
</blockquote>

<h3>Unsorted URLs</h3>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://weblog.masukomi.org/2008/2/4/some-thoughts-about-git">http://weblog.masukomi.org/2008/2/4/some-thoughts-about-git</a></li>
<li><a href="http://texagon.blogspot.com/2008/02/use-mercurial-you-git.html?showComment=1202345880000#c900552130121547868">http://texagon.blogspot.com/2008/02/use-mercurial-you-git.html?showComment=1202345880000#c900552130121547868</a>: 
<em>I used to be more of a Mercurial guy, but there's just a moment (at least
there was for me) where it all clicks and Git makes sense. Having your
repository be just a giant DAG of commits is what you want -- forcing each
fork in the road to live in its own separate repository is a pain and
unnecessary.</em></li>
</ul>
</html>

<html>
<h1><a name="for_people_who_think_SVN_is_good_enough_">for people who think SVN is good enough ;-)</a></h1>

<p>The official comparison is <a href="http://git.or.cz/gitwiki/GitSvnComparsion">here</a>.
There is also a <a href="http://git-scm.com/course/svn.html">Git - SVN crash course</a>.</p>

<p><em>Lots of SVN info is scattered in a few other files in this directory;
eventually it should all be pulled into this file.</em></p>

<p><sup>as Churchill said, so much to do, and so little time in which to do it... (<em>sigh</em>)</sup></p>

<p>What follows is my understanding of the SVN scenario, from various sources.  I
personally have used SVN only briefly.  If there are errors in the SVN part of
this description please let <a href="mailto:sitaramc@gmail.com">me</a> know.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#for_people_who_think_SVN_is_good_enough_">for people who think SVN is good enough ;-)</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#briefly_">briefly...</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_and_a_bit_more_detail">...and a bit more detail</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#_svn_update_on_very_active_projects">'svn update' on very active projects</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#local_caching_and_repository_size">local caching and repository size</a><br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="#some_links">some links</a><br></p>

<hr />

<h3><a name="briefly_">briefly...</a></h3>

<p>Git's advantages over SVN (all of them affect productivity and/or
maintainability, indicated in parens as <strong>P</strong> or <strong>M</strong>) are:</p>

<ul>
<li><p><strong>(P)</strong> handles merges automatically (in fact SVN doesn't really "handle"
merges; merge history must be manually recorded and managed, and it's
almost impossible to have 2 branches merging regularly in SVN without a
lot of pain for the integration team)</p></li>
<li><p><strong>(M)</strong> handles file renames correctly; helps in refactoring (in SVN, a
rename is handled as a delete of the old file plus an add of the new file,
and it is only tracked as such if you explicitly told svn about the
rename.  That is not the only brittle aspect; renames and merges don't mix
well, apparently.  Also, SVN may <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apache_Subversion#Current_limitations_and_problems">become confused</a> when files are
modified and renamed in the same commit.)</p></li>
<li><p><strong>(P, M)</strong> devs can create local branches without polluting the central server
-- experimental features can be developed and tested "on the side", with
full revision control and granular commits.  If the experiment worked, you
bring it into the main repo (without losing the individual commits),
otherwise you toss it.  In SVN, a successful side project is forced to
enter the main project as one large chunk of code, which seriously affects
future maintainability.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>(P, M)</strong> devs make lots of small commits instead of one humongous commit --
much easier for code review, debugging, cherry-picking, and merging with
other changes.  Merge-conflict resolution happens on much smaller units
instead of one huge chunk of code dumped on the repo!  In SVN, every
commit goes to the server, forcing commits to be large and monolithic, in
turn causing every merge to be a serious exercise rather than a couple of
minutes work.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>(P)</strong> common VCS operations do not need network or server access, and are
blazingly fast.  SVN and other VCSs may take so long that a developer who
is, say, trying to trace the changes that caused a bug may feel it's
easier to go through the code himself than run a 'diff' against the last
known good version!  That is, these VCSs have the tools but it's a pain to
use them!</p></li>
</ul>

<p>Git does a lot of things better than any other VCS:</p>

<ul>
<li><p><strong>(P)</strong> branching/merging is so bad in most other VCSs that lots of projects
forgo all the advantages of parallel development!  Or they have to have a
separate "merge team", and they freeze development for a couple of days to
do the merge.  With git, merges (and therefore, merge conflicts, if any)
are (i) handled by the developer closest to the merged code, not an
upstream integrator who probably doesn't know the new code well, and (ii)
processed in many small chunks instead of one large chunk of code.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>(M)</strong> git doesn't track files, it tracks content.  So if a piece of code
moved from one source file to another, and you look at the history of that
file visually, git will tell you that these lines came from that file over
there, and it'll also tell you the history of those lines before they came
here.  This is way beyond what any other VCS can imagine doing, and is a
real lifesaver for someone who picks up a complex project for maintenance
or a new team member is trying to understand the existing project.</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="_and_a_bit_more_detail">...and a bit more detail</a></h3>

<h4><a name="_svn_update_on_very_active_projects">'svn update' on very active projects</a></h4>

<p>When you, as a developer, have made a fair number of changes on your
workstation, and wish to commit these to the SVN repo, you do an 'svn update'.
This brings in the latest changes from the server.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, if the other developers have also been very active, there could
be a lot of new/changed code.  All of those changes, in one fell swoop, are
now merged into your working copy, so conflicts are very likely.</p>

<p>Worse, the 'svn update' has managed to lose the separation between your local
changes and the updates that came from the server.  You now have exactly one
chance to resolve those conflicts and commit the result.  And you'd better do
it fast -- before the upstream tree changes <em>again</em>!</p>

<p>[This is when an SVN newbie will realise he should have backed up his current
source tree using tar or zip ;-)]</p>

<p>With git, you would not do the <code>git pull</code> while you still have uncommitted
changes in your local repository.  This is a <em>distributed</em> VCS, so you have a
local repository to take care of all that.</p>

<p>So just commit all <em>your</em> changes locally, and <em>then</em> do a <code>git pull</code>!</p>

<p>Of course this will have the same conflicts as in SVN and you still have to do
a manual conflict resolution, <em>but</em>:</p>

<ol>
<li>your local changes are <em>cleanly</em> saved, so if you botch up the manual
conflict resolution, you can go back to your last local commit and try
again.  As many times as you need to, really.</li>
<li>if you do a <code>git pull --rebase</code>, (which is closer to what SVN does
actually), then git will apply your local changes <em>one commit at a time</em>
instead of the whole thing in one shot, making the conflict resolution
also go in small, easily digestible chunks.</li>
<li>in rare cases, the 'upstream' has changed so much that a lot of your local
changes become invalid and you have to redo them.  With SVN -- you have to
throw the whole lot away and start again.  With git, you would have made a
series of small, granular, commits on your local tree, and this lets you
salvage the pieces that are still acceptable and redo only those that are
not.  Then you do your <code>git pull</code> or <code>git pull --rebase</code> again.</li>
</ol>

<p><sup>Basic idea from a post by Junio at
<a href="http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/110671">http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/110671</a></sup></p>

<h4><a name="local_caching_and_repository_size">local caching and repository size</a></h4>

<h5>What extra information is cached locally?</h5>

<p>When you do an 'svn checkout', you get a working copy of the revision you
checked out, plus svn saves away an extra copy of the same stuff.  This allows
you to do things like see what you changed with respect to the checked out
version.</p>

<p>But if you need a diff between your copy and some other version, you need
network access.  If you need a diff between two checked-in revisions, again
you need network access.</p>

<p>When you do a <code>git clone</code>, however, git stores the complete history of all the
branches that the parent repository has!  So the only time you now need
network access is when you want to update the server, nothing else.</p>

<p>This might make you think git's repositories are <em>huge</em>!  Far from it; here's
<a href="http://keithp.com/blogs/Repository_Formats_Matter/">an example</a> that uses the
Mozilla repository, with full history from 1998 or so:</p>

<ul>
<li>CVS repo: 2.7 GB</li>
<li>imported to SVN: 8.2 GB</li>
<li>imported to GIT: 450 MB!</li>
<li>(a full checkout of just the source: 350 MB)</li>
</ul>

<p>That's a ratio of almost 20:1 in size over SVN.</p>

<h3><a name="some_links">some links</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://markmcb.com/2008/10/18/3-reasons-to-switch-to-git-from-subversion/">http://markmcb.com/2008/10/18/3-reasons-to-switch-to-git-from-subversion/</a>:
the first example, 'Endless, Easy, Non-File-System-Based, Local Branches',
is particularly powerful and convincing</li>
<li><a href="http://developers.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=1079921&amp;cid=26321869">http://developers.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=1079921&amp;cid=26321869</a> from
somewhere in the trenches</li>
</ul>

<hr />
</html>

a mailing list <a href="http://marc.info/?t=119198137100002&amp;r=1&amp;w=2">http://marc.info/?t=119198137100002&amp;r=1&amp;w=2</a></li>

branching and merging:

<h3><a name="basic_stuff_concepts">basic stuff/concepts</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://sitaramc.github.com/gcs/index.html">http://sitaramc.github.com/gcs/index.html</a> -- my version of the classic
"Git for Computer Scientists"</li>
<li><a href="http://cworth.org/hgbook-git/tour/">http://cworth.org/hgbook-git/tour/</a> -- I cannot emphasise how useful this
URL has been in getting started!</li>

<li>who says git is harder than SVN?  Try <a href="http://git.or.cz/course/svn.html">http://git.or.cz/course/svn.html</a></li>

<a href="http://www.kernel.org/~junio/200607-ols.pdf">http://www.kernel.org/~junio/200607-ols.pdf</a></li>

<h4><a name="_for_SVN_and_other_Centralised_VCS_users">...for SVN and other Centralised VCS users</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><p>If you always wondered what exactly was meant by "<strong>commit-then-merge
versus merge-then-commit</strong>", take a couple of minutes to read
<a href="http://www.ericsink.com/entries/dvcs_dag_1.html">http://www.ericsink.com/entries/dvcs_dag_1.html</a>.  You'll also understand
what a DAG (directed acyclic graph) is, in case you didn't know, with very
nice ilustrations at an easy reading pace.</p>

<p>This site belongs to someone who is making a commercial version control
system, and is documenting his findings and thoughts very laboriously.
While I don't always agree with him, he (a) certainly writes well, and I
absolutely love his sense of humour, and (b) is refreshingly honest about
his biases in <a href="http://www.ericsink.com/entries/dvcs_dag_2.html">his followup blog
post</a>.</p></li>
<li><p><a href="http://codeclimber.blogspot.com/2009/05/git-solves-all-your-branching-and.html">http://codeclimber.blogspot.com/2009/05/git-solves-all-your-branching-and.html</a>
talks about the reluctance to try branching when coming from a
painful-to-branch model like SVN.  The fact is, in git, branching is one
of those rare beasts: easy <em>and</em> powerful.</p></li>
<li><p><a href="http://www.lwn.net/Articles/381796/">http://www.lwn.net/Articles/381796/</a> Subversion is unable to separate the
steps "fix bug A" and "integrate with bugfixes B C D and E, having been
checked in while you've been working on A". Mr. Corporate Manager wants
this feature.</p>

<p>Subversion cannot do that unless you create a branch for everything.
<em>Poof</em> your workflow is now an order of magnitude more complicated than
git or hg (which is IMHO even less complicated than SVN, once you let go
of the centralized-repo, poisoned-by-CVS mindset.)</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="tut">detailed tutorials</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>about the best darn doc on using the 3 GUIs that come with git:
<a href="http://nathanj.github.com/gitguide/tour.html">http://nathanj.github.com/gitguide/tour.html</a> has a Windows slant but
except for the "installation" pieces, the rest is just as applicable to
Linux</p></li>
<li><p>another <em>very useful</em> resource is the <a href="http://gitready.com/">gitready</a>
site, where you'll find lots of tips and techniques.  In particular, they
explain things very graphically (for example, if you always wondered what
rebase is, try <a href="http://gitready.com/intermediate/2009/01/31/intro-to-rebase.html">intro to
rebase</a>,
then maybe <a href="http://gitready.com/advanced/2009/02/11/pull-with-rebase.html">pull with
rebase</a> or
<a href="http://gitready.com/advanced/2009/02/10/squashing-commits-with-rebase.html">squashing commits with
rebase</a>).</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="advanced_stuff_best_practices">advanced stuff/best practices</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><p>release engineering, branches never-merged-back, etc.,
<a href="http://gitster.livejournal.com/2009/01/14/">http://gitster.livejournal.com/2009/01/14/</a></p></li>
<li><p>Ingo Molnar (mingo) on reviewing merge commits versus rebased ones:
<a href="http://lwn.net/Articles/409775/">http://lwn.net/Articles/409775/</a></p></li>
<li><p>Shawn on contrib/workdir/git-new-workdir:
<a href="http://kerneltrap.org/mailarchive/git/2007/10/11/335637">http://kerneltrap.org/mailarchive/git/2007/10/11/335637</a></p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="digging_into_git_troubleshooting">digging into git/troubleshooting</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/46609">http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/46609</a> -- how
<code>git am -3</code> works</li>
<li><a href="http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/howto/recover-corrupted-blob-object.txt">http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/howto/recover-corrupted-blob-object.txt</a></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="opinions_discussion_DVCSs_in_general">opinions/discussion/DVCSs in general</a></h3>

<ul>
<li>a somewhat longer, more philosophical article on git:
<a href="http://www.betaversion.org/~stefano/linotype/news/106/">http://www.betaversion.org/~stefano/linotype/news/106/</a></li>
<li>on tracking content instead of files: <a href="http://marc.info/?l=git&amp;m=116473016012824">http://marc.info/?l=git&amp;m=116473016012824</a></li>
<li>a more detailed version of the same:
<a href="http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/217">http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/217</a></li>
<li>descriptive article on the advantages of a DVCS and speculative branching
and low overhead repos and so on:
<a href="http://griddlenoise.blogspot.com/2007/12/distributed-vcss-are-great-enablers-or.html">http://griddlenoise.blogspot.com/2007/12/distributed-vcss-are-great-enablers-or.html</a></li>
<li>very informative comment on the advantages of a distributed system:
<a href="http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/preed/2006/11/version_control_system_shootou.html#comment-486521">http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/preed/2006/11/version_control_system_shootou.html#comment-486521</a></li>
<li><a href="http://keithp.com/blogs/Repository_Formats_Matter/">http://keithp.com/blogs/Repository_Formats_Matter/</a>  -- discusses git
from a small project point of view; you can retain your central model even
with git</li>
<li><p><a href="http://blogs.gnome.org/newren/2007/11/24/local-caching-a-major-distinguishing-difference-between-vcses/">http://blogs.gnome.org/newren/2007/11/24/local-caching-a-major-distinguishing-difference-between-vcses/</a></p></li>
<li><p>on git being very liberal: <a href="http://tomayko.com/writings/the-thing-about-git">http://tomayko.com/writings/the-thing-about-git</a></p>

<ul>
<li>Version control systems have traditionally required a lot of up-front
planning followed by constant interaction to get changes to the right
place at the right time and in the right order. And woe unto thee if a
rule is broken somewhere along the way, or you change your mind about
something, or you just want to fix this one thing real quick before
having to commit all the other crap in your working copy.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="advocacy">advocacy</a></h3>

<ul>
<li>features unique to git: <a href="http://gitster.livejournal.com/16077.html">http://gitster.livejournal.com/16077.html</a></li>
<li><a href="http://lwn.net/Articles/317154/">http://lwn.net/Articles/317154/</a>: <em>git bisect "is well-nigh
single-handedly responsible for reducing our average bugreport-to-fix time
from 4 days to 6 hours".</em></li>
<li>on why git is so revolutionary.  This is actually the most "concept-ish"
of all the praising articles on git, and yet the most tangible because he
keeps on pumping us with examples of stuff he and others had done which
could ALL be replaced by git:
<a href="http://www.advogato.org/person/apenwarr/diary/371.html">http://www.advogato.org/person/apenwarr/diary/371.html</a>.  Has stuff like "I
wanted to build distributed filesystem, but git beat me to it; I wanted a
file backup system, but git beat me to it", etc., essentially saying that
git is a platform for building whatever you want, not just a VCS.  Or how
about a "hash indexed backup system" to store backups from different
systems efficiently?</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="other_VCSs_comparision_criticism_etc">other VCSs -- comparision, criticism, etc</a></h3>

<p>look, don't expect too much praise for any of the other systems, except
possibly Hg -- and even that might be back-handed ;-)</p>

<h4><a name="CVS">CVS</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/802573/difference-between-git-and-cvs/824241#824241">http://stackoverflow.com/questions/802573/difference-between-git-and-cvs/824241#824241</a>
-- no summary possible; it's very well written and covers a lot of ground.
It starts off with "even if you use version control for single developer,
on single machine (single account), there are a few differences between
Git and CVS", listing 10 points there :-)  A "must read".</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="SVN">SVN</a></h4>

<p>...but also see the <a href="../other-stuff/svn.html">main article on subversion</a> for
a lot more; SVN is the most used VCS in terms of what potential git users are
<em>currently</em> using, so it has its own page.</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://blog.mwolson.org/tech/why_i_dislike_subversion.html">http://blog.mwolson.org/tech/why_i_dislike_subversion.html</a></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="Visual_Source_font_size_5_un_font_Safe_and_TFS">Visual Source <font size=-5>un</font>Safe and TFS</a></h4>

<ul>
<li>data integrity issues in VSS:
<a href="http://www.developsense.com/testing/VSSDefects.html">http://www.developsense.com/testing/VSSDefects.html</a></li>
<li><p>from <a href="http://martinfowler.com/bliki/VersionControlTools.html">http://martinfowler.com/bliki/VersionControlTools.html</a>: <em>Before I
finish with those behind the threshold, I just want to say a few things
about a particularly awful tool: Visual Source Safe, or as I call it:
Visual Source Shredder. We see this less often now, thank goodness, but if
you are using it we'd strongly suggest you get off it. Now. Not just is it
a pain to use, I've heard too many tales of repository corruption to trust
it with anything more valuable than foo.txt.</em></p></li>
<li><p>TFS rant <a href="http://developers.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=1872398&amp;cid=34258672">http://developers.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=1872398&amp;cid=34258672</a></p></li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="Clearcase">Clearcase</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://creativekarma.com/ee.php/weblog/comments/why_clearcase_sucks/">http://creativekarma.com/ee.php/weblog/comments/why_clearcase_sucks/</a></li>
<li><a href="http://evilparty.org/~orc/2004/08/03/001/index.html">http://evilparty.org/~orc/2004/08/03/001/index.html</a></li>
<li><a href="http://selenic.com/pipermail/mercurial/2007-April/012864.html">http://selenic.com/pipermail/mercurial/2007-April/012864.html</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.digitaltorque.ca/2006/12/18/clearcase-making-easy-things-hard/">http://www.digitaltorque.ca/2006/12/18/clearcase-making-easy-things-hard/</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.germane-software.com:8080/ser/aikido/clearcase-sucks">http://www.germane-software.com:8080/ser/aikido/clearcase-sucks</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.littleredbat.net/mk/blog/story/63/">http://www.littleredbat.net/mk/blog/story/63/</a> -- git to the rescue :-)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.trolocsis.com/wp/2007/04/18/the-joys-of-clearcase/">http://www.trolocsis.com/wp/2007/04/18/the-joys-of-clearcase/</a></li>
<li><a href="http://codicesoftware.blogspot.com/2008/04/break-up-clearcase-bad-love-affair.html">http://codicesoftware.blogspot.com/2008/04/break-up-clearcase-bad-love-affair.html</a></li>
<li><a href="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/132311">http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/132311</a> -- on
CC's speed</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="Hg">Hg</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://weblog.masukomi.org/2008/2/4/some-thoughts-about-git">http://weblog.masukomi.org/2008/2/4/some-thoughts-about-git</a> (cf Hg)</li>
<li><a href="http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/preed/2007/04/version_control_system_shootou_1.html">http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/preed/2007/04/version_control_system_shootou_1.html</a>
:-)</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="darcs">darcs</a></h4>

<p>All this is moot -- the GHC (Glasgow Haskell Compiler) people themselves moved
from Darcs to git :-)</p>

<p>Think about it.  Darcs was the poster child of "mainstream" use of Haskell
(i.e., outside the ivory towers).  And the people who maintain the standard
Haskell compiler decided it was too slow or something.</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://blog.moertel.com/articles/2007/12/10/how-i-stopped-missing-darcs-and-started-loving-git#comment-856">http://blog.moertel.com/articles/2007/12/10/how-i-stopped-missing-darcs-and-started-loving-git#comment-856</a>
a very cogent comparision with Darcs from someone who used Darcs for 3
years and git for 1 year</li>
</ul>

<h4><a name="perforce">perforce</a></h4>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://kb.perforce.com/UserTasks/WorkingDisconnected">http://kb.perforce.com/UserTasks/WorkingDisconnected</a></li>
<li><a href="http://luqui.org/blog/archives/2007/02/19/perforce-sucks/">http://luqui.org/blog/archives/2007/02/19/perforce-sucks/</a></li>
<li>very interesting stuff.  SVN guys will like this :-)
<a href="http://www.harukizaemon.com/2006/09/no-really-perforce-does-suck.html">http://www.harukizaemon.com/2006/09/no-really-perforce-does-suck.html</a></li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="funny_stuff">funny stuff</a></h3>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://changelog.complete.org/posts/698-If-Version-Control-Systems-were-Airlines.html">http://changelog.complete.org/posts/698-If-Version-Control-Systems-were-Airlines.html</a>
-- esp the last 2 "airlines".  No wonder I like git so much :-)</li>
</ul>

<h3><a name="git_and_I_">git and I :)</a></h3>

<p>http://colabti.org/irclogger/irclogger_log/git?date=2009-08-08#l839</p>
</html>

<html>
<h1>presentation on git, a DVCS</h1>

<h1>why</h1>

<p>../images/projects-sans-vcs.png</p>

<h1>why use a VCS</h1>

<ul>
<li>reversibility or rollback@@, aka C-Y-A!
<ul>
<li>linear (on the time axis)@@, simple to implement</li>
</ul></li>
<li>concurrency
<ul>
<li>non-linear@@, all the complexity is here</li>
<li>make or break productivity
<ul>
<li>individual productivity also@@, if it can make context switching
trivial</li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
<li>annotation</li>
</ul>

<h1>VCSs in common use</h1>

<ul>
<li>open source
<ul>
<li>CVS</li>
<li>SVN (Subversion)</li>
<li>Darcs/TLA/Bazaar/Monotone@@, Mercurial, Git</li>
</ul></li>
<li>proprietary
<ul>
<li>VSS@@, Clearcase@@@@, Perforce</li>
<li>Bitkeeper</li>
<li>others??</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>"distributed"?</h1>

<ul>
<li>every dev has his/her own repository
<ul>
<li>on their own workstation</li>
<li>no single point of failure/contention</li>
</ul></li>
<li>all repos are (usually) "clones" of the central repository</li>
<li>easy to work offline
<ul>
<li>e.g., long weekend+laptop :-)</li>
<li>commits made while offline retain their identity</li>
<li>they don't get collapsed into one big commit</li>
</ul></li>
<li>commit-then-merge, not merge-then-commit</li>
</ul>

<h2>disconnected operation</h2>

<ul>
<li>local caching: how much is cached locally when you check out?
<ul>
<li>CVS: working copy of specific version, plus info about what version
was checked out</li>
<li>SVN: CVS, plus extra copy of the specified version</li>
<li>BZR/HG: SVN, plus complete history of current branch</li>
<li>GIT: BZR/HG, plus complete history of ALL branches!</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h2>notes on above</h2>

<ul>
<li>CVS: Anything other than edit needs network access, even a diff between
your working copy and the currently checked out version</li>
<li>SVN: Diffs between working copy and any other version need network</li>
<li>BZR/HG: Comparing to a different branch or switching to it needs network</li>
<li>VSS
<ul>
<li>no network access except via "shares", so local teams only</li>
<li>no atomic commits!</li>
<li>no merge tracking</li>
<li>repository corruption</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>what's different about git?</h1>

<ul>
<li>cryptographically secure integrity checks builtin</li>
<li>fast
<ul>
<li>most operations are local</li>
<li>network operations are highly optimised</li>
<li><strong>ideal</strong> for distributed teams</li>
</ul></li>
<li>easy to setup/deploy
<ul>
<li>server requires minimal hardware</li>
<li>no license costs</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>what's different about git? (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>very small repo size
<ul>
<li>Mozilla repo in CVS: 2.7 GB</li>
<li>imported to SVN 8.2 GB</li>
<li>imported to GIT: 450 MB!</li>
<li>(a full checkout is 350 MB)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>very, very, cheap branching</li>
<li>excellent merging</li>
</ul>

<h1>caveats about git</h1>

<ul>
<li>no partial checkouts -- it's the whole project or nothing
<ul>
<li>but you can use the "submodule" mechanism if you know in advance what
pieces will be separately needed</li>
</ul></li>
<li>will not track
<ul>
<li>permissions and ownership, except the "x" (executable) bit
<ul>
<li>in unix terms, only cares about the first "x" in rwxrwxrwx</li>
</ul></li>
<li>empty directories</li>
</ul></li>
<li>not optimised for tracking <strong>very large</strong> binary files (movies, etc.)</li>
</ul>

<h1>history</h1>

<ul>
<li>initially designed as a file system!</li>
<li>originally only a backend@@, now all in one</li>
<li>reputation for being hard to use@@, now no longer valid</li>
<li>focus on large projects with many developers
<ul>
<li>but that doesn't mean small projects can't use it</li>
<li>remember: multi-tasking</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>working with git</h1>

<ul>
<li>CLI is the most powerful</li>
<li>don't like the CLI?
<ul>
<li>3 excellent GUI tools come with git</li>
<li>very powerful; for an excellent intro to these tools, see
http://nathanj.github.com/gitguide</li>
<li>plugins: Eclipse and VS plugins available</li>
<li>but you miss many features <strong>unique</strong> to git if you only use these
plugins</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>some mindset changes needed...</h1>

<ul>
<li>learn to make many fine-grained commits rather than a few large ones</li>
<li>commit locally before performing any remote operations
<ul>
<li>example, in the typical "svn update" scenario, if your changes are not
yet ready to be sent to the server, you can either
<ul>
<li>avoid doing the update</li>
<li>do it and pray :-)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>in git, you just commit locally before doing the "git pull"</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>normal workflow - CVCSs</h1>

<p>../images/flow-CVCS.png</p>

<h1>normal workflow - most DVCSs</h1>

<p>../images/flow-DVCS.png</p>

<h1>normal workflow - Git</h1>

<p>../images/flow-Git.png</p>

<h1>something unique to git</h1>

<ul>
<li>index
<ul>
<li>a staging area for the next commit</li>
<li>stuff gets sent here when you "add"</li>
<li>when you "commit", the current index is turned into a real commit
object</li>
</ul></li>
<li>helps in reviewing changes</li>
<li>helps when fixing conflicts during a complex merge</li>
</ul>

<h1>problems in SVN</h1>

<ul>
<li>slow on large repositories</li>
<li>.SVN directories all over the place
<ul>
<li>often as large as the entire git repo!</li>
</ul></li>
<li>refactor/rename support missing</li>
<li>branching is fine...
<ul>
<li>but merging...?</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>problems in SVN (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>merge tracking not very well done
<ul>
<li>does not record who did the branch (attributes all changes to the dev
who did the merge)</li>
<li>does not record "merge-only" changes separately from the two branches</li>
<li>can make repeated merges very difficult
<ul>
<li>SVN mergeinfo has many limitations</li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
<li>merges can be slow</li>
<li>large merges can be painful</li>
</ul>

<h1>branching in most older VCSs</h1>

<ul>
<li>branching is considered advanced and people avoid it
<ul>
<li>either the tool has no branching,</li>
<li>or has really bad merging</li>
</ul></li>
<li>and branching is useless without good merging</li>
<li>so lots of parallelism goes unused
<ul>
<li>or you need "SCM admins" to do the merge!</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>problems in SVN (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>lack of local commits
<ul>
<li>you don't want to "break the build"</li>
<li>so you keep lots of uncommitted changes outside the VCS</li>
<li>and do one big checkin when you're ready</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>productivity advantages of git</h1>

<ul>
<li>history tracking handled much better; makes repeated merges a breeze
<ul>
<li>all "commits" identified by a SHA-1 checksum
<ul>
<li>this is what gives it the cryptographically secure integrity
check)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>a branch is just a pointer to some commit</li>
<li>every commit records its parent commit's sha</li>
<li>a merge is just a commit with more than one parent commit</li>
</ul></li>
<li>so, every commit knows all of its ancestors
<ul>
<li>regardless of repository, branch, etc</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>Linus on merging</h1>

<ul>
<li>merging is the most important activity
<ul>
<li>"I merge 22,000 files several times a day, and I get unhappy if a
merge takes more than 5 seconds" -- Linus</li>
<li>the linux kernel has 22000 files and has averaged 4.5 merges/day over
the last 2 years</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>Linus on merging (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>make it fast and painless
<ul>
<li>...and people will start using it every day</li>
</ul></li>
<li>merge often, merge early</li>
<li>otherwise you have huge conflicts to resolve later!</li>
</ul>

<h2>Linus on merging (cont'd)</h2>

<pre><code>http://git.or.cz/gitwiki/LinusTalk200705Transcript

If you can do something really fast, really well, people will start using
it differently. One of the things I wanted to make sure is that merges go
really really quickly because I want people to merge often and merge
early, because as it turns out it becomes easier to merge. If you merge
every day, suddenly you never get to the point where you have huge
conflicts that are hard to resolve. So if you actually make branching and
merging easy, you actually avoid a whole class of problems that you
otherwise have a really really hard time avoiding.
</code></pre>

<h1>productivity advantages of git (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>complex merges handled much better; frees devs from worrying about it most
of the time
<ul>
<li>merges involving renames</li>
<li>criss-cross merges</li>
</ul></li>
<li>encourages many small commits instead of few large commits
<ul>
<li>easier code reviews</li>
<li>easier debugging</li>
<li>easier cherry picking</li>
<li>easier merging/rebasing (conflict resolution happens in much smaller
units)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>productivity advantages of git (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>encourages creating local branches
<ul>
<li>no need to pollute the central server</li>
<li>experimental code can be developed "on the side"
<ul>
<li>if it works, promote it to the central server, with the full
history of commits intact</li>
<li>otherwise, delete it; no need to immortalise failed experiments on
the central server :-)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>branch <strong>names</strong> are also local
<ul>
<li>we can all have a branch called "my-test" or "test" or whatever,
without worrying about "is someone else using the same branch
name?"</li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>productivity advantages of git (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>encourages using the tools available
<ul>
<li>important vcs operations (like "diff") do not need network access</li>
<li>blazingly fast
<ul>
<li>even against a very old revision</li>
<li>or a version in some other branch</li>
</ul></li>
<li>centralised VCSs take too long
<ul>
<li>painful to use</li>
<li>so programmers avoid them (?)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h2>above stuff mostly from</h2>

<ul>
<li>http://www.bitkeeper.com/Comparisons.html has subsections like
http://www.bitkeeper.com/Comparisons.CVS.html and so on</li>
<li>excellent resource, but knowing Mr McVoy, a little NaCl may be useful :)</li>
</ul>

<h1>maintainability -- refactor/rename support</h1>

<ul>
<li>in most VCSs, renaming a file
<ul>
<li>is treated as a copy+delete</li>
<li>loses history (?)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>how about...
<ul>
<li>rename + move + edit a file in one branch</li>
<li>while making some bugfixes to it in another?</li>
</ul></li>
<li>git handles this without any fuss -- demo 09</li>
</ul>

<p>../images/demo-09-01.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-02.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-03.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-04.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-05.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-06.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-07.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-08.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-09.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-10.png</p>

<h1>demo 09 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-09-11.png</p>

<h1>maintainability: code movement detection</h1>

<ul>
<li>example
<ul>
<li>move an important function with lots of history to some other file</li>
</ul></li>
<li>what would other VCSs do to the <strong>history</strong>?</li>
<li>next 5 slides show code movement
<ul>
<li>displayed using "git gui blame", one of the 3 GUI tools that come with
git</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>code movement detection in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/gui-blame-1.png</p>

<h1>code movement detection in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/gui-blame-2.png</p>

<h1>code movement detection in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/gui-blame-3.png</p>

<h1>code movement detection in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/gui-blame-4.png</p>

<h1>code movement detection in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/gui-blame-5.png</p>

<h1>maintainability: code movement detection (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>this is <strong>way</strong> beyond what any other VCS can even dream of</li>
<li>great help for new people trying to understand existing code base</li>
<li>here's a secret...
<ul>
<li>the information you see is not <strong>stored</strong> in the repository</li>
<li>it is <strong>computed</strong> on demand, dynamically!</li>
<li>which means you can get the same tracability for all your existing
code
<ul>
<li>simply by converting to git!</li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>maintainability: revision history viewer</h1>

<ul>
<li>git has another GUI to show you the version history graph
<ul>
<li>very intuitive, shows merges etc very nicely</li>
<li>lots of "right click" options in various places, to help track things
down...</li>
<li>(one small example follows; there are many, many, more features --
there is not enough time to talk about more!)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>revision history viewer</h1>

<p>../images/gitk-1.png</p>

<h1>revision history viewer</h1>

<p>../images/gitk-2.png</p>

<h1>revision history viewer</h1>

<p>../images/gitk-3.png</p>

<h1>git concepts</h1>

<ul>
<li>repo
<ul>
<li>self-contained; remove ".git" and it's all gone</li>
</ul></li>
<li>branch
<ul>
<li>active line of development</li>
<li>a repo can track any number of branches</li>
</ul></li>
<li>master
<ul>
<li>default branch in a new git project</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>concept detail: branches</h1>

<ul>
<li>easy and inexpensive</li>
<li>can have separate branches for separate features</li>
<li>many being worked on "simultaneously"!</li>
<li>you can switch rapidly between branches</li>
<li>boosts individual productivity as well as team productivity</li>
<li>almost all existing VCSs suck at this</li>
</ul>

<h1>git concepts (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>working tree
<ul>
<li>is associated with only one branch</li>
</ul></li>
<li>head
<ul>
<li>the tip of a branch</li>
</ul></li>
<li>HEAD
<ul>
<li>the tip of the branch associated with your working tree; this is where
commits go</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>git concepts (cont'd)</h1>

<ul>
<li>index: holding area for changes approved for commit
<ul>
<li>git tracks content, not files</li>
<li>lets you select some files to commit while postponing others</li>
<li>lets you keep uncommited changes hanging around</li>
</ul></li>
<li>remote</li>
<li>origin</li>
</ul>

<h1>some more git concepts</h1>

<ul>
<li>commit ancestry</li>
<li>commit ancestry as a DAG
<ul>
<li>the essence of git is to build and traverse this DAG</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h2>life savers</h2>

<h1>CVS/SVN equivalence</h1>

<pre><code>    CVS                  GIT
    ---                  ---
    checkout             clone
    update               pull
    checkin              commit + push
    add                  add
    remove               rm
    ???                  mv
</code></pre>

<h1>cool stuff</h1>

<ul>
<li>the reflog, reachability, and garbage collection</li>
<li>demo 10 -- cherry picking</li>
<li>rebase</li>
<li>bisect</li>
<li>stash</li>
</ul>

<h1>demo 10 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-10-01.png</p>

<h1>demo 10 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-10-02.png</p>

<h1>demo 10 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-10-03.png</p>

<h1>rebase -- what and why</h1>

<ul>
<li>what</li>
<li>why
<ul>
<li>parallel and serial branching</li>
<li>getting the best out of bisect</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>rebase -- when and how</h1>

<ul>
<li>killing off an old commit</li>
<li>re-arranging your commits interactively -- demo 11</li>
<li><strong>when not to use it!</strong></li>
<li>origin has moved
<ul>
<li>demo 12 -- parallel branch using merge</li>
<li>demo 13 -- serial branch using rebase</li>
</ul></li>
<li>same, but after some of your changes have gone upstream
<ul>
<li>and they have DIFFERENT SHA1s now!!</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h1>demo 11 in pictures</h1>

<p>../images/demo-11-01.png</p>

<ul>
<li>and now we do:
<ul>
<li><code>git rebase -i HEAD~8</code></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>../images/demo-11-02.png</p>

<p>../images/demo-11-05.png</p>

<p>../images/demo-11-06.png</p>
